webTitle: Defoe deflated as record-breaking strikers come out of the woodwork

fields.headline: Defoe deflated as record-breaking strikers come out of the woodwork
fields.trailText: A steady stream of former professionals have been dusting off their history books yesterday to prove that 'record-breaking' Jermaine Defoe still has some work to do.
fields.body:
Jermaine Defoe could be excused for wishing the mountain of statistics that go hand in hand with football was always as accurate as his shooting.

By scoring for Bournemouth at Cambridge on Tuesday the 18-year-old striker was acclaimed across the country as having set a new post-war record for scoring in 10 successive league games.

But, just as he was beginning to enjoy his new-found fame yesterday, a steady stream of former professionals were dusting off their history books to show that he still has a bit of work to do.

It turns out an understandably confused Defoe is still one short of setting a record after a more studied look at the annals revealed that two other players have also scored in 10 consecutive league games.

The first suspicions were raised when Phil Noble, the curator of Manchester City's museum, delved into the club's archives to find that Billy McAdams did the trick in 1957. "I'm very proud of that record," the 67-year-old McAdams said last night at home in Barrow. "And there is one difference that is worth pointing out: I did it in the old First Division.

"To be honest I've never heard of this Jermaine Defoe. I only really keep in touch with the Premiership these days."

No sooner was Defoe digesting that revelation than it transpired that Ron Davies had also netted 10 on the trot for Southampton in 1966-67.

Meanwhile John Aldridge would like it noted that he, too, scored 10 in succession, although not in one season - the final game of Liverpool's 1986-87 league campaign and the first nine games the following season.

After Defoe's 64th-minute strike at the Abbey stadium he posed for photographs with 10 digits held up while preparations began at Football League headquarters for a special presentation marking the feat. "It's a great feeling to break the record," he said. "It had been playing on my mind a bit but I just tried to get on with it."

Now, however, all eyes will be on the loaned West Ham striker yet again when Bournemouth travel to the Second Division leaders Millwall on Saturday.

If all goes well at the New Den, Defoe will then have Dixie Dean's record of 12 straight league games in his sights, followed by Tom Phillipson's all-time record of 13 for Wolves in the old Second Division in 1926-27.

Of course, if Defoe wants to be really ambitious he should be chasing Pele's record of 16 in a row. Then there would be no disputing his place in history.

webTitle: Kanchelskis signs on loan for City

fields.headline: Kanchelskis signs on loan for City
fields.trailText: Manchester City have signed Andrei Kanchelskis from Rangers.
fields.body:
Joe Royle last night moved to halt Manchester City's free fall down the Premiership by signing Andrei Kanchelskis from Rangers.

Kanchelskis, who celebrated his 32nd birthday on Tuesday, has signed on loan until the end of the season with a view to a permanent move, in a deal that reunites the Ukrainian international with his former Everton manager.

Royle has been looking for a right-sided midfielder all season although Kanchelskis will not be eligible to make his debut in Saturday's FA Cup fourth-round tie at home to Coventry City. He spent five seasons at Manchester United, during which time they won two titles and the FA Cup.

Managers and coaches are forcing their footballers to play through injuries, doctors said yesterday. They also accuse clubs of discouraging players from registering with outside GPs for fear they would be told to take time off when sick.

The medical care of footballers was being further compromised by the "old boys' network" appointing club doctors and physiotherapists who lacked the independence to stand up to their clubs, said the authors of a highly critical article in the British Journal of Sports Medicine.

fields.headline: Double trouble delays transfer solution
fields.trailText: Negotiations over the future of the transfer system remained deadlocked yesterday over how much notice a player must give before leaving a club and an effective system of compensation.
fields.body:
Negotiations over the future of the transfer system remained deadlocked yesterday over two crucial issues that continue to divide the European Commission and football authorities: the notice a player must give before leaving a club and an effective system of compensation.

The EC yesterday rejected a Fifa-Uefa proposal that players should honour contracts of five years or more for a minimum of three years and said it could not agree to a system where players would not be allowed to leave clubs but their clubs could sell them.

Fifa-Uefa also want to see compensation introduced that would take into account a player's commercial worth and not just the remainder of his salary, as the EC demands.

It is expected that February 16 will mark the final meeting before resolution of the transfer system alteration to satisfy EC law. Last night both parties said they were optimistic.

An EC spokesman said the sides are "very close" to a solution. "There appears to be willingness from the football family to settle the period players must remain at clubs."

The EC is also opposed to financial penalties being imposed on players unilaterally wanting to terminate long contracts without justification. Players should be free to walk out after a year, the EC insists.

But there is agreement on an arbitration mechanism to settle compensation when a player's move is in dispute and that it would include representatives of the players' union Fifpro and football officials. For players of 23 and under, two fees would be paid: one for the years spent on his training and another in the form of a transfer sum. Straightforward transfer fees would apply only to players over 23, and all contracts would be for a minimum of one year.

Southampton's Hassan Kachloul has turned down a move to Ipswich in the hope of a more lucrative transfer elsewhere, with Tottenham heading the queue.

The Moroccan forward will be a free agent in summer after also rejecting a new deal at the Dell because Southampton would not meet his wage demands of £26,000 a week. Glenn Hoddle is thought to have already identified a replacement in Leicester's out-of-favour Steve Guppy, born in Hampshire.

Barnsley's new manager Nigel Spackman has brought in Derek Fazackerley as first-team coach after the club parted with the No2 Peter Shirtliff. Fazackerley formerly coached under Kevin Keegan with Newcastle and England.

Taribo West has agreed in principle to stay with Derby until the end of the season at least. Jim Smith is confident talks to that end will be completed on Monday.

Gary Locke, Hearts' former captain, is going to Bradford City on a free transfer, rejoining the manager Jim Jefferies.

webTitle: Treasury made Greaves 'invisible' between Milan and Tottenham

fields.headline: Treasury made Greaves 'invisible' between Milan and Tottenham
fields.trailText: Jimmy Greaves was regarded as an "invisible import" to facilitate his £99,999 transfer from AC Milan to Tottenham in 1961, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Leaden-footed centre-halves of the 60s would often complain, shortly after Jimmy Greaves had scored one of his 357 league goals, that the England forward had been "invisible for 89 minutes".

Yesterday it emerged that that assessment received official approval at No11 Downing Street after treasury officials, examining the terms of Greaves's £99,999 transfer from Milan to Tottenham in 1961, decreed that for the purposes of the deal he should be counted as an "invisible import" or "luxury goods", and referred the matter to the chancellor of the exchequer.

Strict currency controls limited the amount of money that could be taken out of the country to £80,000 but officials feared that if the deal was blocked it would cause outcry among football supporters.

Treasury papers released yesterday show that an ingenious official, William Clowser, dreamed up a means by which Greaves could return home. Writing to recommend that the transfer be approved, he commented: "The transfer fee paid by one club to another for a player's release represents the means by which the paying club secures his services and skill, which are of course of little value except as a member of a football team.

"This is closely analogous to a royalty payment which might be made by an industrial concern for the use of a patent or know-how. I have told the bank that, on this justifiable analogy, they may approve the application we would no doubt run into trouble if it were refused."

Another official concurred, replying that Greaves be counted as "an invisible import, however Irish that may appear". So concerned were officials that a junior treasury minister, Anthony Barber, wrote to the chancellor Selwyn Lloyd to explain.

"It may be said by the uninitiated (those with common sense) that it is very odd to allow the remission of the sums in question in respect of a professional footballer, whereas remission of a smaller sum for the purposes of setting up a business abroad would be refused," he wrote.

"So far as the balance of payments is concerned, it is more sensible to regard this as a payment on the current account, and therefore similar to a payment made for luxury goods, which would not be refused."

The decision still drew criticism from some members of the public, one of whom complained: "Is this person worth, in the national interest, the transfer of so many million lira from our reserves? I say no, especially as he is a spoilt puppy."

fields.headline: I can see clearly now the rain has come
fields.standfirst: Sam discovers why New Zealand is truly the world's best place to enjoy the great outdoors, but also finds time for some serious reflection on the life he left behind in London
fields.trailText: New Zealand This has been a week of firsts. My first time in a sea kayak, first time camping solo, first ride in a helicopter, and my first time ice climbing on a glacier.' But Sam also has time to reflect on life back in London
fields.body:
This has been a week of firsts. My first time in a sea kayak, first time camping by myself, first ride in a helicopter and my first time ice climbing on a glacier.

I also finally began to think about what I'm going to do when I get back to England. "Why - you have four months yet?" I hear you say. Well for me this trip is as much about the travelling as finding the time and space to figure out where my life is heading.

I didn't manage this in the US - too rushed and too soon. I started to get close in Fiji but I still needed some time out just to relax completely and leave everything behind. However, three days kayaking and hiking by myself in the empty wilderness of New Zealand's coastal Abel Tasman National Park gave me plenty of time to think about a lot of things. But first let me tell you how I got there.

I'm travelling round New Zealand with a tour company called Magic Bus. They offer a variety of routes round both North and South Islands covering all the main highlights. Buses run every day of the week during the summer so I've been jumping on and off as I please. The downside is that I am restricted by the pre-defined route, but there are advantages: the driver books your accommodation and sorts out any activities you might want to do. And best of all, if you get a good driver (and I've only had one who wasn't really enthusiastic) you get an excellent commentary on the sights and sounds of New Zealand. These range from pointing out the small farm where the current prime minister grew up, to explaining New Zealanders' hatred of possums. They also all seem to be obsessed with telling you the population of each town you go through.

The tours are very laid back. The majority of people on the bus are in their mid-twenties, but there are always a few older and younger people too. The other main tour bus, Kiwi Experience, is supposed to be more of a party bus. You have to wear a dress and down 10 pints before they let you into the hostel - that sort of thing. You can probably guess by now that that isn't really my style, so I'd opted for Magic.

By the time the bus reached the city of Nelson on the South Island the sun had come out (hooray). I had booked a three-day sea kayaking and hiking trip and after a night in Nelson I headed out to the park to grab my paddle.

Abel Tasman covers a relatively small area in comparison to New Zealands's other National Parks, but it's incredibly beautiful with golden beaches, lush gullies and thick forests. Road access only extends as far as the park entrances, so to get into the wilderness you must walk in or take a boat.

I was in a small group of three double kayaks, and after our guide for the day, Kea, had set out the proposed route and given a quick demonstration of what to do in the unlikely event of capsizing we got onto the water.

It was a unique experience. The waters were crystal clear and quite calm. We paddled out along the coast, dipping into secluded bays. Kea pointed out the wildlife and told us the history of the park as we went along riding the waves.

We pulled up on a beach for a leisurely lunch and a bit of snorkelling before setting off again. In the afternoon, the wind picked up so all three kayaks came together to form a raft and we put up a sail attached to the paddles. With the wind behind us we ran between the anchored sailing boats into Torrent Bay where I was to spend my first night.

My rucksack was there waiting for me on the beach. I had hired a tent, stove and pans and brought just enough food for a couple of days. Not having camped for years and never by myself, I didn't know what to expect.

I waved goodbye to Kea as he stacked the kayaks onto the waiting boat and set off back home. Then I walked off to the nearby campsite and chose my spot for the night. This was the nearest site to the park entrance so it was quite busy. I set up in the shade under some trees, lit the stove and began to cook dinner. I had dried pasta with a tomato sauce and dried fruit for afters, and while not exactly a culinary triumph, it was very satisfying.

After a rather disturbed night (two possums decided to have an argument right outside my tent) I decamped and set off along the coastal track. It was early (about 7 am) and I tramped slowly up into the hills as the sun got higher and hotter. Streams cascaded down by the path. I stopped to have a solitary dip in a cold, deep pool surrounded by forest.

And it was now with only myself and the cicadas for company that I began to think about my life and where it was going.

In London, I'd had a pretty good life with great friends, a well-paid, interesting job and I had been saving to buy a flat. I had done all the things you were supposed to do: school, university, proper grown-up job. I have ticked all the boxes but like many people my age, all I'm left with is a feeling of "is this it?"

I'm the sort of person that will always believe the grass is greener on the other side of the fence. But looking back, I did jump into my first job without really thinking about what I actually wanted to do or what sort of quality of life I was looking for.

It may well be that I decide the civil service is for me after all, but I have definitely decided that I don't want to live in London any longer. I'm fed up with urban life. I want to live by the sea or up in the mountains with clear air and beautiful views.

Admittedly, I might get a little bored so that's why I need to come up with an interesting variety of jobs (rather than one single career) to keep me busy. Ideas so far include travel writing (you'll have to judge whether that's viable or not); teaching people to sail or kayak (ok I've not got much experience at the moment but it would be fun); running a Bed and Breakfast (after staying in numerous hostels, I reckon I know exactly what makes a good place). I'm sure more useful ideas will follow.

I walked 11 miles that day and spent my second night camped on an empty beach, and after another day's hike across a wide estuary, I caught a water taxi back home.

The next day I was back on the Magic Bus heading down the west coast and it was raining again. There's no half measures with weather here: it's either pouring or clear blue skies.

The scenery was now very dramatic with steep gorges, glaciated valleys, thick rainforests and wild rocky coastlines. It all looked very young - as though everything had only just been formed and the elements hadn't had the chance to erode it all down.

We passed through a series of isolated towns with dreary names like Westport and Greymouth before reaching the spectacular Westland National Park. Here huge glaciers push down to the rainforest and the coast.

Maori legend says that the goddess Hinehukatere loved the mountains in this area and encouraged her lover, Tawe, to climb them with her. He slipped and fell to his death and Hinehukatere's tears formed the glaciers.

We stopped at the Franz Josef Glacier where I and fellow Londoner, Steve, took a heli-hike up to the ice. The helicopter took us on a trip swooping up the valley and then dropped us off on the glacier. With crampons and ice axes our guide took us climbing up frozen ice falls and squeezed through narrow blue crevasses.

I can't find the words to describe what an amazing experience this was and will have to leave it to my photos to give you an idea of the sheer magic of this stunning, unreal landscape. All I can say is that Steve and I kept laughing out loud and exclaiming "wow, look at that" and "I can't believe we are really doing this!".

Such experiences are so completely different from my previous nine to five existence that they provide clarity, brief moments when I feel I'm getting just an inkling of "what it's all about". I'm not so naive to think that I'm somehow going to come up with the great solution and then go off to live happily ever after. But if I can get some sense of purpose, of direction then that will be a huge step forward.

I think the fog that has lasted for the last few years might be beginning to clear.

He slipped and fell to his death and Hinehukatere's tears formed the glaciers. We stopped at the Franz Josef Glacier where I and fellow Londoner, Steve, took a heli-hike up to the ice. The helicopter took us on a trip swooping up the valley and then dropped us off on the glacier. With crampons and ice axes our guide took us climbing up frozen ice falls and squeezed through narrow blue crevasses. I can't find the words to describe what an amazing experience this was and will have to leave it to my photos to give you an idea of the sheer magic of this stunning, unreal landscape. All I can say is that Steve and I kept laughing out loud and exclaiming "wow, look at that" and "I can't believe we are really doing this!". Such experiences are so completely different from my previous nine to five existence that they provide clarity, brief moments when I feel I'm getting just an inkling of "what it's all about". I'm not so naive to think that I'm somehow going to come up with the great solution and then go off to live happily ever after. But if I can get some sense of purpose, of direction then that will be a huge step forward. I think the fog that has lasted for the last few years might be beginning to clear.

fields.headline: A room of one's own
fields.standfirst: An unwelcome encounter with a giant wave and a  jellyfish don't dampen Milly's enthusiasm for Australia. Craving a little time alone, she finds a room of her own, learns to merengue and does a waitressing shift
fields.trailText: Coogee: An unwelcome encounter with a giant wave and a jellyfish don't dampen Milly's enthusiasm for Australia. Craving a little time alone, she finds a room of her own, learns to merengue and does a waitressing shift
fields.body:
I seem to have spent the whole week getting smashed and attacked by the water in various ways, but hasn't stopped me from enjoying myself! The first day of this week I received a disturbing mail from home telling me I'd not got too much money left. It brought a bit of a reality check on to how best to spend the rest of my time in Sydney, so I decided I would try to achieve the most fun as possible on a minimal budget. And in a city as alive as this, it's extremely possible.

So, that evening I took a walk along the coast I'd not yet explored, away from Coogee towards Maroubra beach. Surrounded by the smell of the ocean and the sound of crashing waves blown by the imminent storm I was again reminded how lucky I am. Then a storm broke. Realising that I was going to be soaked to the skin whatever, I stopped to watch the die-hard surfers at Maroubra beach before making my wet way back to the hostel. I'm just hoping this will be the last of the recent bad weather and the November floods Sydney saw aren't planning a come-back - I thought I'd escaped them when I left England!

This week it's dawned on me how desperately I want my own place for a little while. One of my biggest fears before I left was that I'd end up alone - I'd like to reassure any other traveller in the same position that this will not happen. It will probably never happen in fact. I was sat on my bed, vainly attempting to read Bill Bryson, but failing because people were constantly coming in and out. This culminated in my talkative dormmate's return when he leapt onto my bed, and announced he was going to read with me. I was starting to long for a little bit of peace.

The next morning I woke full of energy so rose early for a short walk/jog to neighbouring Clovelly then back. On my return I stopped for a quick dip in the sea and got a costly reminder that the ocean isn't my friend. The waves at Coogee can be reasonably strong and I'm not a brilliant swimmer, so I only just went out of my depth, but after my jog I soon needed to return to shore again. With the tide against me this was a lot harder than swimming out had been, and soon I was totally exhausted. It was at this point that I got pounded by a giant wave that held me underwater for a long time until I eventually came up coughing, with fortunately just a long graze down my back from the sand to show for it.

After limping back to the hostel, the first guy I told laughed and told me ambulances carry people off from Coogee at least once a week - which left me wisely cautious of my next trip into the sea. The same day I had my second disturbing mail of the week, from those friendly Guardian travel people, saying they'll be getting calls from alcoholics anonymous about me! So, for the rest of this week - and the future - I'm experimenting to see how much money an average Brit in Oz would save by keeping off the drink. I'll let you know at the end of the report how it's gone.

In the evening I went with Brian to my much loved spot, Darling Harbour. There are still so many activities being held there until the upcoming Australia Day that I can't believe I've neglected it for a while. Firstly we watched a bizarre lazer show named Fish Opera which literally was just that, then moved straight on to watch some fire jugglers. Various differences between mine and Brian's homes were becoming apparent all the time - I was impressed by the jugglers, but he told me they'd never have made it in LA! I think our sweeping generalisation on different nations is that Australians seem happiest, women from LA are most attractive and the English. . . well, we'd both got bored of hearing their voices more frequently than Australian accents!

That evening there was also the Festival de Cuba on the harbour, and we stumbled across a brilliant Mexican band called Los Del Abajo who got a 2000-strong crowd dancing and jumping to their lively brand of Latin/ska/punk. After the brilliant band finished we headed for the Daintree Cafe to continue dancing - largely because we'd seen a cameraman enter first. We also both noticed the great ethnic diversity of Darling Harbour in comparison to Coogee which partly explains my love of the place. That evening was fantastic - dancing, salsaing and generally working up a sweat for the price of nothing and fuelled by water. Also, the main thing: that evening I got a place of my own!!

I'd been texting a girl (the wonders of mobile phones) about an advert I'd picked up that evening, and just a few hours later after a quick look and think I decided to go ahead and take the spare bed. My new apartment may be basic but at long last I have a place to call my own. Woo-hoo!!

Saturday morning I packed up my world into my bag again and carried everything up the hill to my new home (still in Coogee). For once I can actually describe a place as home!

That afternoon I'd been hoping to go to Watson's Bay. This was one of the last spots in Sydney I'd been advised to go to through the feedback mails, and the writer had specified Saturday afternoon. Brian and I took the bus there, but exhaustion from the night before meant we both collapsed in a spot of shade as soon as we arrived! Watson's Bay was definitely a nicer area of Sydney. Boats were out sailing in their masses enjoying the weekend sun, no doubt from the many private jetties attached to the beachside houses.

Late afternoon we headed back to the domain in central Sydney to enjoy another free concert, this time by the Sydney Symphony Orchestra. Though we arrived early we still struggled to find a spot - I guess some people must have been there all day waiting, judging by the fact that one group had a table and chairs set out for dinner! Despite it being neither of our first choices musically, the concert left us with a good feeling -especially as the last piece was accompanied by cannons and fireworks in time with the music, soaring over the top of the neighbouring skyscrapers.

The next morning I woke and stood on the balcony of my own apartment. Gazing out across the view of uptown Coogee I felt inordinately happy. Myself and a guy named Pete from the apartment then headed to the beach so I could get back into the water. Luckily he had a snorkel with him, and remembering how much I'd loved it in Hawaii I was soon floating face-down in the ocean - even though there were no fish. I felt I'd conquered my temporary fear.

In the evening me, Brian and a diminutive Canadian girl, Shauna, returned to Darling Harbour for the last day of the Festival de Cuba. This time we arrived early so we could participate in Learn to Merengue classes lead by a slick-looking Brazilian and his scantily dressed sexy dancers. I don't think the massed crowed achieved anything resembling their moves, but at least we had a lot of fun! After that we had our second helping of Los Del Abajo only this time we must have jumped about even more, if possible. The three of us came away tired (again) but definitely happy.

Then on Monday I went for a walk across the harbour bridge to North Sydney, Kirribilli and beyond as I hadn't really been that way before. In a shop on the way, I got talking to the assistant, and it turned out he lives about 10 miles from my home in England. It really is a small world at times.

I had a weekly travel pass, so took full advantage of it by spending the afternoon ferry-hopping about the harbour. My roommate Michaela then phoned to tell me I had a trial at her The French Bistro restaurant, where she worked too, the next day, so I cut short my exploration to save myself for my first day's work in a while!

Next afternoon I was having a short amount of sun and sea before my evening's employment. I was in the water when I felt a hot pain across my legs, and looked down to see what looked like a blue string of seaweed with bobbles attached to my leg. Unfortunately I recognised this as one of the tentacles of a bluebottle jellyfish, one of the many Australian creatures that will happily cause you pain. Leaving the water I rushed to the first aid stand set up specifically for those who get stung (and who are careless enough to have not kept a closer eye on the water) to rub ice into my bright red leg. The attendant happily informed me that a girl had once swallowed one, so my sting was nothing. He was right too - though it hurt, by the evening it had totally subsided, leaving only a trail of little red dots as a reminder if where it had been.

I hadn't been particularly nervous about my trail shift at the restaurant, but maybe I should have been. The boss was a Frenchman who was extremely particular about the running of his restaurant. After a 15-minute look at the menu I was given a pad and basically had to get to it. My evening's work certainly brought me down to earth a bit - it made me realise that, unfortunately, I can't spend my whole life enjoying the leisure I've had up until now. Even though I've been a waitress before (and hello to everyone at Holes Bay), after five hours I was completed exhausted. Which reminds me, I've got another job trial in two hours from now, so I'd best be off. . . Until next week (when I can increase my $28 total made from drinking water . . )
Milly

webTitle: Hain shunted sideways on his way upwards

fields.headline: Hain shunted sideways on his way upwards
fields.standfirst:
The foreign office minister pushed out by the post-Mandelson cabinet reshuffle is still a good bet for a cabinet post, writes diplomatic editor Ewen MacAskill

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText:
The foreign office minister pushed out by the post-Mandelson cabinet reshuffle is still a good bet for a cabinet post, writes diplomatic editor Ewen MacAskill
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.body:
Peter Hain, ex-Welsh Office minister and ex-Foreign Office minister, is still a good bet for eventual promotion to the cabinet.

He looked like the biggest loser - after Peter Mandelson - in the surprise government reshuffle. He had reasonable hopes that his next ministerial move would be into the cabinet but instead he was shuffled off to the energy department , a move downwards or, taking the most optimistic view possible, sideways.

The reason why he had cause to expect more was the high profile he had achieved since becoming minister of state at the Foreign Office. Mr Hain is one of the freshest thinkers in government.

Instead of just espousing the briefs put before him by the Foreign Office diplomats, he used the post to tackle issues close to his heart. He named and shamed, using Commons privilege, people alleged to be involved in illegal trade in arms, and he has been pushing the diamond industry into a proper certification scheme in an attempt to end the illicit trade in blood diamonds, one of the contributory factors to the wars in Sierra Leone, Angola and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

The interest in Africa is because he was raised in South Africa: the interest in arms and conflict diamonds is because he has long been on the Labour left.

During his time at the Foreign Office, he was involved in a series of rows that attracted lots of publicity. The most serious were exchanges with the Zimbabwe leader, Robert Mugabe, over the forced expulsion of white farmers. In recent days, he has been involved in renewed controversy in southern Africa, with the South African president, Thabo Mbeki, threatening to cancel a state visit because of remarks by Mr Hain.

He has also confronted former comrades on the left in making a case for sanctions against Iraq. He knows how to secure publicity and how the media works. That is a strength but it also contributed to his downfall at the Foreign Office. His relations with the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, have cooled over the last nine months, either because he was envious of the publicity Mr Hain generated or because he regarded such public rows as the one with Mr Mugabe as counter-productive.

Paranoia has been rife in the corridors of the Foreign Office, with Mr Hain suspicious that Mr Cook's circle has been briefing against him and Mr Cook's office increasingly wary of Mr Hain.

Ironically, the two men had once been very close. In the run-up to the general election, Mr Hain had been Mr Cook's lieutenant and both had expected to be leading a leftwing group of Labour MPs after the election, using that rump to influence policy informally.

Instead, Mr Hain and Mr Cook have fallen out. But it is not the end of Mr Hain. He has steadily impressed Mr Blair, not least in the job he held before he went to the Foreign Office, when he delivered Alun Michael as leader of the new Welsh Assembly. It proved a disaster but it was done at the bidding of Mr Blair.

When Mr Blair moved Mr Hain from the Foreign Office on Wednesday he told him that he could expect promotion. Mr Hain may get his reward after the general election.

fields.headline: Reaction: what Scotland is saying
fields.trailText: What Scotland is saying about Henry McLeish's statement on long-term care.
fields.body:
What Scotland is saying about Henry McLeish's statement on long-term care.

Help the Aged

Help the Aged Scotland said it was disappointed that, in spite of raised expectations, the Scottish Executive had yet again failed to introduce free care for all older people in Scotland. But it welcomed moves for more older people to receive free care, especially those with conditions such as dementia.

Liz Duncan, Scottish executive of Help the Aged, said: "We had hoped that today's announcement would see the Scottish Executive commit to the full implementation of the Sutherland report - almost two years after it was published. Instead, they still seem determined to cherry-pick from it, leaving us a little further forward but by no means there yet for older people."

Age Concern

Age Concern Scotland director Maureen O'Neill said: "Age Concern is astonished that the Scottish Executive has again failed to make a real commitment to end the practice of charging frail older people for help with bathing, eating, dressing and going to the toilet. People's expectations were raised over the past eight weeks only to be dashed again.

"The Scottish Executive should have made a firm commitment to free personal care and the new group should have been charged with the task of delivering it as quickly as possible."

British Association of Social Workers

Ian Johnston, director of BASW, said he was disappointed that the Scottish Executive had fallen into line with the UK government.

"The level of confusion about financial issues that has faced people in the UK when they need care in later life is entirely unacceptable. Such uncertainty gives rise to additional stress for the individuals concerned and their families.

"The Sutherland report offered a sensible way forward. The government should have grasped the nettle and either raised the necessary funds from taxation or introduced a fair charging system that does not differentiate between health and social care, effectively discouraging people from getting better."

Unison

Unison's Scottish organiser for health, Jim Devine, said: "We are deeply disappointed that the Scottish executive has not fully implemented the Sutherland report. If equality of access prevails for pensioners in hospitals, it should equally prevail for pensioners in their homes. You could argue that the position adopted by the executive is perverse."

Royal College of Nursing

James Kennedy, head of the Royal College of Nursing in Scotland, said: "We are very disappointed that all personal care will not be made free - which would be the simplest and most effective way of bringing equity to the funding of long-term care for the elderly. We are however encouraged by the introduction of a single needs assessment for older people and that the work on the definition of nursing care under the chief nursing officer will be taken forward, which should extend the provision of free nursing and personal care to more people."

Association of Directors of Social Work

The ADSW said it would have been irresponsible of ministers in the Scottish Executive to have decided to fund free personal care at the expense of service development to provide for unmet need.

Carole Wilkinson, vice president of the ADSW, said: "The experience of ADSW members, who work for the people in these groups, is that their greatest need is not for free services, but for an adequate level of services. The biggest issue is not who funds services, but whether the current level of services is adequate."

Scottish National Party

SNP leader John Swinney tabled a motion noting that it is the policy of the SNP to introduce free personal care under Sutherland, and urging the Scottish Executive to make a similar, firm and unequivocal commitment with a definite timetable for its implementation.

Shadow health and community care minister Nicola Sturgeon MSP said: "Labour are in a minority in resisting free personal care for all Scotland's elderly. We are determined to allow the Parliamentary majority on implementing the Sutherland recommendations in full to prevail."

Scottish Conservative & Unionist Party

Scots Tory health spokesman Mary Scanlon MSP said: "Henry McLeish, [health minister] Susan Deacon and all of their colleagues in the Scottish Executive and on the Labour and Lib Dem backbenches should be thoroughly ashamed of themselves. After months of endlessly insinuating that it would pick up the tab for personal care costs, this clarified once and for all that the executive has never had any such intention.

webTitle: Elderly care puts Scots coalition at risk

fields.headline: Elderly care puts Scots coalition at risk
fields.trailText: Scotland's coalition administration was under threat last night after the first minister, Henry McLeish, failed to offer free long-term care for the elderly.
fields.body:
Scotland's coalition administration was under threat last night after the first minister, Henry McLeish, failed to offer free long-term care for the elderly.

Mr McLeish had hinted he would implement in full the Sutherland royal commission recommendatons on funding of this care, creating the biggest policy rift to date between Holyrood and Westminster.

Yesterday Susan Deacon, the executive's health minister, announced a care package for the elderly that stopped short of the universal free care recommended by the commission, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland.

Pensioners' groups and opposition parties accused Mr McLeish of betraying devolution for Downing Street. Ten Liberal Democrat MSPs tabled a motion calling for an unequivocal commitment to free care for all, and efforts were under way last night to force a debate on the issue in the parliament.

Under the proposals announced by Ms Deacon, free personal care will be extended to cover people suffering from dementia; a development group will be set up to make further recommendations on elderly care; and a single needs assessment scheme will be adopted.

She said that she was offering Scotland's elderly a new deal, and claimed that many more would receive free nursing and personal care.

Nicola Sturgeon, the Scottish National party health spokesman, said the minister and Mr McLeish had sold out.

It has been reported that Downing Street was dismayed by Mr McLeish's plans and put pressure on him not to adopt a vastly superior care package to that provided to the rest of Britain, where nursing care is free but personal care is means tested.

"All of this comes after three months of Scotland being led to believe by the first minister that his government would implement Sutherland in full, but today we are being told that is not what he said," said Ms Sturgeon.

"It seems the only people that didn't agree with this was London Labour, and when faced with the choice of doing what is right by Scotland or appeasing London Labour, this government will always choose keeping London sweet, and let Scotland down."

Ms Deacon denied that the executive had bowed to pressure, saying: "We are here to deliver policies and solutions which meet Scotland's needs."

To jeers and shouts from the opposition benches, she added: "We will not make promises that we know we cannot keep."

Margaret Smith, Liberal Democrat MSP and convener of the health committee that unanimously backed full implementation of the Sutherland recommendations, said her party intended to keep forcing the issue. Its motion demanded a commitment to free care and a timetable in which to achieve it.

"The question now is: is Mr McLeish on London's leash, or is he on this government's leash?" she said.

When it was suggested that her actions might lead to a defeat for the executive and possibly the end of the Labour-Lib Dem coalition, Mrs Smith said she did not see why that should be the case.

If the motion was endorsed by the parliament, she said, "That will be the will of the parliament being exercised, and I think that would be a good day for this parliament."

fields.headline: Clinton's pardon furore
fields.standfirst: Outrage as fugitive dealer Marc Rich is freed of charges
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton has been intensely criticised by friend and foe alike for issuing a last-minute presidential pardon to a fugitive commodities trader, Marc Rich, after lobbying by prominent Israelis and political donors.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton has been intensely criticised by friend and foe alike for issuing a last-minute presidential pardon to a fugitive commodities trader, Marc Rich, after lobbying by prominent Israelis and political donors.

The decision to pardon Mr Rich, who fled to Europe 18 years ago to avoid 51 charges of tax evasion, racketeering and illegal trading with Iran, has become the most controversial of the record 140 pardons Mr Clinton issued on Saturday, just hours before he handed over the presidency to George Bush.

Mr Rich's pardon covers all the charges against him, which included cheating the US government out of $48m in taxes and trading with an enemy by defying trade sanctions against Iran while more than 60 Americans were being held hostage in the US embassy in Tehran in 1978-80.

Mr Rich, 65, is now free to return to the United States, though he is no longer a citizen.

Most presidential pardons are given to people who have been convicted of their crimes, served their sentences or repented of what they did.

Mr Rich, who never even made a court appearance to answer the charges against him, fits none of these categories. As a result, his pardon shines a fresh spotlight on the nexus of favours and influence between the Clinton White House and its richest donors.

The indignation focuses on the fact that Mr Clinton and the former White House counsel Jack Quinn - who coordinated efforts on Mr Rich's behalf - kept the possibility of a pardon secret from the justice department and the prosecutors in charge of the case. This bypassing of the normal procedures left the prosecutors "shocked and flabbergasted", officials said.

The New York Times, normally a defender of Mr Clinton, described Mr Rich's pardon as "a shocking abuse of presidential power" which "undermined the pursuit of justice".

The mayor of New York, Rudolph Giuliani, who was the prosecutor who brought the case against Mr Rich in 1983, said he found it "very, very hard to understand" Mr Clinton's decision.

Other Republicans have been less diplomatic.

The lobbying effort on behalf of Mr Rich involved a Who's Who of prominent Israelis, who emphasised the financier's role as a generous backer of dozens of Jewish and Israeli causes.

Among those who wrote to Mr Clinton were the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, a former head of the Mossad secret service, Shabtai Shavit, and the musical director of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, Zubin Mehta.

A central role was also played by Mr Rich's former wife Denise, who has given more than $1m to the Democrats, as well as giving the maximum $10,000 donation to Mr Clinton's legal defence fund. Mrs Rich is a hugely rich and ambitious Manhattan hostess who has regularly showered the Clintons with gifts.

Two coffee tables and chairs given by her were among gifts worth more than $190,000 (£130,000) which Bill and Hillary Clinton took with them when they left the White House last week, an action which prompted the Washington Post to say in a leader yesterday that the Clintons "have no capacity for embarrassment".

fields.headline: Trade news column
fields.trailText: Booksellers enjoy a cracker of a Christmas, but fears as wholesaler Bertrams cuts back. Plus, news from Waterstone's, Fourth Estate and the Anthea Turner effect.
fields.body:
Booksellers enjoy cracker of a Christmas

So that was Christmas. And, to the surprise of many, for the book trade it was a cracker. On the high street the sales data monitoring company BookTrack reported that sales in the week before Christmas reached £66m, up more than 20% on the same period last year. High street chain Ottakars reported like-for-like sales growth of more than 10% in a six week Christmas period and even Waterstones, amid increasing speculation about the future of the business, received a festive fillip with like-for-like sales growth of almost 6% over Christmas.

In the virtual world, Amazon.com's sales in its last quarter reached almost $1bn, up by more than 40% on the same period last year. In the UK, Amazon.co.uk, Bol.com and WHS.co.uk all reported healthy sales increases; although as immature businesses this was hardly surprising.

All of this was in sharp contrast to the US where recessionary fears appeared to knock the life out of the nation's Christmas spirit, leading to a flatter than expected festive season for the book business. The downturn was, perhaps, best examplied by Borders, America's second biggest book shop chain, which issued a profits warning after recording dismal sales growth. Whether these recessionary fears find their way across the Atlantic remains to be seen but, with many UK book trade companies owned by Americans or heavily reliant on the US market, it is doubtful that the UK will be inured for long and post-Christmas jubilation could be short-lived.

Competition ruling boost for Waterstone's

Waterstone's was further boosted in the new year by the news that the Office of Fair Trading had rejected a motion, on the part of more than 600 small publishers, that it was abusing its (dominant) position in the market by seeking greater discounts from the aforementioned publishers.

But it would be remiss of the book business to let Waterstone's management enjoy an entirely worry-free new year and, sure enough, rumours soon re-emerged concerning its chairman (and founder) Tim Waterstone and his desire to rescue the business by leading a buy-out. The rumour, which has a Banquo-like hold over the national press, was swiftly denied by Alan Giles, chief executive of the parent company HMV Media, citing Waterstone's latest results as evidence of the chain's value to the HMV Group.

But this can be read two ways and, ironically, the turnaround in the chain's performance might be just the catalyst needed to secure the buy-out; after all, those investors backing Mr Waterstone are likely to be more interested in a business that is finally showing some signs of life than one that has been run into the ground. The performance might also be the fillip Giles needed to strengthen his bargaining position and get the price he has clearly been holding out for.

However the endgame resolves itself, it is unlikely that Messers Giles, Waterstone and Kneale (Waterstone's embattled managing director) will be attending the same office Christmas party next year.

Internet implications as Bertrams cuts back

Publishers, who have learnt to live with Waterstone's tribulations and tantrums over the past 18 months, will doubtless treat these latest manouverings with due scepticism. Besides, they already have a new hobbyhorse, following the news, first reported in trade bible the Bookseller, that wholesaler Bertrams is cutting back the number of titles held in its warehouse. In a letter sent to customers Bertrams argued that more than 60% of its sales came from just 5,000 titles and holding more than 200,000 individual lines was no longer practicable.

The move goes to the heart of the book business. UK publishers annually push out more than 100,000 new titles on top of the million or so titles already in print, blithely hoping that most will somehow make their way into the nation's bookshops or, at the least, the wholesalers' warehouses . This is no longer guaranteed, as those small publishers frozen out by Waterstone's recent destocking and subsequent terms negotiations have been forced to recognise.

The move could also have interesting implication for internet booksellers who rely on wholesaling giants, such as Bertrams, to carry a large enough range to back up their online offerings. Indeed, it is not beyond the realms of possibility that one of the big internet retailers will move for the business as would have already happened in the US but for the anti-competition authorities.

In brief

 Did she jump? Or was she pushed? At the time Victoria Barnsley's decision to accept the post of chief executive of HarperCollins and take her company Fourth Estate with her was seen as something of a two-way coup for Barnsley and HarperCollins. But the latest accounts for Fourth Estate reveal a slightly different story, with sales and profits down and cash non-existent. As finance director Patric admitted in the Bookseller, the company was sold at its shareholder's request. One wonders if HarperCollins, often bedevilled by take-over/sale rumours, will suffer the same fate.

 Will they ever learn? Not content with the debacle otherwise known as the memoirs of Anthea Turner, the trade is already abuzz with news of record deals for Betty Boothroyd, Hillary Clinton and Robbie Williams. Booksellers are already taking bets on which of these will wearing Anthea's clothes come Christmas 2001.

fields.headline: Hinduja passport inquiry ordered
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night ordered an investigation into the passport application case which led to Peter Mandelson's dramatic resignation.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night ordered an investigation into the passport application case which led to Peter Mandelson's dramatic resignation.

The former Treasury solicitor Sir Anthony Hammond QC begins work today on reviewing the case to ensure the application "was properly dealt with in all respects". The inquiry is certain to examine in detail whether Mr Mandelson's initial raising of billionaire Srichand Hinduja's proposal to apply for British citizenship with immigration minister Mike O'Brien had any influence on the outcome.

It will also look at the role of passport application sponsors.

Mr Blair told the Commons yesterday that he believed the application from Srichand Hinduja, who with his brother provided £1m of sponsorship for the Millennium Dome's faith zone, had been handled in "accordance with the proper criteria".

The home secretary, Jack Straw, is also satisfied that the proper procedures were followed and that his minister of state, Mr O'Brien, acted correctly. But a thorough inquiry could unearth new facts.

Officially, applications for naturalisation should be handled impartially by civil servants without any ministerial influence. Mr Blair promised to publish the inquiry's findings but Downing Street said no date had been fixed for the completion of the inquiry - so it could come out after the expected May 3 date for the general election. Nor is the government committed to publishing all the details surrounding the passport application.

Last night Srichand Hinduja said he was saddened by Mr Mandelson's resignation. He said: "I wish to reiterate that I have never at any time linked our support for the faith zone of the Millennium Dome with a request to Mr Mandelson for information in 1998."

The Hinduja foundation was created to support multicultural and cross-religious dialogue and its support for the dome was to fulfil those objectives and "not for any other reason", he said. The Hinduja brothers, who moved the centre of their growing business empire from India to Britain in the 1980s, were generous benefactors in the Asian community and had well-placed social connections. Among guests invited to celebrate the Hindu festival of Diwali were Mr Blair and his wife Cherie.

But it was widely known at the time Srichand Hinduja applied for a British passport that the two brothers could face charges over alleged corruption over the huge Bofors gun contract to the Indian government. Last week they were granted bail by an Indian court while the allegations are investigated.

webTitle: Space station crew busy and tired

fields.headline: Space station crew busy and tired
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Life aboard the international space station, Alpha, is noisy and hectic but never dull, its skipper has said.
fields.body:
Life aboard the international space station, Alpha, is noisy and hectic but never dull, its skipper has said.

The three station residents, three months into their inaugural mission, say they're too busy to be bored or depressed.

"We've definitely been kept on our toes with the schedule the ground's given us," commander Bill Shepherd said. "We've had full days and really sleepy nights, put it that way."

The men have to wear ear plugs in order to sleep because of machinery that makes intermittent clicks and clacks.

"We'd like to see the noise level come down," Shepherd noted.

The loud - and balky - equipment has frustrated the crew at times, as has the heavy workload. "Yesterday was a good example," Shepherd said. "We wrestled all day with a software tool we're trying to use to organize all the logistics (supplies) on board."

"For me, the most frustrating thing has been to try and do our best for people's expectations on the ground. Everybody wants to get things done with every good intent, but sometimes we just can't make it happen."

Shepherd said he and his crewmates, Russian cosmonauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev, are doing their best to be patient with flight controllers.

"We're trying to preclude starting a food fight," Shepherd said. "We know there's a lot of things that could maybe go better, but try not to be too critical because in the long run, all that won't matter. What matters is that we have people up in space. Space station's working and we're making progress building the station. That's what's important."

Shepherd and his crew already have had their four-month mission extended two weeks because of space shuttle problems, and face yet another delay in coming home.

Space shuttle Atlantis was supposed to be docked to the space station right now, after having delivered the US laboratory Destiny.

But last week, the launch was postponed until February 6 at the earliest so Nasa could inspect more electrical wiring on Atlantis' booster rockets. That delay is expected to have a domino effect on Discovery, the ride home for the station crew in March.

Shepherd doesn't seem to mind all the delays.

"Actually, send us some more fuel," he joked. "We'll keep this thing going for a while."

webTitle: In brief: Ford and Neeson team for cold war thriller

fields.headline: Ford and Neeson team for cold war thriller
fields.standfirst: Plus: Neeson also joins Gabriel Byrne in Irish gangster pic; Jason Connery hopes to boost film career with a turn in the theatre; Mel Gibson tries to heal rift with Bono
fields.trailText: Plus: Neeson also joins Gabriel Byrne in Irish gangster pic; Jason Connery hopes to boost film career with a turn in the theatre; Mel Gibson tries to heal rift with Bono
fields.body:
 Harrison Ford (pictured) and Liam Neeson are set to team up for the cold war suspense film, K-19: the Widowmaker, which will also star Peter Sarsgaard (best known for his role as John Lotter in 1999's Boys Don't Cry). The project, to be directed by Point Break director Kathryn Bigelow, will tell the true story of a Soviet submarine crew's attempt to prevent a nuclear meltdown in the North Atlantic in 1961. Hollywood veteran Ford is set to play the commander of the submarine with Sarsgaard playing a nuclear scientist. Neeson's role is not yet clear. Filming is due to begin in February in Canada and Russia.

 Liam Neeson has also signed up to star alongside Gabriel Byrne in a new American Irish gangster movie according to ananova this afternoon. The stars will play rivals in a tale of an Irish orphan who is taken to America where he becomes a rich and influential figure drawn towards organised crime. A source close to the project's writers, Chris Wilkinson and Steve Rivele, says that this could produce a series of forthcoming film adventures for the Irish gangsters. "As the story encompasses such a huge period there is plenty of room to go back in time and forwards again with other members of the main character's family." Rod Steiger and James Cromwell are also rumoured to be signing up to the project in major supporting roles.

 Jason Connery, son of Sean, is hoping to raise his profile by putting on a play in London to an audience made up entirely of top Hollywood movers and shakers. According to People News, the 38-year-old actor, last seen in the Jackie Chan drama Shanghai Noon, will put on a play called Faithful Dealing, about the death of Elizabethan playwright Christopher Marlowe, at the Soho Theatre. Only 20 tickets have been made available to the theatre-going public although they don't seem to be beating down the door - most of them are still available.

 Mel Gibson has taken a major step back from his ongoing feud with Bono (see earlier story) over the Wim Wenders film Million Dollar Hotel. He told ananova that his original comments that the film was "as boring as a dogs arse" might have been "slightly rash in judgement, possibly even callous." He couldn't resist, however, having a slight dig at the thriller which was voted one of the major turkeys of 2000. "I can't say it's one of my favourites. That would be wide of the mark. But it still has a lot of merit. I think it's one of those movies people will see in a couple of year's time and say 'Hold on, this is great!'"

webTitle: The gadget that came in from the cold

fields.headline: The gadget that came in from the cold
fields.standfirst:
The Russian's are coming says Jack Schofield
More net news
fields.trailText: The Russian's are coming says Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Maksim Kharchev just can't keep away from the Cybiko lab. On a freezing January afternoon in Moscow when the 18-year-old should be dozing through another dull lecture in his law course at Moscow university, he is instead ensconced on the fifth floor of a plush new business centre in the east of the city clutching a day-glo green gizmo.

"I've been coming here every day for about a month," he recounts, his gaze fixed firmly on the small LCD screen in his right hand. Like teenagers everywhere, he has trouble looking you in the eye when hypnotised by a computer game.

The room is filled with some 60 Muscovite teenagers having great fun. What's more, they get paid for it. All of them are sending each other messages via the hand-held toys, or playing games and making notes.

Behind them, a gang of older website designers are perched at desktops drawing fantasies. On the two floors below them another 150 programmers and engineers are beavering away round-the-clock, producing instant computer games for posting on the web or new software for their pride and joy.

Welcome to the wacky Russian world of Cybiko. The $100 handheld gizmo combines the functions of a Game Boy, a personal digital assistant, and a wireless communicator all in one.

It might be marketed in America and made in Taiwan, but the brainpower is here in eastern Moscow, with a bunch of young boffins, graduates of the elite cybernetics schools of the old Soviet military-industrial complex, quickly adapting to the new world of virtual entertainment, taking on the Sonys and Nintendos of this world, and emerging with a winner.

Kharchev and his mates are installed in a room echoing with giggles, whoops,and whistles as he and his chums put the new Cybiko games through their paces and make notes on the new games before they are released on to the web. There they are downloaded free of charge by the armies of American teenagers snapping up this year's must-have accessory.

"The response is amazing," says Alexei Logoshin, the Cybiko production manager who flits between Moscow and Taiwan, while his boss and Cybiko's creator, David Yang, divides his time between Moscow and Bloomingdale outside Chicago.

"We get around 40,000 messages on the website every day. At Christmas when all the American kids got their new Cybikos, we got 143,000." But the teenage testers in the Moscow lab cannot buy themselves a Cybiko. The wireless networks operate on radio frequencies whose use would land them in jail in Russia.

"Besides," says Logoshin, "the market here is too small. It's targeted at teenagers, but there's not many Russian teenagers who can afford $100 for a Cybiko."

But Kharchev and his pals are extremely willing mice in the Cybiko lab and there's no stopping the infectiously enthusiastic cyberfreaks.

Downstairs a bunch of hardware engineers are producing prototypes for a new model.

"Slimmer, smoother, and cooler," they say, proudly displaying their work.

It's all a rare and cheering triumph in a Russia more noted for its collapsing infrastructure and technological backwardness than a cutting edge entertainment industry.

"Russians are great engineers and great scientists, but they need a lot of help turning good ideas into successful products," says Vaidyanathan Sivakumar, a Moscow-based Indian fund manager.

He put together a consortium last year to plough more than $16m into Cybiko, gaining 23% of the company in the process.

"We are very happy with our investment," he says, not ing that the company expects to sell more than half a million gizmos in North America this year after 300,000 since last September.

The brainchild of David Yang, 32, a Russian of mixed Armenian-Taiwanese parentage, Cybiko appears to be going from strength to strength, spurring hopes that Yang can become a role model for other budding Russian entrepreneurs.

"I don't see a trend yet. David Yang is unique," says Sivakumar, who keeps a close watch on the Moscow market for promising investment opportunities. Logoshin ascribes Cybiko's success to "Russian brains and American management. That's a good combination."

The Japanese-sounding tinkling from the device, the creator's surname, the made-in-Taiwan label on the back of each handset,and the Cybiko name itself (Japanese for cyber-girl) do not exactly parade the fact that Moscow's elite Institute of Physics and Technology is the alma mater for the creators of Cylandia. That is where the Soviet Union's brightest perfected the computer systems for inter-continental missiles.

"The advertising supports the traditional perception of the origins of such products," says Anton Tyurin, product management director, sitting in a plush office with leather sofas and English books on 21st century management. Translated into plain English, he is saying that Cybiko is mock-Japanese.

"They don't exactly hide the fact that Cybiko's Russian," says Sivakumar. "But let's say, they don't highlight it either."

With a growing community of Cybiko afficionados thriving on the net, accessories provided for free, and a new free game available daily on the web, the Cybiko culture appears refreshingly low-budget and democratic while technologically advanced.

The relative lack of money involved means that American anoraks are designing their own games and posting them on the website. "We've got 5,141 game designers registered on the site," says Vadim Sytnikov, director of the large applications department. "Their average age is 24. Some are so good that we end up employing them and paying them for their games."

Maksim Kharchev briefly looks up from his immersement in Kamikaze Highway and grins the satisfied grin of a contented laboratory guinea pig. "It's much better than Game Boy. More functions, changing games, no contest."

Cybiko specification

Hardware

11MHz Hitachi S8H 32-bit Risc processor

512K working memory

512K Flash memory for storage

59 x 40mm LCD screen with four level grey scale and 160 by 100 pixel resolution

30 channel digital radio

Serial communications port

68-pin expansion slot

Rechargeable batteries

Size: 5.7 x 2.8 x 0.9 inches

Weight: 4.3oz

Software

CyOS 1.2

Scientific calculator, spellchecker, Spanish- English dictionary, multilingual phrasebook, time planner, address book, alarm clock, calendar, notebook, journal, photo viewer, and games.

fields.headline: 'Overwhelmed' London teacher commits suicide
fields.trailText: A south London teacher who had been awarded an MBE for his work in education hanged himself in a school outbuilding yesterday.
fields.body:
A south London teacher who had been awarded an MBE for his work in education hanged himself in a school outbuilding yesterday.

The body of 45-year-old assistant head Patrick Stack, who was described as "extra hard-working and very popular", was found in a garage at Sedgehill School in Catford.

"Everyone at the school is flabbergasted and there is no immediate explanation, but it is true he was carrying a Herculean workload and involving himself inside and outside school in an enormous range of activities," said Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of teachers' union NASUWT. "The only, admittedly superficial, explanation is that he was just overwhelmed by all these commitments," he said.

Mr Stack, who was married with a son, was a vocational, outward-bound and life skills teacher who also taught PSHE. According to Mr de Gruchy, he took pupils on 20 outdoor trips each year. Sedgefield was last inspected by Ofsted in 1996 and its vocational teaching was praised in the inspectorate's report.

A 16-year-old pupil said that pupils had guessed that Mr Stack was dead because " all the teachers were in the playground when we were sent home, but he wasn't there."

NUT general secretary Doug McAvoy said: "Pat Stack was a highly regarded, extra hard-working and very popular teacher, very popular with colleagues and pupils. "His sad death in such shocking circumstances is very painful for his colleagues and his pupils, but it is most distressing for his wife and family to whom I send my deepest sympathies."

A spokesman for the department of education described Mr Stack's death as a "sad personal tragedy" and said the department would "look at what support it could offer the school and Lewisham local education authority."

webTitle: El Salvador takes first steps back to normality

fields.headline: El Salvador takes first steps back to normality
fields.standfirst: Water starts to flow again as Oxfam aid workers - including our diarist Rachel Stabb - get to work in El Salvador's earthquake zone
fields.trailText: Water starts to flow again as Oxfam aid workers - including our diarist Rachel Stabb - get to work in El Salvador's earthquake zone
fields.body:
It's hard to emphasize strongly enough just how vital it is to get clean water flowing again after an earthquake. Lack of water leads to dehydration, illness and eventually loss of life.

In the earthquake that shook El Salvador just over a week ago, disruption to water supplies in towns and villages was extensive. And with landslides cutting off some of the worst affected and poorest areas, knowing the extent of the problem was the first task. Providing the remedy is now underway.

Wilfredo Pena of Cordes, a local organisation with long-standing links to Oxfam, was quick to recognise the need in El Conacaste, a typical hilltop settlement 35kms west of the capital, San Salvador.

He summoned one of our engineers and myself to go and have a look and 24 hours later, we were steering our pick-up truck up the impossibly steep dirt track, loaded with a tank kit that's designed to be quick and easy to assemble.

As we climbed, the views across deep, verdant gorges were breathtaking but they were an unwelcome distraction from the struggle to keep the vehicle on the road.

Adobe-style housing by the roadside showed signs of collapse from the mighty tremor that caused such destruction in communities across the country.

On reaching the school in El Conacaste, we quickly mobilised a team of volunteers, who worked tirelessly all day, first finding the best site to set up the tank and then bolting it together. The headmaster, Manuel de Jesus Escalente, who'd approved the installation the day before, stood beaming as his new project materialised.

Within a couple of hours, the galvanised steel was glinting in the evening light. Spirit levels ensured the tapstands were correctly set in concrete and children ran around excitedly, oblivious to the importance of the task.

Since the earthquake, some 2,500 people here have been sheltering in the school. They're afraid to sleep in the remaining dwellings scattered over the hillside, fearful of further collapse. Daily aftershocks occur, some still quite severe.

Marta Lucinez Acosta watched the day's activity. She'd come not because she needs water, but to support others who do. "We're a community, we're very close and I've come to support the others here," she said, smiling. A positive attitude of sharing and supporting others is alive and well in the villages of El Salvador.

Once the tank was completed and tested, 122 buckets were handed out and the taps turned on. Watching to see how it went was the British ambassador, Patrick Morgan. British government funds were pledged to Oxfam soon after the earthquake struck and Mr Morgan wanted to see how the aid agency's plans were taking shape.

Further afield, in the badly affected provinces of Ahuachapan, Sonsonate and Usulutan, similar Oxfam tanks are springing up in rural communities. It's the first step on the long road to recovery in El Salvador.

Daily Express associate editor Chris Williams has been confirmed as editor of the newspaper, a spokesman for the company said.

webTitle: A glittering career in ruins: Mandelson quits over passport deception

fields.headline: A glittering career in ruins: Mandelson quits over passport deception
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson's glittering political career collapsed yesterday for the second           and final time over an unnecessary act of deception - his fatal refusal to be frank           with the prime minster about his role in brokering a British passport for a £1m donor to the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's glittering political career collapsed yesterday for the second and final time over an unnecessary act of deception - his fatal refusal to be frank with the prime minster about his role in brokering a British passport for a £1m donor to the Millennium Dome.

In a day of high drama not equalled at Westminster since Mr Mandelson's previous resignation, over his secret home loan in 1998, the man who helped to craft New Labour's modernising image for 15 years stepped down as the Northern Ireland secretary and renounced all strategic responsibility for the coming general election.

Waking up to a barrage of hostile headlines yesterday, both Tony Blair and Mr Mandelson almost certainly knew it was all over by the time they met at number 10 in mid-morning. Three hours later came an apologetic resignation statement in the street outside.

Before the meeting the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, had refused to endorse the Northern Ireland secretary when he briefed reporters. "The prime minister has got to face the House of Commons this afternoon and there are a number of areas of fact he feels the need to pin down."

In their hour-long meeting Mr Blair and his most trusted aide discussed why the media, Mr Campbell and ministers were misled for 48 hours about Mr Mandelson's single phone call to Mike O'Brien, the immigration minister, in June 1998.

Mr Mandelson insisted he had done nothing improper, but accepted that he had not told the whole truth about his intervention in the application for naturalisation by Srichanda Hinduja, a wealthy Indian businessman.

After revelations in the Observer on Sunday, Mr Mandelson had insisted that he had merely asked his private office to pass on a request for information regarding a possible application from Mr Hinduja to the Home Office in June 1998. In fact he made the crucial two-minute phone call in person.

In the same month the Hinduja brothers offered to sponsor the faith zone at the Millennium Dome. Mr Mandelson, as the cabinet office minister, was in charge of the Greenwich project.

Mr Mandelson, who was out of office for 10 months after the Guardian's revelations about his £373,000 home loan from Geoffrey Robinson, is now entitled to his second ministerial pay-off, of £12,129, in just over two years.

Yesterday insiders emphatically denied that Mr Campbell had threatened to resign if Mr Mandelson did not. There was no need to do so, MPs agreed. The minister's inconsistencies, in private and on also television on Tuesday night, were all too evident.

"If Tony ever had to choose between Peter and Alastair, Alastair would win. He is the long-distance runner, Peter the sprinter," one Labour veteran explained.

Mr Campbell later confirmed that Mr Mandelson would not be taking part in Labour's general election campaign. "I think Peter's making clear from his statement that he is clearly looking to wind down his political activity," he said.

Mr Mandelson's exit leaves the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in a much stronger position. He and his close ally, Douglas Alexander, will now be in complete charge at Millbank , the party's headquarters. Mr Man delson had been responsible for the nuts and bolts planning for the election.

Last night there was even doubt about whether Mr Mandelson would stay on as an MP. Tim Allan, a former Downing Street press officer and friend of Mr Mandelson, said the member for Hartlepool would think "long and hard" before dropping his constituency, and insisted that he would want to remain in public life.

In his statement Mr Mandelson denied "acting improperly" over Mr Hinduja's passport bid, but admitted: "I do accept that when my office spoke to a Sunday newspaper at the weekend I should have been clear that it was me personally, not my officials, who spoke to a Home Office minister."

He also attacked the media for its relentless vilification of his political role as a pro- European, pro-Lib-Lab moderate, and for its interest in his private life. "I want to remove myself from the countless stories of controversy, feuds and division and all the rest. I want in other words to lead a more normal life, both in politics and, in the future, outside," he said.

In the Commons, William Hague gleefully denounced the prime minister's "monumental error of judgment" in giving his old friend a second chance in 1999 - leaving Mr Blair loyally to defend the achievements of the flawed colleague who sat grim-faced at his side.

But few Tories believe their election chances have been much improved. "William has 24 hours to make this stick to Blair," said one MP. The Tory leader did so by claiming that Mr Mandelson had been "central to everything you have done" - from spin to smears on colleagues. The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, joined Mr Blair in saying it was Mr Hague who had demeaned himself.

Downing Street last night moved to replace Mr Mandelson at what is seen as a crucial stage in the Northern Ireland peace process, giving the job to the Scottish secretary, John Reid. He is replaced, in turn, by Helen Liddell.

Meanwhile, Mr Blair appointed a leading QC, the former Treasury counsel Sir Anthony Hammond, to examine the way the Hinduja passport was eventually granted in March 1999 - although the prime minister told MPs that he and Jack Straw, the home secretary, were satisfied that it was properly done.

But the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, wrote to Mr Straw last night demanding that he makes a Commons statement on the whole affair.

webTitle: Councils in the red over children in care

fields.headline: Councils in the red over children in care
fields.trailText: The rising number of children taken into care has caused local authorities to run up a projected £205m overspend this year, according to the local government association. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
The rising number of children taken into care has caused local authorities to run up a projected £205m overspend this year, according to the local government association (LGA).

In a survey published in advance of next week's local government financial settlement, the LGA says 85% of English social services departments will end up an average £2m in the red.

Most councils have blamed increasing pressures relating to children's services, especially the cost of providing residential accommodation for children in care.

The LGA has also speculated that attempts by social services departments to tighten up child protection services in the wake of recent scandals may have contributed to the overspend.

LGA chairman Jeremy Beecham said: "This survey highlights that the commitment by local authorities to deliver swift improvements in children's services is forcing them to spend more than they can afford.

"This is obviously a serious financial problems for councils and cannot be sustained in the long term. The numbers of children in care is rising and the cost of provision especially in residential settings is also increasing."

The LGA survey, to which 146 out of 150 authorities replied, found that 124 authorities are expecting to overspend their budgets by the end of the financial year.

The overspends in individual authorities range from £418,000 to "many millions", with 38 authorities expecting an overspend of more than £2m.

LGA head of social affairs, health and housing John Ransford said the projected overspends were "significantly worse" than last year.

He called on the government to overhaul the "out of date" standard spending assessment for children's services.
