webTitle: Immigration rise main social trend of 1990s

fields.headline: Immigration rise main social trend of 1990s
fields.standfirst:
Facts and figures about life in Britain highlight growing inequality between rich and poor, consumer debt and use of credit cards

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Facts and figures about life in Britain highlight growing inequality between rich and poor, consumer debt and use of credit cards.
fields.body:
The chief statistician yesterday identified a rise in immigration as the most significant social change in Britain of recent years.

Len Cook, the former head of New Zealand's statistical service who took over as the UK national statistician in July, said population patterns through most of the 20th century had changed dramatically during the 1990s as migration became the main engine of population growth.

The figures came in Social Trends, the official annual digest of facts and figures about life in Britain. It also showed growing inequalities between rich and poor, mounting consumer debt and increasing use of credit cards instead of cash or cheques.

Mr Cook said "homegrown" population increases - the surplus of births over deaths - hugely exceeded net migration into the UK from 1900 to 1990. Indeed for much of the century there was a net outflow of people. But between 1991 and 1999 net immigration averaged 104,000 a year, compared with a homegrown population rise averaging 107,000.

Mr Cook said the change was particularly stark in the closing years of the century, when migration became the predominant demographic influence. Immigration overtook natural population growth in England and Wales in 1994-95. By 1998-99 net inward migration increased to 194,000, while natural population growth fell to 72,000. "This amounts to a huge shift in the importance of immigration to changes in the British population, with consequences for ethnic mix and age structure," he said.

"Since immigrants go disproportionately to London, it will also affect where people live."

The immigrants came mainly from outside the European Union. Refugees who were granted asylum or given leave to stay made up a small proportion - just over 10,000 in 1999. On Monday the Home Office forecast between 150,000 and 175,000 immigrants from outside the EU each year until 2005.

Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, said: "The UK is a nation of immigrants. Immigration is a very good thing and has benefited the country." Advantages included skills brought by workers needed by the expanding information technology industry, and the younger age profile of immigrants that would help to balance the pressures of an ageing population.

Social Trends estimated that the UK population would rise from 59.5m in 1999 to peak at nearly 65m in 2036. Population growth in England, Wales and Northern Ireland would be partly offset by a slight fall in Scotland.

The survey said the British population had increased by more than half during the 20th century, but the number of households tripled in the same period to almost 24m in spring 2000.

Almost three in 10 households comprised one person in spring 2000 - more than two and a half times the proportion in 1961.

There were 179,000 first marriages in the UK in 1999 - less than half the number in 1970. The average age of women at childbirth in England and Wales rose over the same period from 26.2 years to 29.

The survey found that the distribution of income became more unequal in the 80s, stabilised in the early 90s and began to widen again in 1997. In 1997-98 the income of the richest 10% rose 4% to £559.70 a week, while for the poorest it rose only 1.8% to £136.10.

Latest official figures for 1998 showed that Britain was the most expensive European country outside Scandinavia. A British resident would find goods and services at least 10% cheaper in Italy and the Netherlands, and more than 20% cheaper in Spain, Greece and Portugal.

The amount of consumer credit outstanding in the UK increased to £115bn in 1999, almost double the 1987 level in real terms. The volume of cash payments fell during the 1990s but still accounted for two-thirds of all transactions.

Plastic card payments tripled, cash withdrawals doubled and there was a 75% increase in direct debits, standing orders and other automated payments. Payments by cheque declined by a quarter. About one in five debit card purchases in supermarkets involved cashback, with an average value of £24.

The survey came on the bicentenary of the first British census. In 1801 there were about 10m people in Britain and about 2m households. Since then population has increased by nearly six times and the number of households by 12 times. In 1821 half the population was aged under 20, compared with a quarter in 1999.

The nation by numbers

Social Trends, a 268-page snapshot of UK life published by the office of national statistics, contains 321 tables and charts. Here are some of the facts they contain:

 Between 1981 and 1999 the number of GPs in Britain rose by a third to 36,000. But the number of nurses and other direct care staff in NHS hospitals and community health services fell by 4%

 The proportion of three- and four-year-olds enrolled in UK schools tripled from 21% in 1970-71 to 64% in 1999-00. In spring 2000, 5.7m people of working age were studying towards a qualification in the UK, just over half of whom were aged 16-24

 The consumption of fresh potatoes has fallen steadily from 1,300 grams a person a week in 1974 to less than 700 grams in 1999. But fresh fruit consumption rose over the same period from 500 grams to nearly 750 grams

 In 1999 about 276,000 hectares of land had been converted, or were in the process of being converted, to organic farming. This was six times more than in 1995

 In spring 2000 there were 27m people of working age in employment in the UK - the most since 1959 when records began. Over that period the proportion of men in work fell to 79% while the proportion of women rose from 47% to 69%

 Among non-married women under 60, the proportion cohabiting almost doubled between 1986 and 1998-99 - from 13% to 25%. For men it more than doubled from 11% to 26%

 Three-quarters of adults agree that "families with working mothers need grandparents' help more and more". One in 10 said grandparents have "little to teach the grandchildren of today"

 A third of domestic water in England and Wales was used for personal washing, including baths, showers and hand basins. A quarter - between 35 and 45 litres a head a day - was used for flushing the toilet, according to environment agency statistics for 1997-98.

 The proportion of houses fitted with a burglar alarm doubled between 1992 and 2000, from 13% to 26%

 The breeding population of woodpigeons doubled between 1971 and 1999, while great tits, chaffinches and robins were up by at least a quarter. But the population of skylarks, yellowhammers and song thrushes fell by more than half and starlings declined by 65%

 In spring 2000, there were 855,000 people working in IT-related occupations, an increase of 45% in five years. In 1999-00 two in five UK households had a PC - almost three times as many as in 1985

fields.headline: ITN steps up war of words
fields.trailText:
3pm update: ITN claims its John Sergeant 'ran circles around the BBC's Andrew Marr on the Mandelson story, reports Jason Deans.
Jan 25: BBC overturns News at Ten victory
fields.body:
ITN has stepped up the war of words with BBC News over the 10pm news clash, claiming John Sergeant "ran circles around" his BBC rival Andrew Marr on the Mandelson resignation story.

"Last night proved exactly why ITN recruited John Sergeant as its political editor - the BBC's loss is very much our gain," said an ITN spokeswoman.

"John and the ITN political team ran circles round Andrew Marr on the Mandelson story," she added. "Despite the fact that it was the major political story of the year so far, the BBC seemed to be resting on its laurels."

Mr Sergeant was BBC chief political correspondent until he replaced Michael Brunson in March last year as ITN political editor.

He left the BBC because he was fed up playing second fiddle to then political editor Robin Oakley.

But two months after Mr Sergeant joined ITN, the BBC ousted Mr Oakley and replaced him with Mr Marr.

Nigel Dacre, ITN editor ITV news, said News at Ten had also secured two "distinctive elements" for its Mandelson coverage - Alastair Campbell speaking to camera and an interview with the disgraced politician's close friend Robert Harris - which the BBC did not have.

"Our coverage on last night's programme of the major story of the day was a prime example of the consistently high quality of ITN's reporting," Mr Dacre added. "It was comprehensive, clear and hard-hitting."

A BBC news spokesman said: "Andrew and John are both first-rate journalists. As far as last night's Ten O'Clock News goes, we are very happy with the quality and comprehensiveness of our coverage of Mandelson's resignation."

He refused to be drawn into the row about Andrew Marr and his prediction that Mr Mandelson was safe just 10 hours before he fell on his sword.

Insiders say the BBC had a film of Robert Harris for the Ten O'Clock News but decided to hand it over to Newsnight where there was more time for in-depth analysis.

The new Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, said today that he would learn from his predecessor Peter Mandelson.

Mr Reid said after arriving in Belfast this afternoon: "I am surprised to be here. I wish the circumstances that got me here were different to what they are but I will pursue the same objectives as, before me, Peter Mandelson did and Mo Mowlam before him."

He added: "I hope I can achieve a little of what they tried to accomplish" and praised the "individuals who had shown dignity and courage".

The former armed forces minister said sympathetic coverage in the press in Northern Ireland reflected the respect with which Mr Mandelson, who resigned yesterday, had been held.

He said he had a "great deal to learn" and added that one of the strengths he would bring to the job was that: "I know what I don't know".

He added: "I don't claim to be a genius but I pledge my total commitment to taking forward the process towards a peaceful and prosperous Northern Ireland."

He dismissed the significance of him becoming the first Catholic to hold the post, claiming everyone has their own private lives but he would be concentrating on helping secure peace.

He went on: "We all have our own beliefs. I bring one belief to this job: I believe every person in Northern Ireland, from whatever background or tradition, wants a prosperous future."

He said, though, that he was merely a "vehicle" to drive the process forward and it was the people of Northern Ireland themselves which would find peace "despite the difficulties we go through from time to time".

Earlier, a senior Ulster Unionist claimed that Mr Reid's arrival must not precipitate any problems.

The Ulster Unionist Party deputy leader, John Taylor, was concerned that the resignation of Mr Mandelson could hold up the current efforts to resolve problems in the process.

"We are at a very critical moment in the Belfast Agreement and this resignation of Mandelson and the appointment of Reid must go through smoothly to keep up the momentum," the Strangford MP said.

"I fear it could (stall the process) and that would be tragic for the remaining stages of the Belfast Agreement - namely the decommissioning of illegal arms and of course, the setting up of the police authorities for the new Police Service of Northern Ireland."

This morning, Dr Reid had his first meeting with the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, in his new role at Downing Street.

No arrangements have as yet been made for meetings with the province's political leaders.

In a statement last night, Dr Reid acknowledged he was entering the job at a critical stage in the peace process.

"The next few weeks provide an enormous opportunity to put the Agreement and the future of Northern Ireland on a more stable basis," he said.

The deputy first minister of the Northern Ireland Executive, Seamus Mallon, today said he did not see why the resignation of Mr Mandelson should derail the current round of talks.

The SDLP deputy leader said: "Certainly, Mr Mandelson's resignation will cause logistical problems and various other problems in terms of the negotiations that are taking place.

"But I am very confident that, given the length of time these matters have been under scrutiny, given the involvement of the prime minister at a central level, that there will not be the time gap that people might expect or one would expect in a similar type situation."

With some nationalists expressing concern about Dr Reid's involvement in the successful bid to free two Scots Guards convicted of killing north Belfast teenager Peter McBride in 1992, Mr Mallon appealed for the new Northern Ireland secretary to be viewed in a "different light".

"He is coming as secretary of state. He is coming at a very difficult time," the Newry and Armagh MP said.

"He is coming at a time when we are almost, I believe, at the threshold of either succeeding or failing completely to get this thing moving properly."

fields.headline: Profile: Dr John Reid
fields.standfirst:
Julian Glover takes a look at Peter Mandelson's successor, a tough-talking ex-Communist who now hopes to deliver peace in Northern Ireland.
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Julian Glover takes a look at Peter Mandelson's successor, a tough-talking ex-Communist who now hopes to deliver peace in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Though Dr John Reid smiles on television, he is a hard man with a past. A Glaswegian ex-Communist trusted by Tony Blair to deliver the goods, Dr Reid has now been charged with saving the peace process after Peter Mandelson's implosion.

If he does so, the highest offices in the land may be open to him in New Labour's expected second term. If he fails, expect this ambitious fixer to crawl undamaged from the wreckage nonetheless.

Born in Lanarkshire in 1947, Reid comes from Catholic mining stock. His father was a postman and his mother a factory worker, but he broke away from his roots thanks to hard work and a good education. This culminated in a doctorate in economic history at Stirling University: a well-informed and sometimes brilliant analyst, Reid is no dim central belt machine politician.

He joined the Communist party in 1973, leaving it to become a professional Labour party activist with close links to Neil Kinnock. He reaped his reward in 1987 when he won the ultra-safe seat of Motherwell North (now Hamilton North and Bellshill). He voted for Tony Blair as party leader in 1994 and by the end of that year was deputy spokesman on defence.

As a junior defence minister after the 1997 election he succeeded brilliantly with the Strategic Defence Review, cutting military costs while winning over the defence chiefs. Friends noticed how he came to love the technicalities of defence administration, able to recite missile specifications at the drop of a hat and fond of taking the salute at parades.

In spring 1999 he was promoted to the cabinet as secretary of state for Scotland, a post greatly diminished in importance by devolution. Despite this, he built his profile, prepared to put the government's case on any issue against tough TV interviewers.

He had to cope with the fall out after Donald Dewar, Scotland's respected first secretary, died in 2000, standing by as Dewar's successor Henry McLeish took the Scottish executive down an increasingly nationalist path.

He will no doubt have been glad to escape to the more challenging fields of the Northern Ireland office. Here he will have to cope with another, even more unpredictable devolved executive as well as the demands of the ex-terrorist organisations.

He will be judged on two things: whether he persuades the IRA to decommission at least some of its weapons and whether he secures the implementation of the Patten police reforms.

But as one of Tony Blair's current favourites he may not get the chance. After all, another reshuffle beckons after the general election.

fields.headline: Pant, Grrr, and Oof
fields.trailText: IT'S HARD BEING KUDDLY
fields.body:
IT'S HARD BEING KUDDLY

Running Chelsea's of Chelsea is a difficult job. Long lunches in the west London boutique's popular Fishnets bar and grill can be irksome. Testing the banqueting facilities in all eleven "stylish, modern and cosmopolitan" function suites is a chore. And press conferences are held at the far end of a very long room, so if you need to make an important announcement you have to wade through miles of luxurious knee-deep carpet. Spare a thought, then, for poor old Kuddly Ken Bates, who this morning had to run the shagpile gauntlet in order to tell the world about Chelsea's £24m four-year sponsorship deal with the Emirates airline.

"We are delighted," a knackered Ken panted, before giving himself time to get his breath back. "It is not just about shirt sponsorship," he continued an hour later, "there is a lot more to it than that." The Kuddlesome chairman then explained how Emirates, who replace current sponsors Autoglass at the end of the season, have also bought themselves a "scholarship scheme" which allows Dubai youngsters to receive training from Chelsea's staff.

Like the classy gent he is, Ken didn't pass up the opportunity to crow about the size of Chelsea's wad, second only to the £35m Vodafone gave Manchester United. And after loudly screaming the word "more" in close proximity to the phrase "Arsenal and Leeds", he decided to take an irrelevant pop at Fulham. "We are an international team based in Fulham and Chelsea, rather like our neighbours Fulham down the road. I am not sure where Mr Fayed comes from but he has quite a few foreigners in his team as well!" quipped Kuddly, as two porters carrying a gold-plated Sedan chair arrived to whisk him back over the limb-sapping rug.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SATELLITE OF LOVE

When the Fiver isn't sniffing around for juicy exclusives (ie: most days), we sometimes waste an idle half-hour or two playing with our new satellite system. What channel shall we watch today? I know, Romanian! Oh look, there's a dubbed version of Cheers. Bunã Norm! Bere Sam! And isn't that Dan Petrescu's agent Giovanni Becali making the outrageous claim that if Glenn Hoddle joins Spurs in the summer he'll take Petrescu with him?

"We know that in the summer it is almost certain that Hoddle will go to Tottenham and that Petrescu will follow him there," Becali blabbed to Romanian TV show Our Life Everyday. "We know that Hoddle has had some talks with Dan and he has promised him that he will not leave him at Southampton," he added, making Hampshire sound like it was being over-run with Viet-Cong. Which it is, if reports from our man on the ground in Farleigh Wallop prove to be correct.

Before our luxury satellite went all fuzzy, Becali revealed that his charge - who has been with the Saints all of 12 days - is ready to jump ship for the third time this season. "Dan's very satisfied at Southampton but his love for London and his admiration for Hoddle will make him decide to follow him," he said. It could be, of course, that the Fiver had missed something in our Romanian to English translation. Unfortunately, a call to Southampton's Daphne Branston was unable to shed any light on the situation. "At the moment the chairman and club secretary are in a board meeting, they are the people you would need to speak to," she whispered, at which point we hung up. The Fiver, once we gets our paws into a story, we never let go. Grrr!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We honestly don't care where the final is being played. It could be played at the local park, it doesn't matter. All we want to do is win the competition" - Honestly, one good game and Robbie Fowler's talking like the perfect professional.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

POP GOES THE TENDON

Now, it is with some sobriety that the Fiver presents the next item. CRASH! A report released this week in the CRUMPLE! British Journal of Sports Medicine reveals the true OOF! shocking BANG! frequency of injury in professional AARGH! football. Yes, apparently, playing a contact sport at a professional level with (often) multi-million pound stakes at stake results in people being hurt.

The study found that between 1997 and 1999, professional footballers in Britain suffered a total of 6,030 injuries (for ease of tallying, Darren Anderton counted as one). Which amounts to a total number of missed matches in the region of 23,876. This, apparently, cost clubs a total of £40m, and amounted to a loss of man hours unheard of in other industries - although shark dentists are believed to be disputing this point.

Other interesting factoids from the report are as follows. Each injury led, on average, to a four-match absence (equivalent to one international jaunt for Celestine Babayaro). The average number of injuries at each club per season was 39. And the average number of cynical belly-laughs from Walter Smith on hearing that last fact was 42.5.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Parma midfielder Johan Micoud is a target for Tottenham and West Ham, according to the Corriere della Sport.

Alaves have received a £2.3m offer for Jordi Cruyff from an un-named Premiership outfit, believed to be Southampton or West Ham.

Arsenal and Tottenham are interested in £3m-rated Lecce striker Cristiano Lucarelli.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Chesterfield could face FA sanctions after an investigation was launched into their financial and administrative arrangements. Though the FA refused to confirm the precise nature of the allegations being lodged against the club, it is believed they centre around payment of gate receipts following an FA Cup game and financial issues relating to the transfer of a player from Chester City.

Gary Locke today joined Bradford on a free transfer from Hearts, subject to passing a medical at Valley Parade. The 25-year-old right-back hopes to make his debut in a friendly at Wrexham tomorrow.

Southampton have rejected a bid for James Beattie from Serie A club Brescia. "We received a derisory offer from Brescia three weeks ago which nobody is taking seriously," chairman Rupert Lowe told the Southampton official website. "A written bid arrived offering £1.7m which we instantly rejected out of hand."

Graham Taylor has been honoured with a Carling No 1 Award to mark his 1,000th league game as a manager - a milestone which has only been reached by two others in English football, Jim Smith and Brian Clough. Taylor began his managerial career back in 1972 when he took charge of Lincoln City at the age of just 27.

Perugia and Napoli are both interested in Lorenzo Amoruso. The player's agent hopes a deal for the Rangers defender can be completed before the Italian transfer window closes on January 31.

Lubomir Moravcik's agent has claimed the player could be tempted to stay another season at Parkhead. The Slovakian has hinted that he will quit Scottish football at the end of the season, but Peter Telek said: "If Celtic show serious interest in signing Lubo for one more season then they have the first option and that would be his top priority."

Fiorentina coach Fatih Terim claims that he has rejected offers from Liverpool and Barcelona. "My agent Moreno Roggi has had offers from Liverpool and Barcelona," revealed Terim. "But I cannot leave Italy. I have only been here six months. My duty is not finished."

Ipswich striker Richard Logan has joined Cambridge on a month's loan. The 19-year-old has made just one substitute appearance for the Premiership side this season.

Wolves centre-back Ludovic Pollet has signed a new two-year contract with the Molineux club.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.20am) [whine, greet, grizzle]

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.30am) Gah! That sounds like effing McCaff again. What does he want?

Dutch Football (1am) [scream, huff, puff]

Argentine Football (2.30am, 4am) We're not getting much joy him, readers, he's too het up. Perhaps his Sky Sports column will help.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.30am) "This morning I wandered out towards my car, when I suddenly became aware of a full scale film crew filming in the house next door. I'm talking the full hit here with massive lights and loads of trucks."

Spanish Football League (8pm, 1am) "There were big Mercedes and they'd even put cones out to keep the other cars clear. They had security men standing outside and so I had to wander over to check it out."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3am) "Anyway, it turns out they're making a Whiskas advert! The bloke said there were five cats and they had their own caravan! Can you believe they actually have their own changing room?"

Australian Soccer League (11pm) "They must have been working them hard because they were there for hours!"

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 12midnight SS1) [yell, stomp, demand]

Sky Sports 3: Football Gold (10pm) What's that? You want a cat of your own and you're holding your breath until you get one?

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) [screet, scraw, boo]

Talksport: Football First with John Kearns (7pm) Well, really! I want never gets. And we're not tolerating this sort of misbehaviour, so go to your room immediately without supper.

That sounds like effing McCaff again. What does he want? Dutch Football (1am) [scream, huff, puff] Argentine Football (2.30am, 4am) We're not getting much joy him, readers, he's too het up. Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.30am) "This morning I wandered out towards my car, when I suddenly became aware of a full scale film crew filming in the house next door. You want a cat of your own and you're holding your breath until you get one? fields.headline: Broadcast
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 26.
fields.trailText: January 26: ITV has reopened talks with Richard Desmond about bringing back OK!TV.
fields.body:
ITV's controller of documentaries and factual television Dianne Nelmes has reopened talks with Northern & Shell boss Richard Desmond about bringing back the ill-fated OK!TV. OK!TV, made by Carlton, was axed after a single series and attempts to bring it back on GMTV collapsed after GMTV fell out with Desmond.

The BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland has told an all-party parliamentary media group that the BBC would not back down over the news scheduling clash, predicting that ITV would give up first.

Former Panorama and Newsnight producer Paul Woolwich has been ousted from his position as a director at Twenty Twenty Television.

The BBC's digital proposals show that programme budgets for the new channels, BBC3 and BBC4, will be as low as £13,000 per hour.

Granada TV is cutting back its network lifestyle programming department with a view to beefing up its low-cost broadband production.

webTitle: Where the great, the good and the angry converge

fields.headline: Where the great, the good and the angry converge
fields.standfirst:
Globalisation's annual thinktank, the World Economic Forum, starts today in the Swiss Alpine resort. Derek Brown takes a closer look

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Analysis: Globalisation's annual thinktank, the World Economic Forum, starts today in the Swiss Alpine resort. Derek Brown takes a closer look.
fields.body:
Thousands of powerful men have converged on the Swiss Alpine resort of Davos, intent on furthering the cause of global trade and economic expansion.

And that's just the police. The annual jamboree known as the World Economic Forum (WEF) is a shade less glitzy than usual this year: no US president, no Tony Blair, no Bill Gates.

Still, there are 19 heads of state, at least eight heads of government, at least one king, and a clutch of princelings. And around 3,500 others, mostly corporate folk, who have paid small fortunes to participate in the world's premier schmoozing event.

Davos is the place where the great and the good toss around ideas, get to know each other, cut a few deals, and generally make the world a better place. That's the theory, at any rate.

Critics say that it is a powerhouse of global capitalism. Some of the Forum's more ardent opponents will be in Davos today and until January 30, hurling abuse and no doubt some more tangible objects at the guests and delegates.

Fears of violent demonstrations have prompted the Swiss authorities to lay on extraordinary security measures. At least 1,200 police have been deployed around the congress centre, backed up by troops.

The state of semi-siege has no doubt deterred some potential participants, but the lure of Davos remains strong. It's also on offer, for a price.

The WEF was launched 31 years ago, to general indifference, by Klaus Schwab, a Swiss business professor and whizzo entrepreneur. Starting with a minuscule budget but with a shrewd instinct for the lure of raw power and immense riches, he has turned the event into a huge engine of influence. Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, will be at this year's beanfeast - he will, very likely, be seized with envy.

The WEF does not believe in hiding its light under a bushel. Publicity for last year's millennial gathering was shamelessly elitist: "By bringing together the most influential business, political and intellectual leaders, the summit sets the tone, atmosphere and priorities for the start of the century."

The immense cost of bringing together world leaders and their retinues is paid for by the other, rather more important, participants: the corporate executives who pay handsomely to rub shoulders with democrats and despots.

The WEF foundation headed by Schwab charges millions of dollars for participation. The main sponsors fork out US$250,000 a year. In return for their largesse, such corporate subscribers get to choose what subjects are dealt with in the Forum's seminar sessions - and the right to speak.

It's clearly a nice little earner. It has enabled Schwab to build a swank new headquarters for his foundation on the shores of Lake Geneva, and set up a clutch of companies - which are prominently represented at the Forum.

In defence of Davos, it is credited with some vital contributions to recent world events. Among them, German reunification, South African reconciliation, and the Middle East peace process are all said to have been eased by contacts made in the Alps.

Schwab himself has made some prescient forecasts. He claims he predicted a popular backlash against capitalist globalisation, long before the first large scale street protest against the World Trade Organisation in Seattle in 1999.

fields.headline: NTL unveils ambitious targets
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: NTL has announced plans to double its subscriber base by the end of the year, reports Dan Milmo.
Jan 24: NTL to ramp up prices
fields.body:
NTL has unveiled ambitious targets in the hope of breaking BSkyB's dominance of the digital TV market.

The UK's largest cable company wants to calm investors' nerves over the health of the industry.

NTL aims to have 1.25m digital subscribers by the end of 2001, more than doubling its current number of 500,000.

This is still far behind BSkyB, which has 4.1m.

Close rival ONdigital recently announced it had passed the 1m-subscriber mark.

"This is a good move," said Christian Maher, cable analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite.

"NTL is adding more visibility to some of its targets, which are relatively aggressive but still achievable."

A rise in subscription fees and a cost-cutting spree will help push pre-tax earnings to £385m this year and to £825m in 2002.

However, pre-tax profits will be some way off in 2005.

But NTL's trump card is its ability to offer a combination of TV, internet and telephone services.

It already has 2m subscribers to its analogue TV or telephone services in the UK.

Despite a debt burden of £8.8bn, analysts remain bullish about the company because it hits its targets and bundling services together could prove lucrative.

"These cable companies still have an innate advantage over BT and BSkyB," added Mr Maher.

NTL also has £1.45bn left to spend on acquisitions.

However, NTL is now expected to concentrate on bedding in the 11 companies it bought last year.

webTitle: Consumer: How much can you pay for ...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst:
... false eyelashes

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: ... false eyelashes.
fields.body:
When is diamond jewellery not diamond jewellery? When it's an eyelash, of course. Eyelure, the leading maker of false eyelashes, has combined its expertise with that of designer Julien Macdonald. The result is a pair of lashes adorned with 36 diamonds, each weighing 0.02 carats. They made their debut at Macdonald's show during the last London Fashion Week - modelled by Elizabeth Jagger - and are available exclusively from Icecool at £600 a pair (20% off the full price).

Unlike the garden variety, these carats may not enhance your eyesight, but they will certainly give your eyes that added sparkle. Sadly, though, losing one at a party will be far more disastrous than mislaying a contact lens - with only 10 pairs in the UK, you may not be able to get a replacement even if you can afford it.

Your other half won't stump up? Buy them yourself - you deserve it. If you do not have internet access you can also order them from icecool.co.uk on 020-7831 7648.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Home furnishings

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Home furnishings.
fields.body:
Those of you who would like to "do a Changing Rooms" rather than merely spring clean your living space should have a look at Furniture 123. With up to 30% off high-street prices and a free swatch service whereby your material samples are dispatched within 48 hours, you could give Laurence Llewellyn-Bowen and the gang a run for their money.

The site's magazine section provides handy hints on choosing a bed, for example: "Make sure you choose a base that you can get into your bedroom!"

If you are feeling flash, take your new-found knowledge to Interior Internet and search by category or look. I ended up in Chic & Bleak, ogling the sort of bed that would only work in a loft apartment in London's Clerkenwell - all sex and chrome. The £1,813.69 price tag did not include VAT, but it did cover the bulbs for the adjustable halogen reading lights.

For more traditional charm, Nina Campbell sells accessories such as scented candles, floral trays for TV dinners, china and glassware. If her fluffy leopard-print hot-waterbottle covers, left, don't warm your cockles, her advice for a happy homestead will: "If you can't hold on to your husband, make sure you hold on to your curtain-maker."

webTitle: Consumer: Illegal buys on the internet

fields.headline: 2lbs of uranium and a pint of pee, please
fields.standfirst: If you can buy babies over the internet, is there anything you can't get?  Tim Dowling  runs through his online shopping list
fields.trailText: If you can buy babies over the internet, is there anything you can't get? Tim Dowling runs through his online shopping list.
fields.body:
After the revelation that you can buy twins on the internet, we have perhaps come a step closer to the day when everything will be available online, allowing each of us to purchase our heart's desire without being restricted by tiresome moral implications. But what sort of dodgy stuff can you buy over the net these days, and how do you go about finding it? You might be surprised.

Can I buy weapons online?

Yes. Sadly, but rather predictably, the Kalashnikov e-shop website is entirely in Russian, but Kalashnikov USA Midwest does offer Saiga 420s and plenty more to anyone who has a federal firearms licence on file. The site Milparade is selling a subscription to the online version of Russia's Arms 2000 brochure, "the catalogue of Russian modern export-oriented weapons", which includes the Tochka modernised tactical missile system and the RPG-7V1 handheld antitank grenade launcher.

The internet is packed with sites offering guns, ammo, grenades, knives etc, mostly from US-based companies. The online ordering systems are generally quite primitive - "Call Jim", says one - but this may have something to do with the fact that the international shipment of deadly weaponry remains bogged down in legal red tape.

I can buy cheap cigarettes online, though, can't I?

Yes and no. It's perfectly legal to purchase tobacco, but only if UK vat and excise duty has been paid by the seller, which would hardly make it cheap. Without the duty being paid "the goods are liable to forfeiture by customs at the postal depot", according to HM customs and excise's spoilsport website.

What about academic work? Say I need an essay on Ben Jonson's Volpone "for reference" by, say, 2:15 this afternoon?

Apart from pornography, this is one of the few areas in which the internet comes into its own. Although there is a published disclaimer stating that all essays are for research purposes only, Termpapers on file has a six-page term paper titled Ben Jonson: Envy and Virtue in Volpone (bibliography lists six sources), at $9.85 (£7) per page. There are cheaper sites, even free exchanges, but with essays you probably get what you pay for.

Can I buy drugs over the internet?

Most certainly. A large portion of the web seems to be devoted entirely to the sale of Viagra, and sites such as RX Palace offerfungal oint ments, allergy medications, Zovirax and other pharmaceuticals, all ready to be shipped worldwide.

No, I mean drugs ... you know.

I see. This is an interesting question. The auction site eBay has from time to time played unwitting host to people trying to sell large consignments of marijuana and cocaine, but these are thought to be hoaxes and are deleted as soon as they are discovered, in spite of the enthusiastic bidding that accompanies them. Likewise, most of the kidneys you find advertised are the work of pranksters. Users of online auctioneers sign an agreement promising not to post illegal items for auction, and monitors stalk the sites removing guns, drugs, organs and other contraband.

Well, there go my hopes of getting some uranium ...

Actually, you can buy uranium at eBay. A 2lb chunk of autunite uranium ore, boasting a level of radioactivity "greater that 5,000cpm on a gamma-ray scintillation counter", was going for about $18 (£12.35) at time of writing. It is for educational and scientific use only, of course.

So apart from drugs, weapons and kidneys, you can get just about anything on the net?

Not really. It is virtually impossible to purchase whale meat, although I eventually tracked down a number to call (in Norway) for fresh whale come the summer.

Likewise, my efforts to obtain a live cheetah came to nought. I did find a site, the Cheetah Conservation Foundation, which said that I could privately adopt a cheetah, at $45 (£30) for an adult rising to $135 (£92) for a female with two cubs. However, on closer examination I realised they were only going to send me an adoption certificate and a photograph, plus some stickers. So I pay the money and they keep the cheetah. It just shows how careful you have to be with some of these online hucksters.

I guess a lot of these websites aren't what they seem.

Too right. The extremely promising web page headed Corpses For Sale was actually selling models of decaying cadavers, albeit very realistic ones ("Each corpse is hand-crafted and is very durable in construction"). The home page for DigiCrime, "formed in 1994 to meet the needs of a growing criminal element around the world" appears to be an attempt at satire.

Are there any sites that do exactly what it says in their URL?

Thankfully yes. The explicitly named Urine for sale, for instance, sells urine and nothing but urine, guaranteed to be 100% human and untainted by any trace of illegal drugs, alcohol or nicotine. Even its slogan, Urine So Pure It Could Easily Pass A Urine Drug Test, is frank, to the point and admirably free of hyperbole.

Every sample is fresh ("the order is filled the day it is put in") and comes pre-packaged in a "hi-tech delivery system". It even includes a certificate of authenticity and a transfer of ownership, "so you can say in good conscience 'this is a clean sample of my own urine'".

There ought to be some sort of award scheme for this kind of open and honest online trading.

fields.headline: Your Christmas turkeys
fields.standfirst: What's the worst present you've ever had? An orange when you wanted a bike, a power tool when you wanted a cashmere scarf? We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here is the winning entry and some runners up
fields.trailText: We asked what was your worst Christmas present ever... here is the winning entry and some runners up
fields.body:
The prize goes to:

Please don't publish my real name on this one. This year I got sent a wedding photo in a frame from a couple I'm friends with. I was unable to get to the wedding, so she thought this might make up for it in some way. The only problem is that I'm still totally in love with the man in question, it breaks my heart to look at the picture and I'm going to have to put it up somewhere so as not to offend them.
'Georgina Evans'

Honorary mention to:

The worst Christmas present I ever had was a local history of Auchterarder - a place I've never been to.
James Andrew

One year I was lucky enough to get this beautifully wrapped gift from a new(ish) boyfriend. What can it be I thought, chocolates , jewellery, cd player etc.? No. It was a plastic "can crusher"! The idea being if you crush your baked bean or soup cans before putting them into your dustbin you can fit more rubbish in the bin. Exciting gift, or what? Needless to say our relationship did not blossom!
Elaine Henderson

My nan hasn't got much money so when she asked me what I would like for Christmas I said that I would like some razors. Imagine my surprise when on Christmas day I opened up a giant packet of raisins. Mind you I didn't cut myself for a change.
Richard Francis

My nomination is the three pairs of "Holy Socks" illustrative of the story of Jonah and the Whale given to me this year by my mother, a Church of Scotland elder. The whale looks more of a slug to me. She assures me that she has sufficient stores of the dratted things (on assorted biblical themes) to be able to make similar gifts, birthdays and Christmases, for the remainder of my natural life. The worst of it is that, through a temporary hiatus in my laundry arrangements, I've actually been forced to wear them.
Graeme Smillie

My mum's sister bought me a sack truck, yes... a sack truck for Christmas. What is a sack truck, well.... it allows for easy movement of sacks around the garden.... One problem, I have no garden, don't ever have the inclination to buy sacks. Have tried to find other uses for the amazing gift, works wellish as a TV stand, but not on BBC2, antenna causes lines, and have tried unsuccessfully to lend it to friends... Would you like it???
Mark Woods

My worst Christmas present ever: A years membership to 'slimmers world' from my (ex!)Boyfriend.
Bernadette Hancock

webTitle: Crouching Tiger now biggest foreign film ever

fields.headline: Crouching Tiger now biggest foreign film ever
fields.trailText: Ang Lee's martial arts romance has beaten the record held by Life Is Beautiful as the most successful foreign-language film ever released in Britain after only three weeks of release
fields.body:
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon officially sealed its place as the most successful foreign-language film in British cinema history last night. As the final till receipts were tallied from box offices around the country, Ang Lee's acclaimed martial arts fable edged ahead of the previous record figure of £3,036,708 posted two years ago by Roberto Benigni's Holocaust tale Life is Beautiful.

Crouching Tiger's success is particularly impressive bearing in mind that the film has only been on general release for 20 days, expanding from a limited run in its opening week when backers, Columbia, got wind of its runaway success. The picture has spent the past three weekends at the top of the London box office and is continuing to perform strongly in other cities across Britain.

On Sunday night Crouching Tiger took the awards for Best Foreign Film and Best Director at the Golden Globes, a crucial indicator of Oscar form. Insiders believe that the film may well go on to scoop the Academy Award for Best Picture - an award it was ineligible for at the Globes - on March 25. Meanwhile, having taken the Globe, Lee is now considered to have the edge on closest rival Steven Soderbergh in the hunt for the Best Director Oscar.

webTitle: Ring of steel awaits Davos protesters

fields.headline: Ring of steel awaits Davos protesters
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Hundreds of police, army security specialists and coils of barbed wire greeted the world's business and political leaders as they arrived today for the annual business summit in Davos, Switzerland.
fields.body:
Hundreds of police, army security specialists and coils of barbed wire greeted the world's business and political leaders as they arrived today for the annual business summit in Davos, Switzerland.

Authorities have banned demonstrations in the ski resort that has hosted the World Economic Forum (WEF) for the last 31 years, but anti-globalization protesters are determined to have their say.

Swiss television reports estimate that between 1,000 and 2,000 police from across Switzerland are on hand to choke off the kind of protests that have hit the European Union summit in Nice, the International Monetary Fund/World Bank meetings in Prague and the World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle.

At last year's Davos forum, some 2,000 anti-free trade demonstrators, denouncing the gathering as a "meeting of murderers", broke shop windows and smashed car windscreens at a McDonald's restaurant. Local merchants and residents in the resort grumbled about this year's tight security, which featured reinforcements from the Swiss army specialists who guard sensitive facilities. The local canton's police chief called the operation the strictest clampdown Switzerland has seen in decades. Swiss police have urged even peaceful protesters to stay away from Davos for fear they could fuel violence.

But protesters are using the Internet to give the latest information on roadblocks set up by police and participants turned back from the event, while encouraging fellow activists not to get discouraged.

"Although some buses and cars are indeed being turned away at the border check points, and also near Davos, some of these people are still managing to find their way into Switzerland via alternate routes," the protesters said.

"Everyone is needed on all fronts and actions are being planned all throughout Switzerland, as well as at the borders," they added.

Eager to dispel critics' view of Davos as a capitalist conspiracy to set the world agenda, organisers say they have given trade unions, lobby groups, environmentalists and other critics of the system unprecedented exposure this year.

Dozens of heads of state and hundreds of senior corporate executives are among 3,200 participants at the summit, and the issues up for discussion include the impact of a projected slowdown in the U.S economy, new ways for companies to do business and the changing face of the Internet.

Participants include Japan's prime minister Yoshiro Mori, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, Mexican president Vicente Fox, Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica and Venezuela's president Hugo Chavez. Israeli elder statesman Shimon Peres and UN secretary general Kofi Annan are also scheduled to attend, raising the possibility of some Middle East dialogue in Davos.

But no officials from the new administration of US president George Bush are expected, according to organisers.

The WEF says demonstrators are targeting the wrong enemy, and emphasise its efforts to help link developing countries to the global knowledge-based economy, fight killer diseases in the Third World and promote peace and economic development. Some 10,000 people are expected at the World Social Forum in Porto Alegre, Brazil, that will run in parallel to the Davos meeting and condemn neo-liberal economic policies. Related articles

webTitle: Why Glasgow is the Rab C Nesbitt of Scottish politics

fields.headline: Why Glasgow is the Rab C Nesbitt of Scottish politics
fields.standfirst: Glasgow city council's decision to pull out of Scotland's local government umbrella group is a lose-lose situation, says Mark Irvine
fields.trailText: Comment: Glasgow city council's decision to pull out of Scotland's local government umbrella group is a lose-lose situation, says Mark Irvine
fields.body:
The Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) is the voice of Scottish local government. Despite many difficult times, it always managed to hold together down the years: when Tories actually controlled councils, during two decades of Margaret Thatcher and John Major, the poll tax, the threat of water privatisation and a gerrymandered reorganisation in 1996.

Having reached the "promised land" with Labour in power at Holyrood and Westminster, Cosla hits the buffers. Glasgow's civic leader, councillor Charlie Gordon, is pulling out. His council will spend its £300,000 annual affiliation fee on children with special needs. Cosla and its bureaucracy in Edinburgh have been declared redundant. The Scottish executive got both barrels as well for serving Glasgow city council with too small a slice of the council spending cake.

If only things were so easy. The truth is Glasgow is fast becoming the Rab C Nesbitt of Scottish local government, telling the rest of the world where to get off, magnificently defiant, but alone and without friends. Mr Angry has failed to win any admirers - no other leader followed, Labour colleagues stayed firmly in their seats.

The sudden concern about children with special needs is a conversion of biblical proportions. Glasgow provides free car parking to many senior employees, a practice tackled long ago by other councils. Charges would raise £400,000 exceeding the savings from pulling out of Cosla. But that would give the game away because children with special needs are not the point. Why weren't they special last year or the year before? Why is free car parking a higher priority?

The real target of the council leader's wrath is the Scottish executive. The winds of change are blowing through local government, but some can see the future and don't like it one little bit. A modern agenda for Scottish councils would mean proportional representation, a service-led culture and elected councillors operating to the highest possible standards. A rearguard action against Labour party policy is the subtext to the affair. Intriguingly, the fight is taking place outside party structures where policy differences would normally be resolved.

Glasgow's Labour group is the last redoubt of those who believe that effective one-party representation is the best model for local democracy in the new Scotland. Witness the composition of the present council - 74 Labour, 2 SNP, 1 Lib Dem, 1 Tory and 1 Scottish socialist party.

The special case for Glasgow is the legacy from local government reorganistion which left the city with too many services and too few council taxpayers. People living outside the city use its services, but make no contribution to their upkeep. In three years Glasgow's council tax rose by an incredible 59%. Major cuts in services were needed to balance the budget, along with 4,000 redundancies.

But the council is not leading the debate or trying to influence the wider agenda, quite the opposite. Glasgow sets its face against the very things that would breathe new life into Scottish local government. Modern politics is about negotiation and compromise, not empty chairs.

The unions have been strangely silent up till now. Glasgow's decision represents a breach of contract for thousands of employees whose pay and conditions are negotiated through Cosla. Consultation on the issue is a sham since it is taking place after angry public statements have been made. Under other circumstances the unions would not hesitate to challenge this kind of arbitrary behaviour from an employer, by legal action if necessary.

Throwing tantrums won't win allies, nor will it impress government ministers. This is a lose-lose situation for everyone, but most of all for the city, its people, services and staff.

fields.headline: Express columnist quits
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Daily Express columnist Topaz Amoore has been poached by Sunday Business to launch edit its new colour supplement, writes Jason Deans.

Tearful Rosie says goodbye
Boycott quits Express
How Rosie said goodbye
Plaudits for 'Renaissance Rosie'
Recent Express stories
fields.body:
Daily Express columnist Topaz Amoore has quit.

She has been poached by new Sunday Business editor Nils Pratley to be launch editor for the paper's glossy colour supplement.

Ms Amoore resigned yesterday and is negotiating her leaving date from the Express, but is expected to begin work at Sunday Business early next month.

She said the new Sunday Business magazine, which is being lined up for a March launch, would be "aspirational, elegant and upmarket".

"There will be lots of meaty business reads, but also fashion, travel and all the other elements you get in a glossy consumer magazine," she said.

The new Sunday Business supplement will be aimed at a similar readership to the Financial Times' How To Spend It magazine.

"How To Spend It is only monthly," Ms Amoore said. "Currently there isn't a single title that offers a mix of great business stories and looks beautiful and elegant that's published every weekend."

Ms Amoore has been with Express Newspapers for nearly five years. She first joined as a football writer on the Sunday Express, before moving to the Daily Express as a features columnist three years ago.

Prior to that, Ms Amoore worked as a business reporter on the Sunday Telegraph and on the Independent's news desk.

Ms Amoore will be continuing with her broadcasting work, which includes regular slots on Sky News and BBC Radio 5 Live.

fields.headline: IPC praises BBC promotions pledge
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: IPC has welcomed the BBC's pledge to toughen up its guidelines on cross-promotion of magazines, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 24: BBC tightens up cross promotion guidelines
fields.body:
The managing director of IPC's television titles, Caroline Ward, has praised the BBC for its pledge to toughen up its guidelines on cross-promotion of magazines on television.

But Ms Ward said she could not rule out taking the BBC's commercial arm, BBC Worldwide, to the Office of Fair Trading for anti-competitive behaviour.

"We're delighted that we are able to make some progress on the issue," she said.

But Ms Ward added: "There is still some way to go - we want an end to all free trails for magazines, or greater clarity on how the money is spent."

Last year several commercial magazine publishers, including IPC and the National Magazine Company, announced that they were considering referring BBC Worldwide to the Office of Fair Trading.

The BBC yesterday ruled that in future, all requests for television trails for BBC consumer magazines Eve and Star, would have to be approved by the BBC controller of fair trading.

Previously, decisions as to whether to trail magazines were taken by editorial staff, according to whether, in their view, the trails "complement the programme and extend access to the subject matter".

Commercial magazine publishers have argued that the BBC's commercial magazines have enjoyed unfair access to free promotion through the BBC's licence-fee financed broadcasts.

The launch last year of two highly commercial consumer magazines, Eve and Star, raised the stakes for commercial publishers.

The BBC denies that the trails breach commercial policy guidelines. But the move will be seen as an admission, for the first time, that access to free airtime does give them a promotional advantage.

fields.headline: Williams takes helm at Express
fields.trailText:
3.15pm update: Express associate editor Chris Williams has been confirmed as acting editor following the departure of Rosie Boycott, writes Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll.
Jan 25: Desmond looks within for successor
Jan 25: Tearful Rosie says goodbye
Jan 25: The Rosie years
Jan 25: Express columnist quits
Jan 25: Boycott quits Express
Jan 25: Rosie's goodbye email
fields.body:
Express associate editor Chris Williams has been confirmed as the paper's new acting editor, following the departure today of Rosie Boycott and deputy Chris Blackhurst.

But sources say Mr Williams will have an interim tenure until new owner Richard Desmond can appoint a long-term successor.

It is thought that Northern & Shell have left itself between two and three months to appoint a successor.

Among the long list of candidates for the role in the long term, Star editor Peter Hill seems to be current favourite.

Another possible internal candidate is thought to be showbusiness editor Robert Jobson, who is believed to have made it clear to Richard Desmond that he is interested in the role.

External candidates are thought to include former Mail on Sunday editor Jonathan Holborow and the News of the World's deputy editor Andy Coulson.

Mr Williams, the number three at the paper, was today lunching with editorial director Paul Ashford, who was thought to be priming Mr Williams for the job of steadying the Express after the seismic shocks over the past weeks.

He was spotted in the canteen with editorial director Paul Ashford and managing editor Lindsay Cook

Although many Express journalists were sympathetic to Ms Boycott, one said he was "relieved" that the soap opera was over and that journalists were looking forward to "getting on with their jobs".

Another said: "Things are surreally normal here. This has been going on for so long, it is an anti-climax. It was fairly emotional when Rosie left, but now people have to get on with it and think about their futures.

"There is also a sense that the redundancies will now start happening."

Insiders at the paper still believe Star editor Peter Hill will ultimately be made editor.

As one source said Mr Desmond needs someone he can trust implicitly.

"He's not going to have anyone writing 'Fuck You Desmond' in the paper anymore," the insider said.

fields.headline: Chelsea strikes £24m Emirates deal
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Chelsea FC has linked up with Emirates Airlines in the second biggest football branding deal in history, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Chelsea Football Club has clinched a £24m sponsorship tie-up with Emirates Airlines.

The deal is the second biggest UK football branding deal in history.

Emirates will splash its logo across Chelsea players' shirts for the next four seasons.

The airline replaces the team's current sponsor, Autoglass, whose contract expires in the summer.

The Dubai-based company will also pay the London club bonuses according to the team's success on the pitch.

In addition, Chelsea training staff will coach youngsters in the middle east, where the game is developing fast.

The deal may eventually involve an Emirates-branded Chelsea team tour to the region during the close season.

The huge sponsorship dwarfs that of rivals Arsenal (Sega) and Leeds (Strongbow) and is not far behind Manchester United's £30m tie-up with Vodafone last year.

Chelsea chairman Ken Bates said: "We are now an international team and an international club so we wanted a more high-profile international partner."

The Autoglass deal was worth only £1.2m a year to the Blues.

Earlier this week, Mr Bates announced a £50m kit supply deal with Umbro.

The latest moves, combined with Sky's £40m stake last year, will make Chelsea one of Europe's richest clubs.

webTitle: World dispatch: What's in a name? Too much in Turkey

fields.headline: What's in a name? Too much in Turkey
fields.standfirst:
The ban on certain street names in the town of Batman has far-reaching implications for Turkey and its place in Europe, writes foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall

Special report: the Kurds
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: World dispatch: The ban on certain street names in the town of Batman has far-reaching implications for Turkey and its place in Europe, writes foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
A plan by Abdullah Akin, the mayor of Batman in south-east Turkey, to change some of his town's street names seemed pretty unremarkable at first glance.

But Mr Akin's choices, which included imaginative constructions like Mahatma Gandhi Street, Democracy Avenue and Human Rights Boulevard, proved too much for the Turkish government.

The Ankara-appointed provincial governor objected, and last week a court ruled that since Gandhi's name was associated with passive resistance to a colonial power and glorified revolt, it could not be used. The same went for 14 of Mr Akin's other seemingly innocent choices.

The court added, for good measure, that streets in Batman must not be given Kurdish names. And therein lies the explanation for the Kurdish mayor's difficulties - and one of several reasons why Turkey's bid to join the European Union, due to be set out in detail by the Ankara government this month, faces some very big obstacles.

So insecure is the Turkish government about its grip on the predominantly Kurdish areas of the south-east, where most of the country's estimated 12m Kurds live, that it continues to stamp down hard on any manifestation of a separate Kurdish identity. Officially, the Kurds are not recognised as Kurds at all, but as Turkish citizens.

Despite a change of tone under the government of Bulent Ecevit, restrictions on broadcasting and teaching in the Kurdish language remain in force. More broadly, attempts to assert Kurdish "cultural rights" or pursue political self-determination bring a routinely harsh response.

At the heart of Ankara's insecurity is the separatist movement spearheaded by the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK). The war with the PKK has cost an estimated 30,000 lives since 1984.

The PKK declared a unilateral ceasefire after the capture of its leader, Abdullah Ocalan, in 1999, and renounced its previous demands for a separate Kurdish state in favour of enhanced cultural freedoms.

But the government has not taken the PKK at its word and the Turkish army continues to mount counter-insurgency operations that not infrequently take its troops into Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq.

Prosecutions of suspected PKK sympathisers have not ceased either, whoever they may be. Earlier this week, the Turkish authorities in Diyarbakir, near Batman, said they would charge 13 juveniles, including one nine-year-old, with "aiding and abetting" the PKK.

The youths' "crime" was allegedly to shout pro-PKK slogans. Their families say they have been tortured while in detention. If found guilty, they face up to seven years in jail.

The infringement of freedoms and rights considered sacrosanct by EU countries and international bodies is not confined to Turkey's Kurds.

The Turkish government is also at war with militant groups such as the Revolutionary People's Liberation Front and the Islamist faction, Hizbullah.

The leftwing RPLF were responsible for a suicide bomb attack that killed a policeman earlier this month. The group said it had acted in revenge for the violent storming by the Turkish army in December of 20 prisons where inmates were on hunger strike. At least 30 prisoners died.

Hizbullah, which shares the aims of the Iranian-backed group of the same name, is equally reviled by the government (and by many Kurds). It advocates the creation of an Islamic state in predominantly Muslim, but traditionally secular Turkey. Hizbullah is suspected of being behind the latest upsurge in violence - the ambush and killing of Diyarbakir's police chief and five policemen on Wednesday.

The crackdown on Islamists has in effect been going on since February 1997, when the army conspired to oust the government led by Necmettin Erbakan of the Islamist Welfare party. Welfare has been a banned organisation since 1998 and legal moves are afoot to ban Virtue, another Islamist party.

"The process (launched in 1997) will continue for 1,000 years if need be," the chief of Turkey's general staff, Huseyin Kivrikoglu, said recently. The military, backed by rightwing elements within the governing coalition, is meanwhile pushing for a purge from government service of suspected Islamist sympathisers.

Even in Turkish society at large, the penal code restricts freedoms of speech and publication taken for granted elsewhere. Prosecutions of journalists, academics and others who breach these regulations are commonplace.

This week, a demonstration was mounted in Ankara in support of the Anatolia news agency after it was accused by the government of being too informative in its reporting of a high-level government corruption case.

Batman was also in the news after a radio station that played a Kurdish song, entitled I Am Wounded, was ordered off the air for 90 days.

The suppression of Kurdish rights, the sometimes violent crackdowns and repression levelled at the left and right, the interference of the military in politics, the disregard for political pluralism, the restrictions on free speech, and a pattern of disrespect, bordering on contempt, for basic human rights are all issues that are certain to bedevil, and possibly scupper, Mr Ecevit's hopes of getting Turkey into the EU.

Add to that this week's furious row with France over its condemnation of the 1915 Armenian massacres as "genocide", Turkey's disputes with Greece and Cyprus and its fragile economic situation, and Turkey's EU accession begins to look like an ever more distant prospect.

webTitle: New boy landing on Northern Ireland's thin ice

fields.headline: New boy landing on Northern Ireland's thin ice
fields.standfirst: Secretary of state John Reid has been plunged in at a delicate stage for Ulster, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Secretary of state John Reid has been plunged in at a delicate stage for Ulster, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's resignation could not have come at a more sensitive time for Northern Ireland. He was playing a central part in intensive negotiations to revive the dangerously beleaguered peace process.

London and Dublin have given themselves just 10 more days to untangle the knots of disagreement which still entangle the pro-peace factions. And while they wrangle, the anti-peace elements - including extreme paramilitary groups - are doing their grisly best to derail the whole process.

There is nothing artificial in the latest deadline for peace. The Good Friday agreement, while still alive and breathing, is in intensive care. The power-sharing executive is paralysed, the cross-border institutions have not started to function, and there has been no progress on the vital twin issues of IRA disarmament and British army withdrawal. The peace process, in short, is frozen, and now a new key player is stepping on to the fragile ice.

John Reid, the new secretary of state, is well respected in parliament and in Edinburgh, where he has won many friends as a staunchly pro-devolution Scottish secretary. That reputation will travel with him to Belfast, where all parties are united in their distrust of Westminster. Reid also has the asset of personal warmth, being something of a wit and bon viveur.

His Scottishness could be a questionable advantage. Scotland has close historical, cultural and political links with Northern Ireland - and a regrettably similar religious divide. Reid was born Catholic, and is a keen Celtic supporter. These things should not matter, but they do. Northern Ireland has never quite grasped the notion of political correctness.

The British and Irish governments are wearing a brave smile this morning, as they play down the impact of Mandelson's abrupt departure, and Reid's consequent plunge into the deep end. They are stressing the continuing commitment of both governments to breaking the impasse in Belfast. In London, Tony Blair is fully involved in the talks, with an important secondary role being undertaken by his influential chief of staff, Jonathan Powell. In Dublin, the Taoiseach Bertie Ahern and his foreign minister Brian Cowen are also engaged virtually full time on the peace process.

The problem, as ever, is in Belfast, where unionists and republicans are still in eyeball-to-eyeball confrontation. Neither side shows any side of blinking over the key issues.

The Unionist Party led by first minister David Trimble is adamant that there must be tangible moves towards IRA disarmament before they will loosen their effective veto on cross-border cooperation. Sinn Fein is equally insistent on radical police reform and 'demilitarisation' as preconditions of disarmament.

There is an undeniable sense of urgency, as both sovereign governments chip away at the deadlock. But other, more malign elements are also at work. There has been a spate of sectarian pipe-bomb attacks on Catholic homes by extreme loyalist factions. Only last night two men were shot and wounded in paramilitary-style punishments. Dissident republican groups are also stepping up their activities, with a series of bomb and mortar attacks on security forces.

There is also looming hiatus of the British general election, in which Northern Ireland candidates will be tempted to retrench their 'no surrender' positions.

All in all, it's the worst possible time for a new secretary of state to be taking over at Stormont Castle.

fields.headline: BBC in domain name buying frenzy
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC has registered 3,000 domain names at a cost to the corporation of more than £1/2m, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC has registered 3,000 domain names - a landmark figure that according to experts must have cost the corporation more than half a million pounds.

Last year the BBC was forced to shell out £200,000 to buy BBC.com from Boston Business Computing and then went to court and won over a cybersquatter using BBCNews.com.

It has also recently secured BBC.tv, a new domain suffix that costs at least £3,000 a year for the privilege of having a TV-related domain.

With international expansion of websites high on the BBC agenda, the corporation is now actively pursuing a policy of securing BBC-related domain names.

Most names are registered with .co.uk or .com suffixes in all countries where the BBC has trademarks, and many more have been registered for shows such as Top of the Pops and Top Gear.

Staff are being encouraged to put forward ideas for new domain names for new products, services or programmes that haven't yet been registered.

"We do not consider it necessary to register every permutation of misspelling of the BBC name in all domain name registries, but we strongly recommend the registration of the names of new products, services or programmes as domain names," said Saul Venit, a lawyer in the BBC's corporate legal and intellectual property department.

Mr Venit was quoted in the BBC's weekly internal magazine Ariel.

fields.headline: Tearful Rosie says goodbye
fields.trailText:
12.15pm update: Rosie Boycott farewell to staff just after 11am today, ending her three-year reign as editor of the Express. By Lisa O'Carroll.
Boycott quits Express
How Rosie said goodbye
Plaudits for 'Renaissance Rosie'
Jan 25: The Rosie years
Jan 25: Express columnist quits
Jan 25: Boycott quits Express
Jan 25: Rosie's goodbye email
fields.body:
Rosie Boycott bade a tearful farewell to her staff just after 11am today, ending a three-year reign as editor of the Express.

The deal was clinched yesterday but she and her deputy Chris Blackhurst, who is also leaving, decided to wait until today to break the news to staff.

The first sign of her departure was a large leaving card that was rushed around the newsroom at 10.30am.

Shortly afterwards an email from her and Mr Blackhurst was sent to all staff alerting them to their plans to leave the building.

Minutes later Ms Boycott emerged, tearful, from her office and walked through the newsroom to the sound of applause and the thumping of tables, the traditional newspaper farewell.

Paul Ashford, editorial director at the Express, said: "Rosie and Chris both leave their considerable mark on the Daily Express and we wish them well for the future."

In a prepared statement, Ms Boycott said: "I would like to wish the newspaper, its staff and the new proprietor well in their endeavours to build on the great name and tradition of the Daily Express."

webTitle: Tumour girl's GP told to re-train

fields.headline: Tumour girl's GP told to re-train
fields.trailText: A GP who failed to examine a nine-year-old girl who subsequently died from a huge tumour in her abdomen was yesterday allowed to continue in practice despite being found guilty of gross professional misconduct.
fields.body:
A GP who failed to examine a nine-year-old girl who subsequently died from a huge tumour in her abdomen was yesterday allowed to continue in practice despite being found guilty of gross professional misconduct.

Krishna Mohan Singh agreed to have further training over the next year, after being told by the General Medical Council that the care he afforded the child fell "seriously short" of standards expected.

Dr Singh, from Slough, Berkshire, first saw the girl at his west London practice in December 1998; he did not examine her, arrange tests, or consider a referral. He prescribed dehydration salts to counter side effects from laxatives prescribed by his partner six days before, when the girl had complained of a swollen stomach and constipation.

The child's mother brought her to see Dr Singh after she began passing blood. She alleged the doctor had told her not to be "a paranoid mother".

On another visit, on January 13, 1999, the child became violently ill and was taken to hospital, where she slipped into a coma and died. Surgeons found she had a tumour 25cms in diameter that had displaced her kidneys.

Kenneth Hobbs, chairing the hearing, said that Dr Singh had not made an adequate assessment of the girl's needs.

"Good medical practice requires that successful relationships between doctors and patients depend on trust. One aspect of this trust is for doctors to listen to patients and respect their views."

Dr Singh must have his educational and development needs assessed with particular reference to communication skills, history-taking, examinations and record keeping. He would have to demonstrate that he had made satisfactory progress by the end of a year.

Dr Singh, in a statement released by the Medical Defence Union, accepted the findings and extended his "sincere condolences" to the child's family. "I will readily comply with the conditions attached to my registration." The girl's mother refused to comment.

webTitle: Cash for councils is general election ploy, say Tories

fields.headline: Cash for councils is general election ploy, say Tories
fields.trailText: The government has been accused of unveiling a last-minute £100m boost for local authorities to dampen down council tax increases in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
The government has been accused of unveiling a last-minute £100m boost for local authorities in a bid to dampen down council tax increases in the run-up to the general election.

Ministers yesterday unveiled the increase as part of their neighbourhood renewal fund, aimed at 88 English councils covering the country's most deprived areas.

The cash will double the amount available in the fund's first year, and is designed to help authorities "make a good start" on improving their services and turning round run-down neighbourhoods.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott said: "This means that the action plan for neighbourhood renewal will get off to a strong start next financial year with even more positive action taking place at a local level."

The Conservatives, however, claimed the government was in a state of panic about council tax increases, which are likely to hit the nation's doormats in the run-up to the general election.

The party claims council taxes could rise by an average 9% this year, but the government has brushed this figure aside. It compares to increases of around the 6% mark in this financial year.

Shadow environment secretary Archie Norman said: "These rises have been compounded by the government fiddling the way local funding is allocated, failing to compensate extraordinary costs like asylum seekers and flooding."

In fact, ministers are discussing whether to give extra funds to councils facing these problems - predominantly those in London, which bear the brunt of the refugee bill, and Yorkshire, where a proposed 63% increase in the annual flood levy threatens to add £7 to local council tax bills.

A spokesman for local government minister Hilary Armstrong said: "It's well known that local authorities have been arguing that they face specific pressures such as floods and asylum seekers. The issue is what's the scale of it, and how do you meet that demand?"

The extra £100m was described by one Labour source as a "tidying-up" announcement, aimed at letting councils know their full funding package before ministers confirm the final local government finance settlement next week.

Howard Knight, head of Labour's local government unit, said the Tories regularly tried to cause council tax scares: "They've always been substantially wrong and I expect them to be wrong this time."

A Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions spokesman added that ministers were not concerned about council tax, and expected increases to continue on a downward trend.
