webTitle: Hitchcock veteran finally makes his West End debut

fields.headline: Hitchcock veteran finally makes his West End debut
fields.trailText: The latest American film star heading for a West End stage debut has left it rather late: Farley Granger, best known for Alfred Hitchcock's 1948 and 1951 classics, Rope, and Strangers on a Train, is coming to London next month at the age of 72.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The latest American film star heading for a West End stage debut has left it rather late: Farley Granger, best known for Alfred Hitchcock's 1948 and 1951 classics, Rope, and Strangers on a Train, is coming to London next month at the age of 72.

He will appear in Semi-Monde, a Noel Coward play written in 1926, but regarded as so shocking that it has never been staged in England. The play was banned by the lord chamberlain in 1926, but was never staged even after theatre censorship was lifted in 1968 partly because of the vast cast. Coward wrote it for 37 actors, but producer Thelma Holt has ruthlessly pruned it and got it down to a cast of 28.

Star gazers will have to look hard at the programme to spot Mr Farley's name. The cast is listed in alphabetical order, so Mr Granger, whose film career began in The North Star in 1943, when he was 17, appears half way down the list in a cast which includes John Carlisle, Nicola McAuliffe, Sophie Ward and Frances Tomelty.

Mr Granger was originally talent spotted by Sam Goldwyn, in a tiny part in a stage play - he said his role consisted of running on, shouting "fire!", then racing off to come back as another one word character.

He eventually bought himself out of his Goldwyn contract to study acting and appear on the New York stage in the 1950s. Since then he has appeared in dozens of films, television dramas and hundreds of stage plays.

He is an old friend of producer Thelma Holt, and they have been discussing a London venture for years. He will play a White Russian emigre in the Coward play, which is set in the febrile world of society London between the wars, in the cocktail bar of the Ritz Hotel through which a carnival procession of the smart set passes. He will also be, Ms Holt said: "One of the few straight men in the whole thing."

"The problem with Semi-Monde was sex," she said. "The play is riddled with it. There was never any chance of it getting past the lord chamberlain. The sexual preferences of the cast are made absolutely clear: there are gay men, and lesbian women, and worst of all, adulterers."

The show opens at the Lyric Theatre on Shaftesbury Avenue on May 21, for a 16-week run. It was never staged in Coward's lifetime. The Glasgow Citizens' Theatre staged the world premiere of Semi-Monde in 1977, four years after Coward's death.

There has also been one small American production: Ms Holt cherishes a review which appeared under the headline "Two queens and a dyke".

"They got that completely wrong," she said gleefully last night. "There's far more than one dyke in it."

webTitle: Weaving a Web of linguistic diversity

fields.headline: Weaving a Web of linguistic diversity
fields.standfirst: David Crystal explains how the internet is turning out to be a friend to all the world's languages
fields.trailText: The World Wide Web is an eclectic medium, holding a mirror up to our linguistic nature. Not only does it offer a home to all linguistic styles within a language; it offers a home to all languages - once their communities have a functioning computer technology. And its increasingly multilingual character has been the most notable change since it started out as a totally English medium.
fields.body:
The World Wide Web is an eclectic medium, holding a mirror up to our linguistic nature. Not only does it offer a home to all linguistic styles within a language; it offers a home to all languages - once their communities have a functioning computer technology. And its increasingly multilingual character has been the most notable change since it started out as a totally English medium.

For many people the language of the internet is English. "World, Wide, Web: three English words" was the headline of a piece by Michael Specter in the New York Times a few years ago. The article went on to comment: "If you want to take full advantage of the internet there is only one real way to do it: learn English." Specter did acknowledge the arrival of other languages: "As the Web grows, the number of people on it who speak French, say, or Russian will become more varied and that variety will be expressed on the Web. That is why it is a fundamentally democratic technology. But it won't necessarily happen soon."

The evidence is growing that this conclusion was wrong. With the internet's globalisation the presence of other languages has steadily risen. By the mid-90s a widely quoted figure was that about 80% of the Net was in English - a figure supported by the first big study of language distribution on the internet, carried out in 1997 by Babel, a joint initiative of the Internet Society and Alis Technologies. This showed English well ahead, but with several other languages - notably German, Japanese, French and Spanish - entering the ring.

Since then the estimates for English have been falling, with some commentators predicting that before long the Web (and the internet as a whole) will be predominantly non-English, as communications infrastructure develops in Europe, Asia, Africa and South America. A Global Reach survey has estimated that people with internet access in non-English-speaking countries increased from 7m to 136m between 1995 and 2000. In 1998 the total number of new non-English websites passed the number of new English websites.

At a conference on search engine strategies last April, Alta Vista was predicting that by next year less than half of the Web would be in English. English-language author David Graddol has predicted an even lower figure in due course, 40%. In parts of the world the local language is already dominant. According to the Japanese internet author Yoshi Mikami, 90% of Web pages in Japan are now in Japanese.

The Web is increasingly reflecting the distribution of language presence in the real world, and many sites provide the evidence. They range from individual businesses doing their best to present a multilingual identity to big sites collecting data on many languages. Under the first heading we encounter such newspapers as the Belgian daily Le Soir, which is represented by six languages - French, Dutch, English, German, Italian and Spanish. Under the latter heading we find such sites as the University of Oregon Font Archive, providing 112 fonts in its archives for more than 40 languages.

A World Language Resources site lists products for 728 languages. An African resource list covers several local languages; Yoruba, for example, is illustrated by some 5,000 words, along with proverbs, naming patterns and greetings. Another site deals with 87 European minority languages. Some sites are small in content, but extensive in range: one gives the Lord's Prayer in nearly 500 languages. Nobody has yet worked out just how many languages have obtained a modicum of presence on the Web. I have found more than 1,000. It is not difficult to find evidence of a Net presence for the vast majority of the more frequently used languages, and for a large number of minority languages too. I would guess that about a quarter of the world's languages have some sort of internet presence.

In all these examples we are encountering language presence in a real sense. These are not sites that only analyse or talk about languages; they allow us to see languages as they are. In many cases, the total Web presence, in terms of number of pages, is small. The crucial point is that the languages are out there, even if represented by only a sprinkling of sites. It is the ideal medium for minority languages, given the relative cheapness and ease of creating a Web page, compared with the costs of print, TV or radio.

However, developing a significant cyber-presence is not easy. Until a critical mass of internet penetration in a country builds up, and a corresponding mass of content exists in the local language, the motivation to switch from English-language sites will be limited to those for whom issues of identity outweigh issues of information. The future is also dependent on the levels of English-speaking ability in individual countries, and the further growth in those levels. There are also practical problems, though a great deal has been done since the mid-90s to address them. First, the Ascii character set still fails to adequately support the array of letter shapes in Arabic, Hindi, Chinese, Korean and the many other languages in the world that do not use the Latin alphabet. The Unicode coding system, the alternative to Ascii, allows more than 65,000 characters; but the implementation of this system is still in its infancy. The Web consortium has an internationalisation activity looking specifically at different alphabets, so that operating systems can support a page in any alphabet.

The future looks good for Web multilingualism. As Ned Thomas commented last year in an editorial for Contact, the bulletin of the European Bureau of Lesser Used Languages: "It is not the case . . . that all languages will be marginalised on the Net by English. On the contrary, there will be a great demand for multilingual websites, for multilingual data retrieval, for machine translation, for voice recognition systems to be multilingual."

And Tyler Chambers, the creator of various Web language projects, agrees: "The future of the internet is even more multilingualism and cross-cultural exploration and understanding than we've already seen." I agree. The Web offers a World Wide Welcome for global linguistic diversity.

David Crystal is honorary professor of linguistics at the University of Wales, Bangor. His book Language And The Internet will be published by Cambridge University Press later this year

fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Express boss Richard Desmond is seeking an acting editor from within to maintain editorial continuity, writes Lisa O'Carroll.

Jan 25: Rosie's goodbye email

Recent Express stories
fields.body:
Richard Desmond is looking for an acting editor from within because he wants to maintain editorial continuity at the Express.

Sources say he doesn't want to rock the boat until the department of trade and industry has finished investigating his takeover of the Express newspapers.

Chris Williams, number three on the paper, is the favourite to step into Ms Boycott's shoes.

He met Richard Desmond for a lengthy meeting today.

Mr Williams, 50, is a long-serving Express staff man and former features editor of the paper.

He was also one of the 25 staff handed a £40,000 cheque by Lord Hollick when he sold the paper to Mr Desmond.

Sources say the acting editor was expected to be in the chair for just two or three months.

Some believe Mr Williams might be willing to accept the new regime, which will have lower editorial budgets.

The new editor is not expected to have the same degree of control over the paper as Ms Boycott, who benefited from Lord Hollick's lack of interest in newspapers.

He or she will have to accommodate Mr Desmond's senior staff who will want to promote his interests, especially OK! magazine celebrities.

The new editor may also have to implement more than 100 redundancies.

Star editor Peter Hill and royal and showbusiness editor Robert Jobson have also been tipped for the job.

webTitle: No love lost as Peter leaves the odd country

fields.headline: No love lost as Peter leaves the odd country
fields.standfirst:
As with most of his predecessors, the secretary of state's departure will cause few tears among Northern Ireland's political class, writes John O'Farrell
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Comment: As with most of his predecessors, the Secretary of State's departure will cause few tears among Northern Ireland's political class, writes John O'Farrell in Belfast
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's demise has caused few tears to flow among the political class in Northern Ireland. Then again, not one departing secretary of state, from Willie Whitelaw to Mo Mowlam, has ever left with paeans of praise ringing in their ears.

Unionists tend to view the occupants of Hillsborough Castle as impatient gravediggers for the Union. Nationalists and republicans dislike whoever represents Her Majesty's Government in the six counties because that is their role in the game. As Gerry Adams said to Mandelson after the suspension of the Northern Ireland Executive last febuary, "we're going to dump all over you, but don't worry. It's nothing personal."

That said, Mandelson probably won't miss the plain speaking folk of Ulster either, despite his earnest wish to continue "to play a part in the peace process."

At one of the last shindigs he threw at Hillsborough Castle, one of his three official residences as secretary of state, he was asked what he thought about Northern Ireland. He stroked his chin and stared into the middle distance for a moment, before opining "odd, very odd." Then he exited in pursuit of a journalist whose copy was, he made clear, in urgent need of a rapid rebuttal.

Another drawback for the glamour-loving ex-SoS is the lack of cosmopolitan glitter among the dreary steeples of Fermanagh and Tyrone, despite the existence of a very prosperous minority who live along the 'Gold Coast' of North Down and the Hampstead-like suburbs of south Belfast.

He did, however, find some entertainment among a small media-celebrity clique which surround the ebullient personality of Sean Rafferty, the BBC Radio 3 presenter. Mandelson and his companion, Mr de Silva, were occasional guests at Rafferty's immodestly described 'cottage' in Donegal, across the border and away from the prim and prying eyes of the Free Presbyterians of Belfast.

Despite the public priggishness of many unionist politicians, Mandelson's sexuality was always a muted issue. The only time homophobic remarks were hurled in his direction was when he accompanied David Trimble to the 'Orange Citadel' of Portadown, where both spoke in favour of the Good Friday Agreement.

The local Drumcree Orangemen were not amused. "Homo!" they screamed at Mandelson. "Traitor!" they screamed at Trimble, as both men ran to their armour-plated car through a cordon of RUC riot police. One of Trimble's aides later said that they had "never seen such a look of fear in their lives, as Peter Mandelson had that night".

Speaking in Westminster at the last Northern Ireland Question Time of the Mandelson dispensation, Trimble made a point of saying that unionists "appreciate the effort he has made" in Northern Ireland, before adding the obligatory point about the "hurt" caused by the Police Bill, reforming and renaming the RUC.

On the surface, not very warm praise from the First Minister, yet unionists are smarting. They would have greeted anybody as a potential friend after the Mo Mowlam experience, whose touchy-feely manner embarrassed and annoyed them.

"He was not Mo", said one unionist close to Trimble, when asked to list Mandy's virtues. "He marked a real change in tone. He didn't hug ex-terrorists. He was sound on the Police Bill, although we didn't get exactly what we wanted. His first stop in Ulster was to a victim's group in south Belfast. He stood up to the nationalists, the Irish government and the Americans over suspension in Febuary 2000."

Indeed, Trimble had actively lobbied Blair for Mandelson to replace Mowlam. It is unclear if they thought that he was an instinctive unionist, but older unionists fondly remember his grandfather, Herbert Morrison, who passionately defended the unionist cause during a mini-crisis in 1949 when the Irish Free State declared itself to be the Republic of Ireland.

Nationalists, in the zero-sum manner of Northern politics, will feel a warm glow. They were as offended by Mandelson's patrician manner as unionists were by Mo's feet on her office desk. Many agreed with the term "our Proconsul", coined by Brian Feeney in his Irish News column.

One said he was "more tory than Sir Patrick Mayhew". In the aftermath of the suspension of the Executive, Gerry Adams stormed out of a meeting shouting "don't patronise us!", and the Irish government's spin doctors expressed concern that the SoS spent too much of his time on the phone to London, briefing his favourite lobby correspondents.

Another constituency offended by Mandelson was the Israeli government. In late Febuary 2000, he left the tattered peace process in Ulster to see how they did things in the Middle East. According to the Israelis, Mandelson spent a couple of hours chatting with their negotiators, before disappearing for three hours to bask in the Dead Sea.

In the end, he could float in the Dead Sea, but could not walk on water.

fields.headline: Volunteering pays
fields.trailText: Young people on a pilot scheme have found that volunteering pays. Before volunteering, 42% of the 60 participants were unemployed. This figure was reduced to 7% after finishing their placement
fields.body:
Young people on a pilot scheme have found that volunteering pays. Before volunteering, 42% of the 60 participants were unemployed. This figure was reduced to 7% after finishing their placement.

The three pilot schemes in Sunderland, Southwark and Cardiff placed 16-24 year-old volunteers in schools, community centres and city farms.

An evaluation has been carried out by the national charity Community Service Volunteers (CSV) which coordinated the schemes. Its report, The road to independence, published this week, concludes that the scheme has challenged young people's perceptions of volunteering and shown that there can be substantial benefits.

One of the participants, Sian Austen, 27, was unemployed for six months before volunteering for Action Southwark. She spent two days a week volunteering in a school in Peckham, London, helping children read and learn science.

She is now the paid manager of Action Southwark, which has become part of the nationwide Millennium Volunteers scheme. Ms Austen said: "Through volunteering I became involved in the local community and met a lot of people, I think this is what helped me to get a job as although I had a degree, no one was prepared to take me on without experience."

Another volunteer, Andrew Rowell, 20, volunteered on a conservation project, working alongside children with special needs and visited Brazil for a month to work as a volunteer. He is now training to become an outdoor instructor.

These pilot schemes were the precursor to the Millennium Volunteers scheme. There are now 160 projects running in England offering 8,000 young people volunteering placements.

CSV runs 13 of these projects. Executive director of CSV, Elisabeth Hoodless said: "This report shows that volunteering is not only a real boost to any CV, but that it can provide a springboard into employment."

Copies of the report are available free from CSV by calling 020 7643 1338

fields.headline: Microsoft 'mystified' by website failure
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Microsoft has admitted it is 'mystified' by a failure on its websites, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Even the world's biggest software company is not immune to internet failure - as demonstrated by Microsoft, which has admitted it is "mystified" by a failure on its websites.

Problems with almost every major Microsoft website, including Hotmail and MSN, surfaced on Tuesday night.

Microsoft boffins are investigating why hundreds of thousands of web users were unable to access its websites for lengthy periods of time on Tuesday and early Wednesday.

The company is not ruling out a malicious hacker, although to save face it has just issued a statement attributing the problem to a "technical difficulty".

Microsoft's corporate computer network has already suffered an embarrassment last October when a hacker stole part of the code for products in development.

Judging by the number of websites reporting problems at the moment, it is currently hacking season.

So far this month, car manufacturers Ford, ChryslerJeep, Fiat and Mitsubishi had their websites defaced by hackers; government and military websites have been hacked; and even high street retailer Boots' website couldn't escape a hacking attack.

webTitle: Arts: Profile of actor Benicio del Toro

fields.headline: 'I just try to do my best'
fields.standfirst: Benicio Del Toro has come a long way since he made his movie debut as Duke the Dog-Faced Boy. This week he won a Golden Globe. Mark Salisbury met him
fields.trailText: Benicio Del Toro has come a long way since he made his movie debut as Duke the Dog-Faced Boy. This week he won a Golden Globe. Mark Salisbury met him.
fields.body:
There haven't been many stars who have managed to combine coolness with great acting. Brando. Bogart. Newman. Sinatra, arguably. Nowadays there's ... well, Philip Seymour Hoffman and William H Macy are certainly two of the finest actors working today, but they're hardly the epitome of cool.

There's George Clooney, perhaps - the Clooney of Out of Sight, Three Kings and O Brother Where Art Thou?, not of Batman & Robin. There's the Brad Pitt of Fight Club. Sean Penn and Johnny Depp in pretty much everything. And then there's Benicio Del Toro, who has just won a Golden Globe as best supporting actor in Steven Soderbergh's new movie, Traffic.

His very name seems to inspire reverence from his colleagues. For Brad Pitt, Del Toro's co-star in Guy Ritchie's gangster movie Snatch, "he is about as good as they come. You'll see that in Traffic. He is amazing."

"He's very cool," agrees Taye Diggs, who worked alongside him in Christopher McQuarrie's modern western The Way of the Gun. "I was watching him work, just stealing from him, waiting for the opportunity to play a character like that, where I can use his subtleties and what he does with his eyes and his furrowed brow. He's something else."

Indeed. While many will remember Del Toro mainly for his hilarious performance as the mumbling, mercurial Latino hood in The Usual Suspects, the Puerto Rican-born actor's star has been rising steadily, with a series of show-stealing character parts in films such as Basquiat and Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, culminating in his role as a desperately honest small-town Mexican cop in Traffic.

A lengthy, labyrinthine drama adapted from the BBC TV series Traffik, it follows the drugs trade across the US-Mexico border and its effects on both communities. Traffic also stars Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Don Cheadle and Dennis Quaid, and, typically for Soderbergh, there's not one bad performance in it. But Del Toro manages to out-act them all, mostly in Spanish.

"My character is trying to do the right thing, and little by little comes to realise everything is corrupted and he's got to dance with situations," begins Del Toro over lunch in a Beverly Hills restaurant. Dressed in a baggy Lon Chaney Jr T-shirt, dark jeans and a black-and-white cap jammed down over unruly black hair, he looks more like a truck driver than a movie star.

"He starts to get a little corrupted but fights it. He wants to do the right thing. That's what's unique. Usually the Latin guy is the bad guy. And working with Steven is quite an experience. He's the coolest director I've ever met. He allows your creativity to flourish. He encourages."

Born in Puerto Rico in 1967, Del Toro moved to Pennsylvania with his lawyer father when he was 12, after the death of his mother. "One of the reasons moving for me wasn't so traumatic was that I wanted to see the Stones' Tattoo You tour," says Del Toro, who had grown up listening to the Beatles, the Stones and the Who. Filming Snatch, he says, allowed him to catch up on the British music scene. "I rediscovered the Jam. I knew them a bit from high school but I was more of a Clash guy."

After a year studying business at the University of California, he went to drama school in New York, before training with Method master Stella Adler in Los Angeles. He made his film debut as Duke the Dog-Faced Boy in Randal Kleiser's Big Top Pee-Wee, and popped up in the Bond movie The Living Daylights as well as on TV playing various drug lords. Later films included Sean Penn's directorial debut The Indian Runner, Peter Weir's underrated Fearless, and George Huang's Hollywood satire Swimming With Sharks.

But it wasn't until Bryan Singer cast him as the unintelligible Fred Fenster in The Usual Suspects that Hollywood really noticed him. Not that Del Toro thought Singer's movie would amount to much. "When I finished my last day of shooting I was driving home and I went, 'What the fuck have I done, doing this fucking stupid character in this stupid fucking movie? It's over.' We didn't know. Honestly, I read the script one time and it didn't make any goddamn ... the names, this and that, but it worked pretty good, yeah."

The Usual Suspects won Oscars for writer Christopher McQuarrie and for Kevin Spacey as best supporting actor, and suddenly people started taking more notice of this quirky looking, quirky sounding guy. There were roles in Abel Ferrara's The Funeral and The Fan, in which he got stabbed by a psychotic Robert De Niro, before he landed his first lead as a car thief opposite Alicia Silverstone in Marco Brambilla's kidnap comedy Excess Baggage - though the less said about that the better.

Not so Terry Gilliam's Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, which saw him play Gonzo to Johnny Depp's Hunter S Thompson. That movie was a trip in more ways than one, but proved a bit too odd for most audiences. "I'm a master of movies that have life in video," he says with a laugh. "They come out, they don't work and eventually in video everyone goes, 'Oh yeah, it's good.' Like Fear and Loathing, which, little by little, has picked up a crowd."

Del Toro's next starring role is in Basic, directed by Lee Tamahori, but he wants to be more than an actor. "I've been writing a little bit," he says. "I've got a couple of things on the shelf."

Del Toro has already written and directed a short film, Submission, starring Matthew McConaughey, and eventually he wants to try his hand at a feature. If he wasn't working, he'd like to hang out on the set of Soderbergh's next movie, Ocean's Eleven, and learn from the best. "I did ask Steven if I could come. I want to learn how fast he goes. I'd like to learn about the lenses and the camera. And he's so unpretentious. I really like his attitude."

The word is that Del Toro is a shoo-in for an Oscar nomination for Traffic. "Yeah. Great. Can't wait," he says. "I've been doing films now for a while and I've been trying to do my best in every film I've done. It would be great, the recognition. It would great for options I would get if it happens. But if it doesn't, it's not going to change anything."

 Traffic is released tomorrow.

fields.headline: The 'Rosie years'
fields.standfirst: When she arrived at Ludgate house, Rosie Boycott memorably observed how the paper had had '17 editors since 1973, each one promising a new era'. The 18th editorship was certainly more memorable than that of her immediate predecessors. Dan Milmo looks back at the Rosie years.
fields.trailText: Dan Milmo looks back on the 'Rosie years' at the Express.
fields.body:
April 1998

Rosie Boycott resigns as editor of the Independent and Independent on Sunday to become editor of the Daily Express and Express on Sunday titles. She said she regretted leaving the papers, but had an "an unbeatable offer" from the Express to produce a "new kind of mid-market newspaper" and "put a torch under the middle market".

Express owner Lord Hollick gives Ms Boycott the mandate to transform the ailing rightwing rag into a leftwing "voice of the new millennium". The Tories are concerned that Ms Boycott will become a Labour patsy.

May 1998

The patsy claims gain credence after Labour is accused of blocking the appointment of Paul Routledge as Express political editor. Alastair Campbell is said to have been "horrified" by the prospect of the defiantly off-message hack taking control of the paper's political coverage. Although the appointment was set up by Ms Boycott, commentators point to the fact that Labour pollster Philip Gould co-owns his company with Lord Hollick and works from the Express building.

October 1998

"Findusgate" hits Rosie after a packet of rotting fish fingers is found hidden in her bathroom. It transpires that former Express hack James Hughes Onslow, who had been fired by Ms Boycott, had visited her house 10 days before under the pretence of being interested in buying it. Police question Mr Hughes Onslow about the incident and Boycott threatens to sue.

November 1998

Rosie comes under fire from politicians and media commentators for printing a story about Peter Mandelson's "friendship" with a Brazilian student. It is alleged that the story was obtained through underhand means.

January 1999

Amanda Platell, editor of the Express on Sunday, takes the flak for the Mandelson story and is fired along with associate editor Ian Walker, prompting Tory MPs to table a motion expressing concern at "Mandelson's revenge". Express management insist the sackings were due to poor sales. Ms Platell is now chief press officer for the Tories.

November 1999

Rosie's biggest coup was a dawn raid on her giant rival, the Daily Mail - poaching Alan Titchmarsh. A year later the Daily Mail is still smarting from Mr Middle England's departure and grudgingly gives coverage to Ground Force's makeover of Nelson Mandela's garden. But in an even more audacious move, she poached the Daily Mail's star astrologer Jonathan Cainer in a staggering £1m deal.

July 2000

The turning point for Boycott, as Lord Hollick scraps United News & Media's merger with Carlton Communications due to regulatory concerns. United sell its ITV assets to Granada for £1.75bn instead, and Lord Hollick decides to turn his back on consumer media and become a business information company. The Express newspapers are up for sale.

September-November 2000

Express staff, including Ms Boycott, are kept in the dark as a top-secret bidding battle rages over her papers and the Daily Star. The Daily Mail, Daily Telegraph, the Barclay Brothers, the Hinduja brothers and former Mirror executive David Montgomery all have a tilt at the paper, which is known to be on a less than stable financial footing. The billionaire Hindujas are installed as favourites.

November 2000

The Express group is sold to porn publisher and OK! magazine owner Richard Desmond for £125m. Almost immediately, Ms Boycott loses her political editor Anthony Bevins and senior commentators Stephen Pollard, Mary Kenny and Peter Hitchens. They are incredulous that the publisher of Asian Babes and the owner of the Fantasy Channel can be allowed to run a national newspaper. Meanwhile, Mr Desmond promises to spend "whatever it takes" to turn around the titles, which includes flogging the group's websites for £1. Ms Boycott consults her lawyers when Paul Ashford, Mr Desmond's right-hand man at the Express, scraps a Daily Express masthead and replaces it with an advert for OK! magazine.

December 5 2000
Ms Boycott lashes out at Lord Hollick's £1m-worth of farewell payouts to select Express staff members, calling it "horrible divisive" as she attempts to calm the stormy atmosphere at Ludgate House.

December 7 2000
The writing is clearly on the wall for Ms Boycott after she attacks Mr Desmond's "heavy handed" management techniques in a memo widely circulated to staff. She sends the memo to senior managers after 60 staff, including a pregnant woman, are sacked by Mr Desmond. She writes: "The journalists on the Express are - to a man and a woman - good and honourable people, who will not stand easily by and watch colleagues' lives being trashed by heavy-handed management techniques."

December 23 2000

Hopes rise for Ms Boycott as MPs urge trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers to block the sale of the Express papers on grounds of public interest. However, such a move is deemed unlikely with a general election looming.

January 4 2001

NUJ members at the Express ponder a vote of no confidence in Ms Boycott because of her inability to improve redundancy terms for staff. They also complain that her email attack on Mr Desmond was inappropriate because it singled out some individuals whom he wanted to make redundant.

January 6 2001

Leader writer Stephen Pollard's parting shot is an editorial which contains the hidden message of "fuck you Desmond." Mr Pollard is immediately fired from his new job at the Times before he even starts.

January 18 2001

As rumours of her departure reach a crescendo, a furious Ms Boycott denies that she has clinched a pay-off deal with Mr Desmond. Sources close to the situation claim she has not even had a compensation offer from Mr Desmond. Daily Star editor Peter Hill and People editor Neil Wallis are touted as replacements.

January 19 2001

Express journalists slam the "shameful betrayal" of 46 internet staff at the group, who were laid off without any compensation after Mr Desmond dumped the Express websites.

January 25 2001

Ms Boycott bows to the inevitable and quits along with deputy Chris Blackhurst. She writes in a farewell message to staff: "Dear all, We're leaving the Express in the next few minutes and we wanted to say goodbye and many thanks to all our wonderful colleagues. We're hugely proud of what we have all achieved. We know we will see many of you in the future and we wish everyone the very best of luck. Best wishes to you all, Rosie and Chris."

webTitle: Mandelson to stay on as MP

fields.headline: Mandelson to stay on as MP
fields.standfirst:
Source document
The Hartlepool Mail interview
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the former cabinet minister forced to resign over the passport-for-favours row, today said he would continue to work for his Hartlepool constituency.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the former cabinet minister forced to resign over the passport-for-favours row, today said he would continue to work for his Hartlepool constituency.

In an interview with the town's local paper, the Hartlepool Mail, the former Northern Ireland secretary said he was going to concentrate on being a good constituency MP.

His pledge will increase speculation that Mr Mandelson intends to continue a career in politics after the next election. He is currently at Hillsborough Castle, his official residence in Northern Ireland, but will return to Hartlepool at the end of the week to meet party officials.

Mr Mandelson added he was tired of being "shafted by the press", as he suggested in his resignation statement yesterday.

"I've just had enough," he told the paper. "Not the job. Just all of the other stuff that goes with it."

The Tories today seized on comments made by a Labour backbencher that Mr Mandelson would continue to play an important role in the Labour party.

Poplar and Canning Town MP Jim Fitzpatrick told the BBC that Mr Mandelson could take an "inconspicuous" role planning for the next election. Shadow cabinet office minister Andrew Lansley said: "You can take Peter Mandelson out of the government, but you can't take Mandelson out of New Labour."

"If as Mr Fitzpatrick predicts, Peter Mandelson remains inside New Labour's election machine, it will condemn the prime minister's judgment for a third time and confirm in everyone the view that you just can't trust Labour."

Tony Blair today again praised Mr Mandelson. The prime minister said he had been "absolutely instrumental" in keeping the Northern Irish peace process going.

Mr Blair said he understood why the press would devote "acres" of newsprint to Mr Mandelson's resignation, but added that the most important thing was for the government to press ahead with its policies on education, health and other issues.

Mr Mandelson was summoned to No 10 yesterday to explain his involvement with the passport application of Indian tycoon Srichand Hinduja.

In his ensuing resignation statement, Mr Mandelson said that he did not accept he had acted "improperly in any way", but wanted to distance himself from the "countless stories and controversies of feuds and divisions" that surrounded him.

fields.headline: Sunderland gets £235m Nissan boost
fields.trailText: Workers in Sunderland have been spared mass layoffs today as Japanese car giant Nissan confirmed it will build the new Micra - and create 500 new jobs - at the company's factory there.
fields.body:
Workers in Sunderland have been spared mass layoffs today as Japanese car giant Nissan confirmed it will build the new Micra - and create 500 new jobs - at the company's factory there.

Carlos Ghosn, the president of Renault-controlled Nissan, told the prime minister, Tony Blair, at 10 Downing Street that his company will invest £235m in the Sunderland plant, boosting car production from 330,000 cars a year to 500,000.

Mr Blair said the announcement was a "tremendous tribute" to the management and workers in Sunderland and added: "We are immensely proud.

"It is a great day for the north and a great day for the country. It shows that Britain is an attractive place for investors."

Although the Sunderland factory already makes more cars than any other car plant in the country, Mr Ghosn had expressed doubts about Sunderland's future.

He had warned the Labour government that if Britain did not join the euro, then a strong pound could make continued production in the UK unprofitable.

Mr Blair pledged £40m of state aid to secure the investment but said he had given no special assurance to Nissan about Britain joining the single currency.

Production of the new car will begin in December 2002 and boost the position of the Sunderland factory, which stood to lose 1,300 jobs if the work was awarded to a rival factory near Paris. The plant employs 5,000 workers and supports a further 11,000 component supplier jobs in the north-east.

Ghosn, known as the Cost Killer of Paris for his merciless cost-cutting strategies, acknowledged that the process to choose between the two sites had been lengthy. He credited the £40m in state aid and the commitment and performance of workers and management in Sunderland for swinging the decision in favour of the UK. The investment will secure work in Sunderland for up to 10 years on the new model.

Mr Hugh Morgan Williams, vice chairman of the northern Confederation of British Industry, said: "The importance of this decision cannot be over-estimated for the north-east. It establishes the Nissan plant in Sunderland as a global leader in car manufacturing."

The leader of Sunderland city council, Colin Anderson, also welcomed the news, saying: "A huge weight has been lifted off everyone's shoulders. "It enables the plant to bid for future models on a level playing field. If the contract had gone to France it would have been bad news not only for Nissan but for the UK components industry."

webTitle: Dispatch from New York: Chinatown's year of the damp squib

fields.headline: Chinatown's year of the damp squib
fields.standfirst: The authorities have taken the spark out of Chinese new year, writes Jane Martinson
fields.trailText: The authorities have taken the spark out of Chinese new year, writes Jane Martinson in New York.
fields.body:
It was late on New Year's Eve in New York's Chinatown but the loudest sound came from footsteps on the icy pavements.

Alfred Lui remembers when Chinatown's Mott and Bayard Streets would be filled with noise at the start of the Lunar New Year, when the grey roads would be ankle-deep in tiny pieces of red paper.

At the start of the year 4699 yesterday, New York's Chinese community is still struggling to overcome the limitations on their celebrations decreed by city authorities.

Four years ago, the city's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, banned firecrackers as a safety measure. Although many cities in the world have followed suit, including Hong Kong and some in China itself, Chinatown residents have found it difficult to replace the traditional way of banishing demons and bringing good luck. "Without firecrackers," says Mr Lui, the head of the Better Chinatown Association, "It just doesn't really feel like New Year."

Matters have been made even worse this year for America's largest Chinese population. The state's board of education scheduled the all-important English Regents exam - a requisite for high-school graduation - for yesterday and today.

At a time when teenagers should be enjoying lion dances and receiving red envelopes full of money, they will be trapped in an examination room for six hours.

Some young students have promised to circulate a petition of protest - after the exam. For its part, the board of education has blamed the changeable nature of the lunar year. New Year's Day can fall at any time during a two-week period.

Mr Lui, an ebullient man who founded the Chinatown association last year to try to improve conditions for the area's estimated 100,000-strong population, is unabashed by this latest assault on his traditions. This year, for the second time ever, he has helped organise an American-style parade to take place this weekend throughout the area's two-square miles.

More than 100 people are expected to join a procession of floats and marching bands. There will be traditional lion dancers for good fortune and many citizens dressed as Monkey Kings.

The only difference between this year and last will be the absence of "mock firecrackers", as the manufactured pretence cost the association $20,000 last year and "didn't make people feel the same", according to Mr Lui.

"We have tried to make it a New York tradition for Chinese New Year," he says. "Everyone can come. We have been trying to use it, not just to celebrate, but to make people realise that a lot of things can be done together."

The association has even reached out to different ethnic groups, he says, and expects to see many American parents of adopted Chinese children participating.

While public displays of revelry have been Americanised into a televised parade, other traditions have remained the same as they were in China. Restaurants served a range of special New Year dishes to celebrate the Year of the Snake this week as well as the staples of good fortune. Such superstitions seemed particularly apposite this year. The last Year of the Snake was in 1989, the year of Tiananmen Square and another Bush inauguration.

Food came round (for wholeness and prosperity) and in red, gold and green (for luck and prosperity). Dishes included the brown seaweed called far chai, which rhymes with "get rich" and looks like hair as well as lotus roots, "lin ngau", eaten because it sounds like "lin yau", which means abundance.

Ordinary meals, like tofu fried in an oblong shape, are also given special lucky names at this time of year to suggest good fortune. The tofu is called "golden bricks" because they look like gold.

The Chinese also have a traditional greeting at New Year, which is perfect for the centre of mammon that is Manhattan. "Gung hay fat choy," they say, which roughly means "wishing you lots of money".

fields.headline: Plaudits for Renaissance Rosie
fields.standfirst: A journalist through and through with a genuine interest in social affairs, Rosie Boycott is a great loss for the Express
fields.trailText: The departure of 'Renaissance Rosie' from the Express signals the end of the paper's flirtation with the left, write Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The departure from the Express of Fleet Street's Renaissance Woman is likely to mark the end of the paper's flirtation with the liberal left.

In an age when every editor should be able to wax as lyrically on the consumer habits of young men as on the Kosovo crisis, Rosie Boycott's credentials were impeccable.

Like a fusion of Polly Toynbee and Marianne Faithful, Rosie Boycott was a fully-paid up scourge of the right, but with a soft edge.

A typical member of what William Hague would call the "liberal elite", she nevertheless had the humour and humility to avoid smugness.

She has made her biggest splashes with "conscience" campaigns such as her bid while at the Independent to raise the tone of the cannabis debate.

And at the Express her staff won awards for their successful campaign to stop the deportation of Ben James, a Nigerian-born commodities broker.

The Express was also the first paper to turn on Blair's government for a 75p increase in state pensions, with an excoriating splash illustrated with a packet of peanuts.

And she was the first to throw the spotlight on the famine in Sudan in 1998.

Her year at the Independent, however, will be remembered chiefly for the notorious campaign to legalise cannabis which culminated in a march to Trafalgar Square and earned her the Guardian diary sobriquet of 'Rizla Rosie'.

Likewise, her championing of the cause of the Express staff who faced sacking under Richard Desmond won plaudits with those who feared that the business of media and social responsibility were mutually exclusive.

It is a sense that these campaigns are based on genuine motives that has allowed her to be forgiven for gaffes such as the Channel 4 fly-on-the-wall documentary Independent Rosie, and what critics on the right saw as the over-zealous trendiness of the cannabis campaign.

Since she co-founded the feminist Spare Rib magazine in 1971, Ms Boycott has continued to champion women's rights, even as editor of men's glossy Esquire (for which she won an editor of the year award).

But she would rather be recognised for her journalism and her management skills and her genuine interest in social affairs.

That said, her ability to wear her heart on her sleeve is as legendary as her frankness over her youthful battles with alcohol and drug addiction.

She famously burst into tears at a news conference upon hearing of the death of the veteran war correspondent Martha Gellhorn and cried like a grieving mother when the Express was taken over by Mr Desmond.

However, she has not been without her critics. Her harsh email to Richard Desmond over the "heavy-handed" sacking of staff led to accusations, albeit whispered, of hypocrisy at the helm - but in the present climate of fear, everyone is ultimately on Rosie's side.

She too got rid of some staff on her arrival and many asked how she could hold onto the £40,000 cheque from Lord Hollick when his selective largesse proved to be so divisive.

"She didn't get where she is today without drowning a few kittens. Every editor has to, but Rosie didn't do it with a sense of glee. She always felt bad about it," said one close colleague.

Despite Richard Desmond's protestations that he does not want to rock the boat editorially, it is clear that her liberal political leanings are not in keeping with his future vision of the Express.

Whoever inherits the editorship of the Express is likely to be safe pair of hands.

As for Rosie - friends say she will do anything she considers challenging and fun. She is not the sort to insist on an editorship.

"She would be a features editor or edit a magazine. She wouldn't find that in the least bit demeaning. She isn't grand and like most women is flexible about life," said a friend.

webTitle: A voice for victims in Scotland

fields.headline: A voice for victims in Scotland
fields.trailText: Victims of crime in Scotland are to be given a say in the criminal justice system for the first time under a new strategy unveiled by Scottish justice minister Jim Wallace. David Mitchell reports
fields.body:
Victims of crime in Scotland are to be given a say in the criminal justice system for the first time under a new strategy unveiled by Scottish justice minister Jim Wallace.

Following the publication last week of the first Scottish strategy for victims and the justice department's own action plan, a pilot victims' statement scheme is to be launched. Under the scheme, victims will be able to put down in their own words how the crime has affected them and the information will be used by the prosecution, judges and parole board when deciding on cases.

Mr Wallace said: "In the past, the position of victims has been unduly neglected. That cannot be right - their cooperation and assistance is essential in bringing criminals to justice. Indeed, because of what they have already suffered, we owe it to them to improve their experience of the criminal justice system, and to minimise the stress placed on them by that experience."

Mr Wallace thought victims often felt that the system was designed for the offender, and that no one listened to their concerns. "Victims' statements are about giving victims a voice - not about making them responsible for decisions. It is for the procurators fiscal, the judges and the parole board to take decisions in the light of all the facts, but the statement means that victims will be able to say in their own words how the crime has affected them. That will be a major change in ensuring that victims' experience is properly recognised."

Under the strategy, criminal justice agencies are being asked to develop their own action plans. The justice department action plan includes: &#149 A pilot victims' statement scheme following consultation
&#149 A model for giving information on release dates of prisoners
&#149 Extending Victim Support Scotland's witness support service to all Scottish cities by the spring
&#149 A website for victims with user-friendly information about criminal justice procedures and agencies, and sources of help and advice.

Victim Support Scotland welcomed the strategy, claiming it was a historic step forward for victims in Scotland. "This marks a major shift of policy and focus in Scotland, and it begins to put us more in line with the rest of the UK and parts of Europe. We now need to monitor it and see what it delivers in practice," said director David McKenna.

Mr McKenna said several projects were likely to pilot the victims' statement scheme. The statements themselves would most likely be written, rather than given orally, and could be prepared by a third party.

"Any pilot project should look at providing support to victims in making decisions about whether to participate or not. Not all will feel it serves a satisfactory purpose. They may decide not to because of possible harassment, further victimisation or threats. They may just want to get on with their lives and not be dragged into it," he said.

fields.headline: BBC overturns News at Ten victory
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: ITV's decision to delay its news turned into a minor ratings disaster last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV's decision to delay its News at Ten by half-an-hour on the biggest news day of the year turned into a minor ratings disaster last night.

After two successive ratings victories, Sir Trevor McDonald's bulletin was forced to take second place to the BBC.

It was toppled in the ratings by the BBC's Ten O'Clock News on a day that News at Ten actually went out at 10.30pm.

Some 5.6m viewers - a 27% share of the audience - tuned into the BBC's coverage of the dramatic resignation of Peter Mandelson, according to unofficial overnights.

ITV News at Ten drew 4.5m half-an-hour later, but could still claim an audience share victory, with 28% of viewers at that time.

However, the fact the BBC won more viewers has fuelled the corporation's public relations slogan that ITV will confuse and lose viewers with its "News at When".

The ITV news was pushed later because the broadcaster had scheduled a 90-minute edition of drama The Vice from 9pm.

As part of the deal thrashed out with the Independent Television Commission in September for the return of News at Ten, ITV only signed up to run the news at 10pm on three weekday nights between Monday and Thursday.

The Vice drew 7.2m and a 33% share.

The BBC1 Ten O'Clock News inherited a 6.5m audience and a 29% share from Crimewatch UK.

The BBC claimed official Barb figures will show the audience for last night's News at Ten will actually be nearer 4m.

A spokesman said the ITV news did not start last night until 10.34pm, so the overnight figure of 4.5m will have included some of the audience for The Vice.

But ITV conceded that "because their bulletin was first on, the BBC benefited from the extremely busy news day".

The figures also appear to support Peter Sissons's arguments that the ratings for the news are directly related to the audience levels for programme before.

The Vice on ITV was down from 8.4m last Wed to 7.2m this week.

Castaway was 4.7 on BBC1 last week and a strong Crimewatch did 6.5m on that slot last night.

fields.headline: No 2. Cardiff City
fields.standfirst: Michael Morris, editor of www.cardiffcity.com, introduces us to the apples of his eye
fields.trailText: Michael Morris, editor of www.cardiffcity.com, introduces us to the apples of his eye.
fields.body:
What makes us so special

Cardiff City is unique and our potential is massive. There's no Premiership club for over 100 miles and over a million people live within a 30-minute drive of the ground.

The high points

The club's high point is the 1927 FA Cup final. Cardiff City 1 - 0 Arsenal remains the only time the trophy has left England. Until this year, of course, when Cardiff hosts the final at the Millennium Stadium. But that's different.

That 1927 win is the major achievement, although personally I was not around to see it. My high points have been watching the club gain various promotions and play in Europe. But this season, to talk to and meet Sam Hammam, and see the changes going on at my club, will take some beating.

The low points

As with any other football club, it's relegation. There have been times over the years when unscrupulous chairman have led the club into danger, but we've always bounced back. Last season we were relegated. That still hurts as it was not so long ago.

How we're doing at the moment

The whole place is buzzing. We're winning games and scoring goals for fun. We've only lost three league games all season and we put up a good show in the FA Cup before going out to First-Division Crewe after a replay. Off the field, the club is becoming more businesslike and professional. Online ticketing, staff that now listen to the fans

Our last game

Cardiff City 4 - 1 Plymouth. Plymouth were down to ten men after eight minutes, but it was still a game of patience. They defended well and we were not at our best in attack, but when one of ours was sent off along with another of theirs, the game opened up and we run out easy winners.

Our next game

Shrewsbury away closely followed by Macclesfield away. I can't see us losing either game.

This is irritating

We're forever scoring own goals - six so far this season. One from 30 yards out to earn Crewe a lucky replay, one the other week at Southend in the third minute of injury time when we were one up, and another live on Sky (although we did score five after that).

The chairman

Sam Hammam. The name spaeks for itself. Not a person to hide away. He has big ideas for Cardiff and he is putting them into action. Most clubs in the league would have him in control in an instant.

Our traditional rivals

Swansea City. Our neighbours of 38 miles away are currently in the Second but they're having a nightmare season while we're on a roll! There is a bitter rivalry between fans, which at times boils over into pure hatred. They are extremely jealous of our new-found wealth and Cardiff fans are not backward in coming forward to remind them.

How we're turned out

Our home kit is not absolutely stunning, but it's simple and looks good. The predominantly yellow away kit is great, although City have a habit of mixing and matching the shorts. They sometimes use white shorts and that makes it looks awful.

The classic blue shirt with the yellow and white stripe down one side of the chest is the most popular kit, and those of my age group remember it looking so good. The current away kit is a replica of it with the colours reversed.

The worst kit, according to my wife, is last year's centenary special edition. Chocolate brown and orange quarters. I thought it looked, well, different. She threw it in the bin and said I was never to go out dressed in one of those.

Mascots

Bartley Bluebird. It's a five-foot bluebird named after the founder of Cardiff, Bart Wilson. More popular than the actual mascot itself is the competition in the home programme to find Bartley hidden amongst the pages. I still haven't found him in last week's issue.

The crowd's favourite

All eyes are on Rob Earnshaw at the moment, 19 goals so far this season. Last year, the management did not think he was ready and so we got relegated. This year he's the Division's top scorer so far.

As for past heroes, we gave John Toshack his start in football. Most former players get a good reception on their return to Ninian Park.

Figure of hate

The home fans are very good with home players. With all the own goals going in, some players could have become targets for abuse but we support them rather than get at them.

On the other hand, anyone who has played for Swansea, lives near Swansea or has the name Jack - the Swansea nickname - is always abused.

The latest villains to come to Ninian Park both left the pitch early. Sean McCarthy, currently with Plymouth and ex of Swansea, was red-carded for use of the elbow. Previous to that Julian Alsop of Cheltenham - yes, formerly of Swansea - was also sent packing for violent conduct in the first-half of an FA Cup game before Christmas. As you can imagine the stick these boys got when they were on the field, the noise as they walked off was amazing.

The ground

Ninian Park is old and run down, but still better than a lot of other lower league grounds. It's three sides all-seater and there's an open terrace behind one goal. We've been there for decades but while the memories bring a tear to the eye a new stadium is the way forward. Did I mention that Sam is building us one of them as well?

The crowd

Now the crowds have come back, the atmosphere is awesome, very intimidating. Sometimes you despair when the chanting gets a bit too near the knuckle, but when we are getting behind the team it's brilliant.

Local knowledge

There have been many improvements for customer care. Bars have been added to both sides of the ground, and the food is now so palatable that people only complain when stocks runs out. Programme vendors are wonderful people if you can find them, so buy early to avoid disappointment.

Links

The internet has spawned several Cardiff websites. CCFC Net is one of the better ones; others have blasted onto the scene but are never updated. City has its fair share of printed fanzines as well. The Thin Blue Line and Watch the Bluebirds Fly are the best.

webTitle: Global warming could be worst in 10,000 years

fields.headline: Global warming could be worst in 10,000 years
fields.trailText: An international group of scientists has confirmed the worst fears of environmentalists: the Earth's atmosphere could soar by almost 6C by 2100 - a rise unprecedented in the past 10,000 years.
fields.byline: By Tim Radford and Paul Brown
fields.body:
An international group of scientists has confirmed the worst fears of environmentalists: the Earth's atmosphere could soar by almost 6C by 2100 - a rise unprecedented in the past 10,000 years.

The United Nations group reported in Shanghai this week that, in the worst case, the average temperature could rise by 5.8C this century, 2C higher than their original predictions. Sea levels could rise by 88cm by 2100, making tens of millions of people homeless in China's Pearl river delta, Bangladesh, the Nile delta of Egypt, and other low-lying regions.

"We see changes in climate, we believe we humans are involved, and we're projecting future climate changes much more significant over the next 100 years than the last 100 years," said Robert Watson, introducing the latest, 1,000-page report of the intergovernmental panel on climate change (IPCC).

Klaus Topfer, the head of the UN environment programme, said the report "should ring alarm bells in every national capital and every local community".

The 90s was the warmest decade for 1,000 years, said the report. Temperatures rose by an average of 0.6C during the past century, with an increase in floods and droughts.

Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have risen by 31% since the industrial revolution, and scientists blame the reckless burning of fossil fuels. In one of the ironies of global politics, the scientists issued their report as George Bush - who has said he is not convinced climate change is really happening - took office as United States president.

Much of the science behind the report comes from the highest tiers of US and European research. The warnings may kickstart a political process that has been stalled since November when developed nations met at The Hague to agree to cut CO2 emissions by 5.5% by 2010 - well short of the 60% cut scientists say is needed - but the talks collapsed, largely because of US attitudes.

The researchers present the "worst case" picture, as well as projections of possible temperature rises if nations cooperate. But the outlook is grim. The area of northern polar sea ice has shrunk by up to 15% in the past 40 years, and the thickness of the ice has fallen by 40%. Snow cover has shrunk by 10% in the past 30 years.

The changes predicted would cause coastal areas to be inundated and lead to major population changes. They would end the ski industry in Europe, cause the disappearance of many of the world's glaciers, and have serious effects on agriculture.

The growing season for many of the staple crops in Africa would be cut too short for a reliable harvest because of excess heat and lack of moisture, and in Europe the Mediterranean fringe would be too dry for cereal crops. Many of the world's forests would die because of changes in water supply and increasing heat.

Night-time average temperatures would increasingly leave much larger areas frost-free, leading to increases in insect life.

Climate models have become far more reliable since the last report in 1995 but there is far greater unanimity among the world's scientists over the issue than among politicians.

The report says that the burning of fossil fuels is going to be "the dominant influence" on climate in the next century. The present CO2 concentration has not been exceeded in the past 420,000 years and probably not for 20m years. It is now going up at the rate of 4% a decade.

The rate of warming is much higher than in the 20th century and at any time in the last 10,000 years since the ice age ended, the report says.

fields.headline: Man United players become chess pieces
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The latest Manchester United spin-off involves miniature players going head to head on the chess board, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
You've bought your son the David Beckham biography, you've splashed out for his official Teddy Sheringham shirt - now pestered parents will be asked to dig into their pockets so he play chess with his Manchester United idols.

The Official Man Utd "Champions" chess set will be unveiled this weekend at London's toy fair, the latest merchandise spin-off from the snowballing football brand.

Retailing at around £27, it will pitch the 1999 European Cup winning side against the famous 1968 side. Hence a miniature Giggs, Beckham and Solksjaer will go head-to-head on the chequered board with Best, Charlton and Law.

Creator of the game Matthew Webb - a lifelong Man United fan - has included interchangeable bases so the team can be switched around on the traditional chess pieces.

Although Mr Webb orginally claimed this was to emulate the increasingly prevalent 'squad rotation' system of modern football, when quizzed, he admitted it actually helped avoid the embarrassment of choosing which player should be 'Queen'.

One can imagine hard man captain Roy Keane being quite upset in the role.

And 1999 goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel won't be appearing. He has refused to licence his character for any merchandising of this type.

Trademark Toys intends to produce 250,000 of the chess sets. They will go on sale from the end of June.

Mr Webb, a consultant to Trademark, said that the sets will be particularly popular in the far east, where both chess and Manchester United are even bigger than here.

Mr Webb holds marketing trademarks for a number of pop bands and sports teams. He has already produced Steps jewellery and Westlife dog tags.

He said that Buffy, of vampire-slaying fame, will be the next character to grace a chessboard.

fields.headline: Chelsea sign £24m deal with Emirates
fields.trailText: Chelsea have signed a three-year sponsorship deal with the Emirates airline, estimated to be worth £24m. It is the second-biggest sponsorship arrangement in British football, after Manchester United's deal with Vodafone.
fields.body:
Chelsea have signed a three-year sponsorship deal with the Emirates airline, estimated to be worth £24m. It is the second-biggest sponsorship arrangement in British football, after Manchester United's deal with Vodafone.

"The deal illustrates how Chelsea are among the clubs with who prospective sponsors want to be associated," Ken Bates told the Standard today. "It is worth more than the sponsorship agreements of Arsenal and Leeds."

Not spurning the opportunity to revel in the good news, Bates claimed the deal proved Chelsea's status as an "international" club. "We are an international team and an international club so we wanted a more high profile international commercial partner.

"We are delighted to be regarded not as a foreign legion but as an international team. We are an international team based in Fulham and Chelsea, rather like our neighbours Fulham down the road.

"I am not sure where Mr Fayed comes from but he has quite a few foreigners in his team as well."

Emirates will replace current sponsors Autoglass at the end of the season. Their money will also buy them a "scholarship scheme" with the club, allowing Dubai youngsters to receive training from Chelsea coaching staff.

"It is not just about shirt sponsorship, there is a lot more to it than that," Bates said. The deal is also thought to include additional performance-related bonuses for the club.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: We're on our way to Cardiff, you're not, you're not
fields.body:
We're on our way to Cardiff, you're not, you're not

You'd expect Liverpool fans to be ecstatic after their side's 5-0 thrashing of Crystal Palace and, quite rightly, they are. But hats off to broad-minded folk like Bri from Liverpool FC, who has generously spared a thought for supporters less fortunate than himself. Well, sort of.

"I know everyone dismisses the Worthington Cup as a Mickey Mouse competition," he continues, "but I bet the likes of Spurs, Leeds, Chelsea, Newcastle and Everton would like to see European football next season.

"I'm sure the chairman of Leeds is quietly shitting himself after spending £18m on Rio Ferdinand, because the fact is that the only bit of Europe they'll be seeing next year is two weeks in Malaga."

Palace fan Mark McNabb has also come in for some stick from jubilant Reds fans. Mark wrote in to Football Unlimited after the Eagles' 2-1 win against Liverpool two weeks ago to gloat - and he did so in big, bold capital letters. "I would like to ask Marc McNabb why 'PALACE ARE ON THEIR WAY TO CARDIFF!!!', what a 'MERE FORMALITY' is and, finally, where 'THE EAGLES HAVE LANDED'," David McIvor responded, picking out a few choice quotes from Mr McNabb's original letter. And we suspect he's not the only one with such sentiments

But not everyone is impressed with Liverpool's 5-0 win. Robin Lord reckons that despite their victory "Liverpool remain inconsistent" and he's not impressed with Gerald Houllier's man-management skills.

"In my opinion it is down to a manager who is not capable of inspiring players to give of their best all the time," he says. "Houllier almost destroyed Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen by taking away their self-confidence. Hopefully Robbie at least is strong enough to come back despite the manager, and hopefully that comeback keeps him with Liverpool."

Strachan: should he stay or go?

The fans at the Coventry may have hurled abuse at him, but it seems that Gordon Strachan still has the support of Football Unlimited readers.

James Bridge pens a personal letter from LA. "Your honesty, under difficult circumstances, is almost unheard of, and your refusal to sink into the negative back-biting displayed by many in your unfortunate league position is an example we can all learn from," he says with the sort of touchy-feely attitude that plays well in the States (but less well in the UK).

Nevertheless most supporters will agree with James when he says: "I hope your club wriggles itself out of relegation this year. It distresses me that your family are getting a hard time from the fans, but some people, let's face it, are just dickheads. Don't let this current situation change your outlook on the game, and maybe your outlook can change the game a little."

Jaysen Permal is less convinced however. "Strachan has a good pool of players, but they need to work more as a unit," he claims. "Having seen Coventry play a few times this season, they look as though they are all over the place, but with players of the likes of Hadji, Chippo, Carsley, Thompson and two very sound keepers, there's no reason why they can't stay up."

Grobbelaar: a personal memory

Finally, Dave Flynn has a personal recollection of Bruce Grobbelaar that plays in slight contrast to the recent media coverage the former Liverpool keeper has received. "The sad thing about the Grobbelar case is that of all the Liverpool players over the last 30 or 40 years Bruce is the only one that I can remember being respected by Everton fans," he says. "This was due to the fact that you could often find him in Stanley Park playing football with the local kids.

"He was a genuine hero in Liverpool. He's probably got an approach to the game that is too difficult for even the most well-informed journalist to understand. Maybe he just didn't take it seriously. It was probably more important for him kicking the ball around with the kids in the park. Winning a European Cup is just business after all. Ask those kids what they think of him."

fields.headline: The Crazy Gang ride again
fields.standfirst: Michael Morris of www.cardiffcity.com is excited about the future. Here's why.
fields.trailText: Usually, sequels are not as good as the original. And how could you possibly follow the Crazy Gang show starring Sam Hammam, Bobby Gould, Alan Cork, Vinnie Jones, Dennis Wise, Dave Beasant and the rest?
fields.body:
Usually, sequels are not as good as the original. And how could you possibly follow the Crazy Gang show starring Sam Hammam, Bobby Gould, Alan Cork, Vinnie Jones, Dennis Wise, Dave Beasant and the rest?

Impossible, you'd think. But look out: there's something happening in south Wales that - by using some of the original cast and adding some new blood to bring the story up-to-date - will be better than Wimbledon.

The show started when Hammam paid his first visit to Ninian Park, home of Cardiff City. There had been many whispers that he was coming. Then, when his interest became public, there were rumours and counter-rumours. Would he? Wouldn't he?

It soon be came apparent that the man who had taken Wimbledon "all the way" was about to start all over again at Cardiff City.

Sam's arrival was the biggest shot in the arm the club has had in its history. After being relegated back to the Third Division after just one season, there looked to be hard times ahead. The former chairman was doing a great job under enormous pressure, but we seemed destined to struggle in the lower-leagues forever.

Sam invested £3.1m into the club. The money was sectioned for paying off debt, covering costs and adding to the playing staff. For players, the original amount budgeted for was around £500,000 - big money for a Third Division side.

Sam quickly got the fans on his side, and it wasn't just about the money, either. Over 11,000 fans turned up for the first home game of the season to see Sam walking into the Ninian Park sunshine with a Welsh flag and a banner, announcing the arrival of his new Welsh army.

Soon after, Sam started to get his teeth into the job. Out went manager Billy Ayre, in came Bobby Gould - Sam's good friend and former Wimbledon cast member. Players followed, as did Alan Cork as Gould's assistant.

Within weeks, Cork was in full control of the team. Since then, Cardiff fans have seen their team rattle in 39 league goals in 14 games, suffering only one league defeat along the way.

Sadly, Sam has overspent on his player budget. Happily, the fans just love it. Record signings under-21 internationals players signing from Premiership teams can it get any better?

Of course it will - when we get promoted. Not just to the Second Division but beyond.

And as expected, the Crazy Gang lifestyle is still alive and well.

Alan Cork's car was trashed when he won manager of the month. As revenge, Cork "accidentally" left a sheep in Sam's office - it was only found when the chairman was entertaining a very important visitor. The animal was not house trained.

Players have found the tyres let down on their cars, journalists have been "baptised" with buckets of water and sheep have been raffled at half time. There are even plans to send hot air balloons and, erm, elephants up the valleys.

In Sam's first six months, the club are fighting hard for promotion, Ninian Park is full and away ticket allocations sell out like gold dust. Quality players are playing without fear and succeeding. There is even talk of some players getting full international call-ups.

Sam Hammam and the Crazy Gang Part II: a box-office smash for sure.

fields.headline: Court of Appeal backs Sunday Times on spy book
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The Court of Appeal has ruled the Sunday Times is free to publish extracts from a book by an ex-MI6 officer, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Sunday Times is free to publish extracts from a book by former MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson after the Court of Appeal ruled that it should not be made to seek clearance before doing so.

Lord Phillips, the Master of the Rolls, sitting with Lord Justice Tuckey and Lord Justice Longmore, said that it was desirable that there was consultation between the newspaper and MI6 before it published matters which might be capable of damaging the service.

But he did not think it right to impose on the newspaper the requirement that they should seek confirmation from the attorney general or the courts that the facts which they intended to republish had been brought into the public domain by prior publication elsewhere.

That was a matter on which an editor was able to form his own judgement and he should be left responsible for exercising that judgement.

Lawyers for the newspaper had argued that the scenario of obtaining such permission at the point of deadline on a Saturday evening was "entirely unworkable".

The judges dismissed an appeal by the attorney general against a high court ruling, on Friday, widening the scope of an undertaking given by the newspaper in November 1996 preventing publication of The Big Breach: From Top Secret to Maximum Security until it came to the "widespread attention" of the public. The High Court had said that extracts could be published once the book became "generally accessible".

The appeal judges today dismissed the appeal on the basis that the newspaper would give an undertaking that publication would not take place until information in the book had previously been published "to such an extent" that it was in the public domain.

Lord Phillips said: "It is not right that they should be be subjected to a fetter on freedom of expression which goes beyond this."

Mr Tomlinson, who was with the service from 1991 to 1995, was imprisoned for breaching the Official Secrets Act in 1997, and now lives in Italy.

fields.headline: Boycott quits Express
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Rosie Boycott has resigned as editor of the Express ending months of speculation about her future. By Lisa O'Carroll.
How Rosie said goodbye
Plaudits for 'Renaissance Rosie'
Recent Express stories
fields.body:
Rosie Boycott has resigned as editor of the Express ending months of speculation about her future following the takeover of the paper by Richard Desmond.

Her deputy Chris Blackhurst has also quit.

They left the Express Ludgate House HQ at 11.20am after almost three years at the helm.

It is believed Ms Boycott leaves with a £200,000 plus pay-off - equivalent to 15 months salary.

The deal was finally agreed yesterday after almost two months of brinkmanship with Mr Desmond.

It was widely accepted that Ms Boycott, a liberal supporting feminist, would quit following Mr Desmond's arrival because her views were incompatible with a proprietor whose publishing empire included 38 soft porn magazines, including Asian Babes and Big Ones.

However, she held out, partly to protect up to 100 journalists who were threatened with the sack, and partly to force Mr Desmond to honour her contract which ran until May 2002.

In December relations between Mr Desmond and Ms Boycott worsened when 60 support staff were made redundant.

In a letter distributed to staff, Ms Boycott condemned "heavy-handed" treatment of workers. She expressed outrage that management had sacked a pregnant woman as well as a disabled man who had been promised a job for life.

At that stage a number of journalists had already left in protest at the changes. Columnist Peter Hitchens and political editor Anthony Bevins were among those who quit because they would not work for the new owner.

Plaudits for 'Renaissance Rosie'
