fields.headline: Chinese New Year
fields.standfirst:
Emma Gibson sees in the new year for the second time - but this time Chinese style
More net news
fields.trailText: Emma Gibson sees in the new year for the second time - but this time Chinese style
fields.body:
Yesterday the first new moon of the year rose in the sky and with it the Chinese celebrated their New Year's Eve. On February 6, as the now full moon rises into the night sky, the Chinese will welcome in the year of the Golden Snake. In the two weeks from new to full moon, there will be dragon dancing, house cleaning, flower decorating, feasting, lantern parades, firecrackers and fortune cookies. Unlike my own new year celebrations, where I struggled to remember the second line of Auld Lang Syne, it is a time for family and reunion, ceremony and superstition.

The Chinese New Year is the oldest and most important festival in China and celebrates spring time and the earth coming back to life. In the past, feudal rulers of dynasties celebrated the new year with elaborate ceremonies. Today, the ritual and importance continues with celebrations occurring throughout Britain - London, Manchester, Liverpool and Birmingham all have their own events planned. Visit www.chinatown-online.co.uk for a comprehensive listing of planned events in all the major cities and excellent background information. www.timeout.com also has listings for celebrations in Shanghai and San Francisco.

The Chinese year is based around the lunar/solar calendar, as opposed to our own Gregorian calendar. www.chineseastrologyonline.com offers a comprehensive explanation of the calendar, which explains why the New Year falls on a different day each year. It is the longest chronological record in history, dating from 2600BC when the Emperor Huang Ti introduced the first cycle of the zodiac. Both www.chinascape.org/china/culture/holidays/hyuan/newyear.html and www.new-year.co.uk/chinese also shed light on this complex system.

Each year is named after an animal. The Chinese believe that the animal of the year into which you are born has a profound influence on your personality. Legend has it that Lord Buddha asked all the animals to come and visit him before he departed from life and only 12 appeared. Detailed zodiac explanations can be found at www.chineseastrology.com, where you can read your own forecast for the year ahead, and www.thefengshuiconsultancy.co.uk, which offers an in depth analysis of snake people, the Chinese astrological sign into which we are entering.

Preparations for the festival start during the last few days of the last moon. Houses are thoroughly cleaned to sweep away all the ill fortune that may have been lurking to make way for good luck. Dirt and rubbish must be swept inwards and then carried out of the back of the house. To sweep it out of the front door is to sweep away the good fortune of the family. On the stroke of midnight, doors and windows of the home should be opened and firecrackers let off to send out the old year and welcome in the new one. Explosives can be found at www.fireworks.com while www.educ.uvic.ca/faculty/mroth/438/CHINA/taboos.html offers an extensive glossary of superstitions and rituals.

Feasting plays an important role in the celebrations, with a large family meal served on New Year's Eve. Traditional food such as jiaozi and Mian Gao is prepared and families gather together for this annual feast. If your local Chinese doesn't deliver, try www.chopstix.co.uk and www.cookingtogether.com for traditional Chinese recipes.

Houses are adorned with flowers, blessings and art. The Chinese believe that without flowers there would be no formation of any fruits, so plum blossom, bamboo, azaleas, waterlilies and pussy willow (which all symbolise rebirth and new growth) are used to decorate the home (See www.greenfingers.com). Lucky is the house with a plant that blooms on New Year's day. Scrolls of red paper bearing couplets of blessings of good fortune are hung from the walls (See www.chinapage.com/newyr.html ).

For some light-hearted entertainment, virtual fortune cookies can be found at www.jy-muggeridge.freeserve.co.uk (search under fortune cookies), which provides all the fun without the calories. Predictions range from the profound "Do not be afraid to go out on a limb for that is where the fruit is", to the bizarre "You can't hide broccoli in a glass of milk".

The Parade of the Lanterns concludes the festivities. The people of ancient China believed that celestial spirits would fly in the light of the first full moon of the new lunar year. The search for the spirits evolved over many years into the lantern festival which now ends the new year celebrations alongside performances of martial arts, folk dancing and dragon and lion dances. Visit www.dancing-dragon.com.

The passing Year of the Dragon was a tempestuous, larger-than-life year, with flared tempers, fortunes made and lost, and the earth and weather reacting violently to the unpredictable beast. The year of the snake will be one of reflection, planning and searching answers. They say it will be an auspicious year for commerce and industry, that there will be courtship and scandal, elegant fashion and blossoming arts. It will be welcomed with panache and style, far removed from my own humble celebrations three weeks ago.

It will be welcomed with panache and style, far removed from my own humble celebrations three weeks ago.

webTitle: Charities call for funds to tackle rise in HIV

fields.headline: Charities call for funds to tackle rise in HIV
fields.trailText: The UK's largest HIV/Aids charities, the Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse and the National Aids Trust have warned that more investment in public education is needed to counter the rising rate of HIV infection.
fields.body:
The UK's largest HIV/Aids charities, the Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse and the National Aids Trust have warned that more investment in public education is needed to counter the rising rate of HIV infection.

Infection rates in the UK hit a high last year, according to the latest official figures, and are set to continue rising.

"With one case of HIV now being reported every 3 hours, we are concerned that the UK's fight against HIV is beginning to falter," said Derek Bodell, chief executive of the NAT.

"If we are to reverse this worrying trend we need to improve our investment in targeted HIV education campaigns, and the government must make this a priority in its long-awaited HIV and sexual health strategy," Mr Bodell said.

The figures are clear evidence that HIV/Aids has not gone away in this country. Powerful drug combinations have slashed the death rate, but have led to complacency in some quarters, which may be behind some of the rise in infection rates.

The public health laboratory service (PHLS) revealed that 2,868 new diagnoses were reported in 2000 with further diagnoses pending.

There was alarm when the 1999 statistics showed the highest infection rate for 10 years. Updated figures for 1999 now show it was worse - there were more diagnoses than for any year since testing began in 1985.

But 2000 has already topped that, with a 7% increase on 1999.

Part of the reason is that people who were infected many years ago are only now coming forward for testing, according to the PHLS. But there are many new infections too, suggesting that people have begun to ignore or forget the safe sex message. There are also large increases in other sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea.

"This is the second consecutive year where we have reported record levels of HIV diagnoses," said Barry Evans, head of the HIV division of the PHLS communicable disease surveillance centre.

"We are now two decades into the HIV epidemic, but we continue to see new cases of an infection which is largely preventable. We cannot afford to be complacent about safer sex. The basic prevention messages remain the same: use a condom when having sex with a new or casual partner and in the case of injecting drug use, never share injecting equipment."

Funding for HIV/Aids projects has been cut back because of the success of modern drugs in keeping people alive.

webTitle: Freeserve enters fray for unmetered access

fields.headline: Freeserve enters fray for unmetered access
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The battle for the hearts and wallets of home internet users heated up yesterday with the launch of a cut-price unlimited access service.
fields.body:
The battle for the hearts and wallets of home internet users heated up yesterday with the launch of a cut-price unlimited access service.

Freeserve - owned by French internet service provider Wanadoo - kicked off its new package offering 24-hour web access for individuals for £12.99 per month, making it some £2 cheaper than similar available packages.

John Pluthero, Freeserve's chief executive, said that "£12.99 is a profitable price point for us. In the telecommunications industry scale is everything, and because of our size and number of users we get telecoms prices that nobody else in the UK can get".

Freeserve - which boasts 2m subscribers - accounts for as much as 15% of local UK telecoms traffic, according to Mr Pluthero. He expects 100,000 to 200,000 users to sign up to the new service.

The Freeserve Anytime package undercuts unmetered packages costing £14.99 a month from AOL, launched last September by the US internet service provider, and is likely to be below a similar service to be announced by BT within the next week. Unmetered access offered by cable firm NTL through its NTLworld package has recently risen from £10 to £15 a month.

Freeserve had announced the unmetered service at the start of December last year, but negotiations with BT delayed the final launch. "Knowing when it would arrive with certainty is a black science with BT," Mr Pluthero said.

BT could retaliate as early as tomorrow with its own BTinternet Anytime package, which sources say would also be priced at £14.99 a month.

 Germany's T-Online, the internet arm of Deutsche Telekom, paid the price of flat-rate net access yesterday when it announced a €125m (£ 79 m) loss for the year.

The losses were slightly better than analysts' predictions, however, and T-Online's earnings soared 86% to €797m for the year from €428m in 1999.

The healthy revenues were not enough to keep analysts happy, however. Investment bank Merrill Lynch said late in the day it was downgrading its recommendation on Europe's largest ISP from "accumulate" to "neutral".

webTitle: In brief: big buy for Miramax enlivens Sundance

fields.headline: Big buy for Miramax enlivens Sundance
fields.standfirst: Plus: Joel Schumacher to direct romantic comedy
fields.trailText: Plus: Joel Schumacher to direct romantic comedy
fields.body:
 The jingle of another sale enlivened an otherwise sluggish Sundance International Film Festival (see earlier story) as Miramax opened their chequebooks to purchase the distribution rights to Todd Fields' In the Bedroom (pictured) for a reported $2m (£1.37m). Adapted from a short story by the late Andre Dubus, the film, which marks the directing debut of Field, is an elegant human drama which traces a wealthy New England family's tumble into tragedy. In the Bedroom stars Sissie Spacek, Marisa Tomei and Britain's Tom Wilkinson. Miramax are believed to be planning to push the film as an Oscar hopeful.

 Joel Schumacher is to direct the romantic comedy, Life, or Something Like It, for New Regency Pictures. Scripted by John Scott Shepherd and Dana Stevens, the film tells the tale of a thrusting female journalist who is forced to take stock when she is told by a homeless psychic that she has only one week left to live. Life continues Schumacher's shift towards more intimate, low-budget movies after the failure of his mega-budget Batman and Robin. Last year he attracted decent reviews for his odd-couple drama Flawless and his guerilla-style boot-camp saga Tigerland (released in the UK in March) is tipped to be his best film to date. Life, or Something Like It begins production in April.

fields.headline: Tremors topple Tokyo's tranquillity
fields.standfirst: Japan's iconic Mount Fuji is rumoured to be close to blowing its top for the first time in almost 300 years, writes Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: Tokyo dispatch: Japan's iconic Mount Fuji is rumoured to be close to blowing its top for the first time in almost 300 years, writes Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
Just three weeks into the new millennium, Japan already seems to have entered into a darkly apocalyptic mood. The newspapers are full of political scandal, Tokyo stock prices have slumped on fears of recession and economists are warning that the country could face a financial crisis in March.

And as if that was not enough to satisfy the doomsayers, the word is now going round that Mt Fuji, the symbol of Japanese serenity, may be about to blow its top.

Rumours about an imminent eruption of the long dormant volcano have spread since signs of heightened magma activity under the mountain were reported late last year.

On average, 10 low frequencies tremors are detected deep below Mt Fuji annually. But according to the national meteorological agency, this pattern changed dramatically in the autumn with 33 minor quakes detected in September, 133 in October and 222 in November.

Scientists say this increase does not mean Mt Fuji will explode into life any time soon, but they acknowledge that the change merits close attention.

Their caution is understandable after a year of intense subterranean movement that is unusual even for Japan, a land that is wrinkled by more earthquakes and pimpled with more volcanoes than almost any other nation on earth.

In the past 12 months, the archipelago has experienced three major eruptions and several large earthquakes, including a trembler in Tottori, western Japan, that registered 7.3 on the Richter scale, making it bigger than the Kobe quake that killed more than 6,000 people in 1995.

Seismology and vulcanology are notoriously imprecise sciences, but many experts in these fields say Japan could be entering a period of heightened seismic activity.

Such vague warnings along with the stirrings nine miles below Mt Fuji have been enough to prompt the weekly tabloids to raise the prospect of a devastating eruption that could threaten the 12m inhabitants of Tokyo, which sits 60 miles from the mountain's slopes.

It has also prompted the local authorities around the mountain to conduct their first disaster prevention drills and to draw up hazard maps of the areas that would be most vulnerable to pyroclastic flows of molten rock and gas.

Such precautions represent a breakthrough. Until now, municipal officials have refused to recognise the possibility of an eruption for fear that it would damage the lucrative Mt Fuji tourist trade.

Rising 3,776 metres (12,388ft) from sea level in a nearly perfect cone, Mt Fuji is not only Japan's tallest and most beautiful mountain, it is also a national symbol and an object of worship.

During the two month climbing season each summer, about 150,000 pilgrims and sightseers make the four and a half hour trek up the mountain's ash-grey slopes to a peak that is home to numerous Shinto shrines as well as a vending machine for soft drinks.

For most visitors, the main concern is the rubbish that has piled up on the mountain's slopes rather than the possibility of an eruption.

Mt Fuji has not blown its top since 1707, when it devastated surrounding villages and rained ash on Tokyo for two weeks. But every few years - usually after an eruption elsewhere in Japan - there are warnings that Fuji will be the next to go.

The most apocalyptic scenario was painted in the 1984 bestseller, "The Great Explosion of Mt Fuji", which predicted that an eruption would trigger a massive earthquake in Tokyo, similar to the one that killed 140,000 people in 1923.

That book was blamed for a 10% fall in tourist numbers in the Fuji area the following year, which makes the move to stage a drill this summer seem all the braver.

The decision appears to reflect an important change in attitude towards disaster preparation in Japan.

Despite the fact that the earth is rarely still in this part of the world, the authorities have often been criticised in the past for taking an overly rosy view of the likelihood and potential impact of natural calamities.

But that certainly was not the case last year, when the government acted quickly and effectively to prevent a single volcano or earthquake fatality.

In this sense at least, it would seem that the growing tendency to assume the worst is proving to be one of the best things to have happened to Japan in years.

webTitle: Start taking stress seriously, say insurers

fields.headline: Start taking stress seriously, say insurers
fields.trailText: A huge rise in the number of claims for stress-related pressures at work is causing alarm among insurers.
fields.body:
A huge rise in the number of claims for stress-related pressures at work is causing alarm among insurers.

They are calling on the UK's employers to start treating staff more fairly, by cutting back on long hours and stop bosses bullying workers.

One of the UK's largest income protection insurers, Unum, says its claims for stress have risen by 88% over the last seven years, while those for chronic fatigue syndrome are up by 40%.

Unum was responding to a recent survey from BMRB International among 1,200 full and part time workers which found two thirds of them were stressed, with some 73% admitting it was affecting their performance.

Eugene McCormack, Unum's marketing director said: "This survey should be seen as a wake up call for the UK's business community. They appear to be allowing the working environment to become increasingly stressful and it cost could them."

Unum is campaigning for employers to move away from long working days, which it says do not result in increased efficiency, only increased levels of illness.

Other income protection insurers such as Royal & SunAlliance and Norwich Union also say they have been hit by increased levels of claims for stress.

The annual cost of stress-related sickness to British business is now more than £4billion, according to Professor Cary Cooper, Bupa professor of organisational psychology and health at University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (Umist).

Professor Cooper warns that stress levels in Britain are higher than in any other country in Europe and that they will increase rapidly in the next decade.

Although some private medical insurance policies will pay for psychiatric treatment for stress problems, those off work for long periods need to have been covered by income protection. This type of insurance pays for the amount of time someone is off work and typically offers a tax-free monthly benefit of around 60% of salary.

But, only around 11% of the UK population is covered by income protection. It is expensive if bought on an individual basis and while some companies provide it, many people in high pressure jobs have no insurance at all.

Critical illness insurance, which is more popular than income protection, does not cover stress. Instead this pays out on diagnosis of a number of severe conditions such as heart attack, stroke or cancer.

Yet the most likely reasons for long term absence from work are stress and back problems.

Many people though are just not able to afford both income protection and critical illness cover - someone in their 30s, for example, could be paying over £80 a month in premiums. This means they effectively have to take a gamble and predict what is likely to be the best type of cover for them.

We are leaving the Express in the next few minutes and we wanted to say goodbye and many thanks to all our wonderful colleagues.

We are hugely proud of what we have all achieved. We know we will see many of you in the future. We wish everyone the very best of luck.

Best Wishes to you all,

Rosie and Chris

fields.headline: Natural father wants twins back
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The battle over the fate of the internet twins bcame a four-way fight yesterday after the babies' real father was granted custody by a judge in their home town, St Louis, Missouri.
fields.body:
The battle over the fate of the internet twins bcame a four-way fight yesterday after the babies' real father was granted custody by a judge in their home town, St Louis, Missouri.

Circuit judge Jack Garvey granted the custody order, effective until the court's next hearing on February 14, to Aaron Wecker, father of the girls and former husband of Tranda Wecker, who "sold" them twice over the internet.

Mr Wecker, who has custody of the couple's three-year-old child, joins the battle against his ex-wife, who says she wants them back, and with the two couples who paid a California-based agency to adopt them.

Kimberley and Belinda, were first given to a California couple, Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernardino, then handed over to Alan and Judith Kilshaw, by Ms Wecker after they agreed to pay more.

Court papers filed by Mr Wecker last Monday allege that Ms Wecker neglected the twins by trying to sell them twice, according to the St Louis Post-Dispatch. He also accused her of "failing to report to me on the whereabouts of the children for weeks at a time, subjecting the twins to illegal activities and underhanded doings." The pair divorced before the twins were born last June.

The order in favour of Mr Wecker has no immediate effect because the twins remain in foster care after being taken from the Kilshaws by Flintshire social services. The Kilshaws adopted the twins in Arkansas, although the adoption may be invalid because Ms Wecker has admitting lying to get around the state's residence requirements.

The twist is another complication for Mr Justice Kirkwood, the high court judge who took over the case last Tuesday. He has promised a decision soon on the twins' future.

Allan Levy QC, a child law expert, said the real father might emerge as the right person to give them a home. "If he's the natural father and he's OK, the sooner they go there the better."

Ms Wecker said on Tuesday that she wanted the babies back. "I have a job. I have family and friends that will help me take care of my children," she said. "I miss my girls very much."

fields.headline: Indie's arts reporter bags £200,000 books deal
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Independent's arts and media correspondent, JoJo Moyes, has clinched a £200,000-plus deal to write two novels. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The Independent's arts and media correspondent, JoJo Moyes, has clinched a £200,000-plus deal to write two novels.

Publisher Hodder & Stoughton won a six-way bidding battle for the deal, which was based on an unfinished manuscript for her first novel.

Ms Moyes, 31, is currently on maternity leave but managed to write four chapters of the first book, which goes by the working title A Temporal Kingdom, in her spare time.

The story centres on three generations of women and starts off in post-war colonial Hong Kong, but finishes in County Wexford in Ireland where the grandmother settles.

"It was quite unusual to have six publishers bidding for it but one of the reasons they went for this was because it broke the mould," said her agent Jo Frank.

"Although JoJo is a young author, this is not 'chick lit', it is not another Bridget Jones. This is good old fashioned story-telling. It was fresh and different," she added.

The five other publishers who bid were Viking, Random House, Little Brown, Simon & Schuster and Macmillan.

Ms Moyes's deal will be the envy of her colleagues in the media world, many of whom aspire to be novelists.

However, she said it was a labour of love and that the money, ultimately, would simply represent a decent salary over the next few years.

She has a three-year-old daughter but tried to squeeze an hour of writing in every night after returning from work, sorting out supper and bedtime for her child.

"I had already written three unpublished novels and had really resigned myself to being the 'Eddie the eagle' of publishing.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Non-stop complaints

When we buy a train ticket we enter into a contract with the train company. Alas for us, it's a contract that no boardroom would accept were it to be to be offered by a business partner. If we arrive 20 minutes late for a train we have prebooked, we have to buy another ticket in order to board the next train. If the train departs 20 minutes late we are entitled to nothing. If we travel further than our ticket allows we are liable for a penalty fare. If the train operator overshoots our stop we are entitled to nothing.

Last month Ann Howard of London was taking her son to a hospital appointment and boarded a Connex train from Nunhead. As it approached her stop at Denmark Hill around three minutes late, the train sped past and deposited her miles from her destination at Victoria. There was no warning that the stop would be omitted and her son missed his appointment.

Connex eventually wrote to explain that in order to ensure a late-running service makes up time, it may run trains non-stop to the terminus. As a gesture of goodwill a rail voucher worth £2 was enclosed with the letter.

 Connex confirms that such decisions are taken to "minimise delays for the most numbers of people" and that, if necessary, it will "provide every help to get stranded passengers back to the correct stop". That is pleasant to know, but shouldn't compensation be a right rather than a goodwill gesture?

The association of train operating companies is curiously coy on the subject. "You should ask the train company involved," says a spokeswoman.

Next we try the rail passenger council, which is supposed to protect travellers' interests. "The train company might provide a taxi to ferry you back to your destination, but there's nothing in the passenger charter about it," says a spokesman. "You wouldn't be charged a penalty fee if the train does overshoot your station, though."

Munificence indeed. He suggests that we try the shadow strategic rail authority, which reveals that train companies are not obliged to get you back to your destination, although in Howard's situation "we would expect them to act sympathetically. Generally passengers are only entitled to compensation if they are delayed more than an hour as a result."

Mail disorder

Mail order shopping can be unpleasantly reminiscent of rail travel: you pay your money and wait in vain for service. Last October Oliver Adelman of London ordered a cupboard from Tesco's home shopping catalogue. He was promised delivery on November 10, but the package arrived a week late and only included the doors.

A month after the agreed delivery date a letter informed him that the remaining components were not in stock and Tesco wanted the doors back. There was no mention of a refund, which Adelman was later promised once the doors had been collected. Another month on he is still waiting for a courier to collect the package and Tesco says airily that it might take another fortnight to fix a date. It refuses to allow him to liaise with this elusive character himself and refuses to name a specific pick-up time.

 Apologies from Tesco, which says its service was not satisfactory. Adelman is now to receive his refund and a £50 goodwill voucher to enable him to embark on another catalogue adventure. He also gets to keep those completely useless cupboard doors.

By law, customers may cancel an order and demand a refund if the goods do not show up within the specific time (usually 28 days), provided that they have not agreed to an extension.

Power and glory

Yes, we're all tired of reading about British Gas, although many of you are still eager to write about it. But permit Consumer to bask in a little glory. Just before Christmas Steve Backes of London wrote in a panic. For months he and a team from the Crawley open house and resource centre had been converting a disused factory into a homeless hostel.

The opening was scheduled for early January, but although the centre had asked for a gas meter installation in October, two months and several false starts later it was still not completed. "Apparently it normally takes three weeks for Transco to give a quote for the job and up to two months to install the meter," says Backes. "This could mean the hostel will be unusable until early March. The homeless are at present in leaky, cramped conditions, with toilets and showers not working, and the building is due to be demolished soon, but British Gas refuses to commit to installing the meter before the new accommodation opens."

 Consumer's British Gas contact works a Christmas miracle. At the 11th hour the meter is installed and the hostel receives its first guests in comfort. The delay, according to our kind friend, was due to foot-dragging on the part of Transco.

Give us some credit

The plight, described last week, of Yvonne Temple, who finds herself refused credit despite a clean credit record, struck a chord with reader Paul Turner. "I was having difficulty getting credit and got one of the underwriters at the bank where I worked to check my record. Like Mrs Temple my credit history was clear, but there was an outstanding county court judgment against the previous owner of the house I now live in.

"I am convinced that this was the problem, although credit checks should be made against a person not an address. If this turns out to be the case with Mrs Temple she should try writing a Note of Correction to the credit reference agencies explaining that she has no connection with the debt. Her letter should then be displayed with any information a future credit check brings up."

 In fact lenders are under no legal obligation to inform applicants why they have refused credit, and are wary of being too specific in case it enables would-be borrowers to devise a fraudulent application. However their codes of practice usually require them to give the principal reason.

They should, for instance, provide the name and address of any credit reference agency which supplied information and they should also confirm whether or not a credit scoring system was used to process the application.

Not such a bad Ikea

It is a while since we visited Ikea. Dawn Hammond and her husband ordered two kitchen cupboards in 11 components from the Brent Park branch, London, in September. There ensued a catalogue of delays, errors and no response to 12 letters and faxes sent by the Hammonds.

 It's amazing how well Ikea can write letters when it wants to. As soon as Consumer gets in touch, Ikea springs into action and issues apologies. The Hammonds have their kitchen and an offer of compensation.

 Write to us at 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Parisian chic
fields.standfirst: Saint Laurent shows why he is still fashion's grand master
fields.trailText: Yves Saint Laurent was a fashion grand master long before most of the industry's current high flyers could tie their shoelaces. Now that he has bowed out of designing the less expensive YSL ready to wear line, the haute couture catwalk is the last remaining showcase for the veteran designer's creations.
fields.body:
Yves Saint Laurent was a fashion grand master long before most of the industry's current high flyers could tie their shoelaces. Now that he has bowed out of designing the less expensive YSL ready to wear line, the haute couture catwalk is the last remaining showcase for the veteran designer's creations.

Yesterday it was used to full effect as a masterclass in blue-blooded Parisian style. This, the last catwalk show of the week, was haute couture as it was meant to be seen. The salon was laden with chandeliers and lined with delicate gilt chairs, the scent of lilies hung heavy in the air, the vulgar trill of mobile phones was muted by strict decree.

First came a series of suits, in every shade of grey from mother of pearl to charcoal. The parallel lines of the sharp-shouldered jackets and wide-brimmed hats, and the seemingly endless legs of high-waisted trousers, were as impossibly elegant as fashion illustrations brought to life.

Pale leather gloves and shiny belts gave an old-fashioned polish to the collection - the Yves Saint Laurent couture client would not dream of leaving the house without earrings, let alone consider customising her handbag or wearing pink fishnet tights.

For a designer renowned for bringing the influence of menswear into women's wardrobes, this was a very curvy collection. Fitted jackets were belted and worn with wiggle-inducing pencil skirts. Puff sleeves, and a millefeuille of organza at the hem of evening dresses both served to emphasise the female form.

As the designs became more elaborate, colour and decoration erupted on to the catwalk. The front row madames were in raptures over classic Saint Laurent colour combinations such as cyclamen pink or jade green silk dresses cinched with black belts, and black suits with white buttons.

A column dress in layers of chestnut tulle came with a gold belt, cappuccino-coloured hem frills and a mauve silk rose at one knee.

For the most adventurous there was a straw hat covered in cherries, and a white organdie strapless dress with scalloped edging, embroidered with pineapples.

The designer has the talent to make these flights of fancy work, but Saint Laurent is nonetheless well aware that even on the catwalk, less is often more. The bride who closed the show - Marianne Laetitia Casta - eschewed veils, trains and posies and strolled the catwalk in a cream going away skirt suit, nonchalantly smoking a cigarette.

The designer himself clutched a bouquet of lily of the valley as he took his bow to a standing ovation.

fields.body:
Arsenal and Tottenham are interested in £3m-rated Lecce striker Cristiano Lucarelli, reports the Express. Both clubs have sent scouts to watch Lucarelli, who has scored eight goals in 13 Serie A games this season.

Southampton want to sign Jordi Cruyff from Spanish club Alaves. Cruyff, who turned down the chance to speak to Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle last summer, has a buy-out clause of £5m in his contract. But Cruyff is a free agent during this summer, and Hoddle is hoping to persuade Alaves to let him go for half that amount.

Meanwhile, Serie A club Brescia have admitted an interested in Southampton striker James Beattie, but say they haven't yet made a bid for him. Brescia official, Edoardo Piovani, told Planet Football: "We are interested in James Beattie, but we are yet to make an offer."

Walter Smith is hoping to bring Celtic striker Mark Burchill to Everton on loan until the end of the season, according to the Express. But according to Planet Football Smith faces competition from Birmingham City, who are still trying to resurrect a deal for Burchill.

Birmingham are very busy in the transfer market at the moment. According to Teamtalk, Trevor Francis has agreed personal terms with Sheffield United midfielder Curtis Woodhouse and hopes to complete a £2m deal by the weekend. And he has also lodged a £300,000 bid for Huddersfield Town right-back Steve Jenkins.

Preston manager David Moyes is lining up moves for Peter Beagrie and Oldham's Welsh U-21 international Matthew Tipton.

webTitle: Legal spat forces Penn film out of Berlin

fields.headline: Legal spat forces Penn film out of Berlin
fields.trailText: A dispute between the producers of The Pledge has resulted in Sean Penn's thriller being withdrawn at the last minute from this year's Berlin Film Festival
fields.body:
The Sean Penn picture The Pledge has been yanked from the Berlin International Film Festival at the eleventh hour following an ugly legal spat between its producers. American company Franchise Pictures are currently locked in a law suit with Munich-based Intertainment, which is traditionally responsible for distributing Franchise movies in German-speaking nations.

According to a report in Variety, Intertainment appear to have fired the first legal volley, claiming that Franchise illegally inflated production costs on The Pledge that were covered in part by Intertainment. Franchise immediately counter-sued, alleging fraud and breach of contract. Both sides now blame the other for preventing The Pledge from screening at next month's festival. "Sean Penn wanted this film to be in competition and is very sad," festival head Moritz de Hadelin told Variety. "But he doesn't own the film."

Directed by Penn, The Pledge stars Jack Nicholson as a retired Reno homicide detective who becomes obsessed with unravelling an unsolved child murder. The film's stellar cast also includes Benicio Del Toro, Vanessa Redgrave, Harry Dean Stanton, Sam Shepard, Robin Wright and Helen Mirren. The Pledge opened in the US last weekend to respectful reviews but lukewarm box office.

fields.headline: With friends like these...
fields.trailText: To shoot the Tories' fox is one thing. To make the bleeding animal perform a song and dance act immediately afterwards seems harsh. But there he was, in public, at the despatch box, less than three hours after he'd been fired by Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's consiglieri.
fields.body:
To shoot the Tories' fox is one thing. To make the bleeding animal perform a song and dance act immediately afterwards seems harsh. But there he was, in public, at the despatch box, less than three hours after he'd been fired by Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's consiglieri.

Tonight, to continue the mob metaphor, Peter Mandelson sleeps with the fishes - or at least with a lobster thermidor.

There were some murmurs of support from Labour MPs, but nothing very loud - more a sort of token rumble to show party solidarity against the other side. I doubt if he was greatly surprised. In politics, you can't afford to lose your friends when you only have one friend in the first place.

As Northern Ireland questions continued, cabinet ministers arrived one by one. They looked relaxed and cheerful. Clearly they were bearing the tragic news bravely. But then champagne is famous for steadying the nerves.

Mr Mandelson answered only one question, about the RUC. It had been his privilege "to support them in their work, their valiant work". Their sacrifices would "never, ever, be forgotten". It sounded like a memorial service at which the corpse gives the address.

Back in his seat, he looked miserable. Sometimes he chewed his lower lip. He clutched the scarlet ministerial file for the last time. These things always mattered to him. When he was minister without portfolio, he had a red and gold portfolio marked "minister without portfolio".

Gordon Brown, one of Mandy's 879 closest enemies, arrived at two minutes to three. So did Alastair Campbell, who's another. The prime minister appeared at 2.59. They exchanged the briefest possible glance, like office lovers anxious not to let anyone know.

Mr Hague had a choice, to be magnanimous or vicious. He opted for the latter, but really he had no choice. His backbenchers, apart from a few crusty old grandees, from the kind of regiment where a disgraced officer went off with a bottle of Scotch and a revolver, demanded vengeance. They wanted to soak their hands in Mandelson's blood.

The Tory leader said Mr Blair had notched up a "historic achievement, being forced to sack the same minister twice for the same offence". His dependency on Mandy had been "a monumental error of judgment".

The prime minister decided to be affronted. "He has done the right thing ... it is a long tradition in this house that when someone does that, we pay tribute to it. I am only sorry that, once again, you have lived down to my expectations."

It was meant to be deeply dignified. It sounded thin and peevish. "Ooh, missus!" one felt like squeaking.

Mr Blair spoke of Mandy's role in "the broad sweep of history". Mr Hague talked about his role in the narrow sweep of the Blair government, "where standards of truth, honesty and integrity have taken second place to spin and smear".

"You diminish yourself far more than you diminish anyone else," Mr Blair replied. My sanctimoniousness meter was buzzing dangerously.

At 3.31, the two men walked out, Mr Mandelson clutching the precious scarlet folder for the last time. Behind him were hundreds of Labour backbenchers, most of whom have always regarded him as the depleted uranium of the government - supported in public, lethal in practice.

fields.headline: Saatchis names new chief executive
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Saatchi & Saatchi has named James Hall as its new chief executive, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Saatchi & Saatchi has named James Hall as its new chief executive, filling the vacancy left over a year ago when Adam Crozier left to head up the Football Association.

Mr Hall, chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi New Zealand, will move to London at the end of March to take up his new position.

He will report to Tamara Ingram, who takes on the new title of executive chairman.

The appointment is designed to enable her to take a step back from the day-to-day running of the agency, freeing her up to focus on attracting new business.

The decision ends a protracted search for a new chairman at Saatchi & Saatchi London. The agency had been expected to hire a heavy-hitter to add gravitas to its relatively young management team, but its recruitment plans were put on ice when it was bought by Publicis last year.

Ms Ingram and Mr Crozier took over at the helm of Saatchi & Saatchi London following the departure of Maurice and Charles Saatchi in 1995.

The rift with the brothers led to a mass walk-out of the agency's senior management.

webTitle: G2: Michael Ellison meets William Woodruff

fields.headline: Not bad for a weaver's son
fields.standfirst: He doesn't like the comparisons to Angela's Ashes that have greeted his latest book - he says his is more fun. And, besides, he's published 60 others, none of them gritty true-life memoirs.  Michael Ellison  talks to William Woodruff, an author with the gift of the gab
fields.trailText: He doesn't like the comparisons to Angela's Ashes that have greeted his latest book - he says his is more fun. And, besides, he's published 60 others, none of them gritty true-life memoirs. Michael Ellison talks to William Woodruff, an author with the gift of the gab.
fields.body:
The old man, stooped now but still spry, propels himself across the room from a bookshelf to a folder and whips out a sheaf of papers with his crooked hands.

"Look, 'a masterpiece', it says. Here's another: 'masterful'. They're all the same," says William Woodruff, whose best-selling account of his pitiable early years is transforming his ninth decade. "Clever? Not at all. Talented? Not at all. It's in the blood. I had a grandmother who was very talented and she ended up in the workhouse. Look where it got her."

Woodruff was brought up the hard way on this side of the Atlantic and made his mark on the other. Sound familiar? "No, I don't like it when it's said that I've written the English Angela's Ashes. I'd prefer to be judged on my own work. I can recommend it. I know the author. At my age, if I can't tell a good book from a bad book, what have I been doing?"

Plenty, is the answer. In the few moments that the emeritus professor of economic history can keep still in his home in two wooded acres of Gainesville, Florida, he is behind a desk drinking tea from a mug advertising the Theatre Royal in Stratford East, London. A big jotter in front of the 84-year-old writer is veined with black-ink lines about his current projects; on the other side of his worktop is a weaver's shuttle to remind him of the Blackburn he came from, if ever that were necessary.

He darts around, snatching up and discarding pieces of evidence to flesh out a point, dropping aitches in his haste so that his 65-year-old wife is 'elga and life has become rather 'ectic.

It is five years since Woodruff was in England and he wouldn't mind making a visit, doesn't think the trip, perhaps with a bit of book-signing, would do him any harm. Then he would be able to tell more people that The Road to Nab End was first published as Billy Boy three years before Angela's Ashes, by a small, now defunct publishing house. The Billy Boy title was rejected by Eland, the publishers which reissued the book last year, because of the German condoms that go by the same name. It has sold more than 20,000 copies.

It is the story of Woodruff's life up to 1933 when he fled a Blackburn where people still died from hunger, for London, where they did not. He has all the ebullience and sense of mission of a new writer, but nothing could be further from the truth. "Look," he says, " that's Woodruff's best work. This one will last." He is talking about Vessel of Sadness, his 1969 book about the Battle of Anzio, the first chapter of which is to be reprinted in April in an anthology of war writing. "It was compared to All Quiet on the Western Front," he adds.

Woodruff believes that life, and naturally history, is random, driven by chance rather than proceeding in a linear fashion. This he illustrates with regular recourse to the nursery rhyme Hey Diddle Diddle. "The dish ran away with the spoon, you see? You understand me?"

Vessel of Sadness was not understood by everyone, due to its unorthodox nature. John Wayne would not have been able to find a role in it. "Where's the sex, they used to say when I sent it to New York. And where are the heroes? There are none - that's war, it's fragmented. There's no sex unless you go to Naples on leave and get the clap. That's the only sex."

On the face of it, Woodruff wants for nothing, writing away, snug in his blue slippers and cardigan. By turns excited about the belated mainstream attention, self-effacing yet sure of his own value, he refers to himself often in the third person. "There must be a buoyancy factor about him. You can't stifle him. You can't kill him. You can't knock him down. Great illnesses. In Africa I had everything. Too long a story, not worth telling."

Woodruff does not need the money: the seven children are long since gone; he and 'elga have their home of 30 years, the pension, the social security and Brendan the black labrador. But 55 years ago, an acting colonel coming home from war, he chose a private life when he could have gone public, spurning the course that might have brought the wider recognition he wants now.

After all, the Japanese produce beautiful editions of his books and have made a documentary about him. He has lectured there too. What is wrong with the UK?

"I suppose if I've done anything, if I'm worth anything, what's the big thing Nab End can do for me? ... if Preston was to give me an honorary degree. But no, Preston's too small." The University of Central Lancashire at Preston is where Woodruff deposits his papers ("Handing in my cloth to God. You understand me?").

"Another university in the north of England, then. Let him boast: I think Nab End is a book that will last because it's a document of a time that would be impossible to write about these days without referring to it.

"The least I've heard from was Lancashire. Blackburn, you'd think the librarian would get in touch. Well, he did: don't send too many, we haven't got the shelf space. Especially Jack Straw, he represents Blackburn, doesn't he? Why doesn't he drop me a note? I've heard he likes the book."

More, one supposes anyway, than Woodruff cares for Frank McCourt's Angela's Ashes. "I started it and gave up. It was too much. Grim. I didn't want to say that. Nab End? Oh grim, yes, but joyful. There's a lot of humour in it. Oh, it was a miserable life, there's no denying it: 'ead in the oven was the normal."

The young Woodruff's predilection for the abnormal took him to London and within a few years the boy who had spent most of his brief years at school sleeping - "they were very kind to me in that way" - was at Oxford on a scholarship. In 1952 another scholarship took him to the US.

But before Harvard there was the second world war, in North Africa and Italy. "I won't pretend he was a close friend at Oxford, but when I told Harold Wilson [the future prime minister] that I was going off to war he put his hand on his heart and said 'Woody, I've been called to higher things. I'm going to work with Beveridge.'

"Harold was a good speaker, but I was a better speaker than Harold Wilson. Gift of the gab. Oh, yes. I wanted to be an MP; I could easily have been given a district. I had a first-class war record; I had a first-class record at Oxford. I turned it down. I'd have made a damn good minister in a Labour cabinet. It's interesting that this guy didn't do it, don't you think? A mistake? Who knows? It doesn't matter. Hey diddle diddle."

Woodruff turned it down because of what he calls the years the locusts ate: in five years of war he had seen his then wife for as many weeks. In the end she died of cancer after they had been together for 19 years.

He produces a list of 61 titles - hardbacks, softbacks and translations - with his name on them and written since he left the UK, among them Impact of Western Man, A Study of Europe's Role in the World Economy 1750-1960; America's Impact on the World: A Study of the Role of the United States in the World Economy, 1750-1970; and his Concise History of the Modern World.

"Nothing compared to some, but not bad for a weaver's son." And that's without mentioning lectures on four continents and the academic positions he has held at the universities of Illinois, Melbourne, Princeton and Florida.

The sequel to The Road to Nab End, Down the Road, which covers the years from 1933 to 1945, is finished and ready for publication, as is a novel that will come after that. "It'll play out, it'll play out. Let's just hope that the comet stays up a little longer. Hey diddle diddle, that's life."

 The Road to Nab End is published by Eland Books, price £9.99.

webTitle: Dino to be honoured on Oscar night

fields.headline: Dino to be honoured on Oscar night
fields.trailText: Dino De Laurentiis, the 82-year-old Italian-born movie producer, will receive the Irving G Thalberg Lifetime Achievement Award for his contribution to the film industry
fields.body:
Veteran producer Dino De Laurentiis will be the recipient of the Irving G Thalberg Lifetime Achievement Award at this year's Oscars. The prestigious statuette - a bust of the late, great MGM producer, who died in 1936 - is one of Hollywood's highest honours. Last year the award went to Warren Beatty.

Italian-born De Laurentiis, 82, who is currently completing work on his latest film, Hannibal, will collect the award in person on March 25. "De Laurentiis's work speaks for itself," Academy president Robert Rehme said yesterday. "His love of, passion for and dedication to making motion pictures has suffused his career. He has always had the courage to make the films that he believes in."

The Irving G Thalberg Memorial Award was established in 1937 (just four years before De Laurentiis made his first movie) to recognise "creative producers whose bodies of work reflect a consistently high quality of motion picture production."

Sceptics, however, may quibble with the term "consistent" in De Laurentiis's case. True, he has either produced or executive produced many film classics, including Blue Velvet, Nights of Cabiria and Serpico. But he has also been responsible for a rash of rather more downmarket affairs: Death Wish, Assassins, Flash Gordon, Amityville 2: The Possession and the 1976 remake of King Kong. During his worst excesses, the De Laurentiis name became, in some quarters, a byword for kitsch and overblown exploiters.

De Laurentiis made his first film L'Amore Canta in 1941 and won the inaugural Best Foreign Film Oscar in 1956 for producing Federico Fellini's La Strada. Since then he has not received a single Oscar nomination. The Thalberg award, however, should make some amends.

fields.headline: White knight for Letsbuyit
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText:
A former hacker is providing Letsbuyit with emergency funds, write John Cassy, Julia Snoddy and Simon Bower.
Jan 19: Reprieve for Letsbuyit.com
Jan 19: Showdown looms for Letsbuyit.com
Jan 17: Letsbuyit.com throws in the towel
Jan 16: Last-minute twist in rescue talks
fields.byline: John Cassy, Julia Snoddy  and  Simon Bowers
fields.body:
A former computer hacker who was sentenced to four years in prison for a series of crimes including changing the credit rating of former German chancellor Helmut Kohl to zero emerged as a white knight for the troubled e-tailer, Letsbuyit.com.

Kim Schmitz, a 27-year-old German who in the late 1990s confessed to hacking into the computers of companies such as US phone group AT&T, has agreed to provide the bulk of a 4m euro (£2.5m) emergency fundraising through his investment vehicle Kimvestor to secure Letsbuyit's short-term future.

Last night he told The Guardian that he was prepared to pump further money into the firm, which is in administration with debts estimated well in excess of 40m euros.

"Letsbuyit is a great company and I would not invest in something I was not absolutely sure of because I don't gamble my money," he said.

"I hope to put in much more soon. The accounts as they are don't matter. Christmas trading figures out soon will be amazing and show how healthy this company could be. With new management Letsbuyit can be great again."

Mr Schmitz said he agreed to provide the funds after being approached by Letsbuyit founder and friend John Palmer. Mr Schmitz said he was hopeful that German media company Pro Siben, which is a large shareholder in Letsbuyit, will also inject further cash.

It is thought that the company needs 40m-80m euros to reach profitability.

Mr Schmitz was given his prison sentence in 1996 after turning himself in to the authorities but was required to serve only three months' probation. "That is all a long time ago now. I am a free man with a white coat," he said.

His wealth has largely come from the sale of an 80% stake in the internet security business Dataprotect he set up after going "legit" in the late 1990s to German credit agency Tuf.

Mr Palmer, last night de scribed Kimvestor as "a large venture capital and start-up company based in Munich with a large fund". He claimed that a "huge amount" of investors are now showing interest in Letsbuyit - which is thought to need a further 30m euros within a few weeks.

Heidi Fitzpatrick, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, questioned the company's ability to generate revenue growth and contain its burn rate - estimated by the trustees to be at 10m euros a month.

"They still need a considerable sum to take the company to break even," she said. "This is going give them a bit of extra time but that is all. They are not off the hook yet."

The company, which has been in crisis since it applied to the Dutch courts for protection against its creditors at the end of last month, has been the subject of a damning report into management practices by the trustees, describing it as "deplorable".

It accused senior executives of appearing to have "no notion" of the "financial obligations of the company" and said it would take three or four experienced accountants a month to make sense of the financial records.

Shares in Letsbuyit ended up 36.84% yesterday at 26 cents. This is still 94% below its 6.45 euro high on its first day of trading in July.

fields.headline: Eidos suffers fresh profit warning
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Computer games company Eidos, creator of cyberbabe Lara Croft, is reeling from yet another profit warning, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games company that created cyberbabe Lara Croft, is reeling from yet another profit warning.

Rough conditions in the US market and continued delays in delivering the PlayStation 2 console have forced the Eidos board to slash its expectations for the company's full-year results.

"The PlayStation console is still the main problem. The small shipment to the UK last year has affected Eidos, which is unfortunate because they had a good Christmas," said an Eidos spokesman.

The maker of the Tomb Raider series was hoping to make a clean break from the events of last year, which saw the resignation of its chief executive and finance director and the issuing of two profit warnings.

The continued absence of PlayStation 2 from UK shops has paralysed the games market and left a hole in the Eidos balance sheet.

Sony, the makers of the hi-tech games machine, will ship 3m units to the UK in April or May.

"When the next shipments come in, we will release new PlayStation games, though we will want to make sure it is a secure market," added the spokesman.

Some good news for the company was supplied by UK and German sales of its Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? game, leading to stronger than expected trading figures in the UK.

The company's shares fell 8%, or 24.75p, to 253.25p in early trading.

fields.headline: Fowler puts Palace in their place
fields.standfirst:
Happy Houllier celebrates first final as errant striker inspires Liverpool
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 5 - 0 Crystal Palace
Captain Fowler crowns five-star display.
fields.body:
To the strains of the unfamiliar anthem, "We're on our way to Cardiff" the long, long wait was finally at an end for Liverpool last night thanks to a performance which saw the recalled Robbie Fowler back to his form of old.

On the 25th day of next month a team which perhaps only now is beginning to awake to its own vast potential will walk out at the Millennium stadium to contest the Worthington Cup final. It will be the Merseyside club's first appearance in a major final since their insipid 1-0 defeat by Manchester United in the 1996 FA Cup.

Having lost the tie's first leg 2-1 a fortnight earlier Liverpool betrayed in their early football an almost tangible sense of desperation.

With Michael Owen missing through injury and Emile Heskey reduced to the role of substitute because of a slight thigh strain the onus was on the reinstated Fowler to produce the deeds to back up a lorry-load of fine and defiant words.

Against a defence which lacked cohesion and seemed awe-struck by the opposition, Fowler looked world-class once again; if only he could play against Palace every week.

"Robbie worked so hard. He is not leaving this club, now you can see why we need four strikers," said Houllier. "Robbie set up two goals and was a key man in a fine team performance. There were times out there when the rest of the players were trying too hard to give him a goal," he added.

"I am a forward and my job is to score goals. I made a few and felt that I did not have a bad game," said Fowler. "I have not played recently, so it's nice to be back on the sheet and scoring goals at Anfield."

The writing was on the Palace wall very early on last night, the relentless red tide washing over a young side's ramparts almost from first whistle to last; it really was as one-sided as that. The visitors did well to emerge unscathed from Liverpool's furious early onslaught. It looked ominous for the First Division side and so it was to prove.

Sadly for Palace, Liverpool were not to be denied and before the first-half had reached its midway point Houllier's boys were disappearing over the hill and into the distance.

Fowler was the architect. After 13 minutes he released Vladimir Smicer down the left with a peach of a pass inside the full-back and the Czech international raced clear to score expertly.

Two minutes on and Liverpool led on aggregate, Murphy volleying home magnificently inside the near post after he had been picked out by Jari Litmanen's exquisite pass to beyond the far one.

Palace barely had time to clear their heads before falling further behind, Igor Biscan galloping clear of a disjointed defence to dispatch Fowler's cheeky backheeled pass. That made three wonderfully taken goals in 5 minutes and all the arguments were over.

Palace, with an average age of 21, were game, dogged in their resistance and their persistence and imbued with enviable self-belief. But they were simply not good enough and were run ragged by a team which never doubted that victory would be theirs.

Murphy skipped his way through the wreckage of the Palace defence to claim his second before Fowler finally found the goal he deserved in the final seconds.

This was Liverpool's night, a non-debatable point under-scored with eight minutes remaining when Palace's Latvian goalkeeper Aleksandrs Kolinko was dismissed, rather harshly, for hauling down Fowler.

webTitle: Charity law in need of a makeover

fields.headline: Charity law in need of a makeover
fields.standfirst: Eton college can be a charity but Greenpeace cannot. There must not be any more delay in changing these 400-year-old charity laws, writes Joe Saxton
fields.trailText: Comment: Eton college can be a charity but Greenpeace cannot. There must not be any more delay in changing these 400-year-old charity laws, writes Joe Saxton
fields.body:
Charity law reform proposals are to be launched at the national council for voluntary organisations (NCVO) conference next month by an advisory group comprising academics, senior charity lawyers and sector practitioners.

The first charity law in England was introduced in 1601 just before the death of Queen Elizabeth I. Four hundred years later our charity law is still based on the same fundamental principles, most notably the four heads of charity - the advance of education, the relief of poverty, advancement of religion and other purposes beneficial to the community - that define charitable activities.

In some people's view the fact that the fundamental tenets of charity law are 400 years old is a cause for celebration. To me, it can only be a cause of despair. The organic growth of charity law has left not-for-profit organisations with an incoherent and unhelpful legal base. The best-known area where charity law is structurally flawed is in what constitutes charitable activity. Eton college can be a charity but Greenpeace cannot. The promotion of the welfare of animals over the welfare of humans is not permitted. Even areas such as the relief of unemployment and urban and rural regeneration only became charitable purposes in the past 18 months.

It isn't just in the area of what constitutes a charitable purpose that the law is outdated. Charities are gagged in their freedom of expression (whereas companies are not) so they are not allowed to campaign on political issues. Unilever can tell you that a political party's policies are bad for the environment, but the World Wildlife Fund cannot.

Worse still, charities are usually subject to two sets of regulators if they are a charity and a company limited by guarantee. This means that both the charity commission regulations and company law applies to most charities. Company law is often highly inappropriate for charities, such as in the application of mass membership. Technically, voting members have to be aware of their liability for £1 in the event of insolvency - not a very appealing way to promote membership.

Company law doesn't recognise trustees, so in the eyes of company law trustees are directors, but they are all volunteers. However the charity commission makes it nearly impossible to pay trustees but insists on trustees taking full legal responsibility for all the activities of a charity. The paid staff have no legal responsibility but the senior ones usually get called directors. It is difficult enough for full-time, paid chief executives and senior staff to know everything going on in a large charity, so how a regulatory framework expects (very) part-time volunteers to do so, is a mystery to me.

If the reforms to be proposed can form the basis of lasting change to charity law introduced over the next decade, after 410 years of charity law we really will have something to celebrate.

fields.headline: Web watchers follow the bear
fields.standfirst: See the ad: Adcritic.com
fields.trailText:
8.30am: An ad for John West salmon has become a cult phenomenon after making its way around the world via email, writes Claire Cozens.
See the ad: Adcritic.com
fields.body:
A British ad for a little-known canned fish brand has become an international cult phenomenon after making its way around the world via email.

For a mere £1m the commercial, for John West salmon, has drawn an audience that many better-known brands can only dream of after it was posted on the influential US website adcritic.com.

The quirky humour of the ad, which shows a giant grizzly bear fighting a fisherman over one of his freshly-caught salmon, appealed to web watchers, who forwarded it to friends via email.

Leo Burnett London, which made the ad, hired the Jim Henson company to make the convincing bear suit, which was designed to enable the stuntman playing the bear to perform a series of kung-fu kicks.

The ad ends with the fisherman escaping with his booty with the help of a well-placed friend on a moped and the line, "We endure the worst to bring you the best".

"I think it's fair to say I was completely astonished by the reaction," said Paul Silburn, who wrote the ad.

"Tinned salmon is not the most inspiring of products to advertise but pretty much as soon as it launched we had retailers calling up to say how much they liked it and when it hit the adcritic site it really went mad."

The ad was the first British commercial to appear on the site and has been its most popular since it was posted in December.

The phenomenon has attracted media coverage as far afield as Australia and the US, although this is not necessarily good news for its UK owners, Heinz, because the brand is owned by rival food company Unilever outside Europe.

John West follows in the famous footsteps of Mahir Cagri, the Turkish teacher who shot to stardom after his personal website was "discovered" by web watchers and forwarded around the world by email.

More recently, Britain's Claire Squires became an overnight celebrity when a risque email she sent to her boyfriend found its way to his friends - and then around the world.

Useful link
Adcritic.com

fields.headline: Hain moved from Foreign Office
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson's demise last night prompted a rushed cabinet and ministerial reshuffle, including the surprise transfer of Peter Hain from the Foreign Office to the relative backwater of energy at the Department of Trade and Industry.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's demise last night prompted a rushed cabinet and ministerial reshuffle, including the surprise transfer of Peter Hain from the Foreign Office to the relative backwater of energy at the Department of Trade and Industry.

Although Mr Hain will be reluctant to give up his Africa brief, he now has the important role of pursuing the economic reform agenda in the European Union, seen by some as a precursor to British membership of the euro.

Mr Hain, who this week had published a highly praised pamphlet on the end of foreign policy, replaces Helen Liddell. Ms Liddell, the former Labour Scottish party general secretary, joins the cabinet as Scottish secretary, the post held by John Reid.

A novelist and former employee of Robert Maxwell, Ms Liddell is a hard-edged negotiator and will strengthen the Scottish Labour election campaign. There have been reports of conflicts between Downing Street and Henry McLeish, who became first minister after the death of Donald Dewar.

The transfer of Mr Hain could be seen as an attempt to shift a potential critic of the new Republican president George Bush. A member of CND, Mr Hain has been open in his criticism of a son of Star Wars, although he has been careful to keep open the government's options on the still unclear US proposal for a national missile defence system, the single most sensitive issue in future Anglo-US relations. Mr Blair said yesterday that the issue needed to be placed in a box labelled "handle with care".

The shift could also be seen as a chance to widen Mr Hain's experience before a post-election reshuffle.

Mr Hain is replaced by the Scottish minister of state Brian Wilson. A Blairite and a former trade minister, he is relatively well-travelled.

fields.bodyText: Peter Mandelson's demise last night prompted a rushed cabinet and ministerial reshuffle, including the surprise transfer of Peter Hain from the Foreign Office to the relative backwater of energy at the Department of Trade and Industry. Although Mr Hain will be reluctant to give up his Africa brief, he now has the important role of pursuing the economic reform agenda in the European Union, seen by some as a precursor to British membership of the euro. Mr Hain, who this week had published a highly praised pamphlet on the end of foreign policy, replaces Helen Liddell. Ms Liddell, the former Labour Scottish party general secretary, joins the cabinet as Scottish secretary, the post held by John Reid. A novelist and former employee of Robert Maxwell, Ms Liddell is a hard-edged negotiator and will strengthen the Scottish Labour election campaign. There have been reports of conflicts between Downing Street and Henry McLeish, who became first minister after the death of Donald Dewar. The transfer of Mr Hain could be seen as an attempt to shift a potential critic of the new Republican president George Bush. A member of CND, Mr Hain has been open in his criticism of a son of Star Wars, although he has been careful to keep open the government's options on the still unclear US proposal for a national missile defence system, the single most sensitive issue in future Anglo-US relations. Mr Blair said yesterday that the issue needed to be placed in a box labelled "handle with care". The shift could also be seen as a chance to widen Mr Hain's experience before a post-election reshuffle. Mr Hain is replaced by the Scottish minister of state Brian Wilson. A Blairite and a former trade minister, he is relatively well-travelled. fields.headline: A dead end no longer
fields.standfirst:
A reform to make school more relevant

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: With luck - and prolonged commitment - the plans outlined yesterday for vocational education could become an historic social reform.
fields.body:
With luck - and prolonged commitment - the plans outlined yesterday for vocational education could become an historic social reform. No group of children suffers worse handicaps in our schools than non-academic pupils. The cost - to individuals as well as to the country - of this deep divide between academic and vocational education was laid bare earlier this week in a grim report from the basic skills agency. The numbers are almost unbelievable: 7m adults unable to read and write as well as the average 11-year-old; one in five adults of working age unable to look up a plumber in the yellow pages, or read the instructions on a medicine bottle. Even more have trouble with numbers.

These are not new statistics. They have been set out in report after report. One cause is the historic divide between academic and vocational education. Compared with what happens in continental Europe, vocational education has always had low esteem in Britain. One result has been a critical shortage of skilled workers. Another has been much lower productivity here than in France, Germany and the Netherlands. The problem begins at 14. There is little on offer for non-academic children. They are able to take a general national vocational qualification (GNVQ), but there is no evidence that employers value them, and masses of evidence that pupils dislike them. And for good reason: they do not lead anywhere. Hence their dismal completion rate: a mere 40%. Disaffection is rife with a system that is still geared to encouraging everyone to pursue the academic - including a ludicrous target of 95% achieving at least one GCSE, as though an F in one subject will get anyone anywhere. No wonder there is such a steep rise in truancy by non-academic children in older age groups.

Belatedly all this is to change. David Blunkett's vocational plan will offer 14-year-olds a positive choice, rather than a second class fall back position. New links are to be made between schools, further education colleges, and work places. GNVQs were meant to be work-related, but had few work-related elements. They will be replaced by vocational GCSEs. Standards will be monitored to raise their esteem. There will be no GCSE in plumbing, but there will be a GCSE in applied technology that will gain access to apprenticeships. Construction industry estimates suggest we need an extra 30,000 plumbers and 35,000 new electricians in the next five years. Both trades pay more than does teaching.

The programme will begin in a modest way - 40,000 part time placements in 2002/3 - but this is probably wise. To succeed, it has to win the support of employers. Better to begin modestly, and demonstrate success. The second key test of the reform is ensuring that the courses provide a genuine career ladder for the non-academic. Their needs have been overlooked for too long.

webTitle: Barak resumes peace talks as Israel buries shot restaurateurs

fields.headline: Barak resumes peace talks as Israel buries shot restaurateurs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
The Israeli cabinet decided last night to resume peace
talks with the Palestinians, a day after suspending the
negotiations because of the killing of two Israelis
visiting the West Bank. A government statement said
the talks would resume this afternoon in the Egyptian
resort of Taba, after the funeral of the two in Haifa.
fields.body:
The Israeli cabinet decided last night to resume peace talks with the Palestinians, a day after suspending the negotiations because of the killing of two Israelis visiting the West Bank. A government statement said the talks would resume this afternoon in the Egyptian resort of Taba, after the funeral of the two in Haifa.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, recalled the leaders of his negotiating team for consultations after the joint owners of a Tel Aviv sushi bar were killed by masked gunmen.

Motti Dayan, 27, and Etgar Zeituni, 36, were abducted and shot dead after entering the city of Tulkarem, looking for supplies for their restaurant.

"They went to eat houmus and were murdered," Yediot Ahronoth, Israel's biggest selling Hebrew language daily, said yesterday. Radio chat shows spent hours discussing the final moments of the men, who were cousins.

The Palestinian negotiators spent yesterday alone in Taba, waiting to hear whether Mr Barak would send his team back. Although he has decided to do so, his advisers admit that he is going through the motions of talks to polish his image as a peacemaker before Israel's prime ministerial election on February 6.

On chat shows and in parliament, Israelis strove to understand how the two Tel Aviv restaurateurs could have been so oblivious to the explosive situation in the West Bank.

Although the Palestinian uprising seeped into Israel's coastal area weeks ago, with the bus bombings in Tel Aviv and Netanya, the toll of more than 370 deaths had little impact on Sheinkin Street, a strip of cafes and boutiques which is the preserve of bohemians who would rather talk about the beach than politics.

Yesterday, as death notices were pasted in the windows of Yuppies, the cafe the men jointly owned, a handful of rightwing protesters arrived to jeer at the quarter's habitues for ever believing there could be peace with the Palestinians.

Friends of the two also had doubts. "Etgar had a lot of Arab Israeli friends. He be lieved in peace and coexistence but he seems to have been wrong," a woman called Irit told Yediot.

The two visited Tulkarem with an Israeli Arab business colleague to stock up on pots and plants for their cafe, taking advantage of the lower prices in the West Bank. They were marched from a restaurant at gunpoint by four masked men and shot dead. The military wing of Hamas, the Islamist group, said it killed them.

Since the uprising began in September, Israelis have been forbidden to visit the West Bank. It is easy to get around the ban and the army roadblocks, but very few Israeli reporters have bothered. Local press coverage of the uprising has been based overwhelmingly on government and army sources.

Although the killing of the cafe owners was the main story yesterday, no one linked their death with the murder of a middle-aged Palestinian dentist, Thabet Thabet, by the Israeli security forces in Tulkarem on January 1.

Nor was much attention paid to a Palestinian woman who died of a heart attack yesterday when Israeli soldiers at a checkpoint stopped the car taking her to hospital. Aisha Abdel-Karim Nassar, 28, was detained for 45 minutes near Ramallah and died there, said Moussa Abu Hmeid, the director of West Bank hospitals.

Despite such media self-censorship, the army said there was no excuse for casual outings to the West Bank.

"Whoever does not understand the reality here of the last four months has been out of the country or has not left the house," Brigadier Ron Kitrey said.

Israeli military officials said yesterday that there were two Palestinian infiltration attempts during the day. Israeli troops shot one man dead and wounded another after spotting three Palestinians infiltrating Rafiah Yam, an Israeli settlement in Gaza.

And two Palestinians were tracked and captured after soldiers discovered a break in the fence around an Israeli village, Holit.
