webTitle: Immigration is Britain's biggest social change

fields.headline: Immigration is Britain's biggest social change
fields.trailText: The chief statistician yesterday identified a rise in immigration as the most significant social change in Britain of recent years.
fields.body:
The chief statistician yesterday identified a rise in immigration as the most significant social change in Britain of recent years.

Len Cook, the former head of New Zealand's statistical service who took over as the UK national statistician in July, said population patterns through most of the 20th century had changed dramatically during the 1990s as migration became the main engine of population growth.

The figures came in Social Trends, the official annual digest of facts and figures about life in Britain. It also showed growing inequalities between rich and poor, mounting consumer debt and increasing use of credit cards instead of cash or cheques.

Mr Cook said "homegrown" population increases - the surplus of births over deaths - hugely exceeded net migration into the UK from 1900 to 1990. Indeed for much of the century there was a net outflow of people. But between 1991 and 1999 net immigration averaged 104,000 a year, compared with a homegrown population rise averaging 107,000.

Mr Cook said the change was particularly stark in the closing years of the century, when migration became the predominant demographic influence. Immigration overtook natural population growth in England and Wales in 1994-95. By 1998-99 net inward migration increased to 194,000, while natural population growth fell to 72,000. "This amounts to a huge shift in the importance of immigration to changes in the British population, with consequences for ethnic mix and age structure," he said.

"Since immigrants go disproportionately to London, it will also affect where people live."

The immigrants came mainly from outside the European Union. Refugees who were granted asylum or given leave to stay made up a small proportion - just over 10,000 in 1999. On Monday the Home Office forecast between 150,000 and 175,000 immigrants from outside the EU each year until 2005.

Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, said: "The UK is a nation of immigrants. Immigration is a very good thing and has benefited the country." Advantages included skills brought by workers needed by the expanding information technology industry, and the younger age profile of immigrants that would help to balance the pressures of an ageing population.

Social Trends estimated that the UK population would rise from 59.5m in 1999 to peak at nearly 65m in 2036. Population growth in England, Wales and Northern Ireland would be partly offset by a slight fall in Scotland.

The survey said the British population had increased by more than half during the 20th century, but the number of households tripled in the same period to almost 24m in spring 2000.

Almost three in 10 households comprised one person in spring 2000 - more than two and a half times the proportion in 1961.

There were 179,000 first marriages in the UK in 1999 - less than half the number in 1970. The average age of women at childbirth in England and Wales rose over the same period from 26.2 years to 29.

The survey found that the distribution of income became more unequal in the 80s, stabilised in the early 90s and began to widen again in 1997. In 1997-98 the income of the richest 10% rose 4% to £559.70 a week, while for the poorest it rose only 1.8% to £136.10.

Latest official figures for 1998 showed that Britain was the most expensive European country outside Scandinavia. A British resident would find goods and services at least 10% cheaper in Italy and the Netherlands, and more than 20% cheaper in Spain, Greece and Portugal.

The amount of consumer credit outstanding in the UK increased to £115bn in 1999, almost double the 1987 level in real terms. The volume of cash payments fell during the 1990s but still accounted for two-thirds of all transactions.

Plastic card payments tripled, cash withdrawals doubled and there was a 75% increase in direct debits, standing orders and other automated payments. Payments by cheque declined by a quarter. About one in five debit card purchases in supermarkets involved cashback, with an average value of £24.

The survey came on the bicentenary of the first British census. In 1801 there were about 10m people in Britain and about 2m households. Since then population has increased by nearly six times and the number of households by 12 times. In 1821 half the population was aged under 20, compared with a quarter in 1999.

The nation by numbers

Social Trends, a 268-page snapshot of UK life published by the office of national statistics, contains 321 tables and charts. Here are some of the facts they contain:

 Between 1981 and 1999 the number of GPs in Britain rose by a third to 36,000. But the number of nurses and other direct care staff in NHS hospitals and community health services fell by 4%

 The proportion of three- and four-year-olds enrolled in UK schools tripled from 21% in 1970-71 to 64% in 1999-00. In spring 2000, 5.7m people of working age were studying towards a qualification in the UK, just over half of whom were aged 16-24

 The consumption of fresh potatoes has fallen steadily from 1,300 grams a person a week in 1974 to less than 700 grams in 1999. But fresh fruit consumption rose over the same period from 500 grams to nearly 750 grams

 In 1999 about 276,000 hectares of land had been converted, or were in the process of being converted, to organic farming. This was six times more than in 1995

 In spring 2000 there were 27m people of working age in employment in the UK - the most since 1959 when records began. Over that period the proportion of men in work fell to 79% while the proportion of women rose from 47% to 69%

 Among non-married women under 60, the proportion cohabiting almost doubled between 1986 and 1998-99 - from 13% to 25%. For men it more than doubled from 11% to 26%

 Three-quarters of adults agree that "families with working mothers need grandparents' help more and more". One in 10 said grandparents have "little to teach the grandchildren of today"

 A third of domestic water in England and Wales was used for personal washing, including baths, showers and hand basins. A quarter - between 35 and 45 litres a head a day - was used for flushing the toilet, according to environment agency statistics for 1997-98.

 The proportion of houses fitted with a burglar alarm doubled between 1992 and 2000, from 13% to 26%

 The breeding population of woodpigeons doubled between 1971 and 1999, while great tits, chaffinches and robins were up by at least a quarter. But the population of skylarks, yellowhammers and song thrushes fell by more than half and starlings declined by 65%

 In spring 2000, there were 855,000 people working in IT-related occupations, an increase of 45% in five years. In 1999-00 two in five UK households had a PC - almost three times as many as in 1985

webTitle: Internet twins' natural father wants children back

fields.headline: Internet twins' natural father wants children back
fields.standfirst: The battle over the fate of the internet twins became a four-way fight yesterday after the babies' real father was granted custody by a judge in their home town, St Louis, Missouri.
fields.trailText: The battle over the fate of the internet twins became a four-way fight yesterday after the babies' real father was granted custody by a judge in their home town, St Louis, Missouri.
fields.body:
The battle over the fate of the internet twins became a four-way fight yesterday after the babies' real father was granted custody by a judge in their home town, St Louis, Missouri.

Circuit judge Jack Garvey granted the custody order, effective until the court's next hearing on February 14, to Aaron Wecker, father of the girls and former husband of Tranda Wecker, who "sold" them twice over the internet.

Mr Wecker, who has custody of the couple's three-year-old child, joins the battle against his ex-wife, who says she wants them back, and with the two couples who paid a California-based agency to adopt them.

Kimberley and Belinda, were first given to a California couple, Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernardino, then handed over to Alan and Judith Kilshaw, by Ms Wecker after they agreed to pay more.

Court papers filed by Mr Wecker last Monday allege that Ms Wecker neglected the twins by trying to sell them twice, according to the St Louis Post-Dispatch. He also accused her of "failing to report to me on the whereabouts of the children for weeks at a time, subjecting the twins to illegal activities and underhanded doings." The pair divorced before the twins were born last June.

The order in favour of Mr Wecker has no immediate effect because the twins remain in foster care after being taken from the Kilshaws by Flintshire social services. The Kilshaws adopted the twins in Arkansas, although the adoption may be invalid because Ms Wecker has admitting lying to get around the state's residence requirements.

The twist is another complication for Mr Justice Kirkwood, the high court judge who took over the case last Tuesday. He has promised a decision soon on the twins' future.

Allan Levy QC, a child law expert, said the real father might emerge as the right person to give them a home. "If he's the natural father and he's OK, the sooner they go there the better."

Ms Wecker said on Tuesday that she wanted the babies back. "I have a job. I have family and friends that will help me take care of my children," she said. "I miss my girls very much."

webTitle: Call for radical shake up of Scots mental health laws

fields.headline: Call for radical shake up of Scots mental health laws
fields.trailText: Proposals for the most radical shake up of mental health law in Scotland for more than 15 years were published today, including new arrangements for the compulsory care and treatment of people with mental health problems.
fields.body:
Proposals for the most radical shake up of mental health law in Scotland for more than 15 years were published today, including new arrangements for the compulsory care and treatment of people with mental health problems.

A report by the government-sponsored Millan committee calls for a new Mental Health Act to be introduced north of the border, together with reforms that will enable new community orders to allow patients to be compulsorily treated in the community.

The Scottish executive welcomed the review and announced that a major policy statement would be published this summer setting out proposals for legislative change.

But its recommendations on compulsory treatment in the community - similar to those proposed in mental health reforms for England last month - were criticised by mental health charity Mental Health Foundation as "unworkable and impracticable".

The Millan committee, chaired by former Scottish secretary Bruce Millan, was set up by the then Scottish health minister Sam Galbraith two years ago to review the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984.

Mr Millan said: "We believe that a new act is required, reflecting the huge changes in mental health care in recent years, and the greater recognition of the rights of mental health service users and their families.

"Compulsion should be justified by clear and specific criteria. Linking compulsory treatment to a specific plan of care is a flexible approach which should help to ensure that patients receive the treatment that they need, without unnecessary use of legal measures.

"In particular, it should be possible for compulsory treatment to be delivered in the community rather than hospital, where this is the best option for the individual patient."

The report also calls for a new independent tribunal to replace sheriff courts in considering compulsory measures, and for the system of dealing with mentally disordered offenders to be reformed, including new arrangements for discharging restricted patients.

"For the small number of people with mental disorders who commit serious offences, there needs to be a more systematic approach to risk assessment and management. The Risk Management Authority, proposed by the MacLean committee, would have a role in this," said Mr Millan.

Scottish health minister Susan Deacon said the executive would deliver changes to both strengthen the rights of people with mental illness and secure a comprehensive framework of measures to protect the community from the small number of mentally disordered offenders who posed a risk to the public.

National Schizophrenia Fellowship (Scotland) welcomed the principles of participation of service users in all aspects of their assessment, care, treatment and support, coupled with recognition and respect for those providing informal care.

"We particularly welcome the recommendation that a new act should be based on principles which should underpin any intervention, with benefit for the service user being the main criterion for compulsory measures, rather than 'treatability', as at present," said spokesman Ian Harper.

The Association of Directors of Social Work welcomed the review's recommendation that adequate resources should be made available.

"In its submission, ADSW argued strongly for the retention of social work-qualified mental health officers being appointed by local authorities, and are pleased to see this in the report," said spokesman Duncan MacAulay.

The British Association of Social Workers said the review took a more holistic approach than proposals in England, which were very much focused on risk assessment. "Unlike south of the border, where the role of the approved social worker has been diminished, it is an endorsement of the social work contribution," said professional officer Ruth Stark.

webTitle: Main points of Scottish Mental Health Act review

fields.headline: Main points of Scottish Mental Health Act review
fields.trailText: The main points of the Millan committee review of the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984:
fields.body:
The main points of the Millan committee review of the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984:

 A new Mental Health Act, incorporating a statement of basic principles, to replace the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984.

 Compulsory care and treatment to be only be used as a last resort, and linked to a plan of care for the patient.

 Some patients to be compulsorily treated in the community rather than hospital.

 A new independent tribunal, replacing the role of the sheriff court, to consider compulsory measures.

 Rights of carers to be clarified and strengthened.

 Reforms to the system for dealing with mentally disordered offenders, including new arrangements for the discharge of restricted patients.

 New legislation, accompanied by adequate resources for mental health services, if the measures are to succeed.

webTitle: Classic pop pushes out boy and girl bands on Virgin Radio

fields.headline: Classic pop pushes out boy and girl bands on Virgin Radio
fields.trailText: Virgin Radio is to ditch boy and girl bands such as All Saints and Boyzone in favour of tracks for the 'musically disenfranchised', writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The pop kids of Popstars may be dominating the TV schedules, but radio listeners are fed up with candy music culture.

As ITV yesterday announced extra weekday episodes of its docu-soap sensation Popstars, Virgin Radio said it would ditch indistinct boy and girl bands such as All Saints and Boyzone in favour of tracks for the "musically disenfranchised".

The network said listeners aged 30-40 were not being adequately served, as the boundaries between contemporary and classic pop music became blurred. In the light of market research, it is refocusing its music policy on classic pop and rock, ditching teen-appeal bands.

Henry Owens, Virgin's programme director, said: "The amount of chart music being played is incompatible with what a large percentage of adults want from their radio station. Listeners want the choice of the great music of today as well as the classic rock and pop songs.

"The majority of radio stations have responded to the trend for manufactured music, competing for a younger age profile of 15-24 and cluttering the market with stations with little point of differentiation."

ITV, meanwhile, announced an extension to the run of Popstars, a hit with youth audiences. It will repeat the Saturday teatime show, in which a five member band is selected from more than 3,000 hopefuls, on Mondays at 11.30pm from next week. It will also screen an extra episode at 8pm next Wednesday.

ITV originally planned to disclose the final five, who will win a record deal from Polydor, on February 10. The rescheduling means that the band's identity will be revealed in a double episode on February 3.

Last weekend the Sunday People claimed to disclose the final band line-up. LWT, which makes the show, refused to confirm the claim, pointing out that a clutch of hopefuls had been "revealed" in the tabloids in the past week.

A spokesman said: "Interest from the press and public has been so overwhelming that we want to reveal the band as soon as possible. We don't want them turning up in the tabloids first and spoiling the fun for our viewers."

webTitle: G2: Stephen Moss meets Trevor McDonald

fields.headline: Clever Trevor
fields.standfirst:
With News at Ten back in its rightful slot and winning the ratings war, Trevor McDonald is a happy man. Stephen Moss finds him warmer and wittier than he is on TV

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: With News at Ten back in its rightful slot and winning the ratings war, Trevor McDonald is a happy man. Stephen Moss finds him warmer and wittier than he is on TV.
fields.body:
Trevor McDonald is visibly pleased to be back in the old routine. News At Ten has returned to its time-honoured slot, and on the first night, with a bit of help from Chris Tarrant, had almost double the audience of its BBC rival. Sir Trevor - McDonald seems rather cold for this living-room presence - feels vindicated: the power of the News at Ten "brand" has been demonstrated and ITV, rapped on the knuckles by the regulator, won't be shifting it again in a hurry.

"In the last few days before it came back, I could hardly walk down the street without being accosted by at least a dozen people," he says. "The programme has a strong hold on the public imagination and it's nice to be part of that. There was a big campaign to bring it back, but there hasn't been the same campaign to bring back the Nine O'Clock News, which is also a venerable institution."

Sir Trevor's part in that campaign was a little ambiguous. He was clearly never happy with the decision to shift the late-evening broadcast to 11pm, but reluctantly went along with it. "I never opposed the move," he says. "If I'd opposed it as strongly as people said, I wouldn't still be working here. I did the 6:30 broadcast and I quite enjoyed working in the early evening despite what people think, but I'm glad News at Ten is back."

And back with a bang, if not a bong. Yesterday came the first big test, with the resignation of Peter Mandelson, and ITV quickly OK-ed ITN's request for a longer bulletin. "ITV gave me a commitment that when there were big stories it would be possible to extend the broadcast," McDonald told me as the Mandelson story unfolded. "Whenever there is a big story, we will extend. ITV recognise the value of news. We did some programmes at nine o'clock during the floods and 11 million people watched them."

On a run-of-the-mill day, 16 or 17 minutes will have to suffice, but Sir Trevor reckons that will suffice. "You have to get more into less, but I think we can do that. The multi-media environment is changing people's habits, and people watch TV news programmes for shorter times now."

The switch back to 10pm has been a major climbdown for ITV's executives, who had spent 10 years wheeler-dealing around government, regulators and viewers to shift News at Ten out to 11pm. An audience of six million had been deemed unsatisfactory; now, it seems, they would be reasonably happy with that. The programme is guaranteed to be on at 10pm three times a week; ITV has the option to move it to 10.30pm once a week; and it will be on at 11pm on Friday. In a nice post-modern touch, it will be called News at Ten regardless of what time it goes out.

McDonald was a dignified part of the mourning process in 1998 when the News at When? debacle began. The Independent Television Commission (ITC) had the power to reverse the decision, though it seemed unlikely that it would do so, but eventually it told ITV that the decline in news audiences was too great and News at Ten must return.

In the meantime, the BBC had announced it would move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, a change it made late last year. Its new-look schedule initially triumphed, with help from Men in Black and The Royle Family, and then began to lose out as soon as BBC1 ran out of its top programmes. Viewing figures for news broadcasts are not primarily about the news, or even who reads it, but what is on before the news. Save for the odd petrol crisis, when viewers will watch wall-to-wall news to find out how to fill up the Micra, our choice of which bulletin to watch is governed principally by what we are watching immediately beforehand.

With head to head bulletins, the BBC knew there was no chance of beating ITV. Senior executives have been briefing journalists for weeks that the programmes in primetime were not really up to the job of beating ITV bankers such as Who wants to be a Millionaire? and Peak Practice. BBC1 still lacks the popular drama hits which sit in primetime and produce healthy lead-in audiences to news bulletins.

On the first night of the new News at Ten, Sir Trevor achieved 8.1m, with a handy 12.8m leg-up from Chris Tarrant. On BBC1, Peter Sissons had less help from Second Sight - one of the worst-performing dramas the BBC has made in recent times - and managed just 4.4m viewers. On Tuesday, Peak Practice handed nearly 9m viewers over to Trevor, who kept 5.9m of them. Sissons, still struggling with Second Sight, which itself lost viewers from Monday to Tuesday, got 4.3m.

Unless the BBC's performance improves, it is sure to come under pressure to move its broadcast back to nine, a move McDonald would support. "I'm not sure how well the audience is served at the moment," he says tentatively. "I prefer choice, personally."

Sir Trevor is the soul of decorum, but can't help crowing a little at News at Ten's performance. "It is slightly churlish of our opponents, to write off an audience of 8m. Never do that. Don't ever suggest that people are stupid enough to watch the opposition."

He also mocks the complaints about letting Who Wants to be a Millionaire overrun to deter channel switching. "ITV have done that before. That's nothing new. These guys are a commercial channel. They play for audiences. They do all sorts of things like that. People seem to think this was a ploy for the return of News at Ten, but they've been doing it for several months - missing the commercial break and so on.

"I don't have any deep inside knowledge of what ITV now calls 'junction management', but they've been doing this for some time. They want to get more people watching their programmes than the BBC's. This may be revolutionary news to the BBC, but I assure you it is ITV's intent."

This rumbustious statement, and the laughter that accompanies it, is delivered with great animation. Much more animation, in fact, than he ever displays when presenting the news, which seems a great shame. He is far warmer and wittier in person than on the screen, where it's all gravitas; his voice also seems more lyrical than when he broadcasts. Why the difference? "One is natural, the other one isn't," he says succinctly. "Going into a studio and reading off an autocue is not terribly natural. It's a performance. It's not like slipping down to the pub."

McDonald has been the public face of ITN for so long - almost 20 years - that he has perhaps forgotten how to show his private face. In his little glass-walled office at ITN's London headquarters, from where he is able to keep a beady eye on News at Ten editor Nigel Dacre, he is full of fun, happy to explain why he was so po-faced about Noel Edmonds' Gotcha ("I was tired after presenting a three-hour awards show and didn't have a clue what was going on") and easy to talk to, not a bit like the voice-of-the-nation image. He would like to do a chatshow at some point, and he would probably be pretty good at it.

He is 61 now, enjoying this second coming, but aware that retirement from ITN and his beloved News at Ten isn't too far away. "I have a contract until I'm 65, and that will probably be enough. They will probably have seen enough of me by then. It's a great art to know when to go. It would be awful to hang around, with people whispering about you in the corridors. It would be really sad after you've had such a great time. Go quickly when the time comes - that's the best advice. But I won't retire completely. The concept of retire ment as stasis, when you do absolutely nothing is not one I understand." Which is where he hopes the chat shows and one-off interviews come in.

He is healthy, plays tennis, and doesn't spend quite as long in the ITN building as he used to. He arrives at lunchtime, attends all the meetings and starts tinkering with his script around seven. "If you are going to make this thing your own, if you are going to stamp your personality on it, you have to be comfortable with what you are saying," he explains.

He rejects accusations, levelled by former ITN political editor Michael Brunson in the London Evening Standard this week, that News at Ten is following a tabloid agenda. "We try to tailor the stories we tell to the audiences," says McDonald. "When I was doing the 6.30 broadcast, there was a kind of consumer riff to some of the stories because we thought that was what people watching at that time would want to see. The three or four foreign stories we ran on News at Ten on Tuesday night would never have run on the 6.30 when parents are feeding their children. It's much too early to talk about News at Ten being tabloid. It never has been, and I don't think it ever will be."

McDonald, who came to the UK from Trinidad in 1970 to work as a producer for the BBC World Service and found his home at ITN in 1973, has been accused of becoming a pillar of the establishment, of forgetting his and not making a public stand against racism in his adopted country. He denies that he has attempted to disown his past - "I am and will always be West Indian," he says proudly - and explains his refusal to become the mouthpiece of anti-racism in terms of his career.

"When I came to ITN, I was not unaware of the fact that I was being hired as the first black reporter. One of the conditions I made was that I was not going to be sent to Brixton to do token black stories. I started travelling round the world, and became very detached from things which were happening in this country. I hardly did any domestic stories and even they were mainly in northern Ireland, and I don't believe in holding forth about things that you can't talk about with authority."

McDonald was the son of highly aspirational parents and one of a generation of highly anglicised West Indians determined to make their way in the world. His father was a refinery engineer and his mother a strong, poetry-quoting woman who insisted he speak proper English. Their hopes were pinned firmly on their first-born son, and they were disappointed when he gave up law to go into journalism, though they were eventually reconciled to the move.

If only they could be watching ITV this evening, when News at Ten, fronted by their son, is followed by Tonight With Trevor McDonald. "It's terribly nice [an urbane piece of understatement] to be able to present the flagship ITN news programme at 10 o'clock and then the flagship ITN current affairs programme immediately after. If anybody had said that to me 30 years ago when I was in Trinidad, I'd have said, 'You must be joking. You must be smoking something odd'."

Their hopes were pinned firmly on their first-born son, and they were disappointed when he gave up law to go into journalism, though they were eventually reconciled to the move. If only they could be watching ITV this evening, when News at Ten, fronted by their son, is followed by Tonight With Trevor McDonald. "It's terribly nice [an urbane piece of understatement] to be able to present the flagship ITN news programme at 10 o'clock and then the flagship ITN current affairs programme immediately after. If anybody had said that to me 30 years ago when I was in Trinidad, I'd have said, 'You must be joking. You must be smoking something odd'."

fields.headline: Analyst cuts ITV ad forecasts
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The City analyst who created havoc in Granada Media shares by a downgrade last autumn cut his forecasts again yesterday, predicting that ITV advertising would decline 1.5% this year.
fields.body:
The City analyst who created havoc in Granada Media shares by a downgrade last autumn cut his forecasts again yesterday, predicting that ITV advertising would decline 1.5% this year.

Merrill Lynch media analyst Neil Blackley produced a gloomy adjustment in his projection for the coming year, reducing his estimates on advertising growth on the network from growth of 2.5% to minus 1.5%. His forecast on pre-tax profits for Granada Media in 2001 was cut from £101m to £79m. Fellow ITV company Carlton Communications was also hit with the headline pre-tax profit forecast reduced to £36m from £68m.

The analyst, however, who has been elevated to celebrity status in the City stuck to his recommendation on both stocks of "accumulate".

Mr Blackley triggered a run on Granada Media shares - which were then at a level of 573p - in September, when he slashed his profits estimate for the broadcaster, citing the "softness" of ITV advertising. But last week he said the shares, now at 425p, represent good value.

Yesterday Granada shares edged 7.5p higher to 397.5p, still well below the offer price of 515p last summer and the peak of 676p. Carlton showed a 7p improvement to 548.5p, both suggesting that investors had already factored the slowdown into the shares.

webTitle: Classic pop pushes out boy and girl bands on Virgin Radio

fields.headline: Classic pop pushes out boy and girl bands on Virgin Radio
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The pop kids of Popstars may be dominating the TV schedules, but radio listeners are fed up with candy music culture.
fields.body:
The pop kids of Popstars may be dominating the TV schedules, but radio listeners are fed up with candy music culture.

As ITV yesterday announced extra weekday episodes of its docu-soap sensation Popstars, Virgin Radio said it would ditch indistinct boy and girl bands such as All Saints and Boyzone in favour of tracks for the "musically disenfranchised".

The network said listeners aged 30-40 were not being adequately served, as the boundaries between contemporary and classic pop music became blurred. In the light of market research, it is refocusing its music policy on classic pop and rock, ditching teen-appeal bands.

Henry Owens, Virgin's programme director, said: "The amount of chart music being played is incompatible with what a large percentage of adults want from their radio station. Listeners want the choice of the great music of today as well as the classic rock and pop songs.

"The majority of radio stations have responded to the trend for manufactured music, competing for a younger age profile of 15-24 and cluttering the market with stations with little point of differentiation."

ITV, meanwhile, announced an extension to the run of Popstars, a hit with youth audiences. It will repeat the Saturday teatime show, in which a five member band is selected from more than 3,000 hopefuls, on Mondays at 11.30pm from next week. It will also screen an extra episode at 8pm next Wednesday.

ITV originally planned to disclose the final five, who will win a record deal from Polydor, on February 10. The rescheduling means that the band's identity will be revealed in a double episode on February 3.

Last weekend the Sunday People claimed to disclose the final band line-up. LWT, which makes the show, refused to confirm the claim, pointing out that a clutch of hopefuls had been "revealed" in the tabloids in the past week.

A spokesman said: "Interest from the press and public has been so overwhelming that we want to reveal the band as soon as possible. We don't want them turning up in the tabloids first and spoiling the fun for our viewers."

webTitle: Past and present media sport coverage

fields.headline: The boy Marconi done good
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Past and present media sport coverage.
fields.body:
There was a rueful irony in two downpage reports in this newspaper yesterday. A news page told of celebrations in Cornwall to mark the precise centenary the day before of the first long-distance wireless "broadcast" - the 200-mile message delivered to the Lizard from the Isle of Wight by the Italian Guglielmo Marconi - and these sports pages told of a commercial row which may threaten television coverage of England's upcoming tour of Sri Lanka.

That is a hundred years to show how money, not enlightenment, really keeps the score in sport - although I daresay Marconi might have approved. He was as much fat-cat businessman as far-seeing inventor.

Unquestionably the excitement at the Lizard 100 Januaries ago was to trigger a fundamental revolution for sport and games. Mind you, after that wintry Cornish breakthrough in 1901 it took an awful long time for sport and broadcasting even to make eyes at each other. And, when they did, the relationship seldom made for cosy cohabitation.

Nor has it always been money that has come between them. For instance, three-score years after Marconi's 200-mile Eureka the Football League still maintained a total ban on any live radio broadcasting of its matches, however much it was offered; and, when it did allow one experimental televised match to be covered - Bolton v Blackpool in 1960 - the 0-0 draw had the League at once reimposing its prohibition, "intensely worried," as it put it, "that broadcasting such boring matches could seriously damage the game's image". (Oh, for such philosophic generosity now).

Marconi's historic broadcast on January 23 1901 transmitted only Morse code dots and dashes, as did his first transatlantic signal from Cornwall to Newfoundland in December that same year. The first long-range voice-speaking "entertainment" radio broadcast was on Christmas Eve five years later when the Canadian inventor Reginald Fessenden accompanied on his violin an un-named female voice singing Silent Night and from transmission at Brant Rock, Massachusetts, it was heard by a wireless operator on board a United Fruit company's banana boat in mid-Atlantic.

Sport did not catch on till 1916 - and then only by the by when sponsors on the first experimental "wireless station", New York's thrice-a-week 2XG, began randomly mentioning that night's baseball scores between playing scratchy phonograph recordings.

In 1919 two New York reporters transmitted by wireless the result to their papers from Toledo of Jack Dempsey's third-round slam-dunk of Jess Willard. Two years later, on July 2 1921, Dempsey's successful title defence against Georges Carpentier in New Jersey is generally accepted as the first live wireless commentary of a sports event - at the microphone was a Major Andrew White - although the fact is that, for practice and by way of a technical run-through, he had begun commentating towards the end of the previous, preliminary, bout, so in fact it is two unknown pugs, Packie O'Gatty and Frankie Burns, who should be indelible in history.

In Australia the following winter a reporter named Len Watt was dispatched with a microphone from Sydney's pioneering 2BL wireless station and told to "stand on the boundary and keep talking" about Charles Bannerman's testimonial match at the SCG.

Britain caught on five years later, when the BBC covered, live, the England v Wales rugby international in January 1927, followed at once that spring with the Boat Race and Cup final and, in October, its first ringside boxing commentary - Teddy Baldock v Willie Smith at the Royal Albert Hall - a fortnight after which a letter in the Radio Times summed up, for sport anyway, this Tuesday's Marconi centenary: "... cosmic, a wonder, a miracle, as I followed each three minutes seated in an armchair with a cigarette".

fields.headline: Sky Sports wins athletics rights
fields.trailText:
8.30am:Sky Sports is to broadcast live athletics for the first time following a two-year TV deal, reports Jason Deans.
Jan 24: Sky loses US tennis rights
fields.body:
Sky Sports is to provide live coverage of athletics for the first time following a two-year TV rights deal covering 14 events.

The BSkyB subsidiary's exclusive live coverage of the IAAF Golden League will begin on June 29 with a three-hour peaktime broadcast of the Golden Gala in Rome and a highlights show the next day.

Coverage of a further six Golden League athletics meetings will follow over the summer from venues including Paris, Berlin and Monaco.

Sky Sports has also signed up to cover seven Golden League events in 2002.

Athletes expected to take part in the meetings include British stars Steve Backley, Ewan Thomas, Colin Jackson and Kelly Holmes.

"It's an excellent time to get involved in athletics, following the British successes at the Olympics last summer," said Sky Sports commercial director Roger Moody.

"Track and field has a great profile and the IAAF Golden League has the very best athletes guaranteed."

Relevant story

fields.headline: JWT swoops for Cheetham Bell
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Ad giant J Walter Thompson has snapped up Manchester agency Cheetham Bell for an undisclosed sum, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
London-based advertising giant J Walter Thompson said today it had snapped up Manchester agency Cheetham Bell for an undisclosed sum.

JWT will immediately merge Cheetham Bell, which employs 35 people, with its own office in Manchester. The new agency will be branded Cheetham Bell JWT.

JWT has acquired 75% of the Cheetham Bell's shares with options to acquire the remaining 25%.

Dr David Bell will become chief executive officer of the new company and Andy Cheetham creative director, although JWT Manchester's managing director Paul Watson will remain in his role.

The merger is the culmination of many months of negotiation between Cheetham Bell's founders and JWT, which is in turn owned by the WPP Group.

Dr Bell said: "It's been a while since anyone shook up the advertising market here and with this leap in scale I feel we can really make an impact."

Cheetham Bell has sales of £1.5m for the year ending June 2000, net assets of £261,000 and billings of around £15m.

It produces ad campaigns for the Manchester Evening News, Pontins and locally-based drinks companies Vimto and Halewood International.

Since it was founded eight years ago it has expanded rapidly, but suffered a 31% drop in billings in 1999.

The newly-merged agency will take on McCann-Erickon's Manchester operation, which is the biggest agency outside London with billings of around £110m, and BDH TBWA.

fields.headline: Duncan to launch Cosmo Girl for Natmags
fields.trailText: 8.30am: NatMags has hired Celia Duncan, a former Company associate editor, to edit its major new teen launch, Cosmo Girl. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The National Magazine Company has chosen Celia Duncan, a former Company associate editor and style magazine journalist, to edit its major new teen launch, Cosmo Girl.

Ms Duncan was promoted to associate editor of Company last March, after joining as features editor two years previously.

She has worked on a variety of style magazines, including the Face, I-D and Arena.

Cosmo Girl, which is based on a successful US launch, is aimed at girls aged between 12 and 17.

But the magazine, originally scheduled for a late spring launch, has now been pushed back to summer.

Magazine publishers have eagerly targeted the young women's market for spin-offs of successful women's magazine brands like Cosmopolitan and Elle.

webTitle: Pay dispute could lead to new fuel crisis

fields.headline: Pay dispute could lead to new fuel crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Britain could face more disruptions to its fuel supplies as oil tanker drivers are to be balloted in a dispute over pay, union officials warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain could face more disruptions to its fuel supplies as oil tanker drivers are to be balloted in a dispute over pay, union officials warned yesterday.

Hundreds of workers who drive Shell tankers begin voting today on whether to strike after they rejected a proposed two year wage deal.

The men, who are employed by P&O Trans European, drive one sixth of the country's fuel tanker fleet, according to union leaders. They belong to the Transport and General Workers' Union, which is seeking a 5% pay rise. The drivers have overwhelmingly rejected an offer which the TGWU claimed represented only a 2.5% rise in basic pay.

The TGWU claimed the drivers received no pay increase last year because negotiations were held up by the blockades at fuel depots over petrol prices.

Ron Webb, the TGWU's national secretary, said: "Fuel tanker drivers are highly qualified workers who do a difficult and dangerous job... Our members did not receive a pay rise last year and we are simply seeking a settlement that reflects the value of the skilled and dangerous work they do."

Mr Webb said if the com pany made a revised offer that "realistically reflects" the value of the drivers' work, then negotiations could be reopened.

A spokeswoman for P&O Trans European, a subsidiary of the P&O group, said the company was still discussing pay with the unions and things were "progressing".

The results of the ballot will be known in mid February.

webTitle: Start taking stress seriously, say insurers

fields.headline: Start taking stress seriously, say insurers
fields.trailText: A huge rise in the number of claims for stress-related pressures at work is causing alarm among insurers.
fields.body:
A huge rise in the number of claims for stress-related pressures at work is causing alarm among insurers.

They are calling on the UK's employers to start treating staff more fairly, by cutting back on long hours and stop bosses bullying workers.

One of the UK's largest income protection insurers, Unum, says its claims for stress have risen by 88% over the last seven years, while those for chronic fatigue syndrome are up by 40%.

Unum was responding to a recent survey from BMRB International among 1,200 full and part time workers which found two thirds of them were stressed, with some 73% admitting it was affecting their performance.

Eugene McCormack, Unum's marketing director said: "This survey should be seen as a wake up call for the UK's business community. They appear to be allowing the working environment to become increasingly stressful and it cost could them."

Unum is campaigning for employers to move away from long working days, which it says do not result in increased efficiency, only increased levels of illness.

Other income protection insurers such as Royal & SunAlliance and Norwich Union also say they have been hit by increased levels of claims for stress.

The annual cost of stress-related sickness to British business is now more than £4billion, according to Professor Cary Cooper, Bupa professor of organisational psychology and health at University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (Umist).

Professor Cooper warns that stress levels in Britain are higher than in any other country in Europe and that they will increase rapidly in the next decade.

Although some private medical insurance policies will pay for psychiatric treatment for stress problems, those off work for long periods need to have been covered by income protection. This type of insurance pays for the amount of time someone is off work and typically offers a tax-free monthly benefit of around 60% of salary.

But, only around 11% of the UK population is covered by income protection. It is expensive if bought on an individual basis and while some companies provide it, many people in high pressure jobs have no insurance at all.

Critical illness insurance, which is more popular than income protection, does not cover stress. Instead this pays out on diagnosis of a number of severe conditions such as heart attack, stroke or cancer.

Yet the most likely reasons for long term absence from work are stress and back problems.

Many people though are just not able to afford both income protection and critical illness cover - someone in their 30s, for example, could be paying over £80 a month in premiums. This means they effectively have to take a gamble and predict what is likely to be the best type of cover for them.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Temper, temper
fields.trailText: All The Rage | In A Land Of Plenty | Coronation Street
fields.body:
Apparently, anger is all around us. It's a social addiction, a curse on modern society, a dangerous habit on which more and more of us are hooked. I'm not sure how far I believe this but - PAY ATTENTION YOU LITTLE SCROTE OR I'LL BREAK YOUR LEGS - according to All The Rage (BBC1) it's a fact. Twenty years ago, almost no one would lose their rag in public, but now it's a daily occurrence, with people getting incandescent with rage over the smallest things. LIKE PEOPLE WHO DON'T PAY ATTENTION.

To prove its point, All The Rage mustered Oliver James and images of breaking glass. Once I got over the disappointment of the two not being connected (James being thrown through a window would have been a positively soothing sight), it was clear that this programme was being deliberately provocative.

Why else show Kilroy? Why else enlist Dr Raj Persaud, the housewives' favourite head doctor? Why else show psychologists trying to turn perfectly normal folks with legitimate reasons to get angry into doormats for those around them?

According to The Observer last Sunday, we all need to become more emotionally literate, so what better proof of emotional erudition than wanting to kick the crap out of people that annoy you? But oh no, that's the WRONG kind of emotional literacy. That's like reading Ernest Hemingway when they want you to peruse Enid Blighton. THERE'S NOTHING THAT MAKES ME ANGRIER THAN PEOPLE MOVING THE GOALPOSTS.

Actually, Dr Raj and Ros Taylor - who must be coining it in, appearing on Confidence Lab as well as this - did a rather interesting job with Graham and Polly, both of whom had difficulties controlling their anger. It was easy to see why Polly was a grump - she was a chef - but Graham worked for a charity. Can you imagine bumping into him in the street with a collecting tin? "Put some money in the slot or I'll pin you against this wall and pluck out your eyes", he would snarl. "No! More than just 40 pence in coppers." Scary.

What Raj and Ros - who could form a pop group if they so chose - taught Polly and Graham was that fury isn't good for you. It damages your relationships and your own body. They warned that everyone else in the world isn't an enemy, that getting angry doesn't help a situation, that it isn't inevitable and, above all, that it isn't cool. WHAT LIARS. Excuse me while I go and have a heart attack. On my own.

Lessons in emotional literacy might not go astray in the Freeman household, where Helen McCrory's decision to throw herself out of a window, probably after re-reading some of her poetry, has thrown those left behind In A Land Of Plenty (BBC2) into emotional turmoil. The alienated Robert has taken up boxing, Simon has gone to work in the factory in an attempt to win his father's unwinnable affection and approval, and James continues to photograph his family, keeping the traumas of the world at arm's length through his camera lens.

Excellently directed, wonderfully acted and intricately written, In A Land Of Plenty manages to be both epic and intimate, conveying as much through the choice of how a scene is shot and the flash of emotion in a character's eyes as through the words spoken. With the six-part series all but abandoned in favour of one-off dramas or two-parters (lest audiences lose interest from week to week, you understand), it's a joy to see a genuinely momentous story told over 10 weeks, unwrapped like a luxurious pass-the-parcel. And the fact that it's a story of one family makes it all the more engrossing. In A Land Of Plenty shows the ordinary to be extraordinary.

I'm not sure how far I believe this but - PAY ATTENTION YOU LITTLE SCROTE OR I'LL BREAK YOUR LEGS - according to All The Rage (BBC1) it's a fact. Twenty years ago, almost no one would lose their rag in public, but now it's a daily occurrence, with people getting incandescent with rage over the smallest things. According to The Observer last Sunday, we all need to become more emotionally literate, so what better proof of emotional erudition than wanting to kick the crap out of people that annoy you? webTitle: TV and Radio: The price is right

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which actor will be the first to get a Vanity Fair cover?
fields.trailText: Which actor will be the first to get a Vanity Fair cover?
fields.body:
Colin Farrell 7-4

Eliza Dushku 2-1

Lauren Ambrose 6-1

Matthew David 10-1

Kip Pardue 12-1

A helpful hand in making it big in Hollywood is the front cover of entertainment bible Vanity Fair. But an actor has to have some clout already to appear there. "If the actor isn't in hit movies and hasn't got the exposure, it's not likely," says Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler.

Colin Farrell has won roles in Steven Spielberg's Minority Report, alongside Tom Cruise, and Joel Schumacher's Phone Booth. "A lot of people will know him as Danny Byrne from Ballykissangel, and he's an interesting character who's had an unusual rise to the top. He's from Dublin, and Americans love a paddy made good, so he strikes me as classic cover material. He obviously looks pretty good too."

At the other end of the odds, Matthew Davis "has done a couple of interviews and he hasn't come across as stunningly intelligent". His striking looks haven't been matched by films like Urban Legends: The Final Cut. Perhaps the sure-fire hit Pearl Harbour will help, but "the odds will tell you what I think of his chances", says Andy.

Model-turned-actor Kip Pardue's CV includes But I'm A Cheerleader and a role in The Glass House opposite Sylvester Stallone. "General opinion seems to be that he's looking at a career of relative mediocrity," slams Andy.

Lauren Ambrose, with a cute Kate Moss appearance, "is obviously cover material". As well as roles in teen flicks like Can't Hardly Wait, Psycho Beach and Swimming, "she's a redhead, which is slightly unusual and could work to her advantage", argues Andy.

"An outstandingly good chance" is awarded to Eliza Dushku. In the pipeline for Dushku are parts alongside Wes Bentley, Robert De Niro, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, and a reprise of her role as Arnie's daughter in True Lies 2. "She's very pretty and already on her way to becoming a star. She's definitely Vanity Fair material."

webTitle: G2: Benjamin Wegg-Prosser on Peter Mandelson

fields.headline: I'm Mandy, fire me
fields.standfirst:
He had pulled off one of the most remarkable comebacks in British political history and was doing well in his new job. So why did Peter Mandelson risk everything by giving a deceptive answer to a reporter's question? Simple, says his former aide Benjamin Wegg-Prosser: he's a born gambler

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: He had pulled off one of the most remarkable comebacks in British political history and was doing well in his new job. So why did Peter Mandelson risk everything by giving a deceptive answer to a reporter's question? Simple, says his former aide Benjamin Wegg-Prosser: he's a born gambler.
fields.body:
Telephone calls before 7am are usually bad news. I received one from Peter Mandelson at 6:30am on the day of his home loan resignation. He was more downcast then than he was yesterday morning when he called again, this time at 6:45am and remarkably upbeat.

I was asleep when the phone rang. What's going on, I asked. "I'll tell you exactly what's going on: I'm being attacked by the right and the left." He then gave an encyclopaedic breakdown of what had happened since the weekend. Despite the obvious pressure he seemed calm. Unlike our similar conversation two years ago, the idea of resignation never arose.

On the face of it the passport story was not that serious. Peter acknowledged that the answer his office had given the Observer on Saturday afternoon had been unclear, though perhaps no more so than similar responses given by him or many of his colleagues to journalists over the years. The conversation ended with Peter's typical sign-off: "Speak to you later."

Yet in little more than five hours he had thrown in the towel and ended his career as a frontline politician. This was so different to my time with him in December 1998 when he clung on to ministerial office for as long as possible until the prime minister effectively asked him to resign. That time I had the surreal responsibility of typing up the resignation letter; which had been drafted by Alastair Campbell. This time there were no letters; he made a swift decision and fell on his sword. There were no tears in front of the cameras or last-ditch attempts to haul himself out of the hole.

His resignation is a personal tragedy, but also a release. The assistance, though misguided, he offered to Srichand Hinduja came at a time when the London chatterati and powerful industrial figures pursued him relentlessly. He was undoubtedly enjoying the fruits of office. He may have sailed close to the wind, as he did on this occasion, but there is no evidence of any wrongdoing. On my watch I often questioned, as he did, whether he should be seeing this person or that. There was usually a good reason for the meetings, though appearances with the likes of Elle Macpherson might have been a photo-opportunity too far. His fondness for rightwing socialites also exposed him to accusations that he was turning his back on old friends, but Peter always had an explanation for his seemingly incongruous new chums: it was part of what was called the "Hoover strategy", an attempt to draw traditional Tories into the New Labour tent. It is a fact of life - often forgotten by old-fashioned liberals - that successful politicians come into contact with influential figures who occupy other arenas.

In fact he largely turned his back on such company after his first resignation. He reluctantly sold his house, which was not half as glamorous as the Daily Mail would have you believe. He was quite happy to give up the parties that had kept him so busy in the 18 months after the 1997 election. Indeed over the past two years, when I have asked him how he's been and what he's been up to, he has often sounded rather proud of the fact that he has spent most evenings at home. The first time I called him at his flat in Hillsborough, he told me gleefully that he was "just cooking some lamb chops and watching a video."

His first few months out of office were a shock to the system. He particularly missed his chauffeur driven car. After selling his house, buying a secondhand Fiat Punto was the first big challenge of his new life. He also found clearing out his ministerial study in the Commons after Christmas a humiliating experience. But despite these indignities he came to relish his new freedom. At the 1999 Labour party conference he told a friend: "It's great. I've just been sitting in my room watching the Cartoon Network." It was almost convincing.

During his 10 months on the back benches he had kept in regular touch with Tony Blair, speaking to him about three times a week. It meant a lot to him during those wilderness months that Blair took care to keep him in the loop. Peter kept up a stream of regular memos to Downing Street, helping to draft speeches, particularly on Europe. He played a key role in securing the support of senior Tories like Clarke and Heseltine for the government's position on Europe.

He had also helped Millbank campaigners in their early planning of the election campaign. His rare forays into the political arena had been met with praise by a number of surprising allies, from Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU to old Labour colleagues. He occasionally spoke out in favour of Europe but actually spent more time attending Labour party meetings out of London.

He never seriously entertained the idea of returning to the cabinet so early. However, he was delighted with his new role in Northern Ireland.

Crucially his new job allowed him to maintain his new regime of avoiding the parties and dinners that many of his critics associated, as he would say, with "Old Mandelson". He had never been happier than when he was working in Hillsborough Castle grappling with fascinating and serious issues away from the Westminster village.

He also had two new close friends to look after - his dogs. Bobby, a very excitable Labrador and Jack, a playful Parson Russell Terrier. Phonecalls that had previously been interrupted by bleeper messages from Number 10 were now stalled by shrieks as one or other of the puppies peed on the carpet.

While in Belfast he would occasionally be dragged into stories from his past, for example last October when Geoffrey Robinson published his memoirs. In the main he was determined to keep out of trouble, which to a great extent he did.

Seasoned New Labour kremlinologists suspected that Peter's power was weakened by his distance from Whitehall and the pressures of peace process. It's probably true that he didn't enjoy the influence he did at the height of his career but, he insisted, he was "well out of it" and pleased that his distant posting kept him out of trouble.

This weekend "Old Mandelson" came back to haunt him. He was visiting Paris when the Observer called his office asking for a comment on the written parliamentary answer which Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, had given the Lib Dem MP Norman Baker, a long-time Peter tormentor. He was aware that the answer had been published after discussions with the Home Office last week.

I was not surprised that a story about his relationship with the Hindujas had appeared in print. In my time I had often received telephone calls from them and was aware of their reputation. It was inevitable that Mandelson would have been drawn into the picture as the Indian criminal investigation into their businesses reached its closing stages.

While working for him I had encountered many similar stories. The simplest response is always to establish the facts and give the least damaging, though truthful answer. Peter was annoyed by the Observer story, though not unduly concerned. The answer that he provided seemed strong enough. However, on this occasion something went wrong. So wrong that Alastair Campbell, one of his oldest friend's, misled the press and Chris Smith, the culture secretary, misled the Commons. How could Peter have got himself in such a mess?

I do not believe he deliberately lied to the press; he provided an answer that was at best economical and at worst evasive. However, if he had been more open he would never have had to resign. It was also an error to highlight the role his private secretary had played, though it is easy to see why he wanted to put more daylight between him and the Hindujas. Nothing unusual about that; politicians are brought up to answer difficult questions in a way which reflect most positively on them. You see it every day on the television and nine times out of 10 the fudge does the trick - unfortunately for Peter, this time he came unstuck.

I was asked countless times yesterday why a man in his position, with precious little political capital, took a chance like that. The answer is simply that Peter is a born gambler. That's why he was able to change the Labour party, and also why he was never going to survive at the top for long. He wore his appetite for risk-taking as a badge of honour. "That's how I got where I am," he would say when asked why he seemed so willing to play with fire.

While even he acknowledges that he was well and trully cornered yesterday morning - "they [the media] got me," he said - it was still surprising to anyone who knows him that he went so quickly. During his stoic Commons performance yesterday he made little reference to his resignation - other than to talk in the past tense.

His statement outside Downing Street was typically abrupt. There will be many who suspect he is simply spinning again, but I'm convinced that the reason for his swift resignation is that he is at last happy in his own personal life. Most importantly, his time in Belfast showed that high political office is not the only thing in life. "I just realised that this can't go on for ever," he said last night.

He has now withdrawn from the many battles he has fought since he first started to work with Neil Kinnock in 1985. He has lived with his critics inside the Labour party and often relished the argument. However the more recent attacks from rightwing commentators, particularly on Europe, have been little more than homophobic rants Richard Littlejohn and others in the Sun have been disgusting.

I for one am pleased that he has retreated from the Whitehall fray. Indeed I made the case to him two years ago that he should turn his back on Westminster and find a more fulfilling (and possibly better remunerated) life outside politics. He told me then, as he did yesterday: "I am a public servant." Though I've always chuckled when he delivers it, the statement has a ring of truth. More importantly, he was a better-organised and more efficient minister than many of his colleagues, though more abrasive than most. While he will move out of ministerial office, he currently has no plans to step down at the next election.

Nowhere will his departure be mourned more than in the Northern Ireland Office and Millbank Tower. Civil servants and campaign staff respect his clear thought and swift decision-making, though they won't miss the occasional tantrums and unreasonable demands. While the peace process will continue and the election campaign will roll on his influence will be missing and his successors will not live up to his reputation.

After a little time I suspect his enemies will miss him too. He took them on singlehandly, faced them down and gave them a bloody good run for their money.

 Benjamin Wegg-Prosser was an aide to Peter Mandelson from 1995-1998. He is now publisher of the Guardian's politics and environment websites.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Red Bull

fields.headline: No: 1808
fields.standfirst: Red Bull
fields.trailText: Red Bull
fields.body:
Age: 14.

Appearance: Small, thin and decidedly expensive.

I know the one - pop star, had her luggage lifted at Heathrow. That's Posh Spice, this is a soft drink.

Soft drink? Well, semi-hard. Stimulating stuff. High-octane combination of caffeine, sugar and something called glucuronolactone. Much in favour among your footballing and City trader classes as a mixer with vodka.

Blimey, what does that do for you? Puts a hole in your current account if nothing else. Pound per litre, this stuff makes four-star look a bargain.

Not very popular, then. A mere 265m cans a year are sold. In some European countries it even outsells Coca-Cola.

How has it managed that? By forgetting to mention the glucuronolactone, presumably. On the contrary, the marketing was based on the drink's scientifically proven energy-giving qualities.

Has it got them? Not according to the advertising standards authority. After a three-year inquiry it decided Red Bull doesn't aid energy, performance and concentration, as it claims.

You'd be better off with a cup of sweet tea? Quite possibly. Though probably not as a mixer with a vodka. Still, the company can continue to use its advertising slogan: " Red Bull gives you wings."

So it's all right for the maker to suggest that anyone who drinks it can fly, but not that it might give them a boost walking down the road. That's about it. Actually, the phrase is a direct translation from the company's original German ads.

Ah, so the Germans are to blame. Austrians, in fact. The company chairman is a big mate of Arnie Schwarzenegger.

Schwarzenegger, glucuronolactone: Pass notes readers prefer short words, you know. How about "profit"? Red Bull makes lots.

Do say: "Swig of the Red, couple of Es and I can dance all night."

Don't say: "I'd prefer an espresso."

webTitle: Organic farm standards at risk, say MPs

fields.headline: Organic farm standards at risk, say MPs
fields.standfirst:
Natural produce 'in danger of having only sentimental appeal', agricultural industry warned

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Natural produce 'in danger of having only sentimental appeal', agricultural industry warned
fields.body:
Organic farming has expanded so fast it is in danger of losing its high standards, and is appealing to sentiment rather than being able to prove environmental or health benefits, MPs said yesterday.

More commercially orientated farmers and the supermarkets are becoming ever more dominant in the market, said the Commons agricultural committee.

The industry needed to be "less messianic and more marketing orientated." There were "huge opportunities" for it to expand but the industry needed to get a grip on supermarkets and create stronger producer-controlled cooperatives.

The committee said organic methods could not feed Britain, and suggested a mixture of organic and traditional agriculture. This disappointed the campaign to give the UK a target of 30% organic farming which has a private member's bill, the organic targets bill, before parliament on February 9. Most European countries have targets of between 10% and 20%. Britain stands at 3%.

The MPs said it was a "common perception" that organic meant pesticide and chemical-free. In fact, it simply meant farming without artificial pesticides.

There was a significant list of non-organic processing aids which may be used in manufacturing organic products and a tolerance level of 5% non-organic ingredients in processed products labelled as organic.

"This is not to accuse the organic movement of misleading the public, but it is perhaps true that the public has a perception of organic farming that is, at least partly, mythical," the report said. "We believe it is important that the claims can be tested and verified in order that consumers know what they are really buying."

The Iceland supermarket chain lost business when it switched totally to organic products, and the MPs urged caution. "Indeed, there is a real question as to the extent to which the government should be providing support at all when the market is so obviously strong. We believe there is a strong case for caution."

Catherine Fookes, from Sustain, the alliance for better food and farming, said: "We are delighted that the committee agrees that an action plan is needed for organic farming. The minister of agriculture has already agreed that an action plan would be useful, so now we need them to put words into action. Without an action plan UK farmers will continue to lose out to overseas competitors."

A Friends of the Earth food campaigner, Sandra Bell, said: "We are disappointed that the committee's report falls short of recommending targets for organic farming.

"However, it contains some sound advice, not least that a more strategic approach is needed to develop the organic sector and more resources should be put into training and research to maximise the considerable benefits of organic farming."

Patrick Holden, director of the Soil Association, said "With British agriculture facing such a serious crisis of environmental damage, food scares, the decline of rural employment and thousands of farmers on the brink of bankruptcy, organic farming does seem to be the one ray of hope.

"The question is whether the government can play a more positive role in enabling the expansion of organic farming. That would send a signal to farmers that there is a better long-term security in organic production."

webTitle: Mandelson resignation: colleagues show little sympathy

fields.headline: Colleagues show little sympathy
fields.standfirst:
MPs dismayed by blow to government

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: MPs dismayed by blow to government.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's enemies on the Labour backbenches yesterday rejoiced at his abrupt departure. "Hubris - that's what brought him down," one Labour MP declared. "I can't wipe this smile off my face," said another.

Few of Mr Mandelson's foes were prepared to record their thoughts publicly, no doubt reflecting the feeling that his influence may continue to be felt throughout the party. But they all felt he had made a catastrophic error of judgment - by misleading Downing Street - from which he could not recover.

One ministerial aide, who lavished praise on Mr Mandelson for his prompt departure when he first resigned from the cabinet in 1998, reflected this thinking yesterday. Denis MacShane, the parliamentary private secretary to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said: "Mr Mandelson's resignation reflects the decisiveness, indeed the ruthless leadership, every Labour MP has come to associate with Tony Blair. Behind the nice smile is a will of steel."

Mr MacShane voiced the hope that the government would quickly recover from the resignation, in contrast to the last government, which was severely damaged by John Major's dithering over troublesome ministers. "Compared to the Tory resignation sagas, when ministers hung on for days and days, Mr Blair has reacted quickly and cleanly."

Another MP, who refused to be named, said that many members of the parliamentary party were dismayed that the government should be nudged off course by Mr Mandelson when Labour was doing so well.

"There is also irritation that Tony Blair brought Peter Mandelson back so quickly in 1999," the MP said. "Friend and foe alike told the prime minister to be careful, but he refused to listen. Instead he listened to the advice of his unelected advisers who, unlike MPs, do not hear what people are saying in the high street."

Fraser Kemp, the backroom fixer and MP for Houghton and Washington East, said: "No one can underestimate the important contribution Peter Mandelson has made to the Labour party and to Northern Ireland. He has courageously decided to take this course of action in order to save the Labour party any embarrassment in its primary task, which is to deliver for the people of this country."

Other Labour MPs lined up in the commons chamber to praise Mr Mandelson during his final appearance at the despatch box. Dale Campbell-Savours, the veteran MP for Workington, described Mr Mandelson's resignation as a "regrettable" move which served as a warning to all MPs of the dangers when the press "want a politician's head on a platter".

He asked: "Can I express the hope that those same editors who have called for his resignation will now turn their attention to writing articles congratulating him for the work that he did in Northern Ireland in resolving the problems of conflict?"

William Hague launched a brutal attack on the prime minister, as the Tories abandoned the traditional post-resignation niceties to exploit Mr Mandelson's departure. During his weekly commons clash with the prime minister, the Tory leader condemned Mr Blair for "a monumental error of judgment" in allowing himself to become so heavily dependent on such an unreliable politician.

His attack delighted Tory MPs, who were ecstatic that such a prominent architect of New Labour had been forced out of office. The Tories have been determined to destroy Mr Mandelson because they regard him as the pivotal figure in Labour's successful attempts to appeal to middle England.

Even before Mr Mandelson resigned, however, the Tory leadership had decided to move on from attacking him personally - he was seen as a busted flush by then - to concentrate their firepower on the prime minister's judgment.

The Liberal Democrats were more measured. Charles Kennedy, the party's leader, said: "Peter Mandelson has made the right decision to resign. After 18 years of Conservative sleaze, the public needed the government to restore their faith in the political process. Today's events have set that cause back."

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP whose parliamentary question about Mr Mandelson's involvement with a passport application by one of the Hinduja brothers set in train his resignation, said: "It was inevitable that this would happen when he had exposed the prime minister and his colleagues in a very unhelpful way."

webTitle: Hijacker back in Britain on campaign trail

fields.headline: Hijacker back in Britain on campaign trail
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Thirty years after she was flown out of Britain in exchange for the release of 56 western hostages, the world's best-known hijacker and iconic Palestinian guerrilla fighter, Leila Khaled, yesterday arrived back in London to campaign for her people's cause in the House of Commons.
fields.body:
Thirty years after she was flown out of Britain in exchange for the release of 56 western hostages, the world's best-known hijacker and iconic Palestinian guerrilla fighter, Leila Khaled, yesterday arrived back in London to campaign for her people's cause in the House of Commons.

Visiting Ealing police station in west London, where she was held for 28 days in the autumn of 1970 after an attempt to commandeer an El Al flight, Ms Khaled said the peace process had failed to solve the Palestinian problem and predicted an intensification of the uprising against Israel.

Ministers intervened to give the go-ahead for a last minute visa for the Haifa-born revolutionary and member of the Palestinian parliament, who was due to speak last night at a Westminster meeting on Iraq and Palestine organised by the Labour MP George Galloway.

Ms Khaled was at the centre of an international crisis which engulfed Edward Heath's government in September 1970, sparked by the seizure of five civilian airliners by the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

The PFLP blew up three of the aircraft for cameras in the Jordanian desert and bargained for the release of seven Palestinian prisoners, including Ms Khaled, who was handed over to British authorities at Heathrow by Israeli guards after the failed hijacking.

Speaking to the Guardian after her return to London yesterday, Ms Khaled defended her role in the hijackings - she also successfully hijacked a TWA airliner in 1969 - which made her a heroine in the Middle East.

"Until then, the world only dealt with us as refugees. We demonstrated and screamed and shouted to make the world listen, but the only answer we got was more tents and humanitarian aid. The hijackings were only a short-lived tactic, but I think they were successful in getting international opinion to ask: who are these people? Now the intifada is giving the answer".

There is likely to be criticism of the decision to give a visa to a woman still regarded by some as a terrorist, even though she was never charged with a crime and no one was killed in either hijacking.

Although she was allowed into Gaza by the Israelis four years ago to vote in a session of the Palestinian parliament, Ms Khaled is still banned from travelling to some Arab countries and has only visited Europe since 1970 under the auspices of the UN. Israeli prime minister Exer Weizmann once said he would ensure Ms Khaled never slept safely - and in 1982, Israeli troops ransacked her home in Beirut.

A Foreign Office spokesman confirmed last night that Peter Hain, the minister in charge of Middle East affairs, had intervened in the case at the request of Mr Galloway and that the government was satisfied that there was "now no reason why she shouldn't be allowed into the country".

Ms Khaled, a senior figure in the PFLP, insisted yesterday: "I am not and have never been a terrorist, I have been a freedom fighter. But I, and my people, have been terrorised by Israel since I was born.

"I have never done anything against Britain," she said, but in a reference to the 1917 Balfour declaration, which promised Palestine would be a national home to the Jewish people, added: "but Britain did something to us - they gave our land to another people."

Ms Khaled, aged 57, who now lives in Jordan with her physiotherapist husband and two teenage sons, remained both guerrilla fighter and political activist - she has played a leading role in both Palestinian and Jordanian women's organisations - in Lebanon and Syria in the years after the hijackings.

Yesterday she said she had good memories of her month in Ealing police station, where she played badminton with her guards, while attempting to win them over to the Palestinian cause.

"When I left, they took me on a helicopter tour, saying: 'You must see the sights of London before you go.'"
