fields.headline: How the drama unfolded
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker receives a written Home Office answer, dated the previous day, on applications for British passports by Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja.
fields.body:
Friday January 19

Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker receives a written Home Office answer, dated the previous day, on applications for British passports by Srichand and Gopichand Hinduja. Immigration minister Barbara Roche confirms that Mr Mandelson, when minister for the dome, "made inquiries about how an application might be viewed given the government's wider policy of encouraging citizenship from long-standing residents who fulfilled the criteria."

Saturday January 20

Mr Mandelson plays down his role, telling the Observer: "To the limited extent that I was involved in this matter, I was always very sensitive to the proprieties. The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship."

Sunday January 21

As the Observer's story is followed up, the Northern Ireland office insists: "Mr Mandelson did not assist in this passport application. He did not support or endorse any passport application, nor would he have considered doing so."

Monday January 22

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, tells journalists: "This was an issue raised by the Hindujas and it was passed to the Home Office and when specifically they asked Peter to endorse or support any application, he refused, perfectly properly and appropriately. He did exactly what any other minister would do, which is pass it to the relevant department, which is the Home Office. Peter did not get involved."

In the afternoon, during culture questions, the culture minister, Chris Smith, dismisses calls from Mr Baker for an inquiry - reiterating that it was Mr Mandelson's private secretary, not the minister, who contacted the Home Office.

Tuesday January 23

Mr Campbell tells a lobby briefing that Mr Mandelson had telephoned the junior home office minister, Mike O'Brien, himself, and that he had been wrong to tell the press otherwise. "Yesterday ... Peter's office was able ... to recollect that he had a call with Home Office minister Mike O'Brien in June 1998 ... it lasted no more than two minutes."

Asked on Channel 4 news how, as Downing Street claimed, he could have "forgotten" the telephone conversation, Mr Mandelson replied: "There is no question of my forgetting about anything. I was not asked until today ... Nobody asked me about a phone call on Saturday, Sunday or Monday. Nobody asked me those questions."

Wednesday January 24

Following this implicit admission of evasiveness - and a vicious savaging in the press - Mr Mandelson is ordered into No 10 by Tony Blair to "establish the facts" of his involvement with the Hinduja brothers' passport application.

The meeting begins at 10.45 and lasts just over an hour, during which time Mr Blair's spokesman, at the 11am lobby, is evasive about the prime minister's confidence in him and his likely future.

Speculation that he will resign increases when it is announced that his deputy, Adam Ingram, will take that afternoon's Northern Ireland questions, but ends at 1.32pm when Mr Mandelson appears on the steps of No 10, to announce his resignation. "I do not accept in any way that I have acted improperly in respect of any application for naturalisation as a British subject," he tells waiting reporters.

At 2.30pm, he takes his final Northern Ireland questions - and at 3.31pm leaves the chamber.

Monday January 22 The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, tells journalists: "This was an issue raised by the Hindujas and it was passed to the Home Office and when specifically they asked Peter to endorse or support any application, he refused, perfectly properly and appropriately. He did exactly what any other minister would do, which is pass it to the relevant department, which is the Home Office. Peter did not get involved." In the afternoon, during culture questions, the culture minister, Chris Smith, dismisses calls from Mr Baker for an inquiry - reiterating that it was Mr Mandelson's private secretary, not the minister, who contacted the Home Office. Tuesday January 23 Mr Campbell tells a lobby briefing that Mr Mandelson had telephoned the junior home office minister, Mike O'Brien, himself, and that he had been wrong to tell the press otherwise. "Yesterday ... Peter's office was able ... to recollect that he had a call with Home Office minister Mike O'Brien in June 1998 ... it lasted no more than two minutes." Asked on Channel 4 news how, as Downing Street claimed, he could have "forgotten" the telephone conversation, Mr Mandelson replied: "There is no question of my forgetting about anything. I was not asked until today ... Nobody asked me about a phone call on Saturday, Sunday or Monday. Nobody asked me those questions." Wednesday January 24 Following this implicit admission of evasiveness - and a vicious savaging in the press - Mr Mandelson is ordered into No 10 by Tony Blair to "establish the facts" of his involvement with the Hinduja brothers' passport application. The meeting begins at 10.45 and lasts just over an hour, during which time Mr Blair's spokesman, at the 11am lobby, is evasive about the prime minister's confidence in him and his likely future. Speculation that he will resign increases when it is announced that his deputy, Adam Ingram, will take that afternoon's Northern Ireland questions, but ends at 1.32pm when Mr Mandelson appears on the steps of No 10, to announce his resignation. "I do not accept in any way that I have acted improperly in respect of any application for naturalisation as a British subject," he tells waiting reporters. At 2.30pm, he takes his final Northern Ireland questions - and at 3.31pm leaves the chamber. fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: Parliament
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: To shoot the Tories' fox is one thing. To make the bleeding animal perform a song and dance act immediately afterwards seems harsh. But there was Peter Mandelson, in public, at the despatch box, less than three hours after he'd been fired by Alastair Campbell.
fields.body:
To shoot the Tories' fox is one thing. To make the bleeding animal perform a song and dance act immediately afterwards seems harsh. But there he was, in public, at the despatch box, less than three hours after he'd been fired by Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's consiglieri.

Tonight, to continue the mob metaphor, Peter Mandelson sleeps with the fishes - or at least with a lobster thermidor.

There were some murmurs of support from Labour MPs, but nothing very loud - more a sort of token rumble to show party solidarity against the other side. I doubt if he was greatly surprised. In politics, you can't afford to lose your friends when you only have one friend in the first place.

As Northern Ireland questions continued, cabinet ministers arrived one by one. They looked relaxed and cheerful. Clearly they were bearing the tragic news bravely. But then champagne is famous for steadying the nerves.

Mr Mandelson answered only one question, about the RUC. It had been his privilege "to support them in their work, their valiant work". Their sacrifices would "never, ever, be forgotten". It sounded like a memorial service at which the corpse gives the address.

Back in his seat, he looked miserable. Sometimes he chewed his lower lip. He clutched the scarlet ministerial file for the last time. These things always mattered to him. When he was minister without portfolio, he had a red and gold portfolio marked "minister without portfolio".

Gordon Brown, one of Mandy's 879 closest enemies, arrived at two minutes to three. So did Alastair Campbell, who's another. The prime minister appeared at 2.59. They exchanged the briefest possible glance, like office lovers anxious not to let anyone know.

Mr Hague had a choice, to be magnanimous or vicious. He opted for the latter, but really he had no choice. His backbenchers, apart from a few crusty old grandees, from the kind of regiment where a disgraced officer went off with a bottle of Scotch and a revolver, demanded vengeance. They wanted to soak their hands in Mandelson's blood.

The Tory leader said Mr Blair had notched up a "historic achievement, being forced to sack the same minister twice for the same offence". His dependency on Mandy had been "a monumental error of judgment".

The prime minister decided to be affronted. "He has done the right thing ... it is a long tradition in this house that when someone does that, we pay tribute to it. I am only sorry that, once again, you have lived down to my expectations."

It was meant to be deeply dignified. It sounded thin and peevish. "Ooh, missus!" one felt like squeaking.

Mr Blair spoke of Mandy's role in "the broad sweep of history". Mr Hague talked about his role in the narrow sweep of the Blair government, "where standards of truth, honesty and integrity have taken second place to spin and smear".

"You diminish yourself far more than you diminish anyone else," Mr Blair replied. My sanctimoniousness meter was buzzing dangerously.

At 3.31, the two men walked out, Mr Mandelson clutching the precious scarlet folder for the last time. Behind him were hundreds of Labour backbenchers, most of whom have always regarded him as the depleted uranium of the government - supported in public, lethal in practice.

Was it my imagination, or was there a certain air of sadness? In a strange way it is as melancholy to have your dreams come true as it is to see them dashed; both take away your opportunity to hope.

fields.headline: Hartlepool loses patience with its prodigal son
fields.standfirst:
Voters start to wonder if it is time for change

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Voters start to wonder if it is time for change.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson must now be considering whether 10 years on Teesside is long enough - and his Hartlepool constituency certainly seems to be coming to that conclusion.

"We've Had Enough" said last night's front page of the Hartlepool Mail, whose staff had been out gathering vox pops and had registered an undercurrent of anti-Mandyism.

"They're right," said Colin Kavenagh, who was out looking for a birthday present for his grandson."It's a different feeling from when he borrowed that money for his London house. Once is one thing, and there was quite a lot of sympathy - we all borrow money for our houses. But resigning twice; well, I don't see how he can carry on."

Mr Mandelson's stylish image and commitments as a cabinet minister have weakened both his hold, and Labour's, on an area which for decades has been as loyal as northern constituencies come. In May, control of the borough council slipped to a Liberal Democrat and Conservative "arrangement".

The former Labour council leader, Russell Hart, said yesterday: "Peter can be enigmatic and Hartlepool can be volatile. It's a place that will change when it wants to change. The electorate's uncertain and we fight Hartlepool as if it was a marginal, not somewhere we've got a 17,000 majority. But we reselected Peter by an overwhelming majority in the autumn and he'll be a splendid candidate."

There was evident glee at the offices of local builder and boxing promoter Gus Robinson, who is already well into a "people's challenge" as prospective Conservative parliamentary candidate.

Back at the shops, childcare student Lauren said: "We need someone you're likely to bump into in a place like this. I'd like to have an MP you'd just see in the street."

But there was some sympathy. One elderly couple felt persecution of their MP by the media was "plain disgusting".

fields.headline: The last, lonely goodbye
fields.standfirst:
Meeting at No 10 meant there was no way out for closest confidant

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Meeting at No 10 meant there was no way out for closest confidant.
fields.byline: Steven Morris, Michael White, Jeevan Vasagar
fields.body:
By the time the three of them - Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and Alastair Campbell - met in the prime minister's office overlooking Horse Guards Parade at 10.45am the end result was a foregone conclusion.

This meeting, just a few yards from the cabinet room where Mr Mandelson had been so proud to take his place, was not about whether or not the Northern Ireland secretary should resign but rather how it should be handled.

Perhaps the three men sat on the two large white sofas and talked across the table which separates them. Perhaps one or more paced around the office while the details of the process were hammered out.

In 1998 Mr Blair had needed to lead his friend to the conclusion that he must quit rather than brazen it out. This time both men knew that there was no way out.

Circumstance had not helped. For a start, they were both set to face fierce questioning in the Commons within a few hours, first during Northern Ireland question time then at the prime minister's own inquisition. They knew the Tories would be on the rampage. There was no chance the matter would blow itself out.

Then there was the general election. If there might have been a lingering trace of uncertainty, an appraisal from Mr Campbell of how the controversy was playing in the media must surely have persuaded them that the status quo was not an option.

During the hour-long meeting, Mr Blair asked Mr Mandelson to tell him in depth what had happened so that he would be prepared for William Hague's inevitable questions. They also decided that they should ask a QC to carry out an inquiry.

They also decided not to exchange public letters of resignation and acceptance, as happened two years ago. Instead Mr Mandelson would make a statement outside Number 10 and Mr Blair would have his say during question time.

After half an hour, Mr Campbell left to attend the daily briefing for lobby journalists in the Number 10 basement. He is often a little tardy but his arrival 15 minutes late added to the feeling that something very big was about to break.

Mr Campbell is not good at hiding his feelings and it was clear he was either angry or upset. He confirmed that the meeting between Mr Blair and Mr Mandelson was underway, that things had to be "ironed out". By now there could be little mistake - for the second time Mr Blair's close confidant was on his way out.

Earlier, a bright, cloudless sky would have greeted Mr Mandelson if he had peeked out of the windows of his £249,000 two-bedroomed flat in an elegant Edwardian villa just off Notting Hill Gate yesterday morning. If he had glanced down, he would also have seen a pack of reporters, photographers and television crews ready to record the start of his last day as Northern Ireland minister.

The newspapers gave him little solace. "How many more lies Mr Mandelson," asked the Mail. "Mandy told a porky" claimed the Sun. Perhaps prompted by the cruel headlines, he was later to take a swipe at media scrutiny.

There was no sign of life chez Mandelson before 9.30am. Then a female assistant arrived to take Mr Mandelson's dogs, golden retriever Bobby and terrier Jack, for a walk. A normal day for them, so different for their master.

Speculation

Just before 10am Mr Mandelson's ministerial blue Jaguar pulled up. He was waiting just inside the black front door - a more modest version of 10 Downing Street - and strode down the steps as the car came to a halt, clutching two red boxes.

There was no smile and no comment as a security officer ushered him into the back of the car, which was shadowed by a silver four-wheel drive carrying two more security officers. At 10.30am Mr Mandelson's car was spotted at the rear of Downing Street, fuelling speculation that he was on the brink of resignation.

Back at Mr Mandelson's house, a Rastafarian cycled by shouting: "Is this where you get the passports?"

The political pack outside Downing Street were speculating that Mr Mandelson had sneaked out of a back door when his spokesman, Tom Kelly, emerged to say that his boss would be out shortly.

At 1.33pm the famous black door swung open and Mr Mandelson strode over to face the cameras.

Wearing a blue suit, pale blue shirt and dark patterned tie, Mr Mandelson fingered a stray lock of his hair which a troublesome breeze was toying with.

Last time, red rings around his eyes showed that the ordeal of resignation had reduced Mr Mandelson to tears. This time he appeared determined to keep his emotions in check.

He began reading his resignation statement strongly, confidently, but his voice faltered as he insisted that his "sole desire" had been to emphasise that he had not sought to influence the Home Office over the passport application. The emotion came when he turned to the role of the press. He licked his lips nervously and his voice cracked as he said: "There must be more to politics than the constant media pressure and exposure that has dogged me." He was back in his stride and even managed a half smile when he said that he wanted a "more normal life".

Unfortunately, when he had finished, he turned the wrong way as he looked for his car, heading back towards Number 10 before spinning almost 360 degrees when he realised his car was further up Downing Street.

At 2.30pm Mr Mandelson rose from the government front bench and buttoned his jacket up to answer questions about the RUC. His deputy Adam Ingram sat next to him, but not too closely. He flicked through papers as David Trimble thanked him for his work in Northern Ireland and ignored a question about his resignation.

Then he sat at Tony Blair's right hand - perhaps for the last time - for prime minister's questions. Mr Mandelson sat arms crossed as the onslaught from William Hague began. When Mr Blair sat down he did not lean back beside his friend but perched on the front of the bench. At one point Mr Mandelson whispered something to the prime minister and managed a "hear hear" when Mr Blair attacked the Tories over rural schools. But for the most part remained impassive, even when his friend paid warm tribute to him.

Half an hour after question time Mr Mandelson was at the Northern Ireland office to clear his desk.

Back at the Mandelson home, a male assistant called to take the dogs out. Then at 4.15 Mr Mandelson's partner Reinaldo Da Silva carried two bags into a chauffeur-driven car. They drove out of the street, picked up the dogs and were away.

Mr Mandelson's immediate plans were unclear. But already by last night the Northern Ireland office had moved on, replying to questions about his movements with a curt: "Mr Mandelson is now a private citizen. His privacy is his own."

He flicked through papers as David Trimble thanked him for his work in Northern Ireland and ignored a question about his resignation. Then he sat at Tony Blair's right hand - perhaps for the last time - for prime minister's questions. Mr Mandelson sat arms crossed as the onslaught from William Hague began. When Mr Blair sat down he did not lean back beside his friend but perched on the front of the bench. At one point Mr Mandelson whispered something to the prime minister and managed a "hear hear" when Mr Blair attacked the Tories over rural schools. But for the most part remained impassive, even when his friend paid warm tribute to him. Half an hour after question time Mr Mandelson was at the Northern Ireland office to clear his desk. Back at the Mandelson home, a male assistant called to take the dogs out. Then at 4.15 Mr Mandelson's partner Reinaldo Da Silva carried two bags into a chauffeur-driven car. They drove out of the street, picked up the dogs and were away. Mr Mandelson's immediate plans were unclear. But already by last night the Northern Ireland office had moved on, replying to questions about his movements with a curt: "Mr Mandelson is now a private citizen. His privacy is his own." webTitle: Hinduja affair raises questions for policing of ministers

fields.headline: Hinduja affair exposes weaknesses in code
fields.standfirst:
Policing of ministers back in the spotlight

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The resignation of Peter Mandelson again raises questions about the ministerial code of conduct - and whether it is strict enough.
fields.body:
The resignation of Peter Mandelson again raises questions about the ministerial code of conduct - and whether it is strict enough.

The code was originally highlighted in the first Mandelson resignation over the £373,000 home loan from the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.

Then it became clear that Mr Mandelson had failed to tell his permanent secretary, Michael Scholar, that he had received the loan from Mr Robinson, who was at the time under investigation by DTI in spectors. Mr Mandelson was trade and industry secretary at the time.

This was seen as being a breach of the code. But it was never clear who was supposed to enforce it.

Yesterday Tony Blair specifically ruled out any further review of the code at prime minister's questions when he was pressed by the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy.

Last year Mr Blair had been put under pressure by Lord Neill, the retiring chairman of the committee on standards in public life, to make the code clearer and more open, and to require Whitehall to keep public records of ministers' lobbying.

Mr Blair refused to accept these changes, one of which would have made it clear that the prime minister would have the final say in whether the code had been breached.

The prime minister could claim in this case that he acted promptly to insist that Mr Mandelson should go. The failure to implement proposals to ensure that anybody lobbying ministers is placed on the Whitehall record is particularly important in this latest case, because Mr Mandelson would have known he would have been required to record the Hinduja brothers' request.

If such a proposal were enacted it might, as is the case in the United States, make politicians think twice about why they are meeting business people, because the fact that the meeting had taken place would be recorded by Whitehall.

Yesterday a panel was choosing a successor to Lord Neill. One of the key members was Sir Michael Scholar, the permanent secretary at the DTI. He is said to have quizzed the three shortlisted candidates very heavily about propriety in public life and how it should be policed.

webTitle: Bankers gave Wheeler 'waiver' to sell shares

fields.headline: Bankers gave Wheeler 'waiver' to sell shares
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Stuart Wheeler, the multimillionaire benefactor to the Conservative party, pledged £5m to William Hague's election campaign before he had even been given permission to raise the money from a share sale, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Stuart Wheeler, the multimillionaire benefactor to the Conservative party, pledged £5m to William Hague's election campaign before he had even been given permission to raise the money from a share sale, it emerged yesterday.

Mr Wheeler, who is the chairman of the spread-betting company, IG Index, only asked his bankers on Monday to break an agreement which prevented him from selling shares in the company he founded in 1974.

Yesterday, however, IG Index confirmed to the stock exchange that Mr Wheeler cashed in 1m shares to raise £5.1m on Tuesday, six months earlier than he was originally entitled to under the terms he signed when IG was floated on the stock market last July.

To sell the shares before July, South African-owned Investec Bank, which advised IG on its stock market debut, had to grant Mr Wheeler an unusual "waiver". By doing so, Investec Bank allowed Mr Wheeler to raise the money he needed to make his donation to the Conservative party, the largest single such gift ever made.

A spokesman for Investec Bank said: "We had to ask him what he going to do." In the prospectus issued at the time of flotation, Mr Wheeler agreed to sell no shares for year "without the prior ap proval of Investec Bank". In selling the 1m shares, Mr Wheeler, who is worth some £80m, was able make a profit of £2.7m on the shares in comparison with their worth when they first began trading on the stock market in the summer.

Investec Bank sold 1m shares for Mr Wheeler at £5.16, more than double the £2.40 they were worth at their stock market debut.

In return for being allowed to sell the shares early, Mr Wheeler has agreed to be locked into IG Index for a longer period.

A spokesman for IG said Mr Wheeler would have been able to sell 4m shares after the first anniversary of the flotation on July 19 2001. Now, however, Mr Wheeler has agreed not sell more than 1m shares before the end of December 2001.

Even with the share sale, Mr Wheeler still owns more than 18m shares in IG, the equivalent of 34% of the shares.

webTitle: Sacked Law Society chief 'created atmosphere of fear'

fields.headline: Sacked Law Society chief 'created atmosphere of fear'
fields.trailText: Kamlesh Bahl, vice-president of the Law Society until she was forced out last year for intimidating staff, was a bully who created an atmosphere of fear and dread, an employment tribunal was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Kamlesh Bahl, vice-president of the Law Society until she was forced out last year for intimidating staff, was a bully who created an atmosphere of fear and dread, an employment tribunal was told yesterday.

Robert Sayer, who was the society's president at the time, said her management style "paralysed" workers at the London headquarters of the solicitors' professional body in Chancery Lane. He said staff at the society, which represents 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales, had come to him to complain about the way Ms Bahl was treating them.

Mr Sayer was giving evidence at the tribunal in Watford, Hertfordshire, where Ms Bahl - the first female and ethnic minority vice president of the Law Society - is seeking damages for race and sex discrimination, victimisation and constructive dismissal. The tribunal started hearing her case in November, but it resumed yesterday after an adjournment.

Mr Sayer told the hearing that he had initially had high hopes that he and Ms Bahl would be an effective team in modernising and improving the "outdated" Law Society. But relations turned sour in 1999, when he heard how one member of staff had been "savaged" on the phone by her.

He said he was also approached by a member of the administrative staff, Ann Fraser, who said Ms Bahl had humiliated her by frequently shouting at her and calling her incompetent.

Mr Sayer said: "By this time I started to realise there was a problem."

He confronted her at a meeting in August 1999, but claimed she refused to discuss the issue. "She said: 'I don't know what you're talking about.' It was a clear refusal to discuss it. It was impossible to have a conversation. She kept saying 'I'm confused', but she wasn't really. She just said that as a shield so we would not have to talk about it."

He added: "When I said to her: 'Staff say you are bullying them,' she said I was bullying her."

Mr Sayer told the tribunal that the matter rolled on for several weeks and was discussed in various committees. Ms Bahl was eventually asked to leave the offices so that an official inquiry could take place. That inquiry, chaired by Lord Griffiths, a former law lord, upheld five complaints against her.

Ms Bahl, 44, a former chairman of the equal opportunities commission, denies that she was a bully and accuses the society of discrimination in the way it handled the allegations.

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Scots coalition at risk over care for elderly

fields.headline: Scots coalition at risk over care for elderly
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Scotland's coalition administration was under threat last night after the first minister, Henry McLeish, failed to offer free long-term care for the elderly.
fields.body:
Scotland's coalition administration was under threat last night after the first minister, Henry McLeish, failed to offer free long-term care for the elderly.

Mr McLeish had hinted he would implement in full the Sutherland royal commission recommendatons on funding of this care, creating the biggest policy rift to date between Holyrood and Westminster.

Yesterday Susan Deacon, the executive's health minister, announced a care package for the elderly that stopped short of the universal free care recommended by the commission, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland.

Pensioners' groups and opposition parties accused Mr McLeish of betraying devolution for Downing Street. Ten Liberal Democrat MSPs tabled a motion calling for an unequivocal commitment to free care for all, and efforts were under way last night to force a debate on the issue in the parliament.

Under the proposals announced by Ms Deacon, free personal care will be extended to cover people suffering from dementia; a development group will be set up to make further recommendations on elderly care; and a single needs assessment scheme will be adopted.

She said that she was offering Scotland's elderly a new deal, and claimed that many more would receive free nursing and personal care.

Nicola Sturgeon, the Scottish National party health spokesman, said the minister and Mr McLeish had sold out.

It has been reported that Downing Street was dismayed by Mr McLeish's plans and put pressure on him not to adopt a vastly superior care package to that provided to the rest of Britain, where nursing care is free but personal care is means tested.

"All of this comes after three months of Scotland being led to believe by the first minister that his government would implement Sutherland in full, but today we are being told that is not what he said," said Ms Sturgeon.

"It seems the only people that didn't agree with this was London Labour, and when faced with the choice of doing what is right by Scotland or appeasing London Labour, this government will always choose keeping London sweet, and let Scotland down."

Ms Deacon denied that the executive had bowed to pressure, saying: "We are here to deliver policies and solutions which meet Scotland's needs."

To jeers and shouts from the opposition benches, she added: "We will not make promises that we know we cannot keep."

Margaret Smith, Liberal Democrat MSP and convener of the health committee that unanimously backed full implementation of the Sutherland recommendations, said her party intended to keep forcing the issue. Its motion demanded a commitment to free care and a timetable in which to achieve it.

"The question now is: is Mr McLeish on London's leash, or is he on this government's leash?" she said.

When it was suggested that her actions might lead to a defeat for the executive and possibly the end of the Labour-Lib Dem coalition, Mrs Smith said she did not see why that should be the case.

If the motion was endorsed by the parliament, she said, "That will be the will of the parliament being exercised, and I think that would be a good day for this parliament."

webTitle: Blair and Hague on Mandelson's resignation

fields.headline: Labour's standards attacked by Hague
fields.standfirst:
Commons PM says Mandelson has 'paid penalty'

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The exchanges between Tony Blair and William Hague on Peter Mandelson's resignation at prime minister's question time in the Commons yesterday.
fields.body:
The exchanges between Tony Blair and William Hague on Peter Mandelson's resignation at prime minister's question time in the Commons yesterday:

Tony Blair: "As the house is very well aware, I had a meeting this morning with Mr Mandelson, who has since announced his decision to resign from the government later today. I would like to pay the warmest possible tribute to him for the tireless efforts he has made in securing peace in Northern Ireland and also for his personal courage and sense of duty in coming to the house this afternoon to answer questions on Northern Ireland before departing the government."

William Hague: "Now you've notched up the historic achievement of being forced to sack the same minister for the same offence, twice in 25 months, do you recognise that your career-long dependency on Mr Mandelson has been a monumental error of judgment?"

Blair: "I don't suppose I ever expected you to behave graciously at all over his resignation. But I believe that the job that Mr Mandelson has done in Northern Ireland well merited his position as secretary of state.

"I think he has made an enormous contribution to it (the peace process). Indeed, I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that I doubt the process in Northern Ireland would have been sustained so well, except with his commitment. I therefore believe it was right that he occupied that position and I also believe that he is a bigger man than many of his critics."

Hague: "The fact is that to reappoint in September 1999 a disgraced minister 10 months after he was forced to resign, in breach of every convention and precedent, was a demonstration of the arrogance with which you wield your power. To spare yourself and the country going through this a third time, will you now guarantee that Mr Mandelson will not be running the election campaign of the Labour party and will not return to office in any government led by you?"

Blair: "Mr Mandelson has already made that clear in the statement he made earlier. I think that he has done the right thing. I think he has done the honourable thing. It is a long tradition in this house that when someone does do that, we pay tribute to it. I am only sorry that once again you have lived down to my expectations."

Hague: "Mr Mandelson has done the right thing, but it's a pity your judgment led him to have to do it twice within the space of one parliament. Doesn't this go wider... because Mr Mandelson has been central to everything you have done. It was Mr Mandelson who picked you out, who briefed the press for you, who stabbed the chancellor (Gordon Brown) in the back for you, who spun all of your campaigns for you.

"The fact that his statement sadly could not be relied upon is not only the reason he has had to go, but it is the reason that he has been at the heart of the entire New Labour project."

Blair: "I repeat that I believe it was the right thing for him to do, that he came back into government as the Northern Ireland secretary. And I honestly do believe that in the broad sweep of history his contribution to that process will be far greater than what has happened in the last 24 hours - tragic though that is."

Hague: "It is not about the broad sweep of history. It is about the conduct of this government and the disgraceful conduct of this government. Hasn't it told us everything we need to know, not about Mr Mandelson, but about the way this government does its business?

"You said they would be purer than pure and as with every other pledge you have failed to deliver. When asked to choose between high standards of government and the low politics of your cronies, you have unerringly chosen the latter. You set those standards yourself. In every incomplete answer in this house, every distorted accusation and every piece of baseless spin, you have set the standards of this government.

"In a government where standards of truth, honesty and integrity have taken second place to spin and smear, aren't you truly the first among equals?"

Blair: "I really think that by that performance, you diminish yourself far more than you diminish anyone else. I made it clear that if people did something wrong they would pay the penalty, and he has paid the penalty.

"But I also believe that he can be very proud of the record and contribution he made while in government. As for the rest of the nonsense you have spoken, I've no intention of getting into it."

Blair: "I repeat that I believe it was the right thing for him to do, that he came back into government as the Northern Ireland secretary. And I honestly do believe that in the broad sweep of history his contribution to that process will be far greater than what has happened in the last 24 hours - tragic though that is." Hague: "It is not about the broad sweep of history. It is about the conduct of this government and the disgraceful conduct of this government. Hasn't it told us everything we need to know, not about Mr Mandelson, but about the way this government does its business? "You said they would be purer than pure and as with every other pledge you have failed to deliver. When asked to choose between high standards of government and the low politics of your cronies, you have unerringly chosen the latter. You set those standards yourself. In every incomplete answer in this house, every distorted accusation and every piece of baseless spin, you have set the standards of this government. "In a government where standards of truth, honesty and integrity have taken second place to spin and smear, aren't you truly the first among equals?" I made it clear that if people did something wrong they would pay the penalty, and he has paid the penalty. webTitle: BSE fears eat into McDonalds profits

fields.headline: BSE fears eat into McDonalds profits
fields.standfirst:
European consumers have started to shun McDonalds amid fears that its burgers might be infected with BSE - mad cow disease

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The US fast food chain yesterday blamed the European crisis for a 10% decline in regional sales in the last quarter and its first drop in profits for more than two years.
fields.body:
The US fast food chain yesterday blamed the European crisis for a 10% decline in regional sales in the last quarter and its first drop in profits for more than two years.

Jack Greenberg, McDonalds chairman and chief executive, also warned that "continuing consumer confidence issues in European beef" would make the next few months "very challenging".

Beef sales have tumbled 27% across the EU since the latest outbreak of bovine spongiform encephalopathy - a disease which has been linked to a brain-wasting illness in humans - was discovered in France in October.

In the past month, brain tissue from an Italian slaughterhouse known to supply McDonalds tested positive for BSE.

Quarterly profits fell by $34m (£24m) to $452m in the last three months of the year, compared with the year before, due to the downturn in Europe.

Sales have been hit particularly badly in France, Germany, Spain and Italy.

webTitle: Death rate down, but HIV infection at record high

fields.headline: Death rate down, but HIV infection at record high
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: HIV infection rates in the UK hit an high last year, according to the latest official figures, and are set to continue rising.
fields.body:
HIV infection rates in the UK hit an high last year, according to the latest official figures, and are set to continue rising.

The figures are clear evidence that HIV/Aids has not gone away in this country. Powerful drug combinations have slashed the death rate, but have led to complacency in some quarters, which may be behind some of the rise in infection rates.

The public health laboratory service revealed that 2,868 new diagnoses were reported in 2000 with further diagnoses pending.

There was alarm when the 1999 statistics showed the highest infection rate for 10 years. Updated figures for 1999 now show it was worse - there were more diagnoses than for any year since testing began in 1985.

But 2000 has already topped that, with a 7% increase on 1999.

Part of the reason is that people who were infected many years ago are only now coming forward for testing, according to the PHLS. But there are many new infections too, suggesting that people have begun to ignore or forget the safe sex message. There are also large increases in other sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea.

"This is the second consecutive year where we have reported record levels of HIV diagnoses," said Barry Evans, head of the HIV division of the PHLS communicable disease surveillance centre.

"We are now two decades into the HIV epidemic, but we continue to see new cases of an infection which is largely preventable. We cannot afford to be complacent about safer sex. The basic prevention messages remain the same: use a condom when having sex with a new or casual partner and in the case of injecting drug use, never share injecting equipment."

Funding for HIV/Aids projects has been cut back because of the success of modern drugs in keeping people alive. The UK's largest HIV/Aids charities, the Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse and the National Aids Trust warned that more investment in public education was needed to counter the rising infection rate. "With one case of HIV now being reported every 3 hours, we are concerned that the UK's fight against HIV is beginning to falter," said Derek Bodell, chief executive of the NAT.

"If we are to reverse this worrying trend we need to improve our investment in targeted HIV education campaigns, and the government must make this a priority in its long-awaited HIV and sexual health strategy," Mr Bodell said.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley on Mandelson's rise and fall

fields.headline: He was just too arrogant
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson's rise and fall were built on the belief that the Labour party could be converted into no more than a vehicle for propelling men and women of talent into the government of the country.
fields.body:
Six years ago, on the Tuesday evening of the Labour party conference, I was a guest at a party in Tony Blair's Brighton hotel room. Earlier that day, the prime minister (as he was soon to become) had made the best speech of his then brief leadership. So, as is the habit on such occasions, the assembled company took it in turns to congratulate him on his eloquence. One of our number, fearing that all the most convincing compliments had been exhausted, expressed his gratitude that the hand of friendship had been held out to old Labour. Peter Mandelson immediately took centre stage. "Let's get it clear," he said. "No room for old Labour, but a welcome to old Labour individuals who realise they have to change".

I felt a momentary fury. Then irritation at his impertinence combined with amusement at his presumption and disbelief that anyone who claimed to possess such acute political antennae could imagine that egalitarian socialism would quietly fade away. Looking back, I realise that I was witnessing an exhibition of the fatal flaw which yesterday made Peter Mandelson fall like Lucifer. The Greeks had a word for it. That word is hubris. It is the quality which lay at the heart of all the Mandelson mistakes and made his fate inevitable. He believed that he was above the rules of personal discipline and public conduct which constrained his colleagues. So he made mistakes which a more humble man would have avoided.

None of the mistakes were inherently unforgivable. Borrowing £300,000 from Geoffrey Robinson was not a heinous crime. It was absurd to suggest that the Legacy Consortium had become preferred purchaser of the Greenwich dome because the company chairman's wife gave a party to celebrate Peter Mandelson's birthday. And I am perfectly prepared to believe that his telephone call to the Home Office was an indication of interest in the Hinduja brothers' passport application rather than an attempt to persuade ministers to behave improperly. But his explanations invariably contain so much extraneous detail that the facts are sometimes difficult to detect. The problem was the frequency, not the size, of his indiscretions - and his belief that he could brush them aside as minor obstacles in his path to greatness.

A byproduct of that attitude was Peter Mandelson's almost total lack of political friends. When a cabinet minister is in trouble he needs the support of backbenchers, not the sort of people who were Mandelson's preferred companions. I have, in my time, organised MPs telephone calls to Downing Street in support of a beleaguered secretary of state. Lady Powell - wife of Margaret Thatcher's foreign policy adviser and apparently one of Mandelson's favourite society hostesses - cannot provide the same service.

There is no doubt that Mandelson was a first-class minister who fully deserved the tribute which the prime minister paid him for the work he did in Northern Ireland. Perhaps he was too good - or at least so good that he thought that his ability was a protection against all adversity. In politics it never is. So in the end he was destroyed by his own arrogance.

Until yesterday, I always assumed that another consequence of that dangerous characteristic would be his undoing. He felt little instinctive loyalty to colleagues with whom he had nothing in common except Labour party membership. There are at least half a dozen cabinet ministers who believe, with good cause, that Peter Mandelson regularly briefed compliant journalists about their supposed incompetence. And as many have been infuriated by his willingness to speak, often against official policy, on matters outside his departmental concern. I suspect that he enjoyed living dangerously. He has fallen off the high wire.

The prime minister's response to the mini-crisis which Mandelson has caused was impeccable. Regret, mixed with determination to protect the government's reputation, was the right note to strike. No doubt William Hague enjoyed his moment of Schadenfreude. But party leaders have not much to gain from behaving like starved terriers who has at last got his teeth into a mouldy bone. Nothing that happened yesterday will have much influence on the outcome of the general election. It ought, however, to have an influence on Tony Blair.

Peter Mandelson's rise and fall were built on the belief that the Labour party could be converted into no more than a vehicle for propelling men and women of talent into the government of the country. He had no time for its tradition, prejudices, foibles and weaknesses and believed that it had to be taught continual lessons about the need to embrace new values. So he behaved in a way which would have been acceptable in a director of a limited company. But politics is more than running the UK PLC. If Peter Mandelson had realised that, he would still be the secretary of state for Northern Ireland. As it is, he is lost to politics forever.

webTitle: WTO opts for safety at annual meeting

fields.headline: WTO opts for safety at annual meeting
fields.standfirst: Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: The hard-line Gulf state of Qatar has been chosen to host the first ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation since its ill-fated conference in Seattle in 1999.
fields.body:
The hard-line Gulf state of Qatar has been chosen to host the first ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation since its ill-fated conference in Seattle in 1999.

Despite reassurances from the WTO's director general, Mike Moore, that campaign groups would be given accreditation for the November meeting, anti-globalisation campaigners said Qatar's authoritarian record made it the wrong venue for talks.

The demonstrations in Seattle meant that there was a distinct shortage of volunteers among the WTO's 140 members to host the ministerial meeting.

Barry Coates, director of the World Development Movement, said: "This outrageous decision sends the clear message that it is OK turn a blind eye to human rights abuses in pursuit of free trade. The WTO has retreated to this inaccessible, repressive state where it won't be able hear the calls for much needed reform."

Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, said: "The WTO can't avoid public protests by holding a meeting in a country that doesn't allow public protest."

fields.headline: Logo only route for Renault
fields.standfirst: Marketing move could mean Nissan rebadging
fields.trailText: Renault, the French car maker, is planning to drop its name from its cars in a move which could make it easier to rebadge Nissan cars as its own.
fields.body:
Renault, the French car maker, is planning to drop its name from its cars in a move which could make it easier to rebadge Nissan cars as its own.

The French car firm says that its silver diamond logo, first used in 1925, is now so well known that the name is no longer needed. But the logo only policy will help when the company starts to sell some re-styled Nissan vehicles under the Renault badge.

Renault, which owns 37% of Nissan, wants to concentrate on either the Renault or Nissan name in some markets and build models on jointly developed platforms. A Renault spokesman said the company was planning a marketing campaign to improve the image of the marque rather than individual models.

The first model to carry just the logo on the back and front of the vehicle would be the Avantine two-door GT coupé, due out in October.

Nissan is due to decide later this month whether to make its new Micra model at its Sunderland plant or at a Renault plant in Flins, near Paris. The new Micra is due to be built on the same platform as the new Renault Clio, which will be made at Flins.

Nissan is reported to have decided to invest up to £600m in the Sunderland plant regardless of whether it gets the Micra contract.

At present the plant makes the Primera, Almera and old Micra models. About 1,300 jobs could be lost if it fails to secure the new Micra work.

The decision to drop the Renault name was hailed in some quarters as a marketing master-stroke and others as an overconfident assumption that its logo is widely known around the world.

The logo only route has been used successfully by firms such as luggage maker Louis Vitton and clothes makers Nike and Ralph Lauren.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Exxon profits biggest ever
European day of GM protest
Gossard axes 160 jobs
Profit warning from Ted Baker
Biotech revives cancer drug
fields.body:
Exxon profits biggest ever

Exxon Mobil, the US's leading oil group, said yesterday that soaring crude and natural gas prices had fuelled a huge rise in its fourth-quarter income, far surpassing analysts' forecasts.

Exxon said that fourth-quarter income - excluding exceptionals - rose to $5.12bn (£3.5bn), or $1.46 per diluted share, from $2.7bn, or 77 cents a share. Revenue rose to $64.13bn from $54.58bn.

"This was a helluva quarter, and it's a helluva company," said Gene Nowak, an analyst with ABN Amro.

Full-year earnings at Exxon rose to $16.9bn, or $4.81 a share, from $8.4bn, or $2.38 per share, in 1999. Those are the highest full-year profits ever posted by a US firm.

European day of GM protest

General Motors will be hit by a day of action in Europe tomorrow carried by thousands of workers protesting at the decision to end production at the Vauxhall plant in Luton, with the loss of 2,000 jobs.

Workers at the Luton factory are not expected to report for their shifts, although union officials have denied suggestions of a mass "sickie".

Workers at Vauxhall's factory in Ellesmere Port are expected to take action in support of Luton colleagues. A Vauxhall spokesman said, however, the company was expecting normal production.

Meanwhile, workers at General Motors' plants in Belgium, Germany, Spain and Portugal are expected to take strike action.

Gossard axes 160 jobs

Lingerie company Gossard today confirmed it was closing a factory with the loss of more than 160 jobs. The plant in Ponllanfraith, south Wales, is to cease production on February 2.

The closure has been blamed on increasing pressure from cheap imports. Gossard's chief executive, Andrew Mann, said: "We have gone to great lengths to keep this factory open to keep it viable as long as possible. But unfortunately we can no longer do that."

Profit warning from Ted Baker

Upmarket fashion brand Ted Baker joined the Christmas casualty list yesterday as it revealed that its sales in November and December had fallen short of expectations and issued a profit warning.

Shares fell by 72p to 232p, wiping £30m off the value of the company. Only six months ago the shares were changing hands at 530p. Sales were ahead by 19% between November 1 and December 24, but even that represented an abrupt slowdown.

Biotech revives cancer drug

British Biotech has revived its failed cancer drug, batimastat, to use as a treatment for blocked arteries in a joint venture with health care company Biocompatibles. British Biotech's shares rose 0.5p to 29p, while Biocompatibles slipped 12.5p to 348p.

fields.headline: LSE sees off old guard
fields.standfirst: Rationalisation could see shares in stock exchange floated as early as May
fields.trailText: Rationalisation could see shares in stock exchange floated as early as May.
fields.body:
Shares in the London Stock Exchange could be floated as soon as May in an attempt to smooth the way for mergers or takeovers with rival exchanges.

Hours after confirming the ground-breaking appointment of Clara Furse as its chief executive and seeing off the "old guard" of its board, the LSE made it clear that it expected 2001 to mark a step-change in the pace of consolidation of exchanges around the world.

The exchange threw off its mutual status last year but then endured the humiliation of failing to merge with Deustche Börse because of the hostile, ill-fated bid by Sweden's OM Gruppen. The LSE then turned away offers from Nasdaq, the US hi-tech market, and Euronext - the French, Belgian and Dutch alliance of exchanges.

Yesterday, Don Cruickshank, chairman of the LSE, said the exchange was considering a flotation as soon as May. Currently they are traded privately through Cazenove. "We'll be more like a normal part of the economy and it will be better basis for talking rationalisation," Mr Cruickshank said.

He made it clear, however, that a decision about the timetable for flotation - which would require the shareholder cap of 4.9% to be lifted - had not yet been reached. Merger talks will be the responsibility of Ms Furse, who joins from French-owned broker Credit Lyonnais Rouse. With 21 years experience in the City, she is former deputy chairman of Liffe, the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange. Ms Furse said yesterday that she was not harbouring preconceived ideas. She will be paid a basic salary of £300,000, £100,000 less than her predecessor, and could receive a performance-related bonus which could reach £300,000. She will also join the share option scheme which will entitle her to shares worth £800,000 over a three-year period.

Of Dutch parentage, born in Canada but educated at an American school in Columbia, Ms Furse insisted she was be mused by the publicity surrounding her appointment. She is the first female chief executive in the exchange's 200 year history.

"I don't understand why it's so interesting to so many people. There are lots of women out there working very hard bring up their families and doing what they do and they are not in the limelight," Ms Furse said.

Her appointment was confirmed as part of a wider shake-up of the LSE board, which appeared to pitch the new management against the smaller stock broking community. Nigel Sherlock, the chairman of Wise Speke, who was regarded as their representative, is leaving.

Also leaving the board is Hector Sants, of CSFB, regarded as a leading candidate for the chief executive role; Simon Robertson of Goldman Sachs; Ian Plenderleith of the Bank of England; and IMI chief executive Graham Allen.

Four new non-executives, from outside the broking community, were named, including Baroness Cohen.

webTitle: Calmer tone on Iraq from MoD

fields.headline: Calmer tone on Iraq from MoD
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Britain seemed to change its tone towards Iraq yesterday, playing down reports in the US that Saddam Hussein had rebuilt three chemical weapons factories and saying that threats posed to British and US aircraft patrolling the no-fly zones had diminished.
fields.body:
Britain seemed to change its tone towards Iraq yesterday, playing down reports in the US that Saddam Hussein had rebuilt three chemical weapons factories and saying that threats posed to British and US aircraft patrolling the no-fly zones had diminished.

There is "no threat yet" from Iraqi nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, said a senior Ministry of Defence official, who added that the past year had seen fewer threats to the patrolling jets.

His remarks were in contrast to recent rhetoric from ministers directed at the Iraqi dictator. They also stood in contrast to a US intelligence report stating there was "no let-up" in Iraq's drive "to reconstitute its [pre-Gulf war] weapons and missile capabilities".

The MoD's shift in tone coincided with praise for Iraq by experts from the International Atomic Energy Agency. Ahmed Abu Zahra, head of the agency's team, refused to comment on whether the group had found evidence that Iraq was reviving its nuclear weapons facilities, but he told Reuters in Baghdad: "Everything went well, we found good cooperation from our counterparts in Iraq and from the Iraqi Atomic Energy Organisation."

However, the senior MoD official did say that if there were evidence of Iraq rebuilding its arsenals or working on weapons of mass destruction, Britain and the US would have no hesitation in bombing relevant sites.

Although the official said that Britain's "overall strategic objectives" remained the same, the change in tone may reflect a realisation in Whitehall that US and British tactics have not swayed President Saddam.

MoD figures released yesterday said that US and British jets had dropped 500 bombs on Iraq last year compared to 1,500 in 1999. British pilots dropped 36 bombs last year.

Although the official said that "we do not want to up the temperature", he said there were other reasons for the relative decline in the number of times British pilots had reacted to Iraqi artillery fire or missiles. The pilots, who have flexible rules of engagement, did not want to respond in a predictable way, he said.

Figures given yesterday to Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrats' foreign affairs spokesman, suggest that the bombing rate has risen slightly in the past few weeks.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, revealed that patrolling the no-fly zones had cost Britain £911m since 1982.

fields.headline: Monotub chief in a spin
fields.trailText: Hi-tech washing machine company Monotub Industries has discovered that its appliances have a tendency to spin out of control with "frightening" consequences - prompting the resignation of its chief executive, Brian Austin.
fields.body:
Hi-tech washing machine company Monotub Industries has discovered that its appliances have a tendency to spin out of control with "frightening" consequences - prompting the resignation of its chief executive, Brian Austin.

The firm is based around a "revolutionary" new machine named Titan, which holds more clothes and uses less water than existing models.

However, Monotub has been forced to delay next month's launch of Titan until summer at the earliest, after the drums in several machines spun off their axles. The news sent the shares crashing 207.5p to 425p, wiping £28m off the firm's market value.

Chairman Martin Myerscough said: "If these machines fail at top speed, they decelerate from 1,200 revolutions per minute to zero in about one second. The effect of that is that cabinets can leap in the air and make an enormous bang, which is really quite a frightening experience."

Although the problem has only emerged in a few units, Mr Myerscough said it was "not a niggle but a fundamental issue". Mr Myerscough said Mr Austin felt "personally responsible" for the debacle and had abruptly quit.

The setback is Monotub's second in three months. It had planned to launch Titan by the end of last year but problems with water seals prompted a delay until February.

webTitle: G2: Oliver Burkeman emulates Richard Tomlinson

fields.headline: Mission impossible?
fields.standfirst: Maverick agent Richard Tomlinson says he was given the usual test to find out if he was MI6 material - he was dumped in Portsmouth for an hour and told to get the passport number of an unsuspecting member of the public. That can't be so hard, thought  Oliver Burkeman  ...
fields.trailText: Maverick agent Richard Tomlinson says he was given the usual test to find out if he was MI6 material - he was dumped in Portsmouth for an hour and told to get the passport number of an unsuspecting member of the public. That can't be so hard, thought Oliver Burkeman ...
fields.body:
3.45pm, Commercial Road, Portsmouth.

I am not qualified for this. Despite having attended one of the noble institutions from which Her Majesty's spooks are supposedly recruited, I was, embarrassingly, never approached about being a spy. My sole source of expertise is a distant memory of the Usborne Book of Spycraft, in which espionage mainly involved cutting eye-holes in a newspaper and looking through them furtively in a cafe. Shoppers in Portsmouth's main commercial precinct are unimpressed by this. So plan B involved purchasing a clipboard and posing as a representative of the French tourist authority, asking people about their last trip to France and offering them a chance to win a holiday - for which I will, for administrative reasons, require a passport number.

This fails, partly because you don't take your passport with you when you go shopping. Even then, the number of people willing to listen beyond the first sentence can be counted on the fingers of one finger. Most are clearly ambling between Debenhams and Marks & Spencer at two miles per hour, but all claim to be "rather busy". My only original inspiration exhausted, it is time to adopt the Tomlinson gambit.

3.55pm, The Marmion pub.

Tomlinson made it look easy: he spent his first half-hour drinking alone in a gloomy pub, then approached two nurses at the bar. He told them he was the skipper of a yacht sailing to France that had a last-minute need for crew. Fortuitously, they were enthusiastic amateur sailors and happily signed up, passport numbers and all.

There are no equivalent young women in the Marmion, a smoking pub with an alarming list posted on the door identifying violent undesirables to whom entry is forbidden. There is, though, an old man with a very big moustache, who chats happily until I mention sailing. "The thing is," he says over his pint of Flowers, "Portsmouth's too tidal. So you won't find anyone here who does that. You'll have to go to Hayling Island. There's a marina there." He politely signals the end of the conversation by moving as far away from me as the dimensions of the building will allow.

4.05pm, Owens pub.

Extrapolating from Tomlinson's sample, I should have met numerous yachting experts by now, but at Owens, a sleazy red and gold drinking den, two Scottish girls drinking wine by the window claim ignorance too. "No," says one, when I subtly turn the conversation to sailing. "We're not really here." A fellow secret agent, clearly: Portsmouth, home to M16's Fort Monkton training base, must be crawling with them. "I mean we don't really live round here. We're here on a course." Not a sailing course, then? "No." The look they both give me at this point is not interpretable in most cultures as meaning: "Please sit down and join us for the evening; we'd love to get to know you."

4.20pm, Palmerston Road, Southsea.

Back to the street - this time in Southsea, 15 minutes from central Portsmouth, in a last-ditch attempt to find obliging locals with time on their hands and passports in their pockets. At this point in his hour, Tomlinson was still on his second pint and hadn't approached anybody. There is hope yet, surely, for my "I'm doing a survey" strategy.

Actually there isn't. Anyone planning a career in MI6 may be interested to know that nobody in Portsmouth is remotely interested in any of the following conversational ice-breakers:

1. Excuse me, I'm doing a project for college.

2. Hello, I represent the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

3. Would you like to help paraplegic children?

4. Would you like to help paraplegic horses?

5. Can I ask you a few security questions?

6. Sorry to bother you, but I'm training to be a spy.

4.35, The Hogshead.

Things are getting desperate. I sprint into the Hogshead and, abandoning all pretence at smooth talking, blurt to the woman behind the bar: "Do you know anything about sailing?" The extraordinary thing is, she does. "I've been a few times," says the Welsh barmaid, who I later learn is called Leanne. "Why?" Because I need a new crew member for my glamorous sailing trip. Would she be interested? "I might be. When?"

Fantastic. A life of intrigue and deviousness, of Martinis and fast cars, and gadgets that look like harmless ballpoint pens but are, in fact, lethal weapons, opens up before me.

"Next weekend."

"Sorry. I'm going away."

She insists that I take the mobile number of her friend, a professional sailor. But if I ask for her passport number now, she's going to think I'm weird or something - which is, of course, an impression I've been strenuously seeking to avoid until now. And then it strikes me: a strategy so audaciously simple that it didn't even occur to Tomlinson.

4.42pm, Portsmouth ferry port

I step out of a taxi at Portsmouth ferry port into silence - we've arrived between sailings - but here, if anywhere, somebody must have a passport.

And it is, in the end, preposterously easy, even though there are only two passengers anywhere to be seen. One, I can now reveal, is Christophe Percepied, an unemployed Frenchman from in Bonsecours. He is studying a glass of beer in the pub inside the terminal, where he accepts my vague claim to be doing "a project" and "some research" that absolutely requires him to hand over the relevant information. The other is David Dawson, a part-time coach driver from Workington, Cumbria. He is behind the wheel of the only car already parked up for the St Malo crossing - which isn't for ages yet, so he can hardly claim to be busy when I tap brightly on his windscreen and spin him the French tourist authority line.

I know both their addresses and passport numbers now, and if anyone from the relevant agency should wish to call, I will be happy to pass them on.

webTitle: Scotia nears bankruptcy after latest setback

fields.headline: Scotia nears bankruptcy after latest setback
fields.trailText: Biotechnology company Scotia Holdings was left limping towards bankruptcy yesterday after European regulators indicated that they were unlikely to approve Foscan, the firm's laser-based treatment for head and neck cancer.
fields.body:
Biotechnology company Scotia Holdings was left limping towards bankruptcy yesterday after European regulators indicated that they were unlikely to approve Foscan, the firm's laser-based treatment for head and neck cancer.

The setback followed a similar thumbs-down from the US food and drug administration in September. Scotia's shares were suspended at 18.5p, valuing the Stirling-based business at £16m, as the company admitted it did not have enough cash to appeal against either decision.

Chief executive Robert Dow said: "We're all deeply disappointed and clearly, there is a sense of despondency among the workforce."

Founded in 1979, Scotia is one of Britain's oldest biotech companies.

The firm originally specialised in developing medicines based on lipids - fatty substances found in the body. However, a series of product failures left its future almost entirely dependant on Foscan.

Foscan is a therapy whereby patients are injected with a drug which becomes active when they sit under a special lamp. Regulators decided, however, that trial results, which showed a positive effect on 25% of cancer sufferers, were not good enough.

The European medicines evaluation agency's preliminary decision followed a majority vote by its scrutineers on Tuesday evening.

Mr Dow said: "There were some that spoke up for us. A majority vote is like losing in a penalty shoot-out - inevitably, you feel robbed. But you can say that coming close isn't good enough and I accept accountability for failing."

At its present rate of expenditure, Scotia is likely to run out of cash by the end of March. Any appeal would take at least 180 days.

Scotia said it was "considering its strategic options". These are thought to include the sale of its remaining assets or a straightforward takeover.

Any buyer would, however, inherit huge debts - the firm has £50m of convertible loans outstanding, which must be repaid unless its share price reaches 340p by next year.

Mr Dow has been criticised for gambling too heavily on Foscan. When he became chief executive of the company in 1998, he cut the number of drugs in development from 28 to five.

webTitle: Ban on North sea cod fishing

fields.headline: Ban on North sea cod fishing
fields.standfirst: Special report: Global crisis in fishing
fields.trailText: A 40,000 square mile swath of the North sea, almost a fifth of its entire area, will be off limits to cod, haddock and whiting fishermen this spring as part of a desperate attempt to ensure the cod stock is not wiped out, the European commission announced yesterday.
fields.byline: Paul Brown  and  Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
A 40,000 square mile swath of the North sea, almost a fifth of its entire area, will be off limits to cod, haddock and whiting fishermen this spring as part of a desperate attempt to ensure the cod stock is not wiped out, the European commission announced yesterday.

It is far more sweeping than the original proposals put for ward in December and will be the first time that parts of the North sea have been closed for fishing - putting many trawlermen out of work. Officials argued that the measure was essential if there was to be any cod left in the North sea next year.

Industrial fishing, which takes juvenile fish to feed salmon farms and to make animal feed, has also been banned in most areas although the Danes have been allowed a small fishery in their own waters.

Gregor Kreuzhuber for the EU said: "If we don't implement drastic measures now there will be no fish left next year. There is no way round this. This is a critical situation."

An area from north of Scotland to the east of England will be closed to trawlermen who take cod, haddock and whiting in the same nets. Cod stocks have fallen to their lowest levels in the last hundred years and quotas for the white fish were cut by as much as 40% by EU fisheries ministers last month.

Supplies to consumers will not be hit by the ban because the big buyers get most of their fish from outside the North sea. Today they are launching the Frozen at Sea Fillets Association to restore confidence in the industry.

The North sea ban will last from mid-February until the end of April - the crucial spawning period for cod and will be rigorously policed. Some fishermen will be allowed into the so-called "controlled zone" - namely those on the look out for species which swim at higher levels such as mackerel. But they will have to put up with on-board observers making sure that they do not catch any cod.

Commission officials said yesterday that they were also considering bringing in a similar scheme for hake and made it clear that shutting off large parts of the North sea for cod fishermen could be an annual event. A five-year plan for stock recovery is being developed and will be put to ministers in June. If stocks recover the North sea could produce more than 10 times as many fish as were caught last year.

Norway, which manages North sea fishing along with the EU, has already agreed to the plan which also includes other emergency measures such as forcing fishermen to apply for special permits and reporting what they catch in greater detail.

The UK has been heavily involved in negotiations. "I welcome this conservation initiative. Taken together with the big cuts in cod fishing effort agreed at December's fisheries council in Brussels this is the most significant conservation measure since the common fisheries policy was set up in 1983," said fisheries minister Elliot Morley.

Other measures such as forcing fishermen to use special meshed nets, which allow juvenile cod to escape, are likely to be agreed shortly, he added.

But Mike Park, chairman of the Scottish White Fish Producers' Association, claimed the plan was too harsh and called for government compensation.

"If the fleet were affluent just now, this measure would seem fine. But the fleet is just managing to exist at the moment. By the end of April we are going to see several casualties in the industry."

WWF joined the fishermen in asking for compensation to tide the fleet over. It said: "We feel for the fishermen but this is a positive step in the right direction."

fields.bodyText: A 40,000 square mile swath of the North sea, almost a fifth of its entire area, will be off limits to cod, haddock and whiting fishermen this spring as part of a desperate attempt to ensure the cod stock is not wiped out, the European commission announced yesterday. It is far more sweeping than the original proposals put for ward in December and will be the first time that parts of the North sea have been closed for fishing - putting many trawlermen out of work. Officials argued that the measure was essential if there was to be any cod left in the North sea next year. Industrial fishing, which takes juvenile fish to feed salmon farms and to make animal feed, has also been banned in most areas although the Danes have been allowed a small fishery in their own waters. Gregor Kreuzhuber for the EU said: "If we don't implement drastic measures now there will be no fish left next year. There is no way round this. This is a critical situation." An area from north of Scotland to the east of England will be closed to trawlermen who take cod, haddock and whiting in the same nets. Cod stocks have fallen to their lowest levels in the last hundred years and quotas for the white fish were cut by as much as 40% by EU fisheries ministers last month. Supplies to consumers will not be hit by the ban because the big buyers get most of their fish from outside the North sea. Today they are launching the Frozen at Sea Fillets Association to restore confidence in the industry. The North sea ban will last from mid-February until the end of April - the crucial spawning period for cod and will be rigorously policed. Some fishermen will be allowed into the so-called "controlled zone" - namely those on the look out for species which swim at higher levels such as mackerel. But they will have to put up with on-board observers making sure that they do not catch any cod. Commission officials said yesterday that they were also considering bringing in a similar scheme for hake and made it clear that shutting off large parts of the North sea for cod fishermen could be an annual event. A five-year plan for stock recovery is being developed and will be put to ministers in June. If stocks recover the North sea could produce more than 10 times as many fish as were caught last year. Norway, which manages North sea fishing along with the EU, has already agreed to the plan which also includes other emergency measures such as forcing fishermen to apply for special permits and reporting what they catch in greater detail. The UK has been heavily involved in negotiations. "I welcome this conservation initiative. Taken together with the big cuts in cod fishing effort agreed at December's fisheries council in Brussels this is the most significant conservation measure since the common fisheries policy was set up in 1983," said fisheries minister Elliot Morley. Other measures such as forcing fishermen to use special meshed nets, which allow juvenile cod to escape, are likely to be agreed shortly, he added. But Mike Park, chairman of the Scottish White Fish Producers' Association, claimed the plan was too harsh and called for government compensation. "If the fleet were affluent just now, this measure would seem fine. But the fleet is just managing to exist at the moment. By the end of April we are going to see several casualties in the industry." WWF joined the fishermen in asking for compensation to tide the fleet over. It said: "We feel for the fishermen but this is a positive step in the right direction." fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: In Our Time | In Business
fields.body:
In Our Time (9.0am, Radio 4) finds Melvyn Bragg and guests wondering at the Victorians' extraordinary capacity to mask their imperial rapacity with moral rectitude. Professor Richard Draper has written a book highlighting Kew Gardens as one of the oddest monuments to this hypocrisy. An army of 19th-century British botanists sailed forth, firmly believing the discovery of new flora to hold the key to human progress. Having found the plants, of course, they thought it essential to conserve them by colonising their habitat.

In the Bush administration's first week at the White House, Peter Day tackles the question riveting the president and the rest of the globe - is America's longest boom now heading for a bust? As he reports for In Business (8.30pm, Radio 4), there are plenty who still think share prices are too high and heading for a fall. And the Federal Reserve's recent unexpected cut in interest rates has made them even more jittery.
