webTitle: Dumas denies forcing oil firm to hire lover

fields.headline: Dumas denies forcing oil firm to hire lover
fields.trailText: The former French foreign minister Roland Dumas denied yesterday that he had demanded that the oil firm Elf-Aquitaine appoint his mistress to a high-paying job, and that the couple had subsequently lived luxuriously on the company's largesse.
fields.body:
The former French foreign minister Roland Dumas denied yesterday that he had demanded that the oil firm Elf-Aquitaine appoint his mistress to a high-paying job, and that the couple had subsequently lived luxuriously on the company's largesse.

Mr Dumas and his ex-lover Christine Deviers-Joncour are on trial in Paris along with five senior Elf-Aquitaine officials, charged with misusing the formerly state-run firm's funds in the early 1990s.

The prosecution claims that Mr Dumas used his influence as foreign minister to get the former lingerie model a job, and that he subsequently received money and other gifts from her paid for by Elf-Aquitaine. They also allegedly shared an apartment paid for with company money.

The allegations have hounded Mr Dumas for the past three years. If found guilty, he could be jailed for five years and fined£250,000.

"I never asked anyone for anything," he told the court. "If I had asked someone to hire Ms Deviers-Joncour, I would have asked [Elf] president Loik Le Floch-Prigent directly, which a minister of state can allow himself to do."

Looking every inch the ageing roué in an elegant blue suit and leaning on a cane, the 78-year-old politician, described by one French newspaper as "the prince of intrigue in [former president] Francois Mitterrand's palace", repeatedly threw glances around the small courtroom to measure the impact of his words.

"I speak for the benefit of the court, but if you will allow the expression, I also speak for history," Mr Dumas said. "It's heartbreaking for me to be here. Running the risk of dishonour at my age is a disagreeable reality."

On Tuesday a former senior Elf official, Andre Tarallo, said he had signed Ms Deviers-Joncour's employment contract at Mr Dumas' behest. In three years she was paid Fr64.5m (nearly £7m), mostly in commissions, he said.

Mr Le Floch-Prigent, who is also on trial, told the court on Tuesday he was unaware of Ms Deviers-Joncour's recruitment.

But the man believed to be the chief protagonist in Elf's £250m spending spree in the early 90s, which was aimed at increasing the global influence of the firm - and France - has fled the country. Alfred Sirven, Elf's former number two, is believed to be in the Philippines and is being tried in absentia.

The company allegedly provide Ms Deviers-Joncour with a credit facility of £20,000 a month, and a £1.7m Left Bank flat which Mr Dumas used for lavish parties. She also allegedly gave him gifts bought with Elf's cash, including a pair of bespoke Italian shoes costing £1,110 and five antique statues costing £26,400.

The prosecution claims that she was employed by Elf to lobby Mr Dumas, notably for the sale of six frigates to Taiwan. The court is not expected to directly deal with that case, which is still under investigation, during this trial.

Asked what was Ms Deviers-Joucour's role when she worked for Elf, Mr Dumas said: "She was the least of my worries. She was an emissary. But not for Floch-Prigent, rather for Sirven. I did not know the terms of her contract, nor how much she was paid."

"You didn't think she was doing it voluntarily?" the court president asked him sarcastically. "Do I appear naive to you?" Mr Dumas retorted.

France has been gripped and revolted by the trial, with its suggestions of sex, betrayal, dubious military sales and corruption at the top of the government. It coincides with inquiries into an arms-trafficking scandal during the Mitterrand era allegedly involving the late president's son Jean-Christophe.

Thanks to these two scandals, the stink of corruption from the Mitterrand era has all but obliterated the stench from the party funding scandal that embroiled President Jacques Chirac late last year.

The trial is expected to last four weeks.

fields.headline: Parthus warns of 2.5G delay
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Overheating mobile handsets and poor battery life could delay the mass take-up of the next generation of internet enabled devices by at least one year, Irish technology firm Parthus cautioned yesterday.
fields.body:
Overheating mobile handsets and poor battery life could delay the mass take-up of the next generation of internet enabled devices by at least one year, Irish technology firm Parthus cautioned yesterday.

The warning coincided with the first next generation phones going on sale in Europe after Berlin-based operator Viag Interkom said it had stocked 20,000 in German stores.

Mobile firms have gambled billions of pounds on developing devices and buying licenses through which they hope to deliver lucrative new services that will transform mobiles into personal organisers and entertainment systems that have an "always-on" high-speed link to the internet.

Big players such as Vodafone, BT Cellnet and Orange hope GPRS (general packet radio switching) or "2.5 generation phones" will be on mass sale by Christmas, but Parthus chief executive Brian Long believes that target may have to be put back until the end of 2002.

Operators already have to contend with worries that demand for the new GPRS handsets will oustrip supply.

BT Cellnet and KPN Mobile of the Netherlands have already started offering the services to corporate customers.

GPRS phones are expected to be around three times as fast as WAP phones, which were launched last year offering access to the internet but have disappointed consumers.

"There are problems with GPRS for sure," he said. "I don't think we'll see mass use of GPRS until the end of 2002. GPRS cellphones will go on sale this year, but the big issue is performance. Phones are running too hot and talk time is too low."

Industry sources say that trials on prototype third-generation or UMTS phones which will also be able to deliver live video footage to users' handsets are proving even more troublesome as engineers struggle to cram into handsets technology that meets power, size and cost requirements.

"Some of the models that we have seen hardly work," said an executive at one European network operator.

Parthus, which designs mobile chips, yesterday reported a 68% rise in revenues to $31.9m (£22m) and a net loss of $16m. Shares climbed 10% to 209.5p.

webTitle: Fischer proposes European federation, not superstate

fields.headline: Fischer proposes European federation, not superstate
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: In eight months Joschka Fischer has turned himself from a much liked and colourful figure into perhaps the most controversial politician in the European Union.
fields.body:
In eight months Joschka Fischer has turned himself from a much liked and colourful figure into perhaps the most controversial politician in the European Union.

Even before his speech in London last night he had taken over Jacques Delors's role as the man British Eurosceptics loved to hate. But they are not the only people he makes uneasy.

Mr Fischer's original sin was to pose a question. In a speech at Humboldt University in Berlin in May last year he asked whether the EU could continue with its present systems and structures when it was preparing to bring in up to a dozen more countries.

What particularly worried him was the notion that decisions were about to be taken that would have an enormous impact on Europe's future shape, without an agreed idea of what the shape should be.

Then he put forward what he insisted was his personal view of a destination to be reached decades hence. Acknowledging that he was risking the wrath of British Eurosceptics, he proposed a federation.

As he tried to explain more fully last night, a federation did not have to be a "European superstate".

Yes, it would have to have some overall authority, but if its building blocks were nation states there was no reason why they should not retain immense powers.

The idea looks a lot like a federal Germany writ large. The British and the French, by contrast, live in two of the most centralised states on earth, and so have little federal experience.

Another reason why Mr Fischer and his boss, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, want a definition of the distribution of power in Europe is that they are under pressure from Germany's component states, the länder. These regional authorities are deeply concerned that European integration could whittle away their considerable powers.

What officials in London and Paris want to know is how Mr Fischer proposes to keep the nation state as strong as he says while preserving the regions' powers and transferring new power to an eventual supra-national authority.

Were he from, say, Portugal, his ideas would no doubt have caused a mere ripple of interest. But Germany is Germany - and, right now, it is throwing its weight around as never before in the EU, where its wealth and the weight of its reunited population make it the natural leader. That fact was recognised for the first time in the voting arrangements agreed at last month's Nice summit.

Mr Fischer is making his case from a platform that now stands higher than those of fellow-politicians.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
New violence in Diyarbakir
Mir operation blasts off
Laos mystery explosion
fields.body:
New violence in Diyarbakir

Six policemen were shot dead in the south-eastern Turkish city of Diyarbakir yesterday, shattering the fragile calm which had been re-established in much of the Kurdish region after years of conflict.

Gaffar Okkan, the provincial police chief, was killed along with his driver and three bodyguards after assailants opened fire on his car at close range. Four other officers were injured.
Chris Morris, Istanbul

Mir operation blasts off

A Russian cargo vessel blasted off from Baikonur in Kazakhstan yesterday to guide the doomed Mir space station back to earth to be ditched in the Pacific Ocean. The rocket is due to dock with Mir on Saturday.
Reuters, Kazakhstan

Laos mystery explosion

A blast on the Laotian side of a bridge linking the country with Thailand injured at least nine people yesterday, the latest in a series of mysterious explosions. Thai police said nine Thais were injured in the blast at the Friendship Bridge over the Mekong river. No one has claimed responsibility for any of the blasts.
Reuters, Bangkok

webTitle: Women: London Underground recruits women drivers

fields.headline: Heard the one about women drivers?
fields.standfirst:
Anita Chaudhuri reports on a revolution underground

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Anita Chaudhuri reports on a revolution underground.
fields.body:
London Underground is advertising for female train drivers. "We believe in modern values ... like opening doors for women," they proclaim, before going on to extol the benefits of a train-driving career (if you're job-hunting, starting salary £27, 656, free travel for you and your partner).

It is surprising enough that London Underground should have developed such a progressive recruitment policy; more surprising still is that the ad runs in the current issue of that well-known bible for locomotive enthusiasts, Cosmopolitan.

"We decided to advertise in Cosmo because we want to attract a new generation of young women to join us," says Terry Day, the woman in charge of LU's equal opportunities programme. "London is a diverse city and we want to reflect that in the people we have working for us."

It is certainly the case that there is a dearth of women driving underground trains: out of the service's 2,900 drivers, only 100 are women. For all LU's positive spin, there is no getting away from the fact that driving a train still has macho-fantasy connotations in a way that, say, being a ticket inspector does not.

Mary Jones (not her real name), 45, has been a driver with London Transport for over a decade. "I'm not in favour of direct recruitment from outside the Underground, from Cosmo readers or anywhere else," she says. "It's far better to train up drivers who have already had experience of stations. It could be a real culture shock for a young woman coming to work in this environment."

She says that although some of the macho culture has vastly improved, there are still instances of harassment and inappropriate behaviour. Although London Underground recently implemented new guidelines on dealing with misconduct, Jones believes staff need to be better educated about the issues involved.

"Over the years, I've had to sit and watch what happens when a new woman joins the depot. Her availability is discussed, her appearance is discussed and it can be difficult for a woman to deal with. How you survive that depends very much on the kind of person you are."

She points out that advertising in Cosmo might attract new recruits, but that doesn't mean London Underground will keep them. "Unless they sort out the inflexible working hours, those women will leave once they want to start families."

The shift patterns involved in the job are daunting: drivers can be asked to clock on as early as 4.45 in the morning, or work until as late as 1.30am, and there are no opportunities for part-time contracts. In addition, working in a largely male environment can take its toll.

"When I first joined, I wasn't intimidated by that, largely because I had come up through the women's movement and knew how to be assertive. But I have seen women come to work here and be taken advantage of in every way possible."

Jones says women do have certain qualities that make them very good at the job, such as the ability to remain calm in a crisis and to be non-confrontational during arguments - an occupational hazard. "You have to realise that as a woman you are going to be wound up by male drivers. Sometimes, if you're stuck in a tunnel, the guy on the train behind you might say: 'This is all your fault, bloody women drivers,' when you know it's the fault of someone four trains ahead. But it's generally good-natured banter."

Jones admits the job has boosted her confidence. "It's a very responsible job, obviously, and you learn to trust your own instincts. If I feel a train isn't safe to drive, then I take it out of service and that's that. If I were a bus driver and I had a breakdown, all I'd have to do was park it and call a mechanic. With a train you have no choice but to get it moving off the track, usually on your own."

The most harrowing aspect of the job is clearing passengers off the train at the end of the night. "That can be very tricky, I don't really like it," Jones confesses. "Very often you have to run your train back to the yard from the end-of-line station and you can get the sack if you don't get all the passengers off first. On a weekend, late at night, imagine what some of the men are like. In the days when there were guards, it was fine; now I have to do it all on my own and if the supervisor's office is miles away, you know it'll be ages before help arrives, even if you do radio for back-up."

But it's the little things that make the job worthwhile, she confides, such as when passengers come up and thank her. "Other times, some bright spark will rap on the window and go: 'Don't tell me you're driving?' but that doesn't happen so often now, thankfully."

If I feel a train isn't safe to drive, then I take it out of service and that's that. If I were a bus driver and I had a breakdown, all I'd have to do was park it and call a mechanic. With a train you have no choice but to get it moving off the track, usually on your own." The most harrowing aspect of the job is clearing passengers off the train at the end of the night. "That can be very tricky, I don't really like it," Jones confesses. "Very often you have to run your train back to the yard from the end-of-line station and you can get the sack if you don't get all the passengers off first. On a weekend, late at night, imagine what some of the men are like. In the days when there were guards, it was fine; now I have to do it all on my own and if the supervisor's office is miles away, you know it'll be ages before help arrives, even if you do radio for back-up." But it's the little things that make the job worthwhile, she confides, such as when passengers come up and thank her. "Other times, some bright spark will rap on the window and go: 'Don't tell me you're driving?' but that doesn't happen so often now, thankfully."

webTitle: Tel Aviv shaken when two of its own die shopping in the West Bank

fields.headline: Tel Aviv shaken when two of its own die shopping in the West Bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Seventeen weeks of bloodshed in Palestinian areas penetrated the protective armour of Tel Aviv yesterday as Israelis mourned the owners of a sushi bar who blundered to their death in the West Bank.
fields.body:
Seventeen weeks of bloodshed in Palestinian areas penetrated the protective armour of Tel Aviv yesterday as Israelis mourned the owners of a sushi bar who blundered to their death in the West Bank.

"They went to eat houmus and they were murdered," said Yediot Ahronoth, Israel's biggest selling Hebrew language daily.

Radio chat shows spent hours discussing the final moments of Motti Dayan, 27, and Etgar Zeituni, 36, cousins and business partners.

Their death on Tuesday brought a temporary halt to the peace talks. The Palestinian negotiators spent yesterday on their own at the Red Sea resort of Taba, waiting to hear whether the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, would send his team back to the talks soon.

Mr Barak called a cabinet meeting last night to make the decision.

The talks could resume today, after the two men are buried. But with less than two weeks to go until Israel votes for a new prime minister, Mr Barak may be calculating that there is no advantage in keeping them going.

His advisers admit that he is going through the motions of talks to polish his image as a peacemaker before the vote on February 6, and with Israelis steeling themselves against further compromises to the Palestinians he may change his strategy.

On radio chat shows and in parliament Israelis strove to understand how two Tel Aviv restaurateurs could have been so oblivious to the explosive situation less than an hour's drive from the coastal capital that they went shopping for bargains in the West Bank.

Although the Palestinian uprising seeped into the coastal area weeks ago with the bus bombings in Tel Aviv and Netanya, the toll of more than 370 deaths had little impact on Sheinkin Street, a strip of cafes and boutiques which is the preserve of body-piercing bohemians who would rather talk about the beach than politics.

Yesterday, as death notices were pasted in the windows of Yuppies, the cafe the men jointly owned, a handful of rightwing protesters arrived to jeer at the quarter's habitues for ever believing there could be peace with the Palestinians.

Friends of the two men also had their doubts. "Etgar had a lot of Arab Israeli friends. He believed in peace and coexistence, but he seems to have been wrong," a woman called Irit told Yediot.

The two men visited the West Bank town of Tulkarem with an Israeli Arab business colleague to stock up on pots and plants for their cafe, taking advantage of the lower prices in the West Bank.

They were marched away from a restaurant at gunpoint by four masked men and shot dead. The military wing of the Islamist group Hamas said it killed them.

Since the uprising began in late September, Israeli citizens have been forbidden to visit the West Bank.

It is easy to get around the ban and the army roadblocks, but very few Israeli reporters have bothered.

Local press coverage of the uprising has been based overwhelmingly on government and army sources.

Although the killing of the two cafe owners was the main story yesterday, no one linked their death with the murder of a middle-aged Palestinian dentist, Thabet Thabet, by the Israeli security forces in Tulkarem on January 1.

There was little attention paid either to the Palestinian woman who died of a heart attack yesterday when Israeli soldiers at a checkpoint stopped the car taking her to hospital.

Aisha Abdel-Karim Nassar, 28, was detained for 45 minutes at the checkpoint near Ramallah and died there, said Moussa Abu Hmeid, the director of West Bank hospitals.

Despite such media self-censorship, the army said there was no excuse for casual outings to the West Bank.

"Whoever does not understand the reality here of the last four months has been out of the country or has not left the house," Brigadier Ron Kitrey said.

webTitle: Leader: Mandelson should have come clean

fields.headline: The price of prevarication
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mandelson should have come clean

The resignation speech
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: What did for Peter Mandelson in the end was the defect which so many had identified in him over the years, his apparently incurable deviousness.
fields.body:
It was not his warm relationship with the Hinduja brothers which did for him; the Blairs themselves were scarcely less friendly. It was not his readiness to lift the phone and courteously check a detail or two with the Home Office on Srichand Hinduja's behalf. That was survivable. Nor was it some sleazy deal to speed Mr Hiduja's passport application on its way and take, in return, a large sum for funding the dome: all sides deny that any such deal was done, and no proof has been adduced for it. It was not even his addiction to the company of fashionable people and people loaded with money - an addiction which seemed to be under better control after the Geoffrey Robinson crisis, but which none the less persisted.

No, what did for Peter Mandelson in the end was the defect which so many had identified in him over the years, and which Tony Blair, his friend and his shield and comforter in times of trouble, had so often been warned against by good friends of Labour's best interests - his apparently incurable deviousness.

Mr Mandelson has left the government for the second time - and very likely, for good - because he did not come clean. When the Observer talked to him on Saturday before publishing its report about Srichand Hinduja's passport application, his version seemed straightforward enough: "The matter was dealt with by my private secretary. At no time did I support or endorse this application for citizenship." But by Tuesday, the prime minister's press spokesman was having to alter that story. Now Mr Mandelson had after all been involved - though only to the extent of a two-minute call to his Home Office colleague, Mike O'Brien. That phone call, we were assured, had somehow slipped Mr Mandelson's mind. But on Tuesday night, a further version surfaced. Mr Mandelson denied having said he had forgotten the phone call: "Nobody asked me about a phone call on Saturday, Sunday or Monday. Nobody asked me these questions."

Alastair Campbell's undisguisedly angry Downing Street briefing signalled the end. Both he and his colleague Chris Smith had been badly misled and on the basis of wrong information had made false statements themselves. And fatally, by failing to come clean to Alastair Campbell, Mr Mandelson had done something unforgivable: he had failed to come clean with the prime minister. Especially after the Robinson crisis, he had every cause to know better. Twice in the past few weeks, first in the context of its embarrassment over donations to party funds, then in that of the MoD's shifty handling of the row over depleted uranium, we have recommended this precept for people in government: at times like this, do not try to wriggle your way out of trouble; come as clean as you can, as soon as you can. Had Mr Mandelson adopted that course right from the time the Observer phoned him, he would still have had a horrible week, but he might still have a worthwhile career in politics ahead of him now.

Because this strand of deviousness links the two cases, what happened yesterday is bound to revive the question of whether Tony Blair was right to recall him to government a mere 10 months after his last expulsion. Ever since he won the leadership, Mr Blair has depended heavily - often too heavily - on Mr Mandelson's friendship and guidance. He has called him his rock and counsellor. He once joked that the New Labour project would not be complete until the party learned to love Peter. When Mr Mandelson had to resign over the Robinson loan, Mr Blair could not disguise his distress, and emphasised right from the start how much he looked forward to welcoming his errant minister back. To stand by a friend in trouble is a virtuous act in anyone, and not to be disparaged. But prime ministers need to be critical, for if they are not, they find themselves in the kind of predicament Mr Blair is mired in today. His dependence on Mr Mandelson had even threatened the party with an election campaign managed by two astute politicians who can barely stand the sight of each other - Mr Mandelson and the chancellor, Gordon Brown. That was never a sensible notion, and at least Mr Mandelson's going will spare Mr Blair the embarrassing consequences.

There are also to be considered the consequences for Northern Ireland, at a moment when Mr Blair is doing his best to keep the peace process alive, and when, as ever, the imminent prospect of a general election makes every calculation more awkward and more sensitive. This was a job that Mr Mandelson always coveted, and one to which he brought conspicuous dedication, seeming at first to bring a new stability too after the last uneasy days of Mo Mowlam. He regained some of the trust she had lost among the Unionists, though Sinn Fein and the SDLP found it a change for the worse. Yet the fate of the process was always less in Peter Mandelson's hands than those of Tony Blair. And at least two able candidates with experience at the Northern Ireland Office are available in the deputy, Adam Ingram, and his predecessor, Paul Murphy, now at the Wales Office.

What happens to Peter Mandelson next is anyone's guess. His statement yesterday seemed to hint at a future both in and outside politics. It would be no great surprise if, contemplating a record which no previous politician in memory has matched - two enforced resignations from the same cabinet in the course of a single parliament - he decided to cut his losses, give up his seat at Hartlepool, and seek his fortune elsewhere. That would be a conspicuous sacrifice in a man whose hopes for the highest political office were never really disguised. Indeed, had his ways of proceeding been as open and shining bright as his ambition, he might have survived far longer.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Ads row
fields.body:
Ads row

The BBC risks abusing its public service status by taking advertising on a planned international news website, its rivals claim. The proposed site, called BBCNews.com, would provide an online news service targeted primarily at internet users in north America. Rob Hersov, chairman of the British Internet Publishers Alliance, whose members include other online news providers such as the Guardian and ITN, accused the BBC of abusing its public service status.

End of a dream

Struggling Japanese video game maker Sega is expected to stop production of its Dreamcast console and focus on its software operations - a move analysts applauded as an important step for the firm's revival. Its shares rose more than 15% on reports that it would abandon the loss-making machine by the end of March in the face of stiff competition from rival Sony and its PlayStation2 console.

Offline
Britain's largest internet bank egg, Egg, admitted yesterday that some customers had been unable to use their accounts online because of technical problems, a spokesman said.

webTitle: Palestinians' rights do not include the right to Jerusalem

fields.headline: Palestinians' rights do not include the right to Jerusalem
fields.standfirst:
The current peace proposal would put much of the area under Arab control

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The current peace proposal would put much of the area under Arab control.
fields.body:
As a Jew living in the United States, I have long denied myself the right to intervene in Israel's internal debates. I consider Israel's destiny mine as well, since my own memory is bound up with its history. But the politics of Israel concern me only indirectly. I find its electoral vagaries interesting, its blunders embarrassing, but as I am not an Israeli citizen, I am not directly involved. I may have more sympathy for a particular politician or greater reservations about another, but that's my personal business; I don't talk about it.

This behaviour at times results in "open letters" and acerbic articles scolding me for not protesting whenever Israeli police or soldiers react excessively to violence from Palestinian soldiers or civilians. I rarely answer. My critics have their conception of social and individual ethics; I have mine. But while I grant them their right to criticise, they sometimes deny mine to abstain.

Now, though, the topic is Jerusalem. Its fate affects not only Israelis, but also diaspora Jews like myself. The fact that I do not live in Jerusalem is secondary; Jerusalem lives within me. Forever inherent in my Jewishness, it is at the centre of my commitments and my dreams.

Jerusalem, for me, is above politics. Mentioned more than 600 times in the Bible, Jerusalem, anchored in Jewish tradition, is the national landmark of that tradition. It represents our collective soul. It is Jerusalem that binds one Jew to another. There is not a prayer more beautiful or nostalgic than the one which evokes the splendour of its past and the shattering and enduring memory of its destruction.

I remember when I went to Jerusalem for the first time; I felt that it was not the first time. Yet each time I revisit the city, it is always for the first time. What I feel and experience there I feel nowhere else. I return to the house of my ancestors; King David and Jeremiah await me there.

In the political division now being considered, the greater part of the Old City of Jerusalem would come under Palestinian authority. The Temple Mount, beneath which lie the vestiges of the temples of Solomon and Herod, would thereafter be controlled by the new Palestinian state.

That Muslims might wish to maintain close ties with this city unlike any other is understandable. Although its name does not appear in the Koran, Jerusalem is the third holiest city in Islam. But for Jews, it remains the first. Not just the first; the only.

How can we forget that between 1948 and 1967, while the Old City was occupied by Jordan, Jews were denied access to the Western Wall in spite of a signed agreement between the two governments? At that time Arabs, who were asking for an Arab state, never mentioned Jerusalem.

Why are the Palestinians now so anxious to make Jerusalem their capital? Anxious enough to jeopardise the Oslo accords?

We are told that Israel's unprecedented concessions, including those on Jerusalem, were made for a good cause. For peace. This is a weighty argument. Peace is the noblest of aspirations; it is worth the sacrifice of that which is most precious to us. I agree. But is it appropriate in all circumstances? Can one always say, "Peace at any price"? To compromise on territory might seem, under certain conditions, imperative or at least politically expedient. But to compromise on history is impossible.

You may ask me, what about peace in all this? I continue to believe in peace with all my heart. I am wary, though, of anything that amounts to appeasement. Would giving most of the Old City of Jerusalem to Yasser Arafat and the extremists be a reward for their actions?

The Palestinians also insist on "the right of return" for more than 3m refugees. On this question, Israel is united in its refusal. It may be necessary to recall the history of this Palestinian tragedy. In 1947 Israel accepted the plan for the division of Palestine; the Arabs rejected it.

In 1948, David Ben-Gurion reached out to what was to be the Palestinian state. Not only did the Arabs reject the proffered hand; they sent six armies to strangle the newly born Jewish state. Incited by their leaders, 600,000 Palestinians left the country convinced that, once Israel was vanquished, they would be able to return home.

I have seen their children in the Gaza refugee camps; their fate can leave none of us indifferent. It is imperative that we resolve this problem. But the solution of a mass return is unthinkable. To many Israelis, that would be tantamount to suicide, just as cutting Jerusalem from its roots would be spiritual suicide.

What I am about to say I say with great sadness: after seeing on television, during the intifada, the faces of young Palestinians twisted with hate, it is more difficult than ever before for me to believe in the Palestinians' will for peace. It is not that they want a smaller Israel; they want no Israel at all.

And yet. Though all options appear to have been exhausted, peace remains our single common hope; violence and war have filled too many cemeteries on both sides. This cannot and must not go on. Most Israelis feel as I do: Palestinians must have the right to live freely and with dignity, without fear and without shame. It is incumbent upon the world and Israel to do everything to help them and to do so in ways that do not make them lose face. I am particularly concerned with the Israeli Arabs. They are citizens of Israel and their civic rights must be protected at all costs.

As for Jerusalem, would it not be better to resolve all other pending questions first and defer until a later time decisions about the fate of the holiest of cities? I still believe human bridges can be built between the two communities, through reciprocal visits between students, teachers, musicians, writers, artists, business leaders and journalists. Perhaps in 20 years, the children of these people will be better equipped to approach that most burning of questions: Jerusalem. Perhaps they will then understand why the Jewish soul carries within it the wound and the love of a city whose keys are protected by its memory.

 Elie Wiesel, a professor of humanities at Boston University, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986.

New York Times.

You may ask me, what about peace in all this? I continue to believe in peace with all my heart. I am wary, though, of anything that amounts to appeasement. Would giving most of the Old City of Jerusalem to Yasser Arafat and the extremists be a reward for their actions? The Palestinians also insist on "the right of return" for more than 3m refugees. On this question, Israel is united in its refusal. It may be necessary to recall the history of this Palestinian tragedy. In 1947 Israel accepted the plan for the division of Palestine; the Arabs rejected it. In 1948, David Ben-Gurion reached out to what was to be the Palestinian state. Not only did the Arabs reject the proffered hand; they sent six armies to strangle the newly born Jewish state. Incited by their leaders, 600,000 Palestinians left the country convinced that, once Israel was vanquished, they would be able to return home. I have seen their children in the Gaza refugee camps; their fate can leave none of us indifferent. It is imperative that we resolve this problem. But the solution of a mass return is unthinkable. To many Israelis, that would be tantamount to suicide, just as cutting Jerusalem from its roots would be spiritual suicide. What I am about to say I say with great sadness: after seeing on television, during the intifada, the faces of young Palestinians twisted with hate, it is more difficult than ever before for me to believe in the Palestinians' will for peace. It is not that they want a smaller Israel; they want no Israel at all. And yet. Though all options appear to have been exhausted, peace remains our single common hope; violence and war have filled too many cemeteries on both sides. This cannot and must not go on. Most Israelis feel as I do: Palestinians must have the right to live freely and with dignity, without fear and without shame. It is incumbent upon the world and Israel to do everything to help them and to do so in ways that do not make them lose face. I am particularly concerned with the Israeli Arabs. They are citizens of Israel and their civic rights must be protected at all costs. As for Jerusalem, would it not be better to resolve all other pending questions first and defer until a later time decisions about the fate of the holiest of cities? I still believe human bridges can be built between the two communities, through reciprocal visits between students, teachers, musicians, writers, artists, business leaders and journalists. Perhaps in 20 years, the children of these people will be better equipped to approach that most burning of questions: Jerusalem. Perhaps they will then understand why the Jewish soul carries within it the wound and the love of a city whose keys are protected by its memory.  Elie Wiesel, a professor of humanities at Boston University, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986. New York Times.

webTitle: £4.5bn on offer to revive rail service

fields.headline: £4.5bn on offer to revive rail service
fields.standfirst:
Rebuilding Britain's biggest interchange station would be the jewel in crown of GNER bid to run commuter routes

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Clapham Junction could be dismantled and rebuilt as part of a £4.5bn bid by Great North Eastern Railways, for a 20-year franchise to operate commuter services from London to the south west.
fields.body:
Clapham Junction, Britain's biggest and most nondescript interchange station, could be dismantled and rebuilt as part of a £4.5bn bid by Great North Eastern Railways, for a 20-year franchise to operate commuter services from London to the south west.

A new £110m station would replace the dilapidated 1860 building with a modern multi-level interchange. The present station in south London has been described by the thousands of people who use it everyday as "like walking through a backyard".

The new station would be built on railway land. Some Railtrack hoardings would have to be replaced, but no residential or commercial accommodation would be affected.

Tourists pouring off the Channel ferries or approaching London on Eurostar from Paris or Brussels have expressed their shock at seeing such a rundown station at the southern gateway to the capital.

GNER, which is directly involved with the Hatfield rail disaster, said yesterday that it was offering an "innovative solution" to chronic congestion problems in London and the south coast.

GNER joins Stagecoach, the franchise holder, and FirstGroup and the Netherlands' railways, in bidding for the south west franchise. The three have applied to the strategic rail authority for a 20-year franchise. Christopher Garnett, GNER's director, said: "South West Trains' passengers, whether they are commuters or long distance travellers, have a right to expect and receive a decent service. Our bids sets us apart from our competitors. We will deliver a high quality passenger friendly railway."

Mr Garnett said that SWT passengers felt a sense of outrage at the lack of cleanliness on trains and stations. His message was: "It does not have to be like this."

GNER said that it would create more than 2,200 new jobs, raising the number of staff at stations and on trains by 50%.

The Clapham transformation cannot be achieved overnight. It is a long term objective, coming in the second half of the 20-year franchise. Until it is opened, the old station will be smartened up with several licks of paint.

Other plans include new trains, tracks and two tunnels. The biggest is from Clapham under the Thames to central London and on to King's Cross.

The idea is to relieve congestion on the crowded Underground network. The Clapham plan is the jewel in GNER's crown.

Otherwise its plans closely resemble its rivals' plans for the new franchise.

If GNER's plans are approved, it will start lengthening platforms as well as re-developing Waterloo station in central London. New continental style double deck trains are planned from 2010.

GNER said that research among passengers showed that the franchise holder, SWT, part of Stagecoach, was regarded as "a soulless, depopulated railway, which puts profits before investment". One part of that statement, "depopulated" is inaccurate. Until Hatfield, SWT has seen a 25% increase in passenger usage over the past four years.

Mr Garnett said that GNER would eliminate cramped commuter carriages. Under a fleet investment programme, 12 coach trains would be introduced on most routes by 2005.

At least 2,000 new coaches would be delivered, and on board CCTV installed on all new trains.

For passengers coming from the outposts of Bournemouth, Exeter and Salisbury, there is the promise of inter-City style trains from 2009.

According to Mr Garnett, the company will embark on a big modernisation programme for several stations. New stations will be build at Chandlers Ford, Southampton waterfront and at Portsmouth.

Vauxhaull, Wimbledon, Isleworth and Basingstoke would be rebuilt and more than 6,000 extra car parking spaces added to the network in the first ten years.

Many parts of the network would get earlier and later trains, reflecting a move towards a "24-hour, turn up and go, seven-day-a-week railway."

GNER's bid for the franchise centres on Stagecoach's infrastructure investment record. SWT has turned out to be a money spinner for Stagecoach, because of the concentration of commuters from the affluent south west London suburbs who depend on rail to get to work. The franchise has resulted in profits of about £30m a year, about a fifth of the annual profits for the bus and train group.

webTitle: Lucent and AOL slash jobs for profits

fields.headline: Lucent and AOL slash jobs for profits
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Two of America's leading hi-tech companies are to shed more than 12,000 jobs as part of a massive effort to cut costs and improve performance.
fields.body:
Two of America's leading hi-tech companies are to shed more than 12,000 jobs as part of a massive effort to cut costs and improve performance.

Lucent, north America's leading telecom equipment manufacturer, announced about 10,000 job cuts yesterday - 10% of its staff - as part of a move to save more than $2bn (£1.37bn) a year and stem mounting losses. The company is also to take a $1.6bn restructuring charge in the current quarter to pay for the reorganisation.

AOL Time Warner, the newly merged media and internet company, is also expected to cut more than 2,000 job on top of the 400 announced last week at cable news channel, CNN. AOL's corporate headquarters in Virginia as well as media divisions such as Time magazine, Warner Bros and Warner Music are to be the focus of the cuts.

The announcements are expected to further depress consumer confidence. Signs of a slowdown have so far failed to affect America's low unemployment levels but many economists believe this could soon change.

Lucent announced its quarterly loss of $1.02bn yesterday, which was worse than expected by analysts, especially after a one-off tax benefit was excluded. Several Wall Street analysts downgraded forecasts for this year after the company failed to meet the lowered targets.

Henry Schacht, who was reinstated as chairman and chief executive last October after the incumbent was ousted, called the company's seven-point plan aggressive yesterday. The job cuts, which were widely expected, will primarily reduce marketing, sales and administrative jobs.

Shares in Lucent were up more than $1 to almost $20 at midday yesterday, about one-third of their levels last July. The company slashed forecasts several times last year as it lost ground in the key optical networking market and suffered manufacturing problems and declining demand in its core telephone equipment products.

Amid the concerns raised on Wall Street yesterday were the company's failure to replace the interim chief executive or to stem market share losses. Leslie Mallon, analyst at investment bank CSFB, said: "We just haven't seen any sign of execution yet."

Steve Levy, industry analyst at Lehman Brothers, said: "I'm encouraged by the size of the restructuring and the breadth of the actions that they intend to take, but it is clear that this is going to be a messy year."

Lucent has also been hurt by the downturn in the fortunes of AT&T, its former parent and largest client.

Wall Street reacted with more enthusiasm to signs that AOL was moving swiftly to integrate Time Warner after their merger took a year to gain regulatory approval. The job cuts represent about 3% of the combined company's 85,000-strong workforce.

In an interview with the Wall Street Journal yesterday, Dick Parsons, AOL's chief operating officer, said that the company would continue to look at savings going forward. "Let's take this opportunity to reset the clock and make sure that the organisation is running as tightly as possible," he said.

Shares in the company rose almost $1 yesterday after rising some 60% since the beginning of this year.

In a note to investors, Henry Blodget, analyst at Merrill Lynch said, "This is clearly going to be an aggressive integration (one that will undoubtedly ruffle some feathers, but that should also quickly demonstrate senior management's seriousness about delivering on its performance targets)."

 Several Microsoft websites, including the software company's main corporate site and its MSN internet portal, were cut off to many users yesterday due to problems with the way web traffic is directed to the sites, the company said.

The problems surfaced on Tuesday night and Microsoft technicians were diagnosing the problem and hoped to have the sites back up soon, company spokesman Adam Sohn said.

Asked if the problems could be the result of a hacker attack, Mr Sohn said: "We're not ruling anything out at this point. There's not enough data at this point, but the guys are working as quick as they can to get it diagnosed, treated and cured."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Flight attendant dies in Nairobi
2,000 DNA tests in rapist hunt
Eight injured in M25 pile-up
Gramophone dog honoured
Soccer star's car in crash
fields.body:
Flight attendant dies in Nairobi

A 21-year-old British Airways flight attendant was found dead in her hotel room, in Nairobi, Kenya, last Thursday during a stopover, the airline said yesterday. It is believed that Kerry Weston, of Broxbourne, Hertfordshire, died of natural causes.

2,000 DNA tests in rapist hunt

Police said yesterday they were planning to carry out DNA tests on up to 2,000 men in an attempt to catch a serial rapist. Known as the Batman because of his baseball cap logo, he is thought to be responsible for 14 sex attacks in Bath and Bristol since 1991.

Eight injured in M25 pile-up

A 17-vehicle pile-up on the M25 left eight people injured yesterday. The accidents happened at 1.15pm on the clockwise carriageway between junctions 16 and 17 in Buckinghamshire. One woman was airlifted to the Royal London hospital.

Gramophone dog honoured

The dog made famous as the symbol of record company EMI and HMV music shops as he stared into a gramophone was immortalised in his home city, Bristol, yesterday. Nipper the fox terrier was honoured with a blue plaque and commemorative statue.

Soccer star's car in crash

West Ham footballer Gary Charles yesterday voluntarily attended a London police station after his Mercedes was found abandoned after a crash with another car in Hornchurch, Essex, on Monday night, Scotland Yard said. He was not arrested and the investigation continues.

Water 'saps brain power'

Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? contestants who sip water between questions may be ruining their chances of striking it rich, according to a report in New Scientist magazine.

A study by psychologist Peter Rogers from Bristol University suggests that drinking too much water could impair mental performance.

Cinemas in new boom

Cinema admissions are booming with the highest attendances for 26 years in the past 12 months, figures from the Cinema Advertising Association showed yesterday.

More than 142.5m tickets were sold in 2000 - an increase of 3m on the previous year. Box office takings were up by 4% on 1999 at £627.5m.

BBC bans plugs for magazines

BBC governors have told programme executives to stop running plugs for BBC magazines after complaints from a rival publisher.

IPC Media objected to the trailers for Eve and Star magazines - published by commercial wing BBC Worldwide - being screened because it felt they breached BBC guidelines.

£10,000 to find missing man

The mother of a 21-year-old man who disappeared during a night out with friends yesterday offered a £10,000 reward.

Ashley Fricker, from Aveley, Essex, disappeared after being refused admission to a London wine bar. Sharon Fricker said yesterday she now feared the worst and the her son was dead.

Numbers for £3.6m jackpot

Winning numbers in last night's national ottery draw were 10, 11, 28, 29, 31 and 39. The bonus was 24. The estimated jackpot was £3.6m. Lottery Extra numbers were 4, 9, 23, 27, 31 and 46 for a £1.3m jackpot.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Body Heat | Klute | Ma Vie Sexuelle
fields.body:
Body Heat
(Lawrence Kasdan, 1981)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Kasdan's stylish, steamy homage to film noir in general, and to hardboiled novelist James M Cain in particular, is set in an 80s Florida steeped in the amoral sleaze of the 40s thrillers. Kathleen Turner's Matty Walker, persuading William Hurt's shady lawyer Ned Racine to murder her husband, ranks with the great femme fatales, while Hurt is the archetypal fall-guy, dragged low by a salty mix of sex and greed. There's no doubt who is in control: "You're not too smart," she tells him. "I like that in a man."

Klute
(Alan J Pakula, 1971)
11.55pm, Sky Cinema

With The Parallax View and All The President's Men, part of Pakula's trilogy of darkly paranoid 70s thrillers. Donald Sutherland as the smalltown detective in the big city may have the title role, but the film belongs to Oscar-winning Jane Fonda as the assured but needy hooker, Bree. She's being stalked by a violent client, and unwittingly holds the key to the murder case Klute is investigating. Shadowy, taut and intelligent, all the way to the clenching climax.

Ma Vie Sexuelle
(Arnaud Desplechin, 1996)
11.40pm, FilmFour

This is a delicately absorbing account of the love-life and commitment problems of thirtysomething philosophy lecturer Paul (Mathieu Amalric). He feels his 10-year relationship with Esther (Emmanuelle Devos) is over and recalls a marvellous affair with Sylvia (Marianne Denicourt), so decides on a fresh fling with Valérie (Jeanne Balibar). At three hours long, the film has plenty of time to explore its little group of Parisians, and it's certainly a rewarding study.

Exotica
(Atom Egoyan, 1994)
2.35am, FilmFour

Another Egoyan portrait of bruised and puzzled souls, here laid bare at the Exotica strip joint, on the outskirts of Toronto, run by the pregnant Arsinée Khanjian. A dancer, a DJ, a taxman and a petshop owner experience varieties of desire, while a Leonard Cohen soundtrack sets the sombre and intense tone.

fields.headline: Roderick Gradidge
fields.standfirst: Architect who led the rehabilitation of Lutyens
fields.trailText: Architect who led the rehabilitation of Lutyens.
fields.body:
The architect Roderick Gradidge, who has died aged 71, spent most of his life in opposition to the trends of his profession. He enjoyed the romantic, the decorative and the excessive, and awakened many people to aesthetic pleasures denied by modernism.

Gradidge seemed born to be a rebel. His father was a brigadier in the Corps of Guides, stationed on the north-west frontier of India, and, although he was born in Norfolk, his childhood was spent in India until he was sent to Stowe school in 1943. There, Gradidge was steered towards architecture. At the Architectural Association School in London, he denounced not only the rigours of modernism, but also the decorative style of the Festival of Britain. The principal, Robert Furneaux Jordan, declared that Gradidge could only have been an architect in pre-war England, but he got launched by building petrol stations in East Anglia and then working for Benskins breweries in Watford, sensitively converting pubs, for which he had a lifelong passion.

From the early 1960s, Gradidge designed pub interiors of legendary elaboration, all long since destroyed. The Three Greyhounds in Soho was a neo-Tudor pub, in which he turned up the decorative volume. The Markham Arms in King's Road, Chelsea, was in the spirit of JM Whistler. By the mid-1960s, the Victorian revival was at its height, and Gradidge became an active member of the Victorian Society. He produced a scheme showing how the Midland Grand Hotel at St Pancras could be returned to hotel use when this was deemed a technical impossibility, contributing to the consensus for its preservation.

His most original contribution to architectural interpretation was to lead the rehabilitation of Sir Edwin Lutyens, then dismissed as an anachronistic stylist. Gradidge demonstrated in an essay that Lutyens's three-dimensional geometry could be traced back to the "vigorous" Gothic of William Butterfield and George Edmund Street, who were "approved" by those inclined to modernism. In his view, the Arts and Crafts movement did not lead towards modernism, but to inter-war neo-Georgian and neo-Tudor. He wrote a monograph on Lutyens, published in 1981 to coincide with the Lutyens exhibition at the Hayward Gallery. Gradidge was also a founder committee member of the Thirties Society (after 1992, the Twentieth Century Society).

He was a good writer on architecture, setting a cultural context, while analysing plan form and composition with an insight that few non-architect historians achieve. His book Dream Houses, The Edwardian Ideal, 1980, was a celebration of the Edwardian house, turning Robert Jordan's modernist condemnation of Lutyens as the designer of a dream into a post-modern term of praise. Gradidge developed this theme through an operetta, Grey Roses, with music by Huw Spratling, performed at the Art Workers Guild during the year of his mastership, 1987. The Surrey Style, 1991, was a manual on the Gradidge doctrine of how to alter and enlarge houses in the Lutyens heartland, showing his own sensitive, inventive and seamless operations on houses such as Lutyens's Fulbrook and Harold Falkner's Tancred's Ford.

He also designed grand country house libraries for Easton Neston and Mount Stuart, and alterations to major Gothic Revival churches, such as Pugin's St Chad's, Birmingham, and St Augustine, Ramsgate. At Northampton Guildhall, the early Gothic masterpiece of EW Godwin, Gradidge reintroduced painted decoration. Working for the National Portrait Gallery, he transformed the interiors of Bodelwyddan Castle, Clwyd, and the entrance hall of the London gallery, where his revolving doors and decorative paint scheme were lately deemed too unmodern to survive. The major additions to St Edmund's College, Cambridge, 1990-93, show how he could spice up a dull building in fulfilment of a practical brief.

Two institutions were the subject of Gradidge's particular loyalty: the church of St Mary, Bourne Street, where he recently completed a new columbarium, and the Art Workers Guild, which he joined in 1969. This he saw as a secret cell of anti-modern resistance, and he was planning a major Arts and Crafts exhibition during the last year.

In the 1980s, the architectural world was inclining his way, and he ought to have had greater opportunities. He had a hybrid approach to things and people, as an intelligent anti-intellectual, a lover of low life and stickler for correctness, an eccentric dresser and tattoo enthusiast who could act like a peppery Colonel of Horse. The masquerade could become excessive, but a genuine human sympathy and boyish enthusiasm always shone through.

Edward Greenfield writes: To have a Georgian house redesigned around one by Roderick Gradidge was an exciting experience. As a close friend, he pointed me towards the derelict houses held by the Spitalfields Trust. He produced over one weekend a design so imaginative and so brilliantly focused on my needs that I had to take it on, whatever the cost.

He modified and refined every detail, insisting on total authenticity, meticulously instructing the builder over reconstruction and renovation, as well as advising my carpenter to the last millimetre as he patiently restored panelling. So instead of having - in the old description - "a Georgian front and a Mary-Ann behind", my house in Spitalfields has a Georgian front and a Lutyens behind.

With him it was not just a matter of not suffering fools gladly; he was reluctant to suffer anyone gladly. Yet after any row all was promptly forgiven - on both sides. fields.headline: Virginia O'Brien
fields.standfirst: Singer with a deadpan comic style and a string of roles in MGM musicals
fields.trailText: Singer with a deadpan comic style and a string of roles in MGM musicals.
fields.body:
Virginia O'Brien, who has died aged 79, appeared in 16 movies between 1940 and 1947, mostly in small roles or merely to deliver a speciality number or two. Yet this singular singer was very much part of that great escapist era during which MGM musicals dominated.

O'Brien, nicknamed variously The Diva of Deadpan and Miss Red Hot Frozen Face, was an attractive brunette, with a deep voice, who delivered her songs in an unsmiling sphinx-like manner, her lovely dark eyes unblinking, her face hardly moving a muscle, although her neck sometimes jutted back and forwards.

A typically memorable moment was her acidly comic rendering of In A Little Spanish Town in the all-star cavalcade Thousands Cheer (1943), in contrast to the sweetly-sung version by Gloria De Haven and June Allyson, who flanked her. In Ziegfeld Follies (1946), after Fred Astaire has sung Bring On The Beautiful Girls - who appear in pink, on a merry-go-round, seated on live horses - the staring O'Brien, astride a vigorous fake white horse, pleads Bring On The Wonderful Men.

Born in Los Angeles, Virginia Lee O'Brien was related to Civil War General Robert E Lee, and she was named after his home state. Her Irish father was the captain of detectives of the Los Angeles Police Department and later the city's deputy district attorney. One of her uncles was the film director Lloyd Bacon, whose credits include 42nd Street.

At North Hollywood high school, Virginia took dancing and singing lessons. In 1939, aged 17, modelling herself on her idol, Ethel Merman, "moving my arms and singing up a storm," in the stage show Meet the People, she won an MGM contract.

Before she made her screen debut, however, O'Brien appeared on Broadway in the revue Keep Off The Grass, which starred Jimmy Durante. New York Times critic Brooks Atkinson called her, "a deadpan singer who convulses the audience by removing the ecstasy from high pressure music".

Her first film for MGM, Hullabaloo (1940), in which she played a wisecracking manicurist, allowed her to interpret two songs in her inimitable poker-faced style. In Lady Be Good (1941), she partnered comedian Red Skelton for the first time as his kooky girlfriend, who is only happy "when she's eating". In the Marx Brothers comedy, The Big Store (1941), she was a salesgirl whose raucous rendition of Rock-A-Bye-Baby would have woken any tiny tot. She delivered three numbers in Panama Hattie (1941), including Did I Get Stinkin' At The Savoy?, which the star of the film, Ann Sothern, refused to sing because she thought it in bad taste. O'Brien, with her expressionless delivery, managed to get away with it.

In 1942, she married actor Kirk Alyn, who was to become the Superman of serials after the war. They had two daughters and a son. In fact, she was pregnant with her first child while making the exuberant Judy Garland musical The Harvey Girls (1946). As Alma, one of the waitresses out west, her part got smaller and smaller as she got larger. Still, she had an enchanting number with Garland and Cyd Charisse in night-gowns called It's A Great Big World.

Her largest previous role had been as the lovestruck cigarette girl in love with Red Skelton in Du Barry Was A Lady (1943), in which she sang Salome Was The Grandma of Them All. In Meet The People (1944), O'Brien sang Say We're Sweethearts Again, which contains the lyric "I never knew our romance had ended till you tried to poison my food." It became her most requested song when she did cabaret.

Her penultimate picture at MGM was the Jerome Kern biopic Till The Clouds Roll By (1946), in which she performed Life Upon The Wicked Stage, and A Fine Romance. She was then co-starred with Red Skelton again in Merton Of The Movies (1947).

Of her role, Variety wrote "Virginia O'Brien proves herself a capable leading lady without recourse to deadpan vocaling. The erstwhile canary doesn't have a number to chirp throughout and sells herself strictly on talent merits in the romantic lead opposite Skelton. The manner in which she delivers should further her career."

Alas, it was not to be, and when MGM failed to replace Garland with O'Brien in Annie Get Your Gun, mainly because she admitted she had a fear of horses, they did not renew her contract.

In 1955, she divorced Kirk Alyn (who died in 1999), and took a small role as a nurse in Francis In The Navy, starring Donald O'Connor and a talking mule. In 1957 she married electronics engineer Vern Evans, a marriage which produced a daughter. In 1968, after a divorce, she wed aviator and inventor Harry B White, a marriage which lasted until his death in 1996.

During the next two decades, O'Brien would appear in many comedy and variety series on television, and she also toured in a number of road companies. In 1983 she recorded a live performance album of her act at the Hollywood Masquer's Club, which included many of the songs that made her famous.

fields.headline: James Mark
fields.standfirst: Whitehall aid and trade expert whose passion for German found practical application during and after the second world war
fields.trailText: Whitehall aid and trade expert whose passion for German found practical application during and after the second world war.
fields.body:
Civil servant, theologian, intelligence officer, academic manqué, and a delighted teller of shaggy dog stories and slightly rude limericks, James Mark, former under-secretary at the Ministry of Overseas Development (1965-74), who has died aged 86, sometimes seemed close to a parody of an absent-minded professor. Behind the mild manner, however, was a quick intelligence, an extraordinarily retentive memory and a wide interest in cultural and current affairs.

Born in Manchester, he was the fourth child of John and Louisa Mark. As a scholar at William Hulme grammar school, he was first interested in German language and culture by his modern languages teacher. It was a passion that remained with him for life. It took him first on an open and state scholarship to a first-class honours degree in modern language studies at Trinity College, Cambridge, and then on to a doctoral thesis on 17th century German poets, which he completed at Cambridge, Munich and Munster universities, receiving his doctorate in 1939.

At the outbreak of the second world war he was quickly recruited into the intelligence corps, and posted to the Eighth Army in Cairo. His knowledge of German language and culture made him a formidable interrogator, and his skilful questioning of two captured German generals, von Thoma and von Arnim, produced useful intelligence on the eve of the battle of El Alamein, winning Mark an MBE.

Such was the charm of the young English major that when he was escorting von Thoma to Cairo, the general ventured to ask Mark, as one scholar to another, if as a special favour they could make a brief detour to look at the pyramids, which he said he had always wanted to see. The English officer and his German prisoner duly turned off the main road to stand solemnly together before the Great Pyramid, before continuing on to Cairo. It was an act of personal kindness and political innocence which was very characteristic. It cost Major Mark a severe reprimand from his commanding officers, but earned him a lifelong friendship with the general, with whom he corresponded until the latter's death.

After the war, Mark's connection with Germany continued, when as principal of the Control Office for Germany and Austria he worked to uncover and weed out Nazi sympathisers in the German post-war universities. In a brief period as personal secretary to Frank Pakenham (now Lord Longford, and then a junior Labour minister), he sped diligently about the country on a motorbike, occasionally scattering classified documents behind him as he went.

In 1948 he joined the Treasury and was sent to Washington for two years as economic counsellor (1951-53), before returning to Britain. In 1964 he transferred to the newly-formed Ministry of Overseas Development, where he became an expert on aid and trade issues, rising to the rank of under-secretary.

After his retirement in 1974, he continued for several years to act as a consultant on aid issues, but he also took on the co-editorship of Theology, a specialist quarterly, from 1974-83, and read and wrote on theological and philosophical issues, which had always absorbed much of his spare time. The thinkers who most interested him were Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Simone Veil and Ludwig Wittgenstein, along with the French existentialists.

He had long been an active member of the Anglican church, having been ordained as a lay reader, and he preached regularly at the church of St Mary's, Bexley, and at the Church of the Ascension, Blackheath, as well as taking an active part in broader church affairs. He was also a keen member of the Chantry Group, with whom he met regularly for many years for discussions and to share thoughts and writings.

A passion which Mark developed in later life was for classical Greek culture and drama, and he taught himself ancient Greek in order to be able to read the great tragedies in the original. His other great joy lay in classical music, particularly the works of German composers such as Mozart and Bach. But his tastes were surprisingly eclectic, particularly in his later years, when he acquired a taste for Messaien, and also for Mahler and Sibelius, along with early medieval composers.

His intellectual openness to new ideas and new tastes was one of his most endearing characteristics, along with his genuine kindness and compassion, and his humility.

His last years were overshadowed by illness - he was diagnosed as suffering from leukaemia in 1994 - and saddened by the death of his wife, Mary, who predeceased him by six years. He is survived by his three sons and two daughters.

 James Mark, civil servant and editor, born June 12 1914; died January 7 2001

webTitle: Turkey raises stakes in genocide row

fields.headline: Turkey raises stakes in genocide row
fields.trailText: Turkey stepped up its economic and diplomatic reprisals against France yesterday as a wave of fury swept the country at the French national assembly's formal decision to recognise the killing of Armenians in eastern Turkey in 1915 as genocide swept the country.
fields.body:
Turkey stepped up its economic and diplomatic reprisals against France yesterday as a wave of fury swept the country at the French national assembly's formal decision to recognise the killing of Armenians in eastern Turkey in 1915 as genocide swept the country.

After street protests in Istanbul and Ankara, rightwing members of the coalition government warned that Turkey would consider imposing sanctions on any country that accused it of a deliberate policy of genocide.

The health minister, Osman Durmus, said medical imports from France would be banned unless the French began to "think more healthily".

Turkey scrapped a £176m spy satellite deal with the French firm Alacatel earlier this week and barred French companies from tendering for a £4.76bn defence contract. It also recalled its ambassador from Paris.

Several Turkish universities have threatened to close their French-language departments. The Turkish parliament will be asked to vote on a declaration accusing France of genocide during Algeria's 1955-62 war of independence.

The prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said at the weekend that officials were examining other measures.

The results of our study on what kind of sanctions Turkey can impose on France, without causing itself any economic harm, will emerge in a few days," he said.

On Thursday the French lower house of parliament unanimously adopted a declaration "recognising the Armenian genocide of 1915".

The declaration, the result of prolonged lobbying by France's large Armenian community, did not mention Turkey by name, lacked any practical effect, and was opposed by both the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and President Jacques Chirac. But its impact in Turkey was explosive.

The Armenians say that 1.5m people died between 1915 and 1923, killed outright or in the epidemics and starvation that attended their forced deportations from eastern Turkey to Syria and Mesopotamia during the break-up of the Ottoman empire.

Turkey is adamant that there was no genocide as such, that the figures are exaggerated, and that those who died were just some of the many victims of the geo-strategic turbulence of the first world war period, which included the Russian occupation of parts of Anatolia and many-sided partisan fighting.

But the independent post-Soviet state of Armenia and the broadly dispersed Armenian diaspora - there are 1m people of Armenian descent in both the US and Russia, and sizeable communities in Canada, Georgia, Iran and Lebanon - put the blame squarely at Turkey's door.

An official statement issued in the Armenian capital, Yerevan, welcomed the French declaration, saying that it "strengthens historical justice".

Ankara is reported to have protested to Britain "in the strongest terms" about plans to commemorate the Armenian dead in ceremonies on Saturday marking Britain's first Holocaust memorial day.

The row with France has potentially serious ramifications for Turkey's application to join the European Union, which is already beset by problems. Turkey is at the bottom of the queue of 13 aspiring EU members.

The EU set out a route map for Turkish entry at its Nice summit last month and Mr Ecevit is due to respond soon.

The main issue to be resolved is Turkey's much criticised human rights record. Ankara is regularly accused by human rights groups of torturing and maltreating detainees, particularly Kurds, leftwing radicals and militant Islamists.

Its curbs on freedom of speech and publication are also at odds with EU standards, as is its retention of the death penalty. To cap it all, Turkey is embroiled in a separate row with France over the EU plan to create a European rapid reaction force.

 Guardian Weekend will carry a special investigation into the Armenian massacres on Saturday.

Ankara is reported to have protested to Britain "in the strongest terms" about plans to commemorate the Armenian dead in ceremonies on Saturday marking Britain's first Holocaust memorial day. The row with France has potentially serious ramifications for Turkey's application to join the European Union, which is already beset by problems. Turkey is at the bottom of the queue of 13 aspiring EU members. The EU set out a route map for Turkish entry at its Nice summit last month and Mr Ecevit is due to respond soon. The main issue to be resolved is Turkey's much criticised human rights record. Ankara is regularly accused by human rights groups of torturing and maltreating detainees, particularly Kurds, leftwing radicals and militant Islamists. Its curbs on freedom of speech and publication are also at odds with EU standards, as is its retention of the death penalty. To cap it all, Turkey is embroiled in a separate row with France over the EU plan to create a European rapid reaction force.  Guardian Weekend will carry a special investigation into the Armenian massacres on Saturday.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: If there's one nice thing about the Guardian, it's this: no one here would ever dream of censoring criticism, even when it's the editor who looks a priceless ass.
fields.body:
 If there's one nice thing about the Guardian, it's this: no one here would ever dream of censoring criticism, even when it's the editor who looks a priceless ass. Ex-Tory MP Janet Fookes was one of many peers Alan Rusbridger wrote to last week, asking about pre-ennoblement contributions to party funds. "I have long made it a rule," was Lady Fookes's withering response, "not to answer questionnaires from commercial organisations unless they make a donation to a charity of my choice."

Risking a further accusation of questionnaire-submission, the editor wrote back adding two questions - does she distinguish between papers and commercial organisations? And does she think working peers are in any way accountable to the public? "Dear Mr Rusbridger..." reads Monday's reply, "I notice that instead of answering the main point in my previous letter you have simply asked further questions." Pull the wool over these eyes? "The position remains that I am only willing to answer what is effectively a questionnaire if you ..." Magnificent.

The editor will, we trust, now cease persecuting this most devoted of public servants.

 Computer experts who spent 1999 earning £3,000 a day have been vindicated as the millennium bug strikes Britain after all. Telecoms firm Vodafone reveals that, since January 1 last year, every new contract issued by Europe's largest company has given the customer's date of birth as 01/01/1901.

The marketing department is said to be confused about this sudden realignment of its demographic profiling, but thrilled about this long-overdue breakthrough in the much-prized centenarian mobile phone market. Vodafone clients receiving junk mail regarding Stannah stairlifts have permission to break the habit of a lifetime and bin them.

 It is too soon for a coherent Diary response to yesterday's events. Suffice it for now that Stuart Dunn of Durham University's Classics department, where my old tutor Dr Chris Rowe is Professor of Greek (hellloooo, doctor!) sends a letter received two and a bit years ago from Mandy's agent Steve Wallace in response to a non-passport inquiry. "I am afraid that parliamentary rules forbid one MP from taking up causes," wrote Mr Wallace, "on behalf of another MP's constituent." Mm.

 The Mandy affair (I'm afraid that O' must go down the drain like an angry divorcee's wedding ring) brings further signs that alopecian Sun editor David Yelland's memory continues to deteriorate.

In yesterday's leader he wrote: "the BBC, especially, have fallen for Mandelson hook, line and sinker. No one is allowed to mention on air that he is gay in case it offends him." Quite true and quite right. What is upsetting is that David has no recollection that he himself instructed his journalists not to refer to Mandy's gayness. All except Richard Littlejohn, that is, who alone could be relied on to handle the matter with sensitivity.

 Speaking of that beauty, we are still poised to write an account of the early hours incident at the Essex home of Milanese catwalk model Simon Heffer in which Richard became confused as to the whereabouts of his own bedroom, with hilarious consequences. Anyone with a clever peg for this ancient but unpublished tale should supply it. Otherwise, we'll do it soon anyway.

 A letter arrives from Jennie Allen, Head of BBC Worldwide Press and PR, regarding an intriguing new book. "Esther Rantzen has had one of the most successful careers in broadcasting of her generation", eulogises Jenny about the woman of whom it might be said "she simply cares too much". And so we are delighted to announce Esther: The Autobiography as the forthcoming Book of the Month, a worthy successor to last month's He Never Said - Discover the Real Message of Jesus, by Diary vicar Steve Chalke.
