webTitle: Texas Two give up after interview

fields.headline: Texas Two give up after interview
fields.trailText: The hunt for the Texas Seven jailbreakers, which entranced much of the United States for the past six weeks, ended yesterday in a welter of words rather than the gunfire their reputation suggested.
fields.body:
The hunt for the Texas Seven jailbreakers, which entranced much of the United States for the past six weeks, ended yesterday in a welter of words rather than the gunfire their reputation suggested.

The surrender of the remaining two in a Holiday Inn in Colorado squared a popular culture circle. Their legend enhanced by media speculation, they were identified through a television show and wrapped up the chase by giving interviews to the presenter of a local news programme before being arrested.

With murder, kidnapping, armed robbery, rape and child abuse on their records, the fugitives saw their flight spun into movie material. The gang, of which one committed suicide and four surrendered two days earlier, is accused of shooting dead a 29-year-old policeman while on the run.

The denouement came when Patrick Murphy, 39, a rapist, and Donald Newbury, 38, a robber, said they would give up peacefully if they were allowed to speak to the local television station in Colorado Springs, 60 miles south of Denver.

Each was given five minutes to speak by telephone to Eric Singer of KKTV, and they used the occasion to criticise Texan justice.

"Our judicial system in the state of Texas is gone to bits," Newbury said. "We had a statement to make that the system is as corrupt as we are. I don't see how the system is working. I've done crime and you've got to face the music, but there's got to be something within reason.

"They're giving kids so much time that they will never see light again, that their lives are gone. Where's the rehabilitation? You can't even help yourself."

Murphy told Mr Singer: "Hopefully maybe this will open the eyes of some people that the penal system does have some problems."

Then he chuckled before describing how the gang drove to Colorado Springs from Texas in a snowstorm three weeks ago, as though he were reliving a difficult journey to a family reunion.

He talked about how they had blended into the community at the nearby Coachlight motel and trailer park, where they made their base, posing as Christians on their way from Texas to California. A neighbour on the site said they played religious music and one even went to a Bible class.

"It was really just by downplaying ourselves, changing our hair colour and such," Murphy said. "We tried to remain as calm as possible at all times, but vigilant. We tried to be as friendly and as neighbourly as we could."

The police were led to the motel by residents who recognised the men last weekend while watching a television programme called America's Most Wanted.

The men broke out of a maximum security prison 60 miles south-east of San Antonio on December 13, raided an electrical goods shop in Houston, and then a sports shop in a Dallas suburb, where the policeman was shot 11 times.

By then they were heavily armed and had about $70,000 (£48,000).

Each new "sighting" - there were more than 1,200 in the South and north to New York City and Canada - increased the belief that the hunt would end in a bloody showdown.

The surviving six could be sentenced to death in Texas if they are convicted of murdering the policeman.

Jayne Hawkins, the mother of the dead officer, said after the two surrendered: "They're talking about rehabilitation. I suggest they go to work and not commit a crime and then come into a prison system and expect to be educated."

webTitle: Racist killer is jailed for life

fields.headline: Racist killer is jailed for life
fields.trailText: A white supremacist pleaded guilty in a Los Angeles court yesterday to murdering an Asian-American postman and wounding five people in a rampage at a Jewish childcare centre in August 1999.
fields.body:
A white supremacist pleaded guilty in a Los Angeles court yesterday to murdering an Asian-American postman and wounding five people in a rampage at a Jewish childcare centre in August 1999.

Under a plea bargain agreement, Buford Furrow, a member of the racist group Aryan Nations, will be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole, but will be spared the death penalty.

Furrow, who has a record of psychiatric problems, said "Guilty" 16 times as the judge, Nora Manella, asked him to plead to the charges.

Federal defence lawyers had planned to plead insanity on his behalf at a trial scheduled for April, but the prosecutors concluded that there was convincing evidence that he was mentally disturbed and agreed to a deal.

Furrow tried to have himself admitted to a private psychiatric clinic in 1998, but became violent while being interviewed and drew a knife on the staff. He served six months in jail for the attack, and was released in May 1999.

Three months later he loaded all his possessions and an assortment of powerful guns into a van and drove from his home in Washington state to Los Angeles. He later told investigators that he wanted to send a "wake-up call to America to kill Jews".

He toured a number of Jewish institutions before deciding to attack the North Valley Jewish community centre, because it had little security. He walked into the building and fired more than 70 bullets, wounding three children aged between five and six, a teenage counsellor and a receptionist.

He drove away, and ended up a few hours later in the suburb of Chatsworth, in the San Fernando valley, where he saw Joseph Ileto, a Filipino-American postman. Furrow walked up to him, asked if he could deliver a letter, and opened fire, hitting Ileto with nine bullets. He surrendered to the police in Las Vegas the next day.

fields.headline: Japan 'bombed city with plague'
fields.trailText: A Tokyo court heard yesterday that the Japanese army dumped fleas infected with bubonic plague on a Chinese city in 1940, in a deadly trial of germ warfare.
fields.body:
A Tokyo court heard yesterday that the Japanese army dumped fleas infected with bubonic plague on a Chinese city in 1940, in a deadly trial of germ warfare.

The claim was made by a Chinese scientist in a case against the Japanese government brought by 180 relatives of those who were killed in experiments carried out by the imperial army's notorious Unit 731 during the second world war.

Huang Ketai, a bacteriologist, said at least 109 people were killed in an outbreak of plague in Ningbo, south of Shanghai, in November and December 1940.

Just a few days before the onset of the disease, several people saw Japanese planes drop fleas and grain over houses in the city, leading him to conclude that the population was being used as a guinea pig for a deadly pathogen.

"It is very clear that the outbreak was caused deliberately," he said in response to questions from the three judges hear the case, which is nearing the end after more than four years.

"The timing and geographical spread of the disease all point to the conclusion that its origin was the cargo dumped by the planes."

Ningbo was no stranger to the plague, which at the time struck north-east China every few years.

But Dr Huang, the first scientist to give evidence in the case, said there were several differences in the 1940 outbreak: it came in winter rather than summer, killed humans but few rats, and was carried by a flea that was not native to the region. It was also unusual in the the rapid rate at which the outbreak spread, the number of lives it claimed and its short duration.

"This was a particularly virulent form of the plague that could only have been created artificially by Unit 731," he told the court.

According to the plaintiffs' case, Unit 731 killed at least 2,100 - mostly Chinese - people in an attempt to develop a biological weapon that could win the war for Japan.

Witnesses have said that the effects of the unit's germ warfare experiments are still being felt in China, because the germ bombs released pathogens which continue to return.

As well as the psychological fear of a fresh outbreak of disease, people in north-east China have to bear the cost of razing properties suspected of being infected.

For years after the war, the activities of Unit 731 remained veiled in secrecy. According to academics, its actions were barely covered in the proceedings of the Tokyo war crimes tribunal because the United States wanted to use the results on live subjects.

Recently, after a series of confessions by veterans, the Japanese government acknowledged the unit's existence. But it still refuses to reveal the scope of the scientists' activities.

Government lawyers maintained this policy of silence in the courtroom yesterday, not challenging, not challenge a single word of the claims made by Dr Huang and two other Chinese academics.

"I suspect they will seek to have the case overturned on a legal technicality rather than try to dispute the facts," the plaintiffs' lawyer, Tsuchiya Kohken, said.

"That's because the facts are indisputable."

The verdict is expected in early summer.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We had a little trouble with MPs in yesterday's paper. Our parliamentary sketch on page 2 asserted that in his public utterances the foreign secretary is so pompous "he makes Sir Peter Tatchell sound like Norman Wisdom". The writer's intended target was Sir Peter Tapsell, MP for Louth and Horncastle. On page 12 of the Education supplement, Tony Blair was assigned the parliamentary seat called Durham. Mr Blair is the MP for Sedgefield, in County Durham.
fields.body:
We had a little trouble with MPs in yesterday's paper. Our parliamentary sketch on page 2 asserted that in his public utterances the foreign secretary is so pompous "he makes Sir Peter Tatchell sound like Norman Wisdom". The writer's intended target was Sir Peter Tapsell, MP for Louth and Horncastle. On page 12 of the Education supplement, Tony Blair was assigned the parliamentary seat called Durham. Mr Blair is the MP for Sedgefield, in County Durham.

The headline on yesterday's Passnotes, page 3, G2, named the new editor of the World of Interiors magazine as Rupert Thompson, rather than Thomas, as correctly given in the text.

Writing about the Bloody Sunday inquiry, page 5, January 23, we referred to "the families of the bereaved and the injured", when what was meant was the dead and injured. Bereaved people are those who have suffered loss.

Our article headed So you want to be a yoga teacher, page 9, Further Education, December 19, erred in describing the British School of Yoga (based in Sleaford, not Salford) as the governing body for yoga. The Sports Council recognises the British Wheel of Yoga as the governing entity for yoga in Britain.

A leader on the Congo region and its history (page 25, January 18) referred to the explorer Henry Stanley as an American. To clarify, Stanley was born John Rowlands in north Wales. After running away to sea at 18 he became American on being adopted by a New Orleans merchant called Stanley, and this was his status during his African expeditions of the 1870s and 1880s. After that he led a more settled life, becoming British again, by legal naturalisation, at the age of 51. He went on to gain a seat in parliament and a knighthood.

webTitle: Letters: Spies still in our midst

fields.headline: Spies still in our midst
fields.trailText: There is one revelation from Richard Tomlinson (What's in that book, January 24) which should cause concern: the fact that MI6 forged a National Union of Journalists membership card as part of Tomlinson's cover in the Balkans is disturbing.
fields.body:
There is one revelation from Richard Tomlinson (What's in that book, January 24) which should cause concern: the fact that MI6 forged a National Union of Journalists membership card as part of Tomlinson's cover in the Balkans is disturbing.

Many journalists have been killed around the world in the past few years, a number because they were suspected of either being part of the state machinery or "agents of influence" of hostile intelligence agencies. Is it not time that the recruitment of journalists and the use of journalist cover by the security services was outlawed?

It would be a step forward if journalists themselves acknowledged that acting as agents for MI6 is unethical. The recent obituaries of Observer journalist Gavin Young illustrates how widespread is the practice.
Stephen Dorril
Holmfirth, West Yorkshire

 Exactly how many more times do we have to read Richard Tomlinson's escapade in Portsmouth to obtain passport numbers from two nurses for MI6? Thankfully it was only twice yesterday (Comment, and Francis Wheen in G2). Ian Traynor's article yesterday struggled to fill half of page 3 with only a few more newsworthy incidents.

Francis Wheen says MI6 recruits "deadballs and oddballs and outright fantasists", and I am adamant I fall into one of those categories (as do many of my friends). However I sincerely doubt whether much recruitment takes place at Newcastle University, my current abode. Or perhaps I'm a spy. I'm afraid I must conceal my email address. My name has been changed (numerous times).
Jake Lee
Newcastle-upon-Tyne

fields.headline: We're all domed
fields.trailText: "In the early morning rush-hour yesterday not one other soul stepped off the train at Greenwich North ..." (We must save the dome, January 24). Well, I don't know what Ms Toynbee was doing up there, but I was at North Greenwich tube station during yesterday's morning rush hour and there were hundreds of people there.
fields.body:

fields.trailText: I wanted to take part in the first Holocaust Memorial Day (Myth and memory, G2, January 24). I was astonished to find that in the capital there is to be a shindig by invitation only for the great and good in Westminster, a gathering outside a pub in Soho and a tree planting in Wandsworth! fields.body:
I wanted to take part in the first Holocaust Memorial Day (Myth and memory, G2, January 24). I was astonished to find that in the capital there is to be a shindig by invitation only for the great and good in Westminster, a gathering outside a pub in Soho and a tree planting in Wandsworth! That's it.

Around the country a host of activities are taking place, but in London, there is nothing for us poor plebians. All I wanted to do was gather somewhere and pay my respects in a public way on what was meant to be a public day. Yet again style triumphs over substance.
Michael Warburton
East Twickenham, Middlesex

fields.headline: Mandelson's last move
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson (Passport row lands Mandelson in trouble, January 24) should have followed his advice to the Major government, published in the Times on November 23 1994.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson (Passport row lands Mandelson in trouble, January 24) should have followed his advice to the Major government, published in the Times on November 23 1994.

He wrote: "When the prime minister talks of the problems of maintaining standards of conduct in public life, he should understand that those problems would be much greater without the integrity, independence and political neutrality that are hallmarks of the Civil Service. As the bulwark of democracy and decency in public life, the service itself needs to be protected from political incursion."

How ironic that it is the small corruptions in government that bring about political resignations. It is essential that home office minister, Mike O'Brien, is now transparent as to whether he too compromised the Home Office through such political incursions.
Richard Skellington
Milton Keynes

 In the relentless pursuit of Peter Mandelson we have seen the repulsive spectacle of hounds tearing a fox to shreds. My sympathies are with the fox.

The baying pack of Tories at prime minister's questions was as sickening to watch as Mandelson's courage in facing them was admirable.
Nicole Sochor
London

 At the time of Peter Mandelson's resignation as "minister without portfolio", I was most impressed with the way he got rid of the Greenwich dome albatross.

I have always assumed that he'd leaked the Geoffrey Robinson story himself to create one of these mass-hysteria non-event scandals that the British media specialise in, thus allowing him to resign slightly tainted by some non-event "Geoffrey Robinson (who?)" mud but with none of the corrosive "I mismanaged X billion on some useless piece of architecture" mud.

He eventually returned cuckoo-like into a job from which the previous and successful owner had been pushed out. Now we have a new minor scandal. Is this Peter engineering his exit from the Northern Ireland scene?
Olly Morgan
Brussels olly@sirocos.com

 So something good came out of the dome, then.
David Taylor
London David.Taylor@construct.emap.com

 Given that Peter Mandelson is the subject of yet another sleaze scandal, couldn't Martin Bell stand in Hartlepool at the next election?
Dillon Nuttall-Mahoney
Altrincham, Cheshire

 To lose a cabinet minister once may be considered a misfortune. To lose him twice looks like recklessness.
Stephen Fairweather-Tall
Oxford stephen.tall@mansfield.ox.ac.uk

fields.headline: Sing something simple
fields.trailText: My wife and I are both of a mature age, indeed we are grandparents. We were thrilled to get the CD free with Saturday's Guardian. We have found this "Singalong with Fat Boy Slim" so useful. My wife says the repetitive beat helps her knitting, with the side effect that our cats go to sleep and give us some peace.
fields.body:
My wife and I are both of a mature age, indeed we are grandparents. We were thrilled to get the CD free with Saturday's Guardian. We have found this "Singalong with Fat Boy Slim" so useful. My wife says the repetitive beat helps her knitting, with the side effect that our cats go to sleep and give us some peace. I have not been affected so far. My younger descendants tell me that I need to take drugs to enjoy this techno-garage-acid-rave music (I hope that's right). This is why I'm writing to ask for help. My wife thinks Veno's cough mixture is the correct drug, whereas I prefer a sparkling stimulant such as Andrews' liver salts. However both may be addictive. Can your newshounds advise us?
Tony Bryant
Twickenham, Middlesex

 How enlightened! Marilyn Manson "flirts with demonic imagery", leads a chant of "Fuck you" and "mock abuses a delighted boy", inter alia, but is an "intelligent, witty and even moral man" (Dave Simpson's review, January 24). This, the day after you report that in the United States the record company of the band Slayer is being sued over violent lyrics which allegedly led to a murder, and the same day as you report a young man committed suicide and left the lyrics of Eminem as his elegy.

Marilyn Manson has said that if his music does not incite the listener to violent acts, then he has failed. Wake up Mr Simpson! Manson's act isn't irony; it's evil.
Anne Ward
Altrincham, Cheshire

webTitle: Letter: Nick Hornby on his son

fields.headline: Nick Hornby on his son
fields.trailText: I don't know whether the measles, mumps and rubella combined vaccine can be linked to autism or not (Stop stifling debate, critics warn government, January 24).
fields.body:
I don't know whether the measles, mumps and rubella combined vaccine can be linked to autism or not (Stop stifling debate, critics warn government, January 24). Indeed, as I understand it, nobody does yet, which is why the forthcoming £3m advertising campaign attempting to assuage our fears is doomed to fail.

I do, however, know this: my autistic son suffers from the bowel condition that Andrew Wakefield is currently researching. Nobody from the medical establishment, currently taking such pains to rubbish Dr Wakefield's work, has the slightest idea of how to deal with this condition; however, Dr Wakefield and his team at the Royal Free hospital in north London, have so far succeeded in relieving the pain my son has endured.

Needless to say, the Royal Free project is chronically underfunded, and as a consequence very young children are being forced to wait in a great deal of discomfort for treatment they simply cannot get elsewhere.

So who's "flaky" here? Perhaps the Department of Health would be taken more seriously if it stumped up another three million, for Dr Wakefield's serious and groundbreaking work.
Nick Hornby
London

webTitle: Letter: The case for Derry Irvine

fields.headline: The case for Derry Irvine
fields.trailText: Yvonne Roberts's ramble (Jobs for the lads, January 19) contains so many errors of fact that it would probably take up the whole Letters page to respond in detail.
fields.body:
Yvonne Roberts's ramble (Jobs for the lads, January 19) contains so many errors of fact that it would probably take up the whole Letters page to respond in detail.

She says of the lord chancellor's appointment of his special adviser that he is a "law breaker". This is untrue. The employment appeal tribunal, applying the relevant legislation, has found quite clearly that there was no discrimination, direct or indirect, in relation to the appointment of Garry Hart.

Ms Roberts has also misunderstood the criminal defence service, which comes into being on April 2. The purpose of reform is to ensure that legally-aided services provided by private practitioners (solicitors and barristers) are quality-assured for their clients' benefit, and provide good value for money for the taxpayer. There will also be a tiny number of salaried defenders: the legal services commission plans to open six offices on a pilot basis. Hardly a threat to the 3,000 odd solicitors' firms who will have a criminal contract.

The lord chancellor has repeatedly made clear that the legal professions will continue to consist predominantly of private practitioners. There is simply no evidence for Ms Roberts's casual assertion that salaried defenders will not be independent. They will be every bit as professionally independent as those in private practice.
Debora Matthews
Principal private secretary to the Lord Chancellor

fields.headline: Taliban accused of killing civilians
fields.trailText: Amnesty International accused the forces of the Taliban regime in Afghanistan yesterday of executing up to 300 civilians, some as young as 13, after capturing several villages in central part of the country earlier this month.
fields.body:
Amnesty International accused the forces of the Taliban regime in Afghanistan yesterday of executing up to 300 civilians, some as young as 13, after capturing several villages in central part of the country earlier this month.

The United Nations also says there has been extensive killing of people in the area, where the fighting continues.

A Taliban commander is alleged to have ordered his troops to kill all the men in Yakaolang they thought were opposed to them. The Taliban government has denied being involved in the deaths.

The incident occured after Yakaolang, which lies 120 miles west of Kabul in Bamiyan province, was retaken by the Taliban from the forces of Hezb-e Wahdat, part of the alliance fighting Taliban rule.

Yakaolang is populated by the Hazara people, who are Shia Muslims. The Taliban, who are Sunni Muslims from the main Afghan people, the Pashtun, have repeatedly attacked the Hazara.

Amnesty called for an international body to investigate a number massacres in which thousands have died since the Taliban seized the capital, Kabul, in September 1996 and started trying to capture the pockets of the country still outside their control.

The UN has called on the Taliban to control their commanders. The secretary general, Kofi Annan, said those killed included Afghan humanitarian workers.

A local UN man in the area is missing.

"There have been numerous credible reports of widespread summary executions of Hazara civilians by the Taliban, who apparently accused the local population of supporting the Hezb-e Wahdat," Mr Annan said.

In May 1999 Taliban soldiers killed scores of Hazara civilians after capturing Yakaolang. Houses were burned and men and boys arrested.

Taliban forces, too, have been killed en masse. In late 1997 Abdul Malik, a leading Uzbek commander from the opposition forces, took 2,000 of them prisoner and tortured and killed them in the desert outside Mazar-e Sharif.

fields.headline: A question of cause and casualties
fields.trailText: There is no doubt that hundreds of thousands of Armenians were killed in eastern Turkey during the last years of the Ottoman empire.
fields.body:
There is no doubt that hundreds of thousands of Armenians were killed in eastern Turkey during the last years of the Ottoman empire. The killing and the exodus of many other Armenians was an early 20th century version of what we now call ethnic cleansing.

What is in dispute is the number of people killed, and whether there was a systematic attempt to wipe out the Armenian race.

For several centuries the Armenians lived peacefully in the Ottoman empire, but towards the end of the 19th century the rise of competing Turkish and Armenian nationalism, as the power of the Ottoman sultans went into terminal decline, began to create serious unrest.

During the first world war the the Ottoman Turks, who were allied with Germany, saw the Armenian minority siding with the Russians against them, and came to look on them as the enemy within.

In 1915 the Ottoman authorities ordered the mass expulsion of Armenians from eastern Anatolia, where they were suspected of working with Russia to carve out a separate state.

The Turkish version of what ensued was that about 300,000 Armenians and thousands of Turks were killed in internal fighting between 1915 and 1918. There were well documented massacres on both sides: entire communities were slaughtered or burned out of their homes.

But the Armenians say there was a campaign of genocide in which the number of dead reached at least 1.5m.

Many Armenians died or were killed during forced marches into exile in the Syrian desert. Witnesses spoke of rape, torture, and mass killings.

The Turks say in response that roaming bands of Armenian irregulars were responsible for similar atrocities.

Both sides produce stacks of documents to back up their claims, and Armenian nationalists around the world have fought for decades to have the killing recognised as genocide. They say the massacres were centrally planned and approved by the Young Turk government in Istanbul.

Turkey strongly rejects the allegation, and says that some of the documents cited by Armenian activists as evidence of genocide are crude forgeries.

Turkey has proposed that a commission of historians should be appointed to examine all the claims.

But it is questionable whether that would resolve the issue. Many researchers say they have not been allowed full access to the Ottoman archives to make a proper assessment of the facts.

The bitter dispute about what happened in 1915 has blighted relations between Turks and Armenians ever since.

In the 1970s Armenian extremists began killing Turkish diplomats abroad. Modern Turkey, established on the ruins of the Ottoman empire in 1923, still has no diplomatic relations with Armenia, its eastern neighbour, now independent after 71 years as a Soviet republic.

Today about 70,000 Armenians still live in Turkey, nearly all in Istanbul. This resident group distances itself from the diaspora's campaign to win recognition for its view that what happened was attempted genocide.

Their leaders say, pragmatically, that the issue should be left to the historians.

webTitle: Roy Greenslade on Mandelson's press relations

fields.headline: Media victim? It won't wash, Peter
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter, you want the world to believe that you are a media victim. Good try, but it just doesn't wash, I'm afraid.
fields.body:
Oh Peter, how could you? You want the world to believe that you are a media victim and your epitaph to read: "Peter Mandelson. Unrecognised Genius. Hounded from office by the press. Twice."

Good try, but it just doesn't wash, I'm afraid. You have certainly suffered from some pretty beastly journalism at times. I know of several occasions when allegations in newspapers have been well wide of the mark.

When I approached you at the Guardian's last summer party to sympathise about one obvious case you told me that there had been so many inaccurate stories, so much spite, such persistent innuendo, you had virtually given up issuing denials.

Employing that odd mixture of world weariness and curtness that has become your trademark - the sigh, the swift turning of the back and a clipped phrase delivered over the shoulder as you aim for the door - you damned the whole lot of us.

Odd, I thought, for here you were at a newspaper party, and funnily enough, the last time I saw you was at a soiree for the Independent. You obviously love mixing with the enemy.

That's the point, though, isn't it? Almost all that we know of your talents as the Labour party's greatest political campaign strategist, as a fixer and a mixer, as the foremost eminence guise of modern times, have come from the media.

While spinning for Neil Kinnock and then for Tony Blair, you have never shied away from spinning for Peter Mandelson. You have made it clear to journalists that you have been the man in the know, the key player.

Your currency has been inside information: the dropped word to this correspondent, the unattributable tip to that one, the nod and wink to yet another. But the coinage has long since been debased, not because what you have said has not been true, but because of its intent.

Journalists, and their editors, have long rankled at the obvious attempt at manipulation.

That might have been okay, too, but once the spinner turns on the people he spins, it's no wonder that papers grew both wary and weary of your activities (and there might well be a lesson there for our old chum, Alastair Campbell, too).

In other words, you have chosen to play that most dangerous of games - poacher and gatekeeper - using the press in private while attacking it in public. That's why, during your home loan fiasco, the press attacked you so forcibly. Did you not understand? It wasn't political, it was personal.

Truly, the press was doing its proper job. Exposing your secret financial deal with another minister, and all the circumstances surrounding it, was in the public interest. But there was undoubtedly an edge to the headlines, the cartoons and the commentary. This wasn't just another minister in trouble.

It was Mandelson.

Journalists leapt at your throat with a glee I have rarely witnessed. Indeed, after researching the last 55 years of British newspapers, in which there have been all manner of political witch-hunts and smears, I am fairly sure you took the biggest and most sustained hammering any politician - aside from a prime minister or party leader - has endured. You were getting your come-uppance from the people you sought so long, but so crudely, to influence.

You said at the time of that resignation that you felt humbled and, for a while, I believed you. You seemed to have realised that you had made a terrible error and, in the unlikely event of a come-back, everything would be different.

By the way, in case this thought crosses your mind, I don't think you should attribute press hostility to homophobia. The way you were outed on Newsnight was unfortunate and, after an initial, and possibly understandable bout of hysteria from you, you did handle it well.

There may be individual journalists who are anti-gay, but don't fool yourself into thinking that's why you have been getting the rough treatment all over again.

Though I was surprised at your return to the cabinet, I expected that you would be a different man. You would now be squeaky clean. You would know, after the last round, that you had few friends in the press. Indeed, implicit in what you said to me that summer evening, was a recognition that newspapers were your implacable enemy. So why Peter, why did you not stop and think before making that call on behalf of Srichand Hinduja?

I can only attribute it to your arrogance. Having returned to high office, you felt invulnerable all over again. You were entertaining Northern Ireland's finest in Hillsborough castle at weekends. You were back inside the beltway, briefing correspondents about many more subjects than Ulster's faltering peace process. You could, you probably thought, do anything.

But your enemies are not confined to the press, as you also know. Some time, that call - however innocently you wish to portray it - was bound to come to light.

It may well have come sooner had Mr Hinduja and his brothers made a successful bid for Express Newspapers. Journalists from competing papers would have expended hours of otherwise good drinking time trying to discover why Mr Hinduja got his British passport so soon after giving £1m to the dome's faith zone.

The revelation has taken longer to emerge than I expected when I first questioned the oddity of that arrangement last October.

Mention of the dome reminds me about the way in which you acted as lightning rod for the early press criticism of that project. It may have been unfair, but did it not give you pause for thought? Did it not suggest that you should step carefully in future?

Peter, you cannot really blame the press for your downfall. You brought all this on yourself. You set out to make newspapers dance to your tune, but they didn't like your music or your lyrics. Now, at the moment of your defeat, the papers are on song again.

fields.bodyText: Oh Peter, how could you? You want the world to believe that you are a media victim and your epitaph to read: "Peter Mandelson. Unrecognised Genius. Hounded from office by the press. Twice." Good try, but it just doesn't wash, I'm afraid. You have certainly suffered from some pretty beastly journalism at times. I know of several occasions when allegations in newspapers have been well wide of the mark. When I approached you at the Guardian's last summer party to sympathise about one obvious case you told me that there had been so many inaccurate stories, so much spite, such persistent innuendo, you had virtually given up issuing denials. Employing that odd mixture of world weariness and curtness that has become your trademark - the sigh, the swift turning of the back and a clipped phrase delivered over the shoulder as you aim for the door - you damned the whole lot of us. Odd, I thought, for here you were at a newspaper party, and funnily enough, the last time I saw you was at a soiree for the Independent. You obviously love mixing with the enemy. That's the point, though, isn't it? Almost all that we know of your talents as the Labour party's greatest political campaign strategist, as a fixer and a mixer, as the foremost eminence guise of modern times, have come from the media. While spinning for Neil Kinnock and then for Tony Blair, you have never shied away from spinning for Peter Mandelson. You have made it clear to journalists that you have been the man in the know, the key player. Your currency has been inside information: the dropped word to this correspondent, the unattributable tip to that one, the nod and wink to yet another. Journalists, and their editors, have long rankled at the obvious attempt at manipulation. webTitle: Hugo Young on the fall of Mandelson

fields.headline: The party animal
fields.standfirst:
Doing his best to blame the media, a compulsive manipulator exits from the limelight

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Doing his best to blame the media, Mandelson, the compulsive manipulator, exits from the limelight.
fields.body:
From the start this New Labour government has been permeated by contrasting cultures. Ideological division is close to zero. Left and right factions that were accorded formal status by every former Labour prime minister no longer exist, though Blairites v Brownies is a battle sometimes made to stand proxy for them. There is really no such contest. But there has always been a contrast of tone, of style, of milieu, of social aspiration, between what one might call flash politics and drudge politics. Peter Mandelson's resignation heralds, not to Labour's disadvantage, a decisive victory for the drudgery style.

One can imagine the scene in Downing Street yesterday morning. Tony Blair had undeviating faith in Mr Mandelson's judgment and fraternity. The parting of the ways was necessary, because once too often, and close to an election, Mandelson skated beyond the edge of the truth. The sundering would be terrible, because the prime minister has a personal instinct for loyalty, as well as a political desire to offer no scalp to the other side. He showed this in the House with decent, eloquent and repeated recognition of what the now-defunct minister did for Ireland. The end had a pain reaching beyond the normal purlieus of political cynicism.

But the departure also marked a cultural shift. Peter Mandelson, though he has other qualities, personifies the flash side of New Labour. He occupied the junction where the new rich met showbusiness, and aspiring socialites made their bids to climb aboard the new establishment. New Labour needed to be friends with royalty. Peter was their friend. It needed business acceptance. Peter was one of the guarantors. It proved the non-existence of the class war by turning up at all the right parties. Nobody better than Peter demonstrated that Labour had no enemies on the boogying, socialising, upwardly mobile right.

This may have been a necessary part of Labour's transformation into a party for all types of people. Its disadvantage was that it distracted attention from so much else. What often got lost - is still largely unnoticed - in the Mandelsonian images that tend to define the Blair government is how large a proportion of its ministers are, in a drudge-like way, competent.

Jack Straw is not one of my favourites, and has single-handedly cut the party off from its liberal constituency. But he is an able minister. He has handled the political minefield of the Home Office with sure feet. David Blunkett is another capable drudge: industrious, creative, committed. Geoff Hoon, Alan Milburn and Alistair Darling fall into the same category. They are unglamorous, and none of them looks like a potential leader. But they get diligently on with the job. They are not sleazy. There are no signs of exhaustion. The opposition can't lay a glove on any of them. This government includes no Hogg or Redwood or Mawhinney, to name but three disasters from the last one.

But the drudges tend to be overshadowed. The public profile of the government barely includes them. They're the victims of the presidentialism that puts Tony Blair at the top and the rest nowhere, around which much of the flashiness and all Labour's image-building rotated. That was a style of politics that Mandelson was most influential in inventing when Labour was in opposition. And Mr Blair, of course, is complicit in the fact that he personally has become the only name and face with which most of the public associate his party.

Yet such a concentration has bad effects. The predominant image of the government - its divisions, its bitcheries, its rivalries, not to mention its apparent obsession with appearance over content - comes from a relentless focus on the lives and work of four men, Blair, Brown, Mandelson and Alastair Campbell, with a few acolytes and hangers-on thrown in. Here's where the glamour and excitement are. Much of the other work is almost wholly obscured. In terms of plodding competence, this is beginning to show itself as one of the best governments of the last half-century. Yet the flash-dancing gets just about all the attention.

Mandelson's withdrawal will help to change that. As he said, the scrutiny of his every move became intolerable, especially when one move turned out to be wrong. His absence won't, on the other hand, make cabinet reshuffling any easier after the election. Yesterday's emergency surgery doesn't diminish Mr Blair's problem which is, unusually, a surfeit rather than a scarcity of talent.

It was never likely that Mandelson would become foreign secretary any time soon. This was less because of his defects than the incumbent's burgeoning talents, after early turmoil in his private life, as a brilliant drudge. Robin Cook will almost certainly succeed Robin Cook. He's regularly singled out for praise in private conversation. His command of detail and negotiating skills, as well as the respect he enjoys abroad, are much valued by the prime minister. Replacing him with Jack Straw, his plausible rival, would be a Eurosceptic signal the leader won't want to give. So that's one non-vacancy.

The Treasury is also unlikely to change hands. Some see Gordon Brown's shift to the FCO as the way to finesse his anti-euro sway at the Treasury, as well as proving Blair's domination. It doesn't make sense. Brown would loathe and fight it. Besides, unlike a succession of Tory chancellors, this Labour one has no serious economic argument with his leader. However, the shuffling field is thereby further narrowed. Plainly there will be some forced departures. The names of Smith, Brown (N), Beckett and, now, Byers, appear in the frame. The main problem, however, is strength not weakness. For down below too, there are able people whose names you have barely heard of behind the incessant static generated by the prime minister's domination: Clarke, Denham, Hewitt, several others.

I regret seeing Peter Mandelson go. He has the breadth and many of the skills our public life always needs. He probably thought he was doing his national duty, giving a minor leg-up to someone who was going to help rescue Blairism's biggest calamity down in Greenwich. He plainly has incautious judgment when it comes to his own affairs and contacts. But he's right about Europe, being one of the few ministers to give that keynote subject the priority it deserves. He also showed a lot of political guts in trying to progress the peace process.

On the other hand, a distraction has departed. Having helped refashion Labour into an electable party of the centre, he leaves the field to people who are more old Labour in style if not content: decent, earnest, often incredibly dull, but, I guess, the kind of types with whom voters feel more comfortable. Mr Blair himself has been moving that way for some time, stressing competence and continuity rather than the exuberant flash of 1997. It's through his own folly that Mandelson went. But his going says a certain style of politics has, quite regrettably, had its day.

webTitle: Real action in Davos will be off piste

fields.headline: Real action in Davos will be off piste
fields.standfirst: As the big three economies slide, globalisation's annual think-in will have one eye on the Fed
fields.trailText: As the big three economies slide, globalisation's annual think-in will have one eye on the Fed.
fields.body:
Today's the day when the great and the good of globalisation gather in the Swiss ski resort of Davos for their annual thinkathon. Some will arrive by limo, some will take the train that winds its way through the pine forests, the really flash will fly in by helicopter.

But despite all the corporate clout on show up in the high Alps, the real action will be taking place on a much smaller hill on the other side of the Atlantic when the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, gives testimony to the Senate budget committee. Having hauled the global economy back from disaster once, Mr Greenspan is again seen as the saviour by CEOs who signed up for Davos when everything still looked rosy.

This time last year, the world was gripped by the last absurd stage of the technology bubble and there was talk of how the American economy had climbed to a new plateau of achievement. The financial crises of 1997-98 were but a distant memory as the talk turned to the business opportunities in the next generation of the internet. Bliss was it to suck in the pure Alpine air and think of stock options.

A gloomier mood will be in evidence this time. A quick glance at the global economy shows that the big three - the United States, Japan and Germany - all have their problems. America's descent from boom to the edge of bust has been rapid; less than two months ago there was still speculation that Mr Greenspan might be forced to raise rates to head off inflationary pressure stoked up by excessive consumption.

For the whole of this week the markets have been on tenterhooks, wondering whether the notoriously cryptic Fed chairman will give a hint that he may follow the surprise half-point cut in interest rates on January 3 with a similar reduction at the scheduled meeting of the central bank's open market committee next week. Financial "experts" have changed their tune somewhat as the weeks have passed and the profit warnings from both new and old economy companies have mounted.

At one stage they were certain the US was on course for a soft landing, then they said the US would probably enjoy a soft landing. When Mr Greenspan moved early in the New Year, it was taken as evidence that a hard landing would be avoided. Now it is said that a hard landing will be averted provided Greenspan cuts rates aggressively in the first half of this year and that President Bush boosts consumer confidence with a package of tax cuts.

Those who have long been bearish of the US economy say that this is all wishful thinking. Brian Redding of Lombard Street Research says that the recession has already started, a view which appears to be supported by the recent survey by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve, which showed a precipitous decline in manufacturing activity at the end of last year. There are already signs that individuals, who ran down their savings to historically low levels in order to play the stock market during its heady rise, have reacted to the pricking of the bubble by saving more. If this is so, then even a halving of US interest rates to 3% in the coming months may not be enough to produce the sharp recovery the optimists are now confidently expecting.

Even so, Mr Redding believes that deep cuts in interest rates are needed to head off the risk of a Japanese-style scenario, where the problem is not inflation but deflation. As policy makers in Tokyo have found, a period of falling prices makes the normal instruments of economic management less effective, with consumers preferring to hoard money rather than spend.

If America's economic illness is acute, Japan's is chronic. More than a decade after its stock-market meltdown, the world's second-biggest economy looks ready to lurch back into recession. Growth is weak, consumer confidence is low, bankruptcies are rising, the stock market is sickly, land prices are still falling.

Above all policy is ineffective and policy makers appear to be lost for answers. Interest rates are unable to go any lower, but deflation means that real rates of interest - nominal rates adjusted for the level of prices - are still too high for companies struggling with weak demand. After repeated boosts to government spending, fiscal policy is also no longer working, with consumers in Japan rightly suspicious that they will eventually have to pay for the increase in borrowing through higher taxation.

In contrast to the US and Japan, Europe looks in relatively good shape, even though the state of the German economy is giving cause for concern. The key measure of business confidence - the Ifo index - has fallen for seven months in a row, and in the past has tended to track what is happening in the US with a six-month time lag. The fact that other parts of Europe, particularly France, are looking more buoyant suggests that Germany may have unique problems, perhaps associated with the rate at which it joined the euro, but with inflation easing as oil prices come down there is a strong case for the European Central Bank emulating Mr Greenspan's example and cutting rates.

Japan and Germany have been through sticky periods before during the 90s, but the global economy has been dragged along by the strength of the US. To have all three economies in the doldrums at once spells trouble; big trouble if Opec pushes oil prices up and policy makers fail to get a move on. Something to ponder over the fondue in Davos.

Those who have long been bearish of the US economy say that this is all wishful thinking. Brian Redding of Lombard Street Research says that the recession has already started, a view which appears to be supported by the recent survey by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve, which showed a precipitous decline in manufacturing activity at the end of last year. There are already signs that individuals, who ran down their savings to historically low levels in order to play the stock market during its heady rise, have reacted to the pricking of the bubble by saving more. If this is so, then even a halving of US interest rates to 3% in the coming months may not be enough to produce the sharp recovery the optimists are now confidently expecting. Even so, Mr Redding believes that deep cuts in interest rates are needed to head off the risk of a Japanese-style scenario, where the problem is not inflation but deflation. As policy makers in Tokyo have found, a period of falling prices makes the normal instruments of economic management less effective, with consumers preferring to hoard money rather than spend. If America's economic illness is acute, Japan's is chronic. More than a decade after its stock-market meltdown, the world's second-biggest economy looks ready to lurch back into recession. Growth is weak, consumer confidence is low, bankruptcies are rising, the stock market is sickly, land prices are still falling. Above all policy is ineffective and policy makers appear to be lost for answers. Interest rates are unable to go any lower, but deflation means that real rates of interest - nominal rates adjusted for the level of prices - are still too high for companies struggling with weak demand. After repeated boosts to government spending, fiscal policy is also no longer working, with consumers in Japan rightly suspicious that they will eventually have to pay for the increase in borrowing through higher taxation. In contrast to the US and Japan, Europe looks in relatively good shape, even though the state of the German economy is giving cause for concern. The key measure of business confidence - the Ifo index - has fallen for seven months in a row, and in the past has tended to track what is happening in the US with a six-month time lag. The fact that other parts of Europe, particularly France, are looking more buoyant suggests that Germany may have unique problems, perhaps associated with the rate at which it joined the euro, but with inflation easing as oil prices come down there is a strong case for the European Central Bank emulating Mr Greenspan's example and cutting rates. Japan and Germany have been through sticky periods before during the 90s, but the global economy has been dragged along by the strength of the US. To have all three economies in the doldrums at once spells trouble; big trouble if Opec pushes oil prices up and policy makers fail to get a move on. Something to ponder over the fondue in Davos.

webTitle: Cricket: Domestic Tests find an energetic new sponsor

fields.headline: Domestic Tests find an energetic new sponsor
fields.trailText: To the accompaniment of funky footage of England successes and no doubt to the general relief of the England and Wales Cricket Board, Npower, the young and extremely thrusting energy-supply company, was installed yesterday as sponsor of home Test matches for the next three seasons.
fields.body:
To the accompaniment of funky footage of England successes and no doubt to the general relief of the England and Wales Cricket Board, Npower, the young and extremely thrusting energy-supply company, was installed yesterday as sponsor of home Test matches for the next three seasons.

The deal, which is worth £11m, an increase of £2m over the past three years of Cornhill's involvement, begins immediately and the first Test under the new banner will take place at Lord's against Pakistan beginning on May 17.

It has been a tough search to find a successor to Cornhill, which bowed out after 23 years, but the board has yet to announce sponsors either for the County Championship or what was the NatWest Trophy.

Apparently three other companies had entered into detailed discussions over the Test sponsorship but the satisfactory outcome has not come easily, not least because of the poor performances of the England side over the past few years.

According to David Andrew, Npower's managing director residential, the performances of Nasser Hussain's side last summer, when they beat Zimbabwe and West Indies, went a considerable way to persuading the company to extend its sponsorship portfolio from the television programme The Bill and the FA Premier League - where for £1.2m a season it is one of a number of "official partners".

"The win against West Indies was definitely a factor," Andrew said. "We want to be associated with value and one part of that is winning."

He also announced that in conjunction with the ECB, Npower will be helping to finance new schemes to attract a younger audience to the sport.

To this end a partnership deal has been set up that will see money ploughed back into the game for every new customer who joins Npower.

In announcing the sponsorship the chief executive of the ECB Tim Lamb added that as a further encouragement, under-16s will be admitted free to the last scheduled day of Tests and will pay half price otherwise.

"We look forward to developing an excellent relationship with Npower in our efforts to broaden the game's appeal to a new generation of cricket-watchers," he said. "Npower is a modern thriving company with a very forward-looking and consumer-focused attitude to its business, and these are attributes with which cricket wants to be associated."

fields.headline: Chasing Scoot
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Presumably investors who dabble in the shares of Scoot.com, the internet business directory company, must know all about the health and wealth warnings that adorn investment literature.
fields.body:
Presumably investors who dabble in the shares of Scoot.com, the internet business directory company, must know all about the health and wealth warnings that adorn investment literature.

Time after time, they have piled in to the company's shares in the hope of a bid from French media group and 22.4% shareholder Vivendi Universal - and time after time they have been disappointed. The worst instance came last September, when many investors were left nursing huge losses after Scoot and its advisers took until 4pm to issue a statement saying it was not in takeover talks with Vivendi.

Yesterday, it all started again. Market rumours that Scoot boss Robert Bonnier had meet Vivendi and agreed a 125p a share offer - apparently it will be announced at some point in the next week - helped its shares close 6.5p, or 8.67%, higher at 81.5p in heavy turnover of 13m.

fields.headline: Fischer in the Eurosceptics' den
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, refused to water down his proposals for a federal Europe last night, even though he was speaking in Britain, home of the most committed Eurosceptics.
fields.body:
The German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, refused to water down his proposals for a federal Europe last night, even though he was speaking in Britain, home of the most committed Eurosceptics.

But choosing his words to avoid embarrassing the Labour government in the run-up to the general election, he stressed that greater integration among the countries of Europe did not mean the end of the nation state. And he avoided saying federalism, referring to it as the "German f-word".

Mr Fischer, who emerged in a Berlin speech last year as the leading proponent of a more powerful and more democratic European Union, struck out in his London address at all the bulwarks of British Euroscepticism: Conservative MPs, Lady Thatcher, and the press.

In one of the most pro-European speeches made on British soil by a foreign leader, he set out what he referred to as "mega-projects" for the EU. This would create a union with wider powers, a more straightforward system of making decisions, and greater democratic accountablity.

He described Europe's single currency, which Britain has not joined, as a success, claiming that the euro was more stable than even the deutschmark had been in the 1990s.

The Foreign Office, which saw an advance copy of the speech, had warned Mr Fischer to be careful what he said, so as not to be misinterpreted by Eurosceptic media.

Mr Fischer, who joked in the speech about being labelled by Eurosceptics "the most dangerous man in Europe", partly heeded the advice.

"The EU is never going to be a state, let alone some kind of superstate," he said. "No one - in Germany, France or anywhere else in Europe - wants a centralised superbureaucracy." He also tried to allay fears that US-European relations could be weakened.

The Conservative MP John Redwood, who was in the audience, said that in spite of a few cosmetic changes, the speech showed that the German minister had not repented and was saying things the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, believed but was embarrassed to say.

Mr Fischer said the sceptics had misread what was happening in Europe. "The nightmare of British Eurosceptics, the so-called superstate, a new sovereign that would abolish the old nation states along with their democratic governments - is therefore nothing but a synthetic construct that has nothing whatsoever to do with European reality."

In a piece of mischief, he said he agreed with the sceptics' heroine, Margaret Thatcher, who said in 1975 there was a need to pool sovereignty to create more effective political bodies.

EU enlargement, he argued, was vital to avoid an east-west split and the prospect of another war. Four wars in Yugoslavia had shown the dangers.

To confront globalisation, he said, Europe had to pool sovereignty on a host of issues. "Whether we are talking about preventing wars, arms control, development assistance, effective help for refugees, global warming, regulating global financial markets or trade matters, on such issues no European country, not even the biggest, can have real influence unless they join forces."

He also called for democratic reform. He favours a directly elected European commission and a European parliament in which there is representation from national parliaments.

webTitle: What next for Labour's master spinner?

fields.headline: What next for Labour's master spinner?
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: What career might the future hold for Peter Mandelson?
fields.body:
What career might the future hold for Peter Mandelson?

An author?

 Michael Fishwick, publishing director of HarperCollins:

"I would love to publish his memoirs. He's a fascinating man and you cannot be uninterested in what he would have to say. But I suspect he's very private and would think twice about rushing into a memoir. He might well write something, but I can't believe he would spill the beans."

Industry?

 Ruth Lea, head of policy at the Institute of Directors:

"He impressed us all as trade secretary. He picked up on the issues very well and was a very coherent thinker. A lot of those skills are transferable and he has wonderful contacts - but he has no business experience."

Lobbying?

 Leighton Andrews, managing director of lobbyists Westminster Strategy:

"I don't think Peter Mandelson would go anywhere near political consultancy or PR. I think he would be more interested in business strategy, perhaps in the media or new media sector."

Public relations?

 Max Clifford, publicist:

"He's perfect for PR. He has a good understanding of the media, seems to be incredibly ambitious and is certainly capable of putting a spin on anything. He also knows where the bodies are buried and which buttons to press."

An estate agent?

 Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents:

"The two key qualities are honesty and integrity. You have to come across as sincere, have extremely good people skills and an in-depth knowledge of the market. Politicians in most people's minds come below estate agents, so he would be well prepared for the flak we get."

Spun out: The rise, fall, rise and fall

 Born in north London on October 21 1953, Peter Mandelson seems destined for a life in politics: his maternal grandfather is Clement Attlee's deputy, Herbert Morrison; his parents are staunch Labourites; and the Wilsons are his near neighbours

 At Hendon County grammar school he tells peers he wants to be prime minister - though in his late teens he flirts with the Young Communist League

 In 1976 he leaves St Catherine's college, Oxford, with a second in politics and a clear allegiance to mainstream Labour politics

 In 1979 he is elected to Lambeth council - then in its leftwing heyday - and in 1980 becomes a political researcher for Albert Booth, Labour's transport spokesman

 Two years later he gets a job as a producer for London Weekend Television's Weekend World

 By September 1985 his climb up the greasy political pole is well on course. Neil Kinnock appoints him director of communications for the Labour party. He sets about making the party re-electable, softening its 'hard face' and replacing it with the soft red rose.

 Five years later he resigns to fight Hartlepool, which he wins in 1992

 Sidelined by the then Labour leader, John Smith, his real ability as the archetypal spin doctor and fixer emerges within 24 hours of Smith's death, when he briefs the press that the new leader 'has to be Blair'. Gordon Brown, who had been regarded as the heir apparent, has never forgiven him

 With Mr Blair in power, the Prince of Darkness - as his detractors call him - continues his meteoric rise. On May 2 1997 he is appointed minister without portfolio at the cabinet office - a role which gives him responsibility for the Millennium Dome

 Just over a year later he wins his coveted cabinet post, becoming trade and industry secretary

 By October 1998 his power seems boundless. After Matthew Parris, an openly gay former Tory MP and Times sketch writer, 'outs' him on Newsnight, the BBC issues a memo insisting: 'Under no circumstances whatsoever should the allegation about the private life of Peter Mandelson be repeated or referred to on any broadcast.' Mo Mowlam, then Northern Ireland secretary, lambasts the corporation for the ban

 But in December things get much worse. Following a revelation in the Guardian the minister resigns over a £373,000 loan from the then paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson, to buy a Notting Hill house. The loan was processed when Mr Robinson was under investigation by Mr Mandelson's department, the DTI

 His time in the wilderness is short. In September 1999 he replaces Mo Mowlam as Northern Ireland secretary, finally securing a reputation as a political heavyweight

 In December 1999 he oversees the setting up of the Northern Ireland executive - a success he describes as the 'proudest moment of my life'

 In February 2000 he suspends the executive after David Trimble threatens to resign as first minister over the IRA's failure to disarm. The move is attacked by nationalists and sours Mr Mandelson's relations with Sinn Fein and the Irish government

 In May 2000 the executive is restored after Mr Mandelson and Mr Blair broker a deal between Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists which sees the IRA make its first serious gesture on decommissioning

 On January 21 2001 the Observer carries the passport story. Within four days Mr Mandelson's political career is over

webTitle: Balance of power shifts towards Brown

fields.headline: Balance of power shifts towards Brown
fields.standfirst:
As the chancellor sees off an enemy who briefed against him, Blair's judgment is called into question

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: As the chancellor sees off an enemy who briefed against him, Blair's judgment is called into question.
fields.body:
Two clear winners have emerged from an affair that will shift the balance of power at the very top of the government.

Gordon Brown's position is strengthened further, his arch enemy's departure tightening his grip on power and removing an obstacle to him running for, and quite possibly winning, the Labour leadership if Tony Blair steps down after the election.

Mr Mandelson was an opposing force within cabinet and more widely in the media, briefing against Mr Brown in a feud that stretched back to 1994, when "Bobby" backed Mr Blair for the party's crown.

The chancellor benefits, too, from the hit Mr Blair will inevitably take from the fall of one of his closest political allies and the inevitable questions about his judgment in bringing back Mr Mandelson nine months after he had to go.

Tellingly, Mr Brown yesterday asked his aides and supporters to say absolutely nothing, to avoid accusations he had "won" the seven-year feud with the Hartlepool MP.

The second clear winner is Alastair Campbell, victorious in what, despite Downing Street denials, looked like a "me or him" showdown after Mr Mandelson's casualness with the truth required the prime minister's official spokesman to apologise for misleading the media.

Relations had been strained between the two masters of spin since Mr Mandelson returned as Northern Ireland secretary in September 1999, and the resignation will reinforce the influence of a press secretary dubbed the real deputy prime minister.

Other winners include Robin Cook, virtually stalked by Mr Mandelson, who coveted his job as foreign secretary, and the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who is close to Gordon Brown and who Mr Mandelson wanted sacked after the election.

On top of the reshuffle triggered yesterday, Mr Mandelson was due to be brought back from Belfast after the election and the line-up of the cabinet will be considerably different without him at Mr Blair's right elbow.

The Paisley South MP, Douglas Alexander, a protege of the chancellor's who was given a Millbank role in November 1999, will also benefit by plotting Labour's election campaign as Mr Mandelson, made joint co-ordinator with the chancellor, takes a back seat.

The option of an April election has probably been closed off by the events of the past few days, yet whether the Mandelson row will help the Tories in May is difficult to gauge, though it cannot have done William Hague any harm.

The biggest loser after Mr Mandelson is Mr Blair. He brought his ally back less than a year after the first resignation in the teeth of warnings that he could prove a disruptive influence.

The prime minister yesterday found himself under fire on two contradictory fronts.

One prominent Labour backbencher said it had exposed his reliance on "Tony's cronies" - appointing friends to key posts and overlooking their failings in return for their loyalty.

A close acquaintance of Mr Mandelson took a contrary view, claiming the prime minister's presentation to the Tories of such a prized scalp betrayed the prime minister's unwillingness to stand by his friends.

"He's got the job he wants so he's not bothered about what jobs other people have," is the harsh view of one member of the Millbank tendency.

Whatever the truth, saying goodbye to Mr Mandelson so soon after welcoming him back into the cabinet casts a shadow over the prime minister's judgment in the eyes of both camps.

A number of policy wonks in Downing Street, and thinktanks and pressure groups who owe their positions largely to the patronage of the great manipulator may also be sleeping less soundly in their beds.

Mr Mandelson's departure is a major blow for "the project", the Blairite drive to take the Labour party away from its trade union roots and get closer to the Liberal Democrats, introducing proportional representation in an attempt to guarantee government from the centre.

The diaries of the former Liberal Democrat leader, Paddy Ashdown, detail Mr Mandelson's desire to push forward co-operation between the two parties, attending crucial meetings and helping to set up the joint cabinet committee.

With Mr Mandelson gone, Mr Blair has few supporters at the heart of government to push ahead with the plan and his opponents, particularly over electoral reform, may be emboldened by the fall.

Mr Mandelson was also one of the government's most enthusiastic supporters of the euro, initially arguing that Britain should have held a referendum on joining the single currency shortly after the last election, before pressing for the plebiscite to be held soon after the next.

With Mr Cook and the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, he championed the benefits of campaigning to sell the euro to the public against the cautious approach of the chancellor.

Out of government and freed of the constraints of collective responsibility, Mr Mandelson may be more vocal in his support for the euro.

But Mr Cook and Mr Byers are more isolated in the cabinet as a duo rather than part of a trio that included a minister with the prime minister's ear, so Mr Mandelson's exit in all likelihood will strengthen the hand of the chancellor.

fields.bodyText: Two clear winners have emerged from an affair that will shift the balance of power at the very top of the government. Gordon Brown's position is strengthened further, his arch enemy's departure tightening his grip on power and removing an obstacle to him running for, and quite possibly winning, the Labour leadership if Tony Blair steps down after the election. Mr Mandelson was an opposing force within cabinet and more widely in the media, briefing against Mr Brown in a feud that stretched back to 1994, when "Bobby" backed Mr Blair for the party's crown. The chancellor benefits, too, from the hit Mr Blair will inevitably take from the fall of one of his closest political allies and the inevitable questions about his judgment in bringing back Mr Mandelson nine months after he had to go. Tellingly, Mr Brown yesterday asked his aides and supporters to say absolutely nothing, to avoid accusations he had "won" the seven-year feud with the Hartlepool MP. The second clear winner is Alastair Campbell, victorious in what, despite Downing Street denials, looked like a "me or him" showdown after Mr Mandelson's casualness with the truth required the prime minister's official spokesman to apologise for misleading the media. Relations had been strained between the two masters of spin since Mr Mandelson returned as Northern Ireland secretary in September 1999, and the resignation will reinforce the influence of a press secretary dubbed the real deputy prime minister. Other winners include Robin Cook, virtually stalked by Mr Mandelson, who coveted his job as foreign secretary, and the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who is close to Gordon Brown and who Mr Mandelson wanted sacked after the election. On top of the reshuffle triggered yesterday, Mr Mandelson was due to be brought back from Belfast after the election and the line-up of the cabinet will be considerably different without him at Mr Blair's right elbow. The Paisley South MP, Douglas Alexander, a protege of the chancellor's who was given a Millbank role in November 1999, will also benefit by plotting Labour's election campaign as Mr Mandelson, made joint co-ordinator with the chancellor, takes a back seat. The option of an April election has probably been closed off by the events of the past few days, yet whether the Mandelson row will help the Tories in May is difficult to gauge, though it cannot have done William Hague any harm. The biggest loser after Mr Mandelson is Mr Blair. He brought his ally back less than a year after the first resignation in the teeth of warnings that he could prove a disruptive influence. The prime minister yesterday found himself under fire on two contradictory fronts. One prominent Labour backbencher said it had exposed his reliance on "Tony's cronies" - appointing friends to key posts and overlooking their failings in return for their loyalty. A close acquaintance of Mr Mandelson took a contrary view, claiming the prime minister's presentation to the Tories of such a prized scalp betrayed the prime minister's unwillingness to stand by his friends. "He's got the job he wants so he's not bothered about what jobs other people have," is the harsh view of one member of the Millbank tendency. Whatever the truth, saying goodbye to Mr Mandelson so soon after welcoming him back into the cabinet casts a shadow over the prime minister's judgment in the eyes of both camps. A number of policy wonks in Downing Street, and thinktanks and pressure groups who owe their positions largely to the patronage of the great manipulator may also be sleeping less soundly in their beds. Mr Mandelson's departure is a major blow for "the project", the Blairite drive to take the Labour party away from its trade union roots and get closer to the Liberal Democrats, introducing proportional representation in an attempt to guarantee government from the centre. The diaries of the former Liberal Democrat leader, Paddy Ashdown, detail Mr Mandelson's desire to push forward co-operation between the two parties, attending crucial meetings and helping to set up the joint cabinet committee. With Mr Mandelson gone, Mr Blair has few supporters at the heart of government to push ahead with the plan and his opponents, particularly over electoral reform, may be emboldened by the fall. Mr Mandelson was also one of the government's most enthusiastic supporters of the euro, initially arguing that Britain should have held a referendum on joining the single currency shortly after the last election, before pressing for the plebiscite to be held soon after the next. With Mr Cook and the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, he championed the benefits of campaigning to sell the euro to the public against the cautious approach of the chancellor. Out of government and freed of the constraints of collective responsibility, Mr Mandelson may be more vocal in his support for the euro. But Mr Cook and Mr Byers are more isolated in the cabinet as a duo rather than part of a trio that included a minister with the prime minister's ear, so Mr Mandelson's exit in all likelihood will strengthen the hand of the chancellor.
