fields.headline: A glittering career in ruins
fields.standfirst:
 Mandelson quits over passport deception
 Blair loses closest ally in run-up to election

Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText:
 Mandelson quits over passport deception
 Blair loses closest ally in run-up to election
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's glittering political career collapsed yesterday for the second and final time over an unnecessary act of deception - his fatal refusal to be frank with the prime minster about his role in brokering a British passport for a £1m donor to the Millennium Dome.

In a day of high drama not equalled at Westminster since Mr Mandelson's previous resignation, over his secret home loan in 1998, the man who helped to craft New Labour's modernising image for 15 years stepped down as the Northern Ireland secretary and renounced all strategic responsibility for the coming general election.

Waking up to a barrage of hostile headlines yesterday, both Tony Blair and Mr Mandelson almost certainly knew it was all over by the time they met at number 10 in mid-morning. Three hours later came an apologetic resignation statement in the street outside.

Before the meeting the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, had refused to endorse the Northern Ireland secretary when he briefed reporters. "The prime minister has got to face the House of Commons this afternoon and there are a number of areas of fact he feels the need to pin down."

In their hour-long meeting Mr Blair and his most trusted aide discussed why the media, Mr Campbell and ministers were misled for 48 hours about Mr Mandelson's single phone call to Mike O'Brien, the immigration minister, in June 1998.

Mr Mandelson insisted he had done nothing improper, but accepted that he had not told the whole truth about his intervention in the application for naturalisation by Srichanda Hinduja, a wealthy Indian businessman.

After revelations in the Observer on Sunday, Mr Mandelson had insisted that he had merely asked his private office to pass on a request for information regarding a possible application from Mr Hinduja to the Home Office in June 1998. In fact he made the crucial two-minute phone call in person.

In the same month the Hinduja brothers offered to sponsor the faith zone at the Millennium Dome. Mr Mandelson, as the cabinet office minister, was in charge of the Greenwich project.

Mr Mandelson, who was out of office for 10 months after the Guardian's revelations about his £373,000 home loan from Geoffrey Robinson, is now entitled to his second ministerial pay-off, of £12,129, in just over two years.

Yesterday insiders emphatically denied that Mr Campbell had threatened to resign if Mr Mandelson did not. There was no need to do so, MPs agreed. The minister's inconsistencies, in private and on also television on Tuesday night, were all too evident.

"If Tony ever had to choose between Peter and Alastair, Alastair would win. He is the long distance runner, Peter the sprinter," one Labour veteran explained.

Mr Campbell later confirmed that Mr Mandelson would not be taking part in Labour's general election campaign. "I think Peter's making clear from his statement that he is clearly looking to wind down his political activity," he said.

Mr Mandelson's exit leaves the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in a much stronger position. He and his close ally, Douglas Alexander, will now be in complete charge at Millbank, the party's headquarters. Mr Mandelson had been responsible for the nuts and bolts planning for the election.

Last night there was even doubt about whether Mr Mandelson would stay on as an MP. Tim Allan, a former Downing Street press officer and friend of Mr Mandelson, said the member for Hartlepool would think "long and hard" before dropping his constituency, and insisted that he would want to remain in public life.

In his statement Mr Mandelson denied "acting improperly" over Mr Hinduja's passport bid, but admitted: "I do accept that when my office spoke to a Sunday newspaper at the weekend I should have been clear that it was me personally, not my officials, who spoke to a Home Office minister."

He also attacked the media for its relentless vilification of his political role as a pro- European, pro-Lib-Lab moderate, and for its interest in his private life. "I want to remove myself from the countless stories of controversy, feuds and division and all the rest. I want in other words to lead a more normal life, both in politics and, in the future, outside," he said.

In the Commons, William Hague gleefully denounced the prime minister's "monumental error of judgment" in giving his old friend a second chance in 1999 - leaving Mr Blair loyally to defend the achievements of the flawed colleague who sat grim-faced at his side.

But few Tories believe their own election chances have been much improved. "William has 24 hours to make this stick to Blair," said one MP. The Tory leader did so by claiming that Mr Mandelson had been "central to everything you have done" - from spin to smears on colleagues. The Liberal leader, Charles Kennedy, joined Mr Blair in saying it was Mr Hague who had demeaned himself.

Downing Street last night moved to replace Mr Mandelson at what is seen as a crucial stage in the Northern Ireland peace process, giving the job to the Scottish secretary, John Reid. He is replaced, in turn, by Helen Liddell.

Meanwhile, Mr Blair appointed a leading QC, the former Treasury counsel Sir Anthony Hammond, to examine the way the Hinduja passport was eventually granted in March 1999 - although the prime minister told MPs that he and Jack Straw, the home secretary, were satisfied that it was properly done.

But the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, wrote to Mr Straw last night demanding the he makes a Commons statement on the whole affair.

webTitle: Mandelson's departure could spell trouble for peace

fields.headline: Sudden departure could spell trouble for stumbling peace
fields.standfirst:
Unionists mourn ally while nationalists rejoice

Northern Ireland
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Unionists mourn ally while nationalists rejoice.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's stint as Northern Ireland secretary was only ever intended as a rehabilitation programme to get him back to London after he was forced to quit his post as trade secretary two years ago.

He arrived to a crisis and he leaves in the middle of another, although he achieved what no one else has done for 30 years - handing over power to a locally elected government.

From the outside, the timing of his departure, at such a critical juncture in the peace process, seems devastating.

His successor, however experienced, will have to spend some time getting into position, and with the general election looming and unionist disillusionment with the Good Friday agreement hardening, every day counts.

However, a change of personnel might not prove too problematic and Tony Blair as always is sure to keep a tight rein on proceedings.

As Mr Mandelson became aware the minute he set foot in the province, Ulster politics is a zero sum game - when one side cries foul the other cheers.

Just as his predecessor, Mo Mowlam, was seen as more sympathetic to nationalists, he was thought to lean toward unionists, who lobbied for his appointment.

And while all sides yesterday publicly praised his contribution and insisted they would not be distracted from vital talks to resolve the deadlock, their private reactions could not have been more different.

Ulster Unionist sources admitted: "We're sorry to see him go. He had good persuasive powers and while we didn't agree with everything he did, particularly in relation to policing, we found him very civil and caring."

But Sinn Fein, who blamed him for the collapse and accused him of making a mess of the police reform legislation, could not disguise their jubilation at his downfall.

"He was high-handed and arrogant and he did a great deal to damage the peace process," said one republican source. "We don't drink much champagne, unlike Peter, but the sparkling wine is on ice."

All sides publicly applauded his intellectual ability when he was chosen as Ms Mowlam's successor in October 1999, and his close friendship with the prime minister underlined Mr Blair's commitment to Northern Ireland.

It was not long before he was embroiled in bitter rows with Sinn Fein and the province's largest nationalist party, the SDLP, about his decision to put the Stormont parliament on ice last February.

Some commentators insisted he had no choice, given that David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist party, had offered a post-dated resignation letter to appease hardliners in his party. But republicans claimed Mr Mandelson knowingly disregarded what they saw as a significant IRA statement to save Mr Trimble.

Intensive talks, in which Mr Blair and Mr Mandelson were heavily involved, got things up and running again in May.

But Mr Mandelson was soon at odds with both sides over policing. Unionists, who thought the reforms went too far, were furious at the dropping of the Royal Ulster Constabulary name.

Sinn Fein accused him of watering down Chris Patten's original recommendations, and the SDLP was also deeply unhappy with the police bill.

The problem often appeared to be as much about a clash of personalities as policy, which led to shouting matches between Mr Mandelson and both nationalist parties.

He once nonplussed a senior member of the SDLP by telling him to go and talk to Mr Mandelson's dog, Bobby, while his rows with Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness, were legendary.

Mr McGuinness dismissed him as being part of the securocrat British establishment, and Sinn Fein's chairman, Mitchel McLaughlin, attacked him for his viceroy-like manner.

webTitle: Larger than life character displays the lawful side of his skills

fields.headline: Larger than life character displays the lawful side of his skills
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Kim Schmitz is a larger than life character. At 6ft 4in and close to 19st he cuts a striking figure in his black suit, black turtle neck tops and black sunglasses.
fields.body:
Kim Schmitz is a larger than life character. At 6ft 4in and close to 19st he cuts a striking figure in his black suit, black turtle neck tops and black sunglasses.

To thousands of computer hackers around the world he is a legendary figure. Under the guise of Kimble - a name taken from Dr Richard Kimball in the film The Fugitive - he hacked into several of the world's largest organisations including the Pentagon.

His coup de grace was changing former German chancellor Helmut Kohl's credit rating to zero, an action that won him adoration in the underground hacking world - and a prison sentence.

That, however, is behind him. He is making the most of his freedom, building companies and living life to the full. Mr Schmitz reckons Monkey, an anti-hacking software that he has developed to enable secure payments over the internet, is uncrackable. "If I can't break it, no one can," he once claimed.

He also has high hopes for his Megacar, a prototype technology enabling cars to have high-speed internet access that he developed while serving a speeding ban. "General Motors and Daimler Chrysler are looking to build prototypes," he told the Guardian last night.

Kimvestor is now closing a pre-IPO private placement round, according to Mr Schmitz. "We plan to raise €20m (£16m) and are 80% there," he said.

Even Jesus Christ did not earn a second resurrection, and there is no chance of Peter Mandelson ever rising again inside the Labour party he did so much to recreate.

On the verge of a historic second term, Labour's election campaign will not benefit from Mr Mandelson's strategic mind, and it is unlikely that the former Northern Ireland secretary will even stand again in Hartlepool. At 47, he is part of Labour's history, albeit a large partfor his role in making Labour electable again.

Any attempt by Blair to restore his friend again, even in five years time, would be met with an armed phalanx of cabinet members, MPs and party activists blocking his path.

Mr Mandelson once said of himself: "I was the agent, the publicist and the spin doctor of the modernisers' cause". But his departure does not mark the end of the Blairites. Instead it probably marks the final stage in the party's over-long transition from a campaigning party of opposition to a party of day to day government.

It is very different from his first resignation in December 1998 over the £373,000 loan from the paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.

Then the possibility of redemption was explicit. The very fact that he spent the tearful night of his first resignation in the company of the Blair family at Chequers showed that the prime minister saw him as a special case. Mr Blair's letter accepting his resignation also explicitly promised that he still had much more to contribute to the party.

Mr Mandelson himself took time to recover from the loss of office, admitting to feeling numbed, empty and sometimes maudlin. Although he never forgave the people that had contributed to his demise, or fully accepted the seriousness of his error, he knew he had to reflect.

A lucrative career in business did not attract him then, although it now may be his best option. Last time he ruminated over working overseas. He travelled to South Africa, but even there advised the ANC on election strategy.

Comeback

After six months, rumours started to flow that he might be called back to help the Labour European or local election campaigns. He visibly brightened. In an attempt to rehabilitate himself with MPs and the rank and file, he accepted countless speaking engagements in Labour constituencies. Despite the bile he engenders in much of the party, he knew was also a prize draw. He was anxious to let it be known that the Labour party, and not Mayfair parties, was his primary love. Within six months, it was clear he would return. It was only a matter of when.

Back in office as Northern Ireland secretary, he tried to mend his ways and show some of the wilder excesses of the period 1997-98 were over.

Unlike many Labour politicians, he had no instinctive dislike of wealth creators - and as he rose in political prominence, the rich and glamourous were drawn to him. They found him amusing company, a little exotic and agreeably indiscreet. He mixed easily and liked dancing a little more than sitting in the Commons tea room trading the gossip of the day.

The invitations duly poured forth from London's social elite - Carla Powell, wife of former Washington ambassador Charles Powell; Elisabeth Murdoch, daughter of the media baron; millionaire Robert Bourne and his theatre impresario wife Sally Greene; even from Prince Charles. Peter Mandelson became New Labour's ambassador to the rich and famous. One of his aides - without irony - compared the quantity of publicity his boss received with the acres of newsprint about Princess Diana. But he was as much a manipulator as target of the media.

On his political rehabilitation in October 1999, he changed tack. He deliberately avoided appointing a special adviser, relying instead on the official Northern Ireland press office. There would be no spin, and no use of the special adviser network, to spread poison about colleagues. Although in private he could be typically droll and imperious about the province's politicians and their self-obsessions, the sheer scale of the task invested him with a new seriousness.

He appeared happier in his private life and less intense. Although for 15 years he had battled to keep his homosexuality from the public, his relationship with his Brazilian boyfriend Reinaldo became a matter for daily reporting.

But even over the water the ability to bury a feud eluded him. For instance, he hardly spoke to Mo Mowlam, his predecessor.

Mr Mandelson would say, by reply, his revengeful Brownite enemies dedicated themselves to his demise, regardless of the damage to the party. The autobiography of Geoffrey Robinson, he believed, had the sanction of the chancellor, Gordon Brown and his circle.

In reply, the Brownites claim he was far too loquacious in handing destructive detail to furnish Andrew Rawnsley's devastating account of Labour in government. More worryingly, Downing Street had started to withdraw support from Mandelson. His crime was ill-discipline, and his relationship with Alastair Campbell, the No 10 press secretary, waned after he made two unsanctioned speeches on the euro, provoking fury in Downing Street and the Treasury. Both looked like they were intended to provoke the chancellor. The fiasco of the dome continued through 2000 to raise a big question mark over his judgment.

It may be that one of his greatest strengths - a willingness to take political risks - was also his undoing.

After joining the Labour party in 1985 as a young director of communications, he was immediately more influential than many embittered shadow cabinet members. He came to see himself as a class apart, someone to whom the normal rules did not apply. The prize, a Labour election victory after so long in opposition, was so great that the ends began to justify the means. It made him perennially careless of the conventions.

His reputation rapidly grew out of control, so much so that Labour politicians began to believe any unfavourable slight in any newspaper must have been planted in one of his waspish asides. He was indeed often ruthless in his private dealings, but left the impression he was re flecting the view of the leadership. More often than not, this was the case.

But he also often freelanced, often audaciously, and got away with it. He issued briefings on Neil Kinnock's interventions at party meetings designed to portray the party leader in a favourable light, but which were entirely from Mr Mandelson's imagination.

John Smith's unexpected death in 1994, and the rift between Gordon Brown and Tony Blair, created a fissure amongst the modernisers from which Mr Mandelson never extricated himself. It left him even more exposed as the client of the prime minister.

Inept

There remains one last curiosity. Mr Mandelson has a sense of strategy, a relentless energy and a premier memory for detail. He was often the first to warn a political colleague of media danger starting to bleep on their radar, yet he seemed inept at handling his own difficulties.

Both in the case of the Robinson loan, and the fateful phone call to the Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, it was his subsequent behaviour that was his downfall. If as secretary of state for industry, he had informed his permanent secretary of his loan by Mr Robinson, he would have had cover. No conflict of interest would have arisen.

Similarly, if last Saturday lunchtime his special adviser, Patrick Diamond, had been allowed to tell the truth to the Observer's political reporter, Gaby Hinsliff, about Mr Mandelson's personal call to Mr O'Brien, his political career might not be in ruins. There would have been acute questions about the phone call, but no evidence existed of undue pressure by Mr Mandelson. He would probably have survived - but no more.

fields.standfirst:

Special report: Northern Ireland

fields.trailText: John Reid, who was last night appointed the first Roman Catholic secretary of state for Northern Ireland, speaks proudly of how one set of grandparents were Irish Catholic immigrants. Unionists will be reassured that his other grandparents were Scottish Presbyterians.
fields.body:
John Reid, who was last night appointed the first Roman Catholic secretary of state for Northern Ireland, speaks proudly of how one set of grandparents were Irish Catholic immigrants. Unionists will be reassured that his other grandparents were Scottish Presbyterians.

Political leaders in Northern Ireland will not be facing a quiet time as long as Dr Reid occupies Hillsborough castle just outside Belfast.

In his first job in government, as minister for the armed forces, Dr Reid fought hard for the military during the strategic defence review. In his role as Scottish secretary - he replaced Donald Dewar in 1999 when the Scottish parliament was set up - Dr Reid came to national prominence as one of the most aggressive members of the cabinet.

With his load lightened by devolution, Dr Reid, 53, became the unofficial "minister for the Today programme," defending the government on subjects beyond his official brief. Despite his pugilistic approach, Dr Reid is a sophisticated political thinker who is a passionate supporter of Labour modernisation.

His promotion marks a significant revival in his fortunes. He had been widely expected to be promoted to the cabinet as defence secretary but suffered a setback when his son became caught up in a cash-for-access scandal.

webTitle: Corus rejects offer of aid to save 10,000 jobs

fields.headline: Corus rejects offer of aid to save 10,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Steel plants at Llanwern in south Wales and Lackenby on Teesside last night looked doomed after Britain's biggest producer Corus rejected an offer of financial aid put personally by Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Steel plants at Llanwern in south Wales and Lackenby on Teesside last night looked doomed after Britain's biggest producer Corus rejected an offer of financial aid put personally by Tony Blair.

Up to 10,000 jobs are to go - including 3,000 at Llanwern - in a massive restructuring of a number of plants expected to be finalised within days.

Mr Blair's intervention at a No 10 summit with Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffatt was seen as a last-ditch attempt to save jobs in depressed parts of the country.

However, the company said after the meeting that it was working to its original plans. A spokesman said: "There is nothing which we could be offered that would change operating conditions in the UK."

He said European rules meant operating aid could not be given, leaving the way open for only relatively small amounts of cash to be distributed through environmental, training and research grants.

Denis MacShane, the Rotherham MP and Labour chairman of a group of 70 MPs interested in the industry - said Corus seemed determined to push ahead with its closure plans despite offers of help and a turnaround in its fortunes caused by the strengthening euro against the pound.

He said: "We were surprised to learn from [industry secre tary] Stephen Byers that Corus had turned down a generous financial package from Whitehall and the Welsh administration which would have helped Corus get through their short-term difficulties caused by the pound-euro imbalance."

Part of a Welsh aid package, worth up to £20m, would include measures to ease Corus's liabilities under the new climate change levy or energy tax, which comes into force on April 1, the defer business rates and training grants. The measures are explicitly designed to escape scrutiny by the European Union competition authorities.

Corus insisted, however, that it had received no formal offer of a financial package but said it was continuing to talk to the Department of Trade and Industry about assistance for the company in future.

Sir Brian is under pressure from the City to act because losses in British carbon steelmaking last year approached £500m.

webTitle: Beazer board holds out for better offer

fields.headline: Beazer board holds out for better offer
fields.trailText: The Beazer board last night was holding out for a better offer after an improved and final takeover bid from Persimmon, worth £538m, to create the country's largest housebuilder.
fields.body:
The Beazer board last night was holding out for a better offer after an improved and final takeover bid from Persimmon, worth £538m, to create the country's largest housebuilder.

There was no recommendation from Beazer for the Persimmon offer - which is made up of a mixture of cash and shares - but the market considered a deal almost inevitable.

A terse statement from Beazer said it "noted" the revised proposals from Persimmon and would make a statement in due course, after meeting its financial advisers.

Persimmon's chairman, Duncan Davidson, said Beazer shareholders stood to benefit from "Persimmon's proven record for integrating acquisitions and delivering value to shareholders". But the company also reserved the right to amend or increase its bid in the event of "a revised offer from Bryant or any other competitive situation arising".

Beazer started the sector restructuring by announcing plans for a no premium merger with Bryant Homes under the Domus banner. This was dropped when Bryant chose two days ago to link up with Taylor Woodrow.

Analysts said the fact that Beazer shares had ended the day up 8p at 184.5p suggested a tie-up was in sight.

Persimmon shares ended the day down 7.5p at 248.5p, reducing the price of its bid to just over £530m.

The Persimmon offer comprised 109p in cash plus 0.3086 of new Persimmon shares for each Beazer share. This was an increase from the 92.5p and 0.349 new shares put forward as an "indicative offer" last week.

Mark Hake, a building sector analyst with Merrill Lynch, said it was always possible that a third party could step in to take Beazer - but that it was more likely that the board would bow to the inevitable and negotiate some kind of deal with Persimmon.

A merger of the two companies is believed to offer considerable synergies, and Persimmon directors promise £20m worth of savings.

webTitle: Market forces: Investors pile into beds

fields.headline: Investors pile into beds
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
While the rest of the market resumed its love affair with telecom and technology companies, the City's shrewder practitioners were yesterday acquainting themselves with the intricacies of the aircraft seat industry.

The reason for their interest was the sharp move in the share price of Britax International - the maker of British Airways' innovative bed seats.

The explanation traders gave for the move - Britax shares closed 10.5p, or 9.63%, higher at 119.5p - was simple if a little short on detail: a management buyout pitched between 140p and 150-a-share. Sources close the company, which could not comment on the speculation, provided a rather different version of events, attributing the gains to bargain hunting.

However, even the cynics accepted that there might be something to the rumours. A couple of months ago there were reports that Britax's chairman, David Newlands (of Tomkins fame), was under pressure from institutional shareholders to break up the company. This followed an accounting scandal in August that forced the company to take an exceptional charge of £25m against profits.

Sector specialists urged caution. They pointed out that Britax's new chief executive, Bernard Brogan, only took the helm in November and has yet to deliver his strategic review. Nonetheless, with a market capitalisation of £356m last night, despite £57m of pre-tax profits last year, a bid from a venture capitalist is not beyond the bounds of possibility.

In the wider market, leading shares rose to a five-week closing high after the minutes of the most recent Bank of England meeting showed it tilting in the direction of lower interest rates.

With technology, telecom and the rate sensitive banking sector in the ascendancy, the FTSE 100 index climbed 49.7 points to 6,264.4, while the FTSE Techmark 100 index rose 70.66 points to 2,805.75. The likes of Autonomy, up 157p at £24.15, Dimension Data, 29p higher at 521p, Baltimore, 47.5p stronger at 425p, and Vodafone 8.75p better at 234.75p, dominated the top performers charts.

Of course, it was not only tech and telecom stocks that were going up. Aerospace firm Smiths Group gained 19p to 726p after analysts at CSFB increased their profits forecasts following a meeting with company executives.

Elsewhere, the performance of Marks & Spencer following Tuesday's dismal trading update puzzled traders. As the downgrades rolled in from the likes of Goldman Sachs and Schroder Salomon Smith Barney the stock remained solid, closing 4.5p higher at 210p.

Market sources reckon the buying is coming from the US value funds that dominate the floundering retailer's share register. However, it may not last. Standard & Poor's is believed to have lowered its credit rating on M&S and is demanding a meeting with the company.

Lower down, the FTSE Mid 250 index rose 37.3 points to 6,713.8, with buyers still nibbling away at a couple of Tuesday's speculative favourites.

Transport group Arriva added 5p to 286p on hopes of an offer from Nomura's Principal Finance arm. The cynics noted the rise came after Merrill Lynch finished selling a large block of Arriva shares for a client.

In the meantime, chip designer Imagination Technologies pushed higher, initially on hopes on a bid but later on consideration of its fundamentals. Unlike its peers - ARC International, up 30p to 312.5p, and ARM Holdings, 22p higher at 567p - Imagination has failed to join in the recent chip stock rally. Even after yesterday's 16.5p rise to 230p, it still has some catching up to do.

Arcadia ended the day 6.5p better at 138.5p on news that three Icelandic companies, including the country's biggest retailer, Baugur, had increased their stake in the Top Shop owner to 8.95%.

Aerospace firm Smiths Group gained 19p to 726p after analysts at CSFB increased their profits forecasts following a meeting with company executives. Elsewhere, the performance of Marks & Spencer following Tuesday's dismal trading update puzzled traders. As the downgrades rolled in from the likes of Goldman Sachs and Schroder Salomon Smith Barney the stock remained solid, closing 4.5p higher at 210p. Market sources reckon the buying is coming from the US value funds that dominate the floundering retailer's share register. However, it may not last. Standard & Poor's is believed to have lowered its credit rating on M&S and is demanding a meeting with the company. Lower down, the FTSE Mid 250 index rose 37.3 points to 6,713.8, with buyers still nibbling away at a couple of Tuesday's speculative favourites. Transport group Arriva added 5p to 286p on hopes of an offer from Nomura's Principal Finance arm. The cynics noted the rise came after Merrill Lynch finished selling a large block of Arriva shares for a client. In the meantime, chip designer Imagination Technologies pushed higher, initially on hopes on a bid but later on consideration of its fundamentals. Unlike its peers - ARC International, up 30p to 312.5p, and ARM Holdings, 22p higher at 567p - Imagination has failed to join in the recent chip stock rally. Even after yesterday's 16.5p rise to 230p, it still has some catching up to do. Arcadia ended the day 6.5p better at 138.5p on news that three Icelandic companies, including the country's biggest retailer, Baugur, had increased their stake in the Top Shop owner to 8.95%.

fields.headline: At this price?  Stanley Leisure
fields.trailText: The storm clouds that have gathered over Britain's race courses in recent months have brought with them a much welcomed silver lining for betting group Stanley Leisure.
fields.body:
The storm clouds that have gathered over Britain's race courses in recent months have brought with them a much welcomed silver lining for betting group Stanley Leisure.

Analysts had been concern about the cancellation of 75 race meetings in the six months to last November due to flooding in the wettest autumn on record. While the bad weather affected Stanley's turnover, high margins have kept profits at £15m - unchanged from last year.

One explanation for this, Stanley's chairman and founder Leonard Steinberg said yesterday, was that consistent heavy going has meant fewer favourites won.

However, the market was unimpressed yesterday, and Stanley's share price fell 12.5p to 187.5p.

The group was also hit by results from Euro 2000 quarter finals and a poor run at Royal Ascot. But the Liverpool-based company's core betting shop business remained strong, with operating profits of £10.3m, up £2.2m on the same period the previous year.

While the group continues to develop an online business arm, industry fears that the internet will put betting shops out of business now appear unfounded.

Peter Joseph, a leisure analyst at stockbroker Peel Hunt, said: "People who use Stanley's betting shops in Toxteth are not going swap their regular trips to the bookies for an online betting service. It is a mature business and there is no way it will be wiped out overnight by the internet."

Stanley's casinos have continued to do good business, with turnover up 4% to £61.5m and a steady flow of high-rollers making an appearance at the group's upmarket Crockfords casino in Mayfair, London. There has also been speculation that if regulatory barriers could be overcome the company could take an interest in the troubled London Clubs group.

If the company can persuade the markets to invest, more acquisitions could be in the pipeline.

webTitle: Rio police foil underworld jail break in nick of time

fields.headline: Rio police foil underworld jail break in nick of time
fields.trailText: It resembled the set for a remake of The Great Escape. The tunnel driven from a brick factory towards Rio de Janeiro's maximum security jail was two metres high and had concrete walls, pickaxes, fans, lanterns and two water pumps.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
It resembled the set for a remake of The Great Escape. The tunnel driven from a brick factory towards Rio de Janeiro's maximum security jail was two metres high and had concrete walls, pickaxes, fans, lanterns and two water pumps.

It was six metres (20ft) below ground and ran for 80 metres, ending 50 metres short of the prison in Bangu, a northern suburb.

"I've never seen anything like it," the Rio de Janeiro state security secretary, Josias Quintal, said.

"This was planned by someone who understands engineering. The structure is so well built it could last for years."

The state justice secretary, Joao Luiz Duboc Pinaud, said: "It's like something straight out of 007."

The police believe that the tunnel was was being built so quickly that it could have reached the jail in three days. They said it was being dug for the drug-trafficking gang Red Command, which has members in the prison.

The tunnel began at a small factory in a shantytown beside the prison. When the police arrived six men fled, one of whom they arrested. He said later that he was paid £35 a week to make the concrete slabs and help dig the tunnel.

Alerted by an anonymous tip-off to a free crime phone number, the police found 10 mattresses at the factory, as well as a book of accounts listing £700 in wages and other costs, including petrol, tyres and food.

The state health superintendent said he was not surprised by the tunnel, because last week he had notified the authorities of a case of leptospirosis in the prison.

"The existence of this bacteria, spread by rat urine, could indicate the building of a tunnel because the micro-organism that transmits it survives in water and mud," he said.

It is not the first time Rio de Janeiro state has played host to daring escapology. In 1986 the drug trafficker known as Escadinha ("little stairs") was airlifted by helicopter from the Devil's Cauldron, the Brazilian equivalent of Alcatraz.

webTitle: Disaster team tries to right Galapagos tanker

fields.headline: Disaster team tries to right Galapagos tanker
fields.trailText: Disaster workers were preparing to straighten the wrecked and half-submerged tanker Jessica yesterday, hoping to pump out the few thousand litres of diesel fuel remaining in its tanks.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman on San Cristobal island
fields.body:
Disaster workers were preparing to straighten the wrecked and half-submerged tanker Jessica yesterday, hoping to pump out the few thousand litres of diesel fuel remaining in its tanks.

The vessel, whose cargo has been threatening the Galapagos Islands with a major ecological disaster since it ran aground last week, lies on a reef less than a mile from the main island, San Cristobal.

Commander Jaime Samariego of the Ecuadorian navy, who is directing operations on the pier outside the island's naval base, from where the stricken ship is clearly visible, said that if the good conditions were to continue the ship could be straightened in a matter of hours.

A US coastguard team called in to help manage the emergency declared by the Ecuadorian government estimated that 34,000 litres (9,000 gallons) of the original cargo of 946,000 litres of diesel and bunker fuel remained.

Favourable winds and currents have been crucial in helping to save the Galapagos from total catastrophe by pushing the spill away from the shore, further diluting it, and allowing accelerated evaporation during several helpfully sunny days.

Such weather has reduced the chances of permanent ecological damage to the archipelago, whose many unique species of wildlife inspired Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.

But the high swells accompanying the new moon have so far deterred the Ecuadorian navy and its US helpers from trying to put the Jessica back on an even keel: surf crashing over a deck pitched at a 50-degree angle is hampering the attachment of the necessary cables.

"The ship is in a really bad shape," the US coastguard commander, Captain Edwin Stanton, said after a morning visit to the wreck. But he insisted that it was unlikely to break up.

Nevertheless, the danger remains. The Galapagos has notoriously unpredictable currents which could cause havoc to the islands' wildlife if it sends the spill back towards the shore.

The rusting ship, built in 1973, ran aground on Tuesday last week, apparently as a result of sloppy navigation as it attempted to enter port and deliver its cargo, including the dangerous bunker fuel for the tourist boats which operate on of the island.

Most of the cargo leaked out at the weekend, leaving one tank with 72,000 litres of bunker fuel intact. But it, too, cracked on Tuesday night, prompting a scramble to encircle the new spill with an absorbent necklace while workers doused it with dispersants.

The local authorities warned people yesterday not to bathe around the islands because the still water could be hiding chemicals.

The Charles Darwin research centre on the island reported that damage had so far been limited, primarily affecting pelicans, more than a dozen of which had been found coated with oil.

Several other species are also threatened, including sea lions and blue-footed booby birds.

Winds and currents have taken the spill away from the colonies of lava gulls, unique to the archipelago.

The world-famous giant turtles were never thought to be in danger, because they live inland.

Local and international ecological groups continue to monitor the situation, however, and some have warned that the real ecological impact could still prove significant, given the delicacy of the islands' ecosystem.

fields.headline: Doctor arrested over heroin allegations
fields.trailText: A doctor in West Yorkshire has been arrested by police and is being investigated by the General Medical Council over allegations involving the inappropriate use of diamorphine on his patients.
fields.body:
A doctor in West Yorkshire has been arrested by police and is being investigated by the General Medical Council over allegations involving the inappropriate use of diamorphine on his patients.

Yesterday Leeds health authority, which called in the GMC and the police, said that it was taking the allegations against Peter Lindsay "very seriously".

The allegations against the Pudsey GP have not been specified, nor has the number of patients he is accused of treating inappropriately with diamorphine, the medical name for heroin.

The drug is used to relieve severe pain, often in the terminally ill.

Dr Lindsay was working until the end of last year at a practice in Pudsey, with four other doctors. Three weeks ago, concerns about his performance were brought to the health authority.

On New Year's Day, Dr Lindsay told a local newspaper that he had received a message that he was no longer wanted at the practice.

The GP claimed that his way was barred by a security guard when he tried to get into the surgery to question his partners. He told the paper his partners had repeatedly suggested before Christmas that he was working too hard.

He said that he was saddened. "I have done my best to care for the patients for 19 years and was looking forward to continue to care for them until the day of my retirement," he told the paper. The doctors told the paper that Dr Lindsay had been expelled from the practice because of serious professional concerns.

The GP then opened a surgery elsewhere in Pudsey, but was arrested by police. A spokeswoman for West Yorkshire police said: "After consultation with the Leeds health authority and the General Medical Council concerning allegations of professional irregularities concerning the issue of prescribed drugs, a 47-year-old Leeds man has been arrested and will be interviewed."

Leeds health authority confirmed that a male doctor had been arrested and that it was "a very serious police matter".

The GMC is thought to be investigating several aspects of Dr Lindsay's professional performance.

A spokeswoman said they were "aware of allegations against a GP that have been referred to us by Leeds health authority and that police are investigating. We're taking the allegations seriously and are currently considering what action to take."

The Medical Protection Society, which is representing Dr Lindsay, said he "is co-operating with police inquiries".

Last week the society said there had been a dramatic rise in whistleblowing cases, where new, young GPs complained about older doctors, following the case of the serial killer Harold Shipman. The number of such calls had risen from a few each year to a few every month.

fields.headline: Rock star becomes a dinosaur
fields.trailText: There is an asteroid called Zappafrank, a lump of orbiting rock called Clapton, and four heavenly rolling stones named after each of the Beatles.
fields.body:
There is an asteroid called Zappafrank, a lump of orbiting rock called Clapton, and four heavenly rolling stones named after each of the Beatles.

Mark Knopfler of Dire Straits has gone one better. He has had a dinosaur named after him.

Masiakasaurus knopfleri, announced in Nature today by Scott Sampson from the University of Utah and colleagues, is a curiously-fanged carnivore hitherto unknown to science.

It would have weighed as much as an alsatian dog, stretched five to six feet from nose to tail, and roamed the late Cretaceous forests around 65m-70m years ago. The bones from six specimens were unearthed on Madagascar by the US researchers. "We always take along plenty of good music to keep us going, and Dire Straits is the most popular with the crew.

"Whenever we took Mark's tapes with us we seemed to find great fossils and when he was not with us, we found nothing," said Dr Sampson. "Finding fossils entails a heavy dose of serendipity and we'll take good luck any way we can get it!"

Masiaka is the Malagasy word for vicious. The jaws of Masiakasaurus carry blade-like teeth for slicing and tearing its prey into bite-sized chunks. Mark Knopfler was said to be delighted. "It is a very special honour. The fact that it is a dinosaur is certainly apt. But I am happy to report that I am not in the least bit vicious."

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Achvaneran
fields.trailText: Achvaneran
fields.body:
When the chain round the gate for the pygmy goats sticks to my fingers, I know the temperature is down to minus 10. It's happened on four mornings so far this January, and there hasn't been a single day when the temperature's risen above zero.

But there's been no precipitation until today, so the hens have coped well and the ducks just go down to the burn and splash around, then preen on the bank. One day, all 23 ducks were standing on the bank when I noticed something different. Binoculars revealed a heron walking among them - a silly thing to do, as it would find more food at the coast in such weather conditions.

There's an amusing side to the cold, as the geese can't get to the burn and take it in turns to bathe in the two baby baths. The seven new silkie hens were out of their run one morning and I heard them cackling in an unusual way. They're due to lay at any time so I went forward with anticipation. I found six of the birds making the noise while the white one was transfixed, staring at a stoat that was running backwards and forwards along the nearby fence and obviously had the hen mesmerised. T

he stoat was a juvenile, in its white winter coat of ermine, with some brown fur on its face and the sides of its head, and I presumed it was one of a litter bred in the paddock last summer that I thought had gone elsewhere for winter. Then things started to fall into place... A while ago our hen egg count went from 20 a week to about three - the stoat had obviously been active on that front. Trouble is, they really are very attractive animals, whether in their white winter coat or brown summer attire.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Caravan of Death programme

fields.headline: The dead zone
fields.standfirst: The story of General Pinochet's Caravan of Death is told on BBC2 this Sunday. How effectively can television revisit the horrors of the past? By  Andy Beckett
fields.trailText: The story of General Pinochet's Caravan of Death is told on BBC2 this Sunday. How effectively can television revisit the horrors of the past? By Andy Beckett.
fields.body:
If you go to northern Chile, the windy desert strip between the Andes and the Pacific, you may find yourself wondering about all the soldiers. There are signs for army reservations by the empty roadsides, screened-off military sections at each dusty airport, barracks in the dry distance on the edge of every town. But deserts suit soldiers, here and elsewhere - they can secretly test new weapons in the dunes, race their tanks around without offending farmers, and, if so inclined, do bad things to civilians without people learning the details.

The latter, at least, was the theory in October 1973. General Pinochet's military junta had seized overall control of Chile the previous month, using surprise and armoured vehicles to capture the capital, Santiago, and the country's main port, Valparaiso. But up in the Atacama desert, these events were hundreds of miles distant and could have been deemed irrelevant. Chile had a history of rebellions by the north against new regimes in Santiago. Early on the morning of October 16, Pinochet dispatched a heavily armed helicopter northwards from the capital. Its journey became known as the Caravan of Death.

In three days, over 70 people were executed. The helicopter would land in a town and unload its troops in full combat dress. They would march into the local barracks, and demand a list of those still being held there after the coup. The commander of the helicopter would produce a red pencil. Names would be ticked - prominent trade unionists, left-wingers, alleged coup opponents, and "subversives" of all kinds. The commander would retire for lunch. Once he'd eaten, and the blinding sun had lowered a little, a firing squad would be assembled. Afterwards, the helicopter would fly on.

The Caravan of Death would probably make a grim footnote for historians, rather than a whole documentary, presented by Isobel Hilton, in BBC2's Correspondent series, had it not had unintended consequences. The lonely shootings and burials were never as discreet as planned - the victims had determined rela tions, and the killings could be linked, quite directly, to General Pinochet. Since his arrest in London in October 1998, and during the resulting steady erosion of his reputation at home and abroad, the desert murders have become his pursuers' central piece of evidence.

Here is an episode of deliberate state cruelty, they say, that melts the fog of euphemism and evasion with which Pinochet and his supporters usually cloak the activities of his regime. The purpose of the Caravan was explicitly to cause suffering and terror - parts of victims' faces were torn off before burial - and so discourage dissent for good across a vast, hard-to-police region. From 1973 until Pinochet's reluctant handover of power in 1990, this strategy essentially succeeded. Since then, people have begun to poke around in the cemeteries of northern Chile.

The appeal of all this as a TV investigation is obvious. There's the horrible melodrama of the progress of the helicopter. Then there's its continuing news value, with Pinochet being questioned in Chile for the first time this week, specifically about the atrocities in the north. And, perhaps most enticing of all, there are the glimpses that can be provided of this thin, mysterious country whose internal agonies came recently but fleetingly to British attention.

After the indoor complexities of the Pinochet case in London, the great caramel-coloured vistas of the Atacama Desert used in this programme come as a bracing surprise. Films about Pinochet rarely leave grey, modern Santiago; this one has the remote mining towns, telegraph poles and towering barren hills that have made Chile the slightly feverish, claustrophobic society it is. In a couple of memorable scenes, Juan Guzman, the magistrate leading the investigation into Pinochet's cruelties in Chile, is filmed out in the desert looking for traces of the Caravan. He and his detectives form a tiny dark knot in their official windcheaters and sunglasses, busily criss-crossing the dunes and scrub. But when the camera draws back, you see the physical immensity of their task.

There's a depressing interview with a retired general, moustache grey and stiff as the ex-dictator's, who still talks unblinkingly about the need in 1973 to "neutralise the extremists". Guzman himself speaks, carefully pursing his mouth and keeping his small eyes on the journalists to all sides. And there are painful close-up interrogations of the still grieving friends and relations of those murdered that October. The survivors' steady gazes and concrete memories suggest why Pinochet hasn't escaped a form of retribution.

The only problem is the absence of actual footage of the General's roving shock troops. This is often a difficulty for documentaries about hidden state brutalities - the viewer has to imagine what happened, via black and white family snaps of the victims, taken long before the crime; through the belated return of the film-makers to the place where blood was spilled; and by testimony lacking any detailed contribution from the people responsible. At times, the programme relies too heavily on spooky recreations, ominous tracking shots of guard towers and barbed wire, and pictures of modern Chilean soldiers, who weren't born in 1973, standing in for the men in the helicopter.

Then again, the army still isn't cooperating fully with Guzman. Recent efforts to excavate bodies supposedly hidden nearer Santiago have ended in false trails. And the find of the film is probably a retired junior officer, himself a torture victim of the Caravan of Death for being too lenient to prisoners. He is still banned from all military bases.

fields.bodyText: If you go to northern Chile, the windy desert strip between the Andes and the Pacific, you may find yourself wondering about all the soldiers. There are signs for army reservations by the empty roadsides, screened-off military sections at each dusty airport, barracks in the dry distance on the edge of every town. But deserts suit soldiers, here and elsewhere - they can secretly test new weapons in the dunes, race their tanks around without offending farmers, and, if so inclined, do bad things to civilians without people learning the details. The latter, at least, was the theory in October 1973. General Pinochet's military junta had seized overall control of Chile the previous month, using surprise and armoured vehicles to capture the capital, Santiago, and the country's main port, Valparaiso. But up in the Atacama desert, these events were hundreds of miles distant and could have been deemed irrelevant. Chile had a history of rebellions by the north against new regimes in Santiago. Early on the morning of October 16, Pinochet dispatched a heavily armed helicopter northwards from the capital. Its journey became known as the Caravan of Death. In three days, over 70 people were executed. The helicopter would land in a town and unload its troops in full combat dress. They would march into the local barracks, and demand a list of those still being held there after the coup. The commander of the helicopter would produce a red pencil. Names would be ticked - prominent trade unionists, left-wingers, alleged coup opponents, and "subversives" of all kinds. The commander would retire for lunch. Once he'd eaten, and the blinding sun had lowered a little, a firing squad would be assembled. Afterwards, the helicopter would fly on. The Caravan of Death would probably make a grim footnote for historians, rather than a whole documentary, presented by Isobel Hilton, in BBC2's Correspondent series, had it not had unintended consequences. The lonely shootings and burials were never as discreet as planned - the victims had determined rela tions, and the killings could be linked, quite directly, to General Pinochet. Since his arrest in London in October 1998, and during the resulting steady erosion of his reputation at home and abroad, the desert murders have become his pursuers' central piece of evidence. Here is an episode of deliberate state cruelty, they say, that melts the fog of euphemism and evasion with which Pinochet and his supporters usually cloak the activities of his regime. The purpose of the Caravan was explicitly to cause suffering and terror - parts of victims' faces were torn off before burial - and so discourage dissent for good across a vast, hard-to-police region. From 1973 until Pinochet's reluctant handover of power in 1990, this strategy essentially succeeded. Since then, people have begun to poke around in the cemeteries of northern Chile. The appeal of all this as a TV investigation is obvious. There's the horrible melodrama of the progress of the helicopter. Then there's its continuing news value, with Pinochet being questioned in Chile for the first time this week, specifically about the atrocities in the north. And, perhaps most enticing of all, there are the glimpses that can be provided of this thin, mysterious country whose internal agonies came recently but fleetingly to British attention. After the indoor complexities of the Pinochet case in London, the great caramel-coloured vistas of the Atacama Desert used in this programme come as a bracing surprise. Films about Pinochet rarely leave grey, modern Santiago; this one has the remote mining towns, telegraph poles and towering barren hills that have made Chile the slightly feverish, claustrophobic society it is. In a couple of memorable scenes, Juan Guzman, the magistrate leading the investigation into Pinochet's cruelties in Chile, is filmed out in the desert looking for traces of the Caravan. He and his detectives form a tiny dark knot in their official windcheaters and sunglasses, busily criss-crossing the dunes and scrub. But when the camera draws back, you see the physical immensity of their task. There's a depressing interview with a retired general, moustache grey and stiff as the ex-dictator's, who still talks unblinkingly about the need in 1973 to "neutralise the extremists". Guzman himself speaks, carefully pursing his mouth and keeping his small eyes on the journalists to all sides. And there are painful close-up interrogations of the still grieving friends and relations of those murdered that October. The survivors' steady gazes and concrete memories suggest why Pinochet hasn't escaped a form of retribution. The only problem is the absence of actual footage of the General's roving shock troops. This is often a difficulty for documentaries about hidden state brutalities - the viewer has to imagine what happened, via black and white family snaps of the victims, taken long before the crime; through the belated return of the film-makers to the place where blood was spilled; and by testimony lacking any detailed contribution from the people responsible. At times, the programme relies too heavily on spooky recreations, ominous tracking shots of guard towers and barbed wire, and pictures of modern Chilean soldiers, who weren't born in 1973, standing in for the men in the helicopter. Then again, the army still isn't cooperating fully with Guzman. Recent efforts to excavate bodies supposedly hidden nearer Santiago have ended in false trails. And the find of the film is probably a retired junior officer, himself a torture victim of the Caravan of Death for being too lenient to prisoners. He is still banned from all military bases.  Correspondent: Caravan of Death, Saturday, 7pm, BBC2. Andy Beckett is currently writing a book about Britain and Chile.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: JD (Spooks), rapper
fields.trailText: JD (Spooks), rapper.
fields.body:
We took our name from Sam Greenlee's book, The Spook Who Sat By The Door, about a guy who badly wanted to be in the CIA so he trained himself with the whole spy routine and took it to the streets.

We identify with that so strongly - we got together in 1994 and we've been in training ever since. We turned down loads of deals until we got a good starting point with the one we've got now. And even then we took nine months to get it the way we want.

I'd like to say to any musicians out there that if you sign your deal on the first day, then I can guarantee something is seriously wrong. We've been working on our music all the time. When you record a song, then that's just one version of it. Live, we can perform with or without a band or DJs - we're ready for any situation and change stuff round all the time.

Our shows are like a carnival. We invite allies (we don't call them fans) on stage and they can stay or whatever. I don't like rappers who get up on stage looking all upset.

We wrote the single Things I've Seen for Laurence Fishburne's movie Once In A Life, his first as a director. He'd heard us and he wanted to use some of our older stuff, but we saw the movie, wrote this specially, and he went for it. He's our favourite actor - no, really, he always has been. He turned up for our video, something he'd never done before. He's most definitely a Spook.

Variety is really our thing. Now, with people like Mos Def and Busta Rhymes, hip-hop is getting its potential back. I hope that soon people will get bored of hearing the same old thing all the time and go for something different. And when they do, we're ready for them. We've been in training. Spooks' Things I've Seen is out now.

fields.headline: At last - a cure for Britney
fields.standfirst: Just when it seemed the whole world had gone pop crazy, rock has begun to fight back.  Dom Phillips  investigates the rise of 'nu metal'
fields.trailText: Just when it seemed the whole world had gone pop crazy, rock has begun to fight back. Dom Phillips investigates the rise of 'nu metal'.
fields.body:
Who said rock is dead? This week's Top 40 is rumbling under the animalistic onslaught of two bands whose chainsaw fusion of rock and hip-hop is part of an angry explosion dubbed "nu metal". Limp Bizkit crashed straight in at number one on Sunday, beating off Jennifer Lopez and All Saints, while new stars on the block Linkin Park are at number 24.

Meanwhile, death metal act Slipknot have sold 130,000 albums in the UK and are up for a Grammy in America, California punk bands such as Blink 182 and The Offspring blast out on daytime Radio 1. Forget Wayne's World, mullets and the ripped Iron Maiden T-shirts the It girls sported a couple of years ago - these days heavy metal dresses like a bad rapper and sounds like Eminem and Motorhead having a rumble in a washing machine.

Linkin Park have made a crucial leap out of the metal ghetto. Not only are they getting their video on kids' TV; their poppy choruses and good looks are taking them into the pages of Smash Hits. Unlike Limp Bizkit, a spokesman declares, Linkin Park "don't need to say 'fuck' every other word". They even tour with the singer's dad, introduced as "Pops", who seems to drink more than any of the band.

At their London showcase at King's College, the usual blasé record industry crowd has been zipped up with 400 competition winners from rock magazine Kerrang!. Singer Chester Bennington, possessed of a bloodcurdling roar of a voice, is wearing a rapper's beanie and baggy jeans, offset with horn-rimmed glasses, a spiked dog collar and tattoos. On stage DJ Joe cuts up terrifying noises he created himself, while rapper Mike Shinoda paces, ranting, and a goateed guitarist fires off searing riffs like a welder slicing steel. The sound shifts from beat-heavy, almost melodic verses to choruses of pure thunder.

It is an impressively raucous performance from a band who see their fusion of electronica, hard rock, rap and noise as symptomatic of the confusion of influences that bombards today's music fans. "Information, technology, music, ideals, everything - the world's changed so rapidly," says Bennington over a Guinness before the show. "We've been forced to absorb a lot of information in a short amount of time, and I think that's why you're going to see a lot more mixing." Their debut CD, Hybrid Theory, lasts only 37 minutes. "These days people have a short attention span," insists DJ Joe. "Yeah," adds Chester. "Everyone's got attention deficit disorder."

"People are bored with being fed pre-processed crap," declares Phil Alexander, editor-in-chief of Kerrang!, which has seen sales rise 10% in the past six months while falling circulations have forced traditional "indie" titles such as Melody Maker and Select to close. "There's a generation of young kids sick and tired of being told they should like Westlife and Britney Spears. They want some excitement."

Four years ago designers such as Alexander McQueen began putting a heavy metal influence into their shows. Robbie Williams got in on the act with his video for Let Me Entertain You - a pastiche of 1970s shock-rockers Kiss. Heavy metal, previously the preserve of the terminally naff, was cool - but only in the way that everything from 1970s porn soundtracks to New Romantics has been declared cool, with tongue placed firmly in cheek.

Rachel Newsome, editor of style magazine Dazed and Confused, argues that rock's new renaissance is a reaction to a culture drowning in irony and double entendre. But when Limp Bizkit and Incubus burst onto the scene, mixing the industrial metal of 1990s acts such as Rage Against The Machine with the blank anger of Nirvana, the pulse and stylings of hip-hop, and the showmanship of stadium acts such as Kiss, American teenagers weren't being ironic as they headed for the mosh pit.

Nor are their British counterparts, who are now snapping up this music. Small wonder that when the makers of Mission: Impossible 2 were looking for an act to rework their signature theme tune, they turned to Limp Bizkit, who then scored a worldwide hit with Take a Look Around.

This unholy alliance between hard rock and hip-hop started in 1986 when rap trio Run DMC rescued the career of fading rockers Aerosmith with Walk This Way, a hit on both sides of the Atlantic. Hip-hop and heavy metal - twin pop music pariahs - have always been about energy, anger, and exclusion. Both have often glamorised violence.

The influential Beastie Boys have flipped from punk-rap to thrash rock since the 1980s. Public Enemy toured with extreme metal group Anthrax; LA rapper Ice T with metal-rap group Bodycount. Five years ago American metal group Korn were ringing the stylistic changes with Adidas tracksuits and goatees, making the mustachioed leather-men of classic heavy metal appear stuck in a time warp.

Kerrang!'s Alexander argues that rock's new rise is partly down to the omnipresence of club culture, for so long the forbidden alternative to mainstream music. "It's become the musical equivalent of Woolworths. It's lost that power of cultiness and that element of danger and excitement. As rock music has had to re-evaluate and move on, it's become multi-faceted and as a result even more powerful."

Chester says a childhood that would have put most people into therapy is what puts hail into his hurricane voice. "There's some pretty pissed-off kids all over the world. I think that's a good thing. Anger feeds change - more so than happiness, because I think when people become happy and comfortable they become lazy and melancholy. When there's a little bit of rage behind, you get motivated."

Chester, who is 24, has a theory: "I have a little brother. He's 13, almost 6ft tall, his arms are bigger than mine, he's more educated than most adults and he's younger. How can a person my age communicate with a 13-year-old who has the mentality of a 13-year-old but the education and body of an adult? I think kids are having their childhood taken away from them. Maybe that has something to do with it."

When the lights go up at King's College, Linkin Park hang around to sign autographs for their fans. Kirsty, 16, is waiting for her dad to give her a lift home. "It's an alternative to pop," she says. Sigmund Judge, who has been camped out in the college bar all day, playing Linkin Park tapes on his ghetto blaster, adds: "Rock's become so popular because everyone's sick of being brainwashed by stereotypical boy bands."

The message is clear: bands like Linkin Park "mean it", whatever "it" is.

 Limp Bizkit's album Chocolate Starfish and the Hotdog Flavored Water is out on Polydor. Linkin Park's album Hybrid Theory is out on WEA.

webTitle: Arts: Profile of musicians Nikki Yeoh and Cleveland Watkiss

fields.headline: World service
fields.standfirst: Nikki Yeoh and Cleveland Watkiss started in jazz but ended up somewhere very different.  John Fordham  spoke to them as they prepared to share a stage
fields.trailText: Nikki Yeoh and Cleveland Watkiss started in jazz but ended up somewhere very different. John Fordham spoke to them as they prepared to share a stage.
fields.body:
The trumpeter Don Cherry once defined world music as the sound "of those who have been listening and travelling". Cherry did a great deal of both, visiting village musicians on three continents. A widening throng has since inherited his vision, including pianist Nikki Yeoh and vocalist and DJ Cleveland Watkiss.

This pair's travels, inside and outside their heads, will inform their appearance together tomorrow at London's Spitz as part of the Serious Sampler series, a project set up to bring together players who are not regular partners. Yeoh and Watkiss disarmingly say their repertoire will be "our experiences".

Yeoh's recent experiences have included hanging out in New York with McCoy Tyner and Rachel Z ("doing a bit of playing, but a lot more checking out") and piano lessons in Cuba with Chucho Valdes and Reuben Gonzalez. Watkiss, a disciple of Bobby McFerrin, Al Jarreau and Cassandra Wilson who strays far beyond jazz, has been recording, DJ-ing, and pursuing his Club 21st Century project, "uniting impro, technology and DJ culture".

His most recent internet venture saw him hook up with tabla player Talvin Singh and the Afro-Celts crossover band in Ireland ("but it could just as easily have been with musicians from the Lincoln Center"). It is clear the experiences he and Yeoh will be sharing at the Spitz aren't the usual run of bebop licks and Coltrane incantations.

Yet jazz was the fuse that launched the musical journeys of both artists, and is still at the core of their performances. Yeoh loves the flexibility and headlong energy of the classic approach (Tyner and Herbie Hancock are audible influences), but she exposes the tradition to a fusillade of Latin music, classical music and fusion, seeking out musical situations that she can't necessarily hear a way out of.

Watkiss, who suggests elements of Nat Cole, Bobby McFerrin and George Benson, spent the 1990s experimenting. As well as MC-ing Hoxton's Metalheadz sessions, he collaborated with drum'n'bass band Project 23 and the Source.

"Don't worry - there'll be a drummer there on Friday," Watkiss chuckles in response to queries about this week's format: just his voice and Yeoh's piano. "But invisible. I've been a big fan of Bobby McFerrin and Al Jarreau for years, people who use their voices percussively. You develop a way of sounding the groove without a drummer playing it. Nikki knows about that m-Base thing, another approach with a strong rhythmic vibe, so we share a rhythmic world. We've been working on this gig for six weeks or so, but that doesn't mean we aren't up for changing it on the night if we need to."

Yeoh says she asked Watkiss, a performer she had long respected, to join her on the Serious Sampler gig after an intense philosophical conversation. "We'd known each other for years and never done that," Yeoh says. "When the invitation came up for a collaboration of my choosing, I knew it was him I should work with. And it's turned out to be a unique vibe, one I've never had before with a singer. It's like doing a solo gig but you have your best mate next to you. There's not another instrument in the way. I wrote this mad tune full of augmented fourths, very hard for a vocalist, and he just went, 'OK, I'll do it.' "

When she emerged towards the end of the 1990s after touring with Courtney Pine, Yeoh could probably have snapped up a record deal - but her respect for music led her to decide that she wasn't ready. Now she is. "I have the experience now and I know myself enough."

But whatever happens in her playing career, Yeoh believes that the music means nothing if it is not shared. This is why she directs the jazz course at Camden's Saturday Music Centre. "I love to teach," she says. "Teaching gives you a perspective on what's going on today. It's also good to keep reminding yourself of where you started. That raw love of music, not thinking about the industry and record companies and all that stuff. There's a saying: 'If you don't help somebody up a step, you don't move up a step.' I believe in it completely."

 Nikki Yeoh and Cleveland Watkiss are at the Spitz, London E1 (020-7392 9032) tomorrow.

webTitle: Women: Does bearing children define womanhood?

fields.headline: Mother love
fields.standfirst: If you want one, you can have one, whatever it takes. But if you don't - what's the matter with you? Philosopher and embryology expert  Mary Warnock  asks why having children has become the Holy Grail of modern womanhood
fields.trailText: If you want one, you can have one, whatever it takes. But if you don't - what's the matter with you? Philosopher and embryology expert Mary Warnock asks why having children has become the Holy Grail of modern womanhood.
fields.body:
There have been several stories in the press this week to make us think about motherhood. Take the case of Lynne Bezant from Oxfordshire who, at the age of 56, is pregnant. If all goes well, she will give birth to twins in the summer.

Here is someone who already has grown-up children but, having suffered miscarriages and stillbirths since her youngest child was born, has been so obsessed with the wish to have more children that, more than 20 years on, she and her husband decided to spend several thousands of pounds, and suffer much inconvenience and discomfort, to go through IVF so that she may, belatedly and with considerable risk, become a mother again.

One is bound to ask what it is that she wants out of it. This is a question difficult even to raise. The relation between mother and child has for centuries, and in every culture, been sacrosanct. Worship of the Virgin Mary did not arise out of the blue: it was built upon an already deep mythology. When Christ on the cross said to his mother: "Woman, behold thy son" and to his beloved disciple: "Behold thy mother", it was to this mythology he so movingly appealed. Swearing on one's mother's grave is the most solemn oath and even to this day it is mildly shocking to hear people speaking ill of their mothers.

This may lie at the root of the very common assumption that women who have never had children have never entered the most profound relationship that there could be and are therefore less than fully human. "Nature" has been denied or defied. This assumption is still made, without any conscious thought. On the scale of those to be pitied, the women at the top are those who are thought to have no sexual relations with men ("spinsters"); but as a close second come those who do have such relations, but have no children.

It is astonishing that such almost instinctive reactions, usually quickly suppressed, still exist, for example in people seeking to appoint women to senior posts such as those of head teacher or consultant. The irrational thing is that ever since contraception became readily available and almost morally obligatory, it must have been obvious women had the option of not having children. Yet such women are often regarded as somehow defective.

I have to admit to finding the decision not to have children depressing. It suggests a Larkin-like pessimism: "Man hands on misery to man/It deepens like a coastal shelf/Get out as early as you can/And don't have any kids yourself."

But people are not defective if they are pessimistic - and their decision may even be a sign of optimism. They may be confident that there is enough purpose and value in their lives without needing children to give them a reason for living.

Of course attitudes to the childless are not consistently held. Motherhood may be sacred but it has to be embarked upon in the right conditions. Teenage girls who become pregnant and do not consider abortion, who actually enjoy and love their babies and want to look after them and give them everything they can, are not much admired by society.

Even respectably married women who do not go out to work are apologetic about being "just a mother". (They are also increasingly rare: financially, it is a difficult path to choose and in any case most women admit that they would find the role too tedious in the long run.) And there is an increasing recognition that whatever may be said about the wonders of having a baby, there are great drawbacks. "There is no more sombre enemy of good art than the pram in the hall," as Cyril Connolly put it.

So what are we to think about the obsessively maternal Bezant? Most people pronounce her mad, then go on to suggest that her twins, if they survive, will have a pretty weird childhood. Similarly, Alan and Judith Kilshaw, who adopted their twins via the internet, have been pilloried for "buying" them.

But many people are led to more general reflections about the so-called commodification of babies, exemplified by the choices that can now be made (and which will become even wider) about what kind of baby you want, or don't want, whether you would like to have a stock of embryos refrigerated so that you can have a baby when it fits in with your other plans, and so forth.

It seems to me that it is certainly justifiable to make such choices if they will prevent the birth of children who will suffer from disastrous inherited diseases. But beyond that, "designer babies" are, in my view, to be deeply deplored. I used to think that my moral objection to the concept was based on the fact, as I believe it to be, that such children would suffer, if they did not come up to scratch; and that, in any case, they were being treated as instruments to satisfy their parents' ambitions or other tastes. But I now think that, besides these relatively rational arguments, there are deep sentiments involved.

Consider the case of surrogacy, where a man, whether he does or does not have a female partner, may choose from a catalogue a woman to give birth to his child. She, the surrogate, contracts to become pregnant using his sperm and to hand over the baby when it is born. I used to think that this was simply a vulgarisation of childbirth, both on the part of the commissioning man or couple and on the part of the surrogate herself. And it is true that some of the agencies to be found in the US are supremely vulgar.

But perhaps my objection to the process derives, after all, from an ineradicable sense of what motherhood is like, a sense arising from experience. There is, literally, nothing like the excitement of the eventual existence of a new life that you yourself have caused to exist, or which at least could not have existed without you. The perhaps trivial element of surprise - not knowing which sex the baby would be or what it would look like - was, for me, part of the pleasure, like a secretly saved up Christmas present. But the non-trivial part was the amazingness of nature.

So perhaps what I am saying is that motherhood is somehow sacred, as other aspects of nature may be; and if babies become commodities, we shall have lost something irreplaceable. Not all women need have babies; they are neither morally nor biologically defective if they do not. Women are more than their wombs. But for those who do, the actual occasion of birth, whatever happens next, is of intense significance and has always been seen to be so.
