fields.headline: Rock with strings attached
fields.standfirst: In a time-honoured tradition, scientists have named a dinosaur found in Madagascar                                                              after another rock legend, writes Henry Gee
fields.trailText: In a time-honoured tradition, scientists have named a dinosaur found in Madagascar after another rock legend, writes Henry Gee
fields.body:
Mark Knopfler, lead guitarist and prime mover behind the 1980s rock band Dire Straits, receives a rare honour this week - a dinosaur has been named after him. In a communique in today's Nature, Scott Sampson of the Utah Museum of Natural History and colleagues have described a new and unusual species of dinosaur from Madagascar, and have given it the formal, zoological name Masiakasaurus knopfleri.

Now, names have power and influence, and the scientific nomenclature of any new species, whether beetle or bandicoot, living or fossil, follows a formal ritual as closely choreographed and bound by tradition as any Baroque fugue - a tradition that extends back to the mid-18th century, when the Swedish botanist Carl von Linn* (known as Linnaeus) laid down the rules of nomenclature scientists follow to this day.

The creation of formal, "latinised" names must follow the code of zoological nomenclature, whose provisions are enforced by the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, a body which, considering its importance to science, runs on a shoestring budget, largely from donations, in an office in the Natural History Museum in London.

The commission rules only on matters of grammar and priority. It can do nothing about personal taste. When, as sometimes happens, scientists submit research papers to Nature in which a new organism is formally described, the editors (sensing trouble ahead) might object to the formulation of a name, but can offer advice only.

The honour of naming an organism new to science rightly falls on the people whose labours have brought it to light - no matter how eccentric the handle. Names for organisms follow classical grammar, but can adopt a root from any language. They may be constructed to honour another scientist, a patron, or organisation.

They may be named to remember a spouse, family member or lover (sometimes in the form of a coy acrostic or anagram, in case of discovery.) They might be simple descriptions. They might be humorous (Jenny Clack of the University of Cambridge named a fossil amphibian, found in the remnants of what was once a foetid swamp, Eucritta melanolimnetes - the creature from the Black Lagoon.)

They might even be complete gibberish. Or they might commemorate a rock guitarist. In the case of the latest monster of rock, Sampson and colleagues have created the generic name Masiakasaurus from the Malagasy word masiaka, which means "vicious" - presumably referring to the animal's sharp, pointed teeth - and the conventional Greek sauros, meaning "lizard".

The species or "trivial" name, knopfleri is "after singer/songwriter Mark Knopfler, whose music inspired expedition crews". For any style police out there, I admit to owning one or two Dire Straits albums. But I plead the following in mitigation - the listening pleasure of palaeontologists doing fieldwork in some remote wilderness is usually extremely limited, and they are forced to put up with music they wouldn't normally allow in the house.

Sometimes palaentologists have no music at all, and their starved imaginations fill in, trawling up unlikely numbers from the dregs of the brain. While prospecting in Kenya on a music-free field trip in 1998, my work ran to a relentless, thundering mental heavy metal soundtrack of Stargazer by Ritchie Blackmore's Rainbow. Truly, explorers have been driven mad - Scott's expedition to the Antarctic could have taken comfort from the fact that it antedated the Fender Stratocaster by half a century.

Another fossil famously associated with pop music was Lucy, the primitive extinct relative of humanity discovered in the 1970s in the Afar region of Ethiopia. She got her name from the Beatles' tune Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds, a song played in the field camp at the time. Happily, the discoverers didn't saddle her with that name, opting for the more formal Australopithecus afarenis ("southern ape from the Afar").

But what of Masiakasaurus knopfleri, besides its Euterpean name? The dinosaur is a theropod - one of those bipedal dinosaurs usually assumed to have been predatory, and which ranged in size from a blackbird (Microraptor) to a bus (Tyrannosaurus). Masiakasaurus belongs to a small and increasingly trendy subgroup of theropods called abelisaurs, believed to have been restricted to the ancient southern supercontinent of Gondwana, consisting of modern South America, Africa, Madagascar, India, Australia and Antarctica.

Abelisaurs have been found in Madagascar before - Masiakasaurus, at a svelte 1.8 metres long, joins the much larger Majungatholus - but have also been unearthed in Argentina. They flourished just at the end of the Cretaceous period, 65-70 million years ago, in a dinosaurian swansong that paralleled a diversity of theropods further north that included the dromaeosaurs and troodontids familiar to anyone who has seen Jurassic Park.

The teeth of Masiakasaurus are unusual in that the ones at the front of the lower jaw were long and pointed straight outwards. What this implied for the dinosaur's lifestyle is impossible to guess, but standing in its path as it ran along would not have been recommended. I have never had the honour of naming any kind of animal, but if I did, the generic name would have to be Cranleya, after a pub - the Cranley - in Brompton Road that was the "in" place for all the coolest palaeontologists from the nearby Natural History Museum in the 1980s (don't look for it, it's not there any more.) The specific, or trivial name, is easy: ladies, gentlemen, fellow scientists, I have pleasure in introducing - Cranleya freddiemercuryi. Now tell that to the style police.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

But what of Masiakasaurus knopfleri, besides its Euterpean name? The dinosaur is a theropod - one of those bipedal dinosaurs usually assumed to have been predatory, and which ranged in size from a blackbird (Microraptor) to a bus (Tyrannosaurus). Masiakasaurus belongs to a small and increasingly trendy subgroup of theropods called abelisaurs, believed to have been restricted to the ancient southern supercontinent of Gondwana, consisting of modern South America, Africa, Madagascar, India, Australia and Antarctica. Abelisaurs have been found in Madagascar before - Masiakasaurus, at a svelte 1.8 metres long, joins the much larger Majungatholus - but have also been unearthed in Argentina. They flourished just at the end of the Cretaceous period, 65-70 million years ago, in a dinosaurian swansong that paralleled a diversity of theropods further north that included the dromaeosaurs and troodontids familiar to anyone who has seen Jurassic Park. The teeth of Masiakasaurus are unusual in that the ones at the front of the lower jaw were long and pointed straight outwards. What this implied for the dinosaur's lifestyle is impossible to guess, but standing in its path as it ran along would not have been recommended. I have never had the honour of naming any kind of animal, but if I did, the generic name would have to be Cranleya, after a pub - the Cranley - in Brompton Road that was the "in" place for all the coolest palaeontologists from the nearby Natural History Museum in the 1980s (don't look for it, it's not there any more.) The specific, or trivial name, is easy: ladies, gentlemen, fellow scientists, I have pleasure in introducing - Cranleya freddiemercuryi. Now tell that to the style police.  Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

More net news
fields.trailText: BBC spreads wide its sweaty palms
fields.body:
BBC spreads wide its sweaty palms

At the risk of being accused of talking up our own book - this is a newspaper with a serious presence on the web - there is something quite alarming about the BBC's apparent plans to take advertising on some of its online news services.

According to the internet magazine Industry Standard, the public service broadcaster has pencilled in June for the launch of BBCNews.com - described as a service for an international audience targeted primarily at north America running off servers based in New York and funded by banner advertising. The international twist, it seems, allows the corporation to skirt round its charter to provide a public service to British citizens which is funded by licence payers.

Under director general Greg Dyke, "think commercial" is the new mantra in an organisation that in the past has only ever thought bureaucratically. Wherever its funding comes from, the BBC operates in a tough world, in which technologies are moving fast, and in which the corporation needs to make its assets sweat.

But the real perspiration from this move will felt in the hundreds of nascent British internet news and information services, all scrambling for a piece of the low-rate banner advertising on offer and wondering whether they will get enough funding to see them through to profitability.

It is all about demand and supply. The BBC is an awesome brand, and its websites enjoy extraordinary hit rates. Allowing ads on BBC pages will saturate a market where 80% of the available ad revenues are already taken by the top 20 world sites. New blood will not be able to compete.

The result will be an endless stream of closures and redundancies in the private sector. The BBC is a state-owned institution with monopolistic tendencies. The people going bust will be young, British, risk-taking entrepreneurs.

On their mark

Independent central banks tend to err on the side of caution. Given the chance, they will opt for slightly higher interest rates than necessary in order to be certain of keeping inflation low, even though this means a deflationary bias to policy. Although it has been setting interest rates for three and a half years, the Bank of England has taken little time to conform to this stereotype, with underlying inflation below its 2.5% target since April 1999.

This has not been lost on some of the members of the Bank's monetary policy committee, who - according to the minutes of the latest meeting - reminded their colleagues that they were there to hit the target, rather than to demand-manage the economy. This was a point well made. It was precisely to avoid a deflationary bias that Labour plumped for a symmetrical inflation target, with undershoots to be treated as seriously as overshoots.

Judging by its actions, not all the members of the MPC have taken on board the policy implications of this stricture. DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani - the most consistent doves - may be kicking up a fuss in private. But it is time the terms of the MPC's remit were spelt out in public by Gordon Brown himself, who gives the impression that he would rather tinker with social security benefits than manage the economy. Perhaps Mr Brown needs to remind himself that he is chancellor of the exchequer and not minister for welfare reform.

Biotech reality

The biotech industry was in an unforgiving mood as Scotia Holdings lost its last realistic lifeline yesterday. One analyst mocked: "Could the last person to leave Scotia please remember to turn off the laser?"

Barring a miracle, the Scottish firm will not survive as an independent entity - and shareholders are unlikely to make much from a takeover, with £50m of convertible loans outstanding.

The unfortunate boss of Britain's biggest biotech collapse is Rob Dow, a former executive at Swiss multinational Hoffman-La Roche. He pointed out yesterday that if it had Roche's resources behind it to fund larger scale trials, Scotia's cancer drug Foscan would probably have made it to the market.

When Mr Dow joined two years ago, Scotia was already in a mess. His response was to up the stakes by focusing on just a few promising medicines.

The gamble has spectacularly failed, but he pleaded for clemency. In the US, he pointed out, investors are accustomed to the risks of drug development.

It is easy to mock a company which thought it could cure cancer by shining a red light on sufferers' necks. But for every successful biotech firm many will fall by the wayside. Scotia's collapse is not the fault of any single individual. It is a reminder of the enormous risk involved in the £200m, 12-year process of taking any new drug to the market.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst:
Welcome to the freaks table says Douglas Rushkoff
More net news
fields.trailText: Welcome to the freaks table says Douglas Rushkoff
fields.body:
One of the greatest side-effects of the dot.com bust has got to be the revitalized interest in cool, weird, and artsy technologies. Wall Street will always be Wall Street, and devotees of the Nasdaq pyramid will continue to understand technologies in terms of their speculative potential. But real human beings with more human concerns have got over the tech-spec narrative, and begun to poke around the datasphere in search of something fun to do.

This is a terrific moment. I feel like I did back in high school, when football season would finally be over and everyone turned to those of us who never got on the team (or even wanted to) for an alternative source of amusement.

Yeah, we were the artsy kids. Theatre people and comic book writers. The geeks. The freaks. Well, we've been sitting here all along at our own table in a forgotten corner of the high school cafeteria, and have some stuff to show you.

Go to Apple.com and download iTunes, their new MP3 player. It'll do everything from stripping CDs to burning DVDs. Best of all, it has a graphics engine that turns Pink Floyd (or any music you choose) into a visual acid trip. Without the drugs.

These are some of the best and fastest rendered visuals I've seen on a home computer. And it is only the beginning. As an invitation to user collaboration, the program has room for plug-ins made by anybody.

Apple's stock may be in the cellar, but its new equipment and software is better than ever. Inexpensive flat-panel displays, G4s with write-able DVD drives and, of course, the new titanium laptop. Even Microsoft has got into the act with the best release of Word since 5.1, as part of its Office 2001 package.

What's that? You don't have a Mac anymore? Don't worry, we'll let you back in the club. This is the freaks' table, remember? All are welcome.

The quality of Apple products is as good an indication as any of the health of the counter-cyberculture. True, Apple is a Nasdaq company like the rest, but it is "our" side's corporation, if for no other reason than we consider it as such. And, these days, we'll take what we can get. See, here in the States it is Bush time again. And while we may weep for the welfare of the nation, George W's literal and figurative reinstatement of the patriarchy will only stimulate energetic creativity from the unruly freaks. It's the pressure-cooker effect.

This, coupled with the failure of all those traditional top-down media strategies enacted by e-commerce and other dot.com businesspeople, is leading inevitably to a resurgence of do-it-yourself culture, media, and experiences. If Amazon.com really isn't going to change my life, then what else can I do with this little machine and the network it's attached to? Take pictures? Make a web site? Create my own movies? (Yet another area where the Mac is ahead.)

And this is exactly what all the artsy freaks were after in the first place: self expression, a bit of collaboration, a few trippy experiences, and a way to disseminate some alternative points of view. Computers - networked or not - have never been good at generating mainstream media experiences.

That is not what this medium is about. No, it is a tool that allows us, at the very least, to customize our media experiences and, at its very best, to create them. Like we say at the freaks table, it allows you to 'roll your own.' Disenchanted with 'the big game' and the obsolete, competitive values it espouses, freaks develop their own sets of experiences.

These are the kids who were enjoying fantasy role-playing, trying to form a band, shooting home videos, writing weird poetry, arguing about Hegel (without truly understanding him) or planning the perfect party. These are the same experiences on computers and web sites today. Ultima Online and other "massively networked" games are now attracting women as much as men, who enjoy creating a universe collaboratively and on the fly.

Blogger.com, an online journal tool and website, is the first internet application that realises the promise of the original world wide web - its user-participants self-publish, cross-post, and comment on one another's work. And people like my Great Aunt Sophie, who just last year told me she'd never get involved with computers because she wasn't really interested in "online trading," is now flooding the family with email containing digital photos of everyone's new babies.

She even used a photo retouching program to paste little angel wings on one of them. Cool, Sophie. Welcome to the freaks table.

webTitle: How to dine on diatoms - and die

fields.headline: How to dine on diatoms - and die
fields.standfirst: Ecologically vital, zooplankton also contain the seeds of their destruction, writes  David Bradley
fields.trailText: Ecologically vital, zooplankton also contain the seeds of their destruction, writes David Bradley
fields.body:
It takes millions and millions of microscopic plankton to sate the appetite of a blue whale on the high seas, and there is not much these tiny plants and animals can do to defend themselves against cetacean digestion. Plankton are right at the bottom of the oceanic food chain, make no mistake.

But, whales and fish are not the only thing they have to worry about. They also eat each other. If there is no defence against being engulfed in their millions by the gaping jaws of a whale with every great volume of water it sucks in, then they can at least have a go at deterring would-be cannibals from tucking into their nutritious, if microscopic parts.

Zooplankton, the tiniest of animals, include the protozoa, minute crustaceans and larvae. They feed voraciously on their photosynthesising cousins the phytoplankton that float in almost every body of natural water, much as cows and sheep munch on juicy blades of grass and dandelions. Now, Georg Pohnert at the Max Planck Institute of Chemical Ecology in Jena, Germany, has discovered that phytoplankton, like many of their very distant relatives on dry land, can hit back with chemical weapons when attacked.

Previous researchers had discovered that the diatom Thalassiosira rotula - a type of single-celled algae and one of the many types of phytoplankton - produce the toxic aldehydes decadienal and decatrienal. These molecules are more complex versions of the all-preserving compound formaldehyde used by the artist Damien Hirst to pickle his sheep and cow's heads. The algal aldehydes seem to prevent the eggs of copepods, tiny crustaceans of which there are more than 14,000 known species, from hatching successfully. Copepods might find algae a rather tasty meal full of nutritional value but they usually have little success in attempts to graze on it simply because of the presence of these potent aldehyde toxins. Pohnert has now discovered that the use of toxic aldehydes is a far more widespread means of protection against being eaten, among the diatoms, than previously thought.

Diatoms such as thalassiosira are small, single-celled algae belonging to one special group with silica cell walls, he explains. "They are among the most important carbon dioxide fixing plants." He has found that several such algae produce not only decadienal and decatrienal, but a whole range of related chemical weapons, in a molecular call to arms against physical attack. These compounds block the onslaught of the amphipodae, for instance. These are another kind of tiny crustacean of which there are tens of thousands of different unnamed species. The aldehydes and their chemical cousins stop amphipodae in their tracks. They can also help the algae ward off attempted invasion by parasitic fungi. Pohnert reveals in a recent issue of the journal Angewandte Chemie, that none of the defensive sub stances are present inside healthy diatoms. They only appear at the time of attack. Within seconds of being wounded by an alien organism, these chemical weapons pour out and destroy the invaders.

To help find out how the diatoms make these chemical weapons so quickly Pohnert swapped the normal hydrogen atoms in various nutrients with "heavy" hydrogen - deuterium. This acts as a kind of marker. The diatoms were then "fed" in his fish tank individual nutrients labelled with heavy hydrogen. Pohnert could then use mass spectrometry, which basically "weighs" the nutrient molecules, to spot which was used to make the toxic aldehydes. It turns out that long chain-like fatty acid molecules provide the starting materials for the diatom's bank of chemical weapons. The diatom's enzymes can transform these fatty acid chains very rapidly into its weapons of defence. The diatom's aldehydes are well trained on their target of zooplankton. The latest evidence from Pohnert's laboratory hints that the zooplankton might be their own worst enemy. They harbour in their guts the chemical trigger that ultimately stimulates the diatoms to release their battery of weapons against them. By only making its chemical weapons in times of trouble, the diatom not only saves energy and resources but also avoids the risk of poisoning itself by carrying an active arsenal inside it. When it is in no danger, the fatty acids are simply used as food and converted into its cellular machinery or used as an energy source.

But, the instant an enemy arrives on the scene, the diatom can set in motion its rapid response. Plankton are right at the bottom of the oceanic food chain so play a critical role in the ecology of the seas, explains Pohnert. "Research into the chemical defence mechanisms of plankton is still in its infancy but nevertheless it is important in order for us to gain a better understanding of the complex processes in marine habitats," he explains.

Pohnert's research could ultimately have practical ecological applications. His team is studying the molecular marvels of various other algae, such as the tropical green species Caulerpa taxifolia. This alga was accidentally introduced into the Mediterranean Sea several years ago and is rapidly colonising the waters.

Figuring out what makes this and other algae so successful might lead to ways to eradicate them from such non-native habitats. "We are trying to understand the defence of Caulerpa taxifolia from a mechanistic perspective," Pohnert said.

"This is done with a focus on the interaction of caulerpa with its predators such as sea slugs." He suggests that by identifying the way the ecosystem works at the molecular level one could look for predators of the algae that might be used to control it.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: The bull from the sea (and ashes) | How to make swine less piggy
fields.body:
The bull from the sea (and ashes)
In Homer's Odyssey, young Telemachus, son of the lost commander, arrives at sandy Pylos, site of the palace of King Nestor. "Now the people of Pylos were gathered on the seashore to offer sacrifice of black bulls to Neptune, lord of the Earthquake," the poem goes on. A team from Sheffield, University College London and the University of Cincinnati have just confirmed that it really was the done thing to burn bones as sacrifice in Bronze Age Greece. Old bones from a museum at Hora, near Pylos, dating back to 1200 BC, provided the proof. They had been stripped of meat before burning. It had not been a simple case of overcooking: the bones were burned far too badly for that.

How to make swine less piggy
A team at Purdue University, Indiana is looking for the gene that makes pigs behave swinishly. The theory is that aggressive attitudes naturally slow meat production. "The more pigs you have in a pen, the slower their growth rate due to stress and aggression," says Allan Schinckel, professor of hog genetics. But a large white in an expansive mood could mean an extra 25% lean growth without the need for extra feed. This may sound like hogwash, says the university, but the approach is based on colleague William Muir's research into aggressive behaviour in chickens. "Here we're talking about something for nothing," says Muir. "This is a win-win situation."

Lethal bug is brought to book
E. coli 0157:H7 is a bit of a mouthful, and an unwelcome one at that. It is the sick-making strain of the normally harmless human gut flora. It was first observed in 1982. Now it infects 75,000 a year in the US alone. A team from the University of Wisconsin, together with Hungarian and Massachusetts colleagues, report in Nature today that they have the low-down on the little monster. They have completed its genetic sequence, and identified 1,387 new genes, including those that could make it so virulent.

"The more pigs you have in a pen, the slower their growth rate due to stress and aggression," says Allan Schinckel, professor of hog genetics. But a large white in an expansive mood could mean an extra 25% lean growth without the need for extra feed. This may sound like hogwash, says the university, but the approach is based on colleague William Muir's research into aggressive behaviour in chickens. "Here we're talking about something for nothing," says Muir. "This is a win-win situation." Lethal bug is brought to book E. coli 0157:H7 is a bit of a mouthful, and an unwelcome one at that. It is the sick-making strain of the normally harmless human gut flora. It was first observed in 1982. Now it infects 75,000 a year in the US alone. A team from the University of Wisconsin, together with Hungarian and Massachusetts colleagues, report in Nature today that they have the low-down on the little monster. They have completed its genetic sequence, and identified 1,387 new genes, including those that could make it so virulent.

fields.headline: The best pier scene
fields.standfirst: Requiem for a dream
fields.trailText: Requiem for a dream
fields.body:
Brooklyn. In his shabby apartment, Tyrone (Marlon Wayans) is on the telephone organising a drug deal, while Harry (Jared Leto) sits at a low table counting out $20 bills.

"Dynamite?" Tyrone asks whoever is on the other end of the phone. "All right. We're on the way."

He hangs up, then turns to Harry.

"Brody's man says it's real fine shit."

"All right," Harry beams. "Here we go."

"Here we go."

Harry holds Tyrone's gaze.

"Let's do this right."

Tyrone looks perplexed.

"Naturally."

He takes the money, shares a high-five with Harry, then leaves.

Harry leans back on the couch, sucking on a joint. As he drifts off, Tyrone's apartment is suddenly filled with sunlight, its back wall replaced with the deep blue of the Atlantic. Harry finds himself standing on the Coney Island pier, his girlfriend Marion (Jennifer Connolly) strolling ahead of him with a baby carriage.

Harry calls out to her, but she keeps going. He chases after her, calling her name. Finally, she spins around and waves back. As Harry is almost by her side, she reaches into the pram.

Then, in an instant, Harry comes to, back in Tyrone's apartment. Tyrone comes back in, with a wide grin on his face and a package in his hand. He drops the package on the table.

"There it is."

See also: Carnival Of Souls, Brighton Rock, Funny Bones, The Usual Suspects

Don't see also: Snake Eyes

Pointless trivia: Having worked with director David Fincher on Fight Club, Jared Leto is also starring in his next project, The Panic Room.

webTitle: FA Cup preview: Bristol City v Kingstonian

fields.headline: Kingstonian hope and pray for more Chapple brimstone
fields.standfirst: The giantkillers look for another rollicking
fields.trailText: Giantkillers Kingstonian will be hoping for another rollicking from chain-smoking, laryngitis-stricken manager Geoff Chapple after their match at Bristol City on Saturday.
fields.body:
The players of Kingstonian, who are dreaming of beating Bristol City on Saturday and securing a fifth-round FA Cup place, expected nothing less than the mother of all rollickings from their manager Geoff Chapple after a 2-0 win over Staines on Monday in the FA Trophy.

They were not disappointed. "We could beat Man United and he'd still pick on something," said the England semi-professional international Geoff Pitcher.

Chapple kept cramming his mouth with Strepsils during the game to ease his laryngitis. But his throat condition did not prevent him chain-smoking throughout the 90 minutes nor giving a post-match address that sounded more like a postmortem.

"I've been in this game a long time and this lot are the most inconsistent, frustrating bunch I've ever been involved with," he said. "We had about nine weak links tonight and even our England players Geoff Pitcher and Gary Patterson weren't doing the business. We can't pass water at the moment and that was the sort of performance that will take us right out of the Conference - through the bottom end."

Even after the historic third-round Cup win over Southend United three weeks ago Chapple made his exasperation with his players plain. He says: "My summary that day was: 'What the fucking hell is going on? We can beat Southend but we can't do a thing in the league? How can that be?'"

As victory speeches go, that one takes some topping though Chapple, the Alex Ferguson of non-league football, may have outdone it after the Staines game.

Chapple is seeking an eighth league scalp at Ashton Gate, having claimed his first as Woking boss in 1991, when Tim Buzaglo scored a hat-trick in a 4-2 win at West Brom. Kingstonian have not lost a Trophy game for almost three years and have reached the fourth round of the Cup for the first time; they had not been in the third before. Yet, even allowing for kidology, Chapple sounds genuinely gloomy about their chances.

Hearing that the Bristol City manager Danny Wilson had left at half-time on Monday, he said: "I'm not surprised. I expect Danny went back down the motorway thinking that his lads might as well play in whites on Saturday cos, if we play like that again, they're likely to run up a cricket score. They'll declare at half-time."

Chapple has dreamed not just of beating league opposition but of joining them, coming closest with a Conference runners-up spot at Woking in 1995. Although his magic had an immediate effect when he brought Kingstonian into the Conference as Ryman League champions in his first season, 1997-98, and to fifth position last season, they are now flailing in the bottom three, having failed to record a league win since November.

Chapple says: "We can't play at home; we've been useless. So we've certainly got a better chance of beating Bristol at their place, though for me, the FA Cup is the least of our priorities. The Conference is the main one, followed by the FA Trophy."

Kingstonian have managed only two Conference home wins, the last in October against Southport. And, if they beat Bristol City and draw Premiership opposition at home in the fifth round, Chapple will push to switch the tie away to raise money to strengthen his squad. They are not only lacking in numbers but injuries have forced them to use six goalkeepers this season.

Chapple recently completed a brilliant piece of business by signing the 22-year-old striker Ian Duerden, knocking Doncaster Rovers down from £10,000 to nothing. Shuffling from foot to foot like Del Boy, he explained: "I was a bit cagey there. I waited until the price went down to £5,000 then, knowing Doncaster had a few wage bills, waited a bit longer until they agreed to a free with them retaining some sell-on rights.

"I'm delighted to have him because he can play a bit and hold things up. There are a lot of nerves out there, they're playing with a lot of fear and you can see some of them are frightened to get the ball."

Pitcher, formerly with Watford and Colchester, the player of the year last season who has shocked even himself this term by scoring 14 times from midfield, believes that others may simply be distracted. "A lot of the lads were bound to be thinking about Bristol," he said. "Many of them have never been in the fourth round and never will be again."

Seeing that safe passage to the fifth round might earn them only another almighty rollicking, it could be a sensible precaution to hide the manager's Strepsils this weekend.

fields.headline: Loose wheels on the NME tour
fields.standfirst:
NME Carling Tour
Leeds Metropolitan University
***
fields.trailText:
NME Carling Tour
Leeds Metropolitan University
***
fields.body:
Every year, the NME nominates four bands tipped to light up the year and sends them out on tour. While the Stereophonics were launched this way, the tour traditionally showcases bands the public then avoid, such as the long-forgotten Symposium and Llama Farmers. But at least this year's outing is fresh and intriguing. By contrasting the increasingly popular nu-metal - in the shape of Amen, hairy rockers from the US - with post-Coldplay acoustic rock, it reflects the reappearance of tribalism in British pop.

Openers Starsailor - named after a Tim Buckley album -have already generated so much discussion that the entire audience (metal kids and all) are in place by 7.30pm. For once, the hype is justified. Starsailor's gushing, rapt songs hinge on the balance between chubby-faced vocalist James Walsh and Barry Westhead, a modern day Ray Manzarek. Though resembling Richard Ashcroft, Walsh is not conventionally good-looking but radiates charisma because of his conviction.

Not quite as fragile as their forthcoming EP suggests, they mesmerise the crowd with the last song's epic bombast. That's more than can be said of Manchester's Alfie, whose psychedelic folk is deafened by chatter. Alfie's early promise seems to be going the way of labelmates Badly Drawn Boy, whose approach to live performance was bewildering. The PA system makes no sense of the trumpets, cellos and flutes, and Lee Gorton, a muttering Ian Brown-lookalike vocalist, is incomprehensible.

Amen are appalling. They have a more old-fashioned Stooges/MC5 style about them than anything particularly nu-metal. But the metal devotees adore greasy singer Casey Chaos's showmanship and the band's determination to avoid anything resembling a tune.

What the whining designer depressives JJ72 are doing on this bill is anyone's guess. Last year's "big new thing" that has yet to properly happen, they have made a decent fist of operating as surrogate Manic Street Preachers, but they will be blown out of the water once the real thing reappears.

 At Sheffield University (0114-222 2000), tonight, then touring.

fields.headline: Shortened odds for rate cut
fields.standfirst:
MPC vote 'on knife edge'

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The odds on a cut in interest rates next month shortened yesterday after the Bank of England revealed that only after a knife-edge vote did its key decision-making body leave rates on hold in January.
fields.body:
The odds on a cut in interest rates next month shortened yesterday after the Bank of England revealed that only after a knife-edge vote did its key decision-making body leave rates on hold in January.

Minutes of the latest meeting of the Bank's monetary policy committee showed that fears of a global slowdown and concern that inflation has been below target for almost two years prompted four of the total of nine MPC members to vote for a quarter-point reduction, bringing the rate to 5.75%.

Chief Bank of England economist Charlie Bean and Chris Allsopp joined DeAnne Julius and Sushil Wadhwani, who both supported an easing of policy at the December meeting, in pushing for a rate cut.

However, the Bank's governor, Sir Eddie George, proposed that rates be left at 6%, and was supported by his deputies Mervyn King and David Clementi, markets expert Ian Plenderleith and Stephen Nickell. They argued that the economy was still strong, with few signs of the slowdown in consumer spending needed to make room for the government's spending plans without exerting upward pressure on inflation.

Further evidence of the resilience of the UK economy came from the Confederation of British Industry's quarterly survey of manufacturing, which showed a slight rise in factory output coupled with increased optimism about the prospects for exports.

While investment intentions remained weak, the CBI found that the competitive pressures on businesses were easing.

For the first time in three years, firms were expecting to be able to rise prices and widen profit margins, the employers' organisation said.

Nick Reilly, chairman of the CBI's economic affairs committee, said that the survey provided mixed news.

"The recent weakening of sterling against the euro and the continuing growth in Europe should help UK exports.

"But signs of a slowdown in the US could be contributing to the further fall in manufacturers' confidence.

"Investment plans remain weak, supporting the CBI's insistence that targeted tax incentives in this area must continue. "We believe a quarter-point cut in rates would not push inflation above target. But it might boost the confidence of companies reviewing their investment plans."

Despite the more upbeat tone of the CBI report, a poll of City economists by Reuters found that 17 out of 20 expected the next MPC meeting to vote in favour of a cut.

Rates have been left unchanged since last February, but the pressure for a cut has grown in recent months.

The latest meeting was held a week after the surprise decision by the Federal Reserve to shave half a point off US rates on January 3 - and the minutes reveal that for some members of the MPC, this had changed the balance of risk "sufficiently to the down side to justify a cut in the repo rate this month".

webTitle: NU pledges £60m to make up endowment shortfalls

fields.headline: NU pledges £60m to make up endowment shortfalls
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Half a million homeowners with mortgage endowments that have fallen off track yesterday won a reprieve when Norwich Union promised to make up potential shortfalls.
fields.body:
Half a million homeowners with mortgage endowments that have fallen off track yesterday won a reprieve when Norwich Union promised to make up potential shortfalls.

NU, the retail arm of the CGNU group, pledged to top up final bonuses on its endowment policies provided that future investment returns average 6% a year.

The biggest beneficiaries will be the 50,000 NU endowment holders who were last year sent a "red" warning letter that their policy was at serious risk of failing to pay off a home loan. A further 450,000 of NU's 700,000 endowment holders were sent an "amber" letter warning of a potential shortfall. All policyholders will be sent a reprojection letter giving them the "green" all-clear on their endowment.

CGNU chief actuary Mike Urmston put the cost of the pledge at about 1.5% of the company's £4bn in free reserves, or no more than £60m. "It gives our customers a lot of comfort and is an example of how we can use our financial strength to the benefit of policyholders."

NU's pledge takes the number of endowments enjoying protection from shortfalls to 3m out of the total 12m in force and will put pressure on other insurers to follow suit.

Over the past year Standard Life, Liverpool Victoria and CGU (Commercial Union and General Accident policies) have all promised to make up shortfalls. Among the biggest providers which have rejected endowment promises are Legal & General, Scottish Amicable and Friends Provident. An L&G spokesman said: "What they are doing is giving promises, not guarantees. Endowments were not designed to contain guarantees and offering them could prejudice other customers' interests."

The NU pledge comes despite its worst years for investment returns since 1994. Yesterday it said that its £80bn with-profits fund had made re turns "close to zero" in 2000, compared with a gain of 17% in 1999. Big falls in equities were partly offset by NU's traditionally heavy investment in property, and Mr Urmston said the insurer, Britain's biggest, will increase property investment this year.

But the fall in investment returns has forced NU to cut payouts on a wide range of policies. A 25-year £50-per-month NU endowment this year will pay out £86,028, a fall of 4% on last year's £89,518, but representing a return over the period of 12.1% a year or 7.4% after inflation.

Axa's 660,000 policyholders recently shared in a £400 per head one-off payout from the company's orphan assets, but yesterday CGNU ruled out a similar distribution to its 2m-plus policyholders in the near future. Mr Urmston said: "We are very conscious of the Axa case and are examining it in detail, but in principle we intend to use the fund to support the growth of new business rather than make payouts."

webTitle: FSA chief calls on traders to 'clean up City'

fields.headline: FSA chief calls on traders to 'clean up City'
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stock market traders are dealing on inside information without any fear of prosecution, Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, admitted yesterday as the City's chief regulator called for the introduction of a whistleblowing culture to help clean up the Square Mile.
fields.body:
Stock market traders are dealing on inside information without any fear of prosecution, Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, admitted yesterday as the City's chief regulator called for the introduction of a whistleblowing culture to help clean up the Square Mile.

Rogue company directors dealing with inside knowledge are also acting on the assumption that limited regulatory powers and the fact that only a few cases have been successfully prosecuted mean their actions are unlikely to be exposed, he added.

"It's widely talked about in the wine bars of the Square Mile that it's practically impossible to get a conviction for anybody on insider dealing - no matter how obvious it is, and that's not healthy," Sir Howard told the Guardian.

The chairman of the City regulator added that the introduction of sweeping new powers allowing unlimited fines on individuals and companies would help restore investor confidence in the market.

The new fines, coming into force later this year as part of the Financial Services and Markets Act, will augment existing criminal proceedings brought by the Department of Trade and Industry.

The FSA is also due to publish within three months a code of conduct defining what it regards as market manipulation. This will include misuse of information, as well as the distribution of false rumours on bulletin boards and internet chat rooms.

webTitle: Reviews: Dance: La Fille Mal Gardée

fields.headline: La Fille Mal Gardée
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London
***
fields.body:
Lise and Colas, the lovers in Frederick Ashton's La Fille mal gardée, are among ballet's most straightforward couples. They don't have royal blood; they haven't been cursed by a spell; they don't have the two biggest families in Veronaon their backs. They are simply a farmer's daughter and a local lad - so the dancers who perform them have a blessed licence to be normal.

Lise is a bit pert and greedy, a little doolally. Colas is the hunk of the village but also quite sweet. Yet while the roles are not on a grand or tragic scale, La Fille is a traditional ballet and Lise and Colas still have to radiate some glamour. But on this night the two most charismatic performers were Lise's grumpy old mum and the neighbourhood squire.

Jane Burn (Lise) has a lovely, upbeat spring and nifty capacity for speed. Johan Persson (Colas) has strength and an emphatically neat finish. They deal smartly and attractively with the tricksy beauties of Ashton's choreography, and with different partners they might even look exciting. As a pair, they hold no surprises.

A deeper part of the problem is dramatic. Persson's face is too set in genial jock mode to register nuances of feeling. Burn has range and a comic timing that makes us laugh out loud. But she too fails to intrigue, and as a pair they don't make us feel the heat of their attraction.

The contrast with the old fuddy-duddies in the ballet is extreme. William Tuckett as squire Thomas - red-faced, blustering and vain - gives fascinating side shows to the role, flirting with monstrous energy with Widow Simone and displaying clumsy but affecting tenderness for his loopy son. Luke Heydon as the Widow Simone doesn't stand on enough crotchety dignity for my taste but his verve is irresistible. His flamboyance is matched by Giacomo Ciriaci as Alain. Playing him as a doleful clown - more commedia dell'arte than rustic fool - Ciriaci flips his way through Alain's addled moves with a comic dysfunctional brilliance.

 In rep until March 10. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Nixon's Nixon
fields.standfirst:
Nixon's Nixon
Lowry, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Nixon's Nixon
Lowry, Manchester
****
fields.body:
When Richard Nixon, the beleaguered president of the United States, called his right-hand man, secretary of state Henry Kissinger, to the White House's Lincoln Sitting Room on the evening of August 7, 1974, it was with some desperation. Embroiled in the Watergate scandal, he had no one left to turn to. The meeting resulted in Nixon's resignation. Russell Lees's clever, often funny, play condenses their conference to 90 minutes of frantic self-analysis, during which Nixon and Kissinger try to find a way of vouchsafing a respectable place in history.

As well as bearing an uncanny resemblance to their characters, both actors give a masterful display of bravado and nervous wit. One moment, Keith Jochim's Nixon is all big mouth and blubber, strutting the stage, delivering bolshie one-liners ("I appeal to the Richard Nixon in everybody"); the next, he's lumbering like a lost boy, clumsy and round-shouldered in defeat.

Tim Donohue as Kissinger, the German Jewish immigrant, is equally captivating, and his deliberate pronunciation means that his every sentence sounds at best like moralising, and at worst like a condemnation of the president. Yet his ponderous demeanour and fastidiousness with words are the perfect foil to the president's strident slang. Not only that, Kissinger cannot afford to tarnish his reputation if he is to retain his post under the incoming president, Gerald Ford, and Donohue's delivery weighs every word in terms of the damage it might do.

Although a political play about power and vulnerability could be rather static with the loaded dialogue and a cast of only two, Nixon's Nixon is saved by the quality of the writing and acting, and by an oft-repeated and wonderful device by means of which the two politicians impersonate the great leaders they have had successful dealings with. Jochim's Nixon is brilliant playing the saggy jowls and seriousness of Brezhnev, while Donohue's Kissinger (minus the Groucho Marx glasses) plays Chairman Mao "being inscrutable all over the place". Nixon then does a death-defying Napoleon, and even considers taking on the Pope.

Of course, this admiration for great leaders (a kind of hubris by proxy) returns to his own failings (and the despairing acknowledgment of the hundreds of thousands killed in Vietnam and Cambodia under his presidency). As the evening advances, and the brandy recedes, Nixon finally accepts that his last heroic gesture will be to do the honourable thing.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 0161-876 2000.

fields.headline: Astonishing revival by the OAE
fields.standfirst:
OAE/ Mackerras
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
OAE/ Mackerras
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
Concerts in the 19th century tended to be a tad longer than today. They also contained a remarkable amalgam of diverse material. This astonishing evening - more than three hours of it - replicated a programme at the Leipzig Gewandhaus in 1855. Clara Schumann played Beethoven's Emperor Concerto and gave a performance of her husband's Introduction and Allegro Appassionato - better known as the Konzertstück for piano and orchestra - that rescued the work from the doldrums into which it had fallen.

In addition, there was Weber's Oberon overture, Schumann's Second Symphony and excerpts from Mozart's Marriage of Figaro, sung by the operatic stars of the day.

The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, under Charles Mackerras, reconstructed all this with painstaking veracity, using German instruments of the time. It could have been dully academic; this was anything but.

The pianist, Robert Levin, flung himself into the Emperor Concerto with visible relish. He plays it with a combination of epic opulence and filigree delicacy, avoiding any self-conscious bravura. Equally majestic and refined, Mackerras perfectly judged the work's ebb and flow, moving the adagio on with a gentle tension that avoids the sentiment and religiosity that many interpreters bring to it.

The Konzertstück was done with equal brilliance, though you gradually became aware of the reasons for its neglect. Soloist and orchestra function as an indivisible unit rather than being forced into opposition. Its dramatic power derives from jolting contrasts of mood, not inner dialogue. The piano writing is fiendishly exacting without being showy. Its impact is formidable, however. During the opening, in which a series of woodwind and brass solos slowly unfurl over rippling piano arpeggios, the audience sat spellbound.

Yet Schumann's Second Symphony was in many respects the high point. Written in 1845, it dramatises the composer's lifelong struggle with depression, passing through intense chromatic anguish before culminating in a mood of rickety optimism. The drier sound of period forces adds to its sombreness. Mackerras's approach is white-hot, unleashing a torrent of dangerous emotion, ambiguous in tone throughout. The finale swirls with unease, the timpani strokes crushing rather than triumphant.

Italian soprano Nuccia Focile dominated the Figaro excerpts, soaring through the tricky aria Al Desio di chi t'adora with joyous ease and a silvery beauty of tone. In the Act Three duet, she manipulated James Rutherford's handsomely voiced Count with seditious sexuality.

It was a tremendous, classy evening from start to finish, and the time simply flew by.

fields.headline: Throat
fields.standfirst:
Circus Space, London
****
fields.trailText:
Circus Space, London
****
fields.body:
A man lies down on a baker's kneading board, using the dough as a pillow. He dusts himself with flour as if expecting to be kneaded into another form, a new identity. Then in a flash he somersaults up a rope and hangs suspended in space, slowly twisting as the flour tumbles from his body like falling snow.

Christmas card moments like this are a feature of John Paul Zaccarini's solo show, a teasing hybrid of circus, cabaret, performance art and dance, but that is not to say there isn't something tough beneath the shimmering wit of this likable, tongue-in-cheek act, seen at the London international mime festival.

Down from the rope, Zaccarini plunges his hands into the heart of the dough, its surface yielding to reveal a bloody centre. It makes you think of inert carcasses in an abattoir. Zaccarini's hands are stained scarlet. He is Cain, Lady Macbeth and his own executioner rolled into one.

Then something magical happens. It begins to rain and water has seeped over the floor of the stage, turning it into a small lake. The ripples and reflections of the water play against the white backcloth. Zaccarini plunges his hands into the water. He slips and slides across it, sometimes floundering like a fish and sometimes almost skating. When he catches sight of his reflection, he stares in wonder like a latter-day Narcissus entranced by a vision of himself. It is as if he is saying: "So, this is what I am."

What is Throat about? The things you dare not say, male identity, the difference between sex, love, and the yearning to be loved. It is all these things and perhaps more, wrapped up in a camp, cheeky, sexy and passionately erotic format that has all the hallmarks of a wet dream.

Zaccarini, a gifted mimic as well as a fabulous physical performer, enjoys himself no end and whips the audience up into a minor frenzy with a peacock display of sexual confidence. He does a particularly witty version of the come-on in which his sly winks and come-hither glances gradually metamorphose into a nervous tic. But although he tries on identities like suits, shaping himself, like dough, into the sexual predator, the carefree good time boy and the slinky vamp, he remains elusive.

At the end he hangs on the rope above us, his hands playing over his body and the light glinting on his torso, over which the water cascades like a waterfall. He twists slowly round and round, like Icarus caught between heaven and earth, out of reach and beyond help. He is a small, lonely figure - beautiful, abandoned, spent and completely human.

webTitle: Reviews: Theatre: Importance of Being Earnest

fields.headline: Wilde classic with a dash of Aussie sassiness
fields.standfirst:
Importance of Being Earnest
Savoy Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Importance of Being Earnest
Savoy Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
A classic comedy, a star performer (Patricia Routledge), a blandly pretty set: initially Christopher Morahan's production, which originated at Chichester in 1999, looks like a safe Sussex transfer. But, in the course of an Antipodean tour, it has acquired three Australian actresses and it is they who bring a touch of salt and sassiness to Wilde's familiar masterpiece.

About Routledge's Lady Bracknell I feel fairly neutral. At first in her interrogation of Mr Worthing she lapses into a singsong contralto that smothers much of the wit. The one point she clearly makes is that Lady Bracknell is as much motivated by money as by pedigree. She builds on that in her second eruption by reminding us that Aunt Augusta is a social arriviste who had no fortune when she married and who spies in Cecily a financially advantageous catch for her nephew. I just wish Routledge made Lady B's upward mobility the key to her whole performance.

But what this production latches on to is that, in Wilde's play, the women steer the action. It would be pushing it to call Wilde's Gilbertian fantasy with social undercurrents explicitly feminist. But, unlike Orton, Wilde was no misogynist. He clearly liked women, and when his female roles are strongly cast, as here, you realise that his play is a subtle tribute to their wit, grit and determination.

The key performance comes from the Sydney-trained Essie Davis as Gwendolen. This is no wilting violet but a woman determined to get her man. When she announces that the name of Ernest "produces vibrations", her whole body shudders with sexual delight and at one point she grabs Mr Worthing and kisses him with undisguised ferocity. But Davis also reminds one of Chekhov's point that, when someone "spends the least possible number of movements over some definite action, that is grace". In the rural scenes she combines a fastidious physical economy with a clear-eyed matrimonial certainty. It is, in Aussie parlance, a beaut of a performance.

This note of sexual single-mindedness is echoed in the Cecily of Sarah Kants. She winds in Algernon like an angler securing a catch, and trades verbal blows with Gwendolen with a tart crispness that belies the character's youth. Even Beverley Dunn's Miss Prism eyes up Canon Chasuble with a romantic eagerness that reminds one of the governess's early devotion to the three-volume novel.

The men are more traditionally played, with Theo Fraser Steele's airy Algernon balanced by the sober gravity of Alistair Petrie's Mr Worthing. But clearly something has happened to this production in the course of a long tour. What starts out as a routine revival of a comic classic ends up by striking a stylish blow for feminism.

 Until March 24. Box office: 020-7836 8888. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.
